The increase in senior worker CPF contribution rates further reinforces this. This additional transfer will help to boost your retirement savings and provide you with higher monthly payouts.
If you have already set aside your Full Retirement Sum in cash in your Retirement Account, the transfer will not occur.']

question: What will happen if I do not instruct CPF Board to start my monthly payouts?
answer:
['We encourage you to use the personalised [**Plan my monthly payouts**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/payout) service to help you decide what best fits your retirement needs, and to submit your instructions. If we do not receive instructions from you, we will start your payouts automatically when you reach 70, and credit the payouts into your bank account in our records.
If you are born in 1958 or after and have not met your FRS, there will be [another transfer of your Special Account (SA) and/or Ordinary Account (OA) savings to your Retirement Account (RA)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/why-is-there-another-transfer-of-monies-from-sa-oa-to-ra-before) to set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in cash. You can use the√Ç¬†**[Plan my monthly payouts](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/payout)**√Ç¬†service to know if this transfer applies to you and how much will be transferred to your RA. This service is applicable to you three months before you reach 65.
Once your monthly payout starts, please also note that any remaining amount from the [additional withdrawable amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-withdraw) will be transferred to your OA for your future withdrawals.
Note: If you belong to the small group of members who have previously joined CPF LIFE before reaching age 65, your payouts will start automatically at 65, or the age (up to 70) you have chosen to start your payouts.']

question: Can I withdraw my savings earlier if I am sick?
answer:
['Yes, you can withdraw your CPF savings earlier if you are certified by an√Ç¬†[accredited doctor](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/who-is-considered-an-accredited-doctor)√Ç¬†to meet any of the following medical conditions:
* **Reduced life expectancy** Due to illness, your life expectancy has been severely reduced.
* **Permanently unfit for work** You are permanently unfit for any form of employment.
* **Permanently lack mental capacity** As defined in the Mental Capacity Act, you permanently lack the mental capacity to make decisions.']

question: Who is considered an accredited doctor?
answer:
['An accredited doctor is a doctor from public hospital, polyclinic, or a specialist.
If the doctor who has certified your medical condition is not an accredited doctor, we will require an independent assessment from our panel of doctors.']

question: Can someone make a withdrawal on a member's behalf when the member loses mental capacity permanently?
answer:
['Yes, the donee appointed by the member under the Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) to make decisions on the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF matters, can apply to withdraw the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings.
To learn more about the LPA, please visit the√Ç¬†[Office of the Public Guardian's website](https://www.msf.gov.sg/opg/Pages/The-LPA-The-Lasting-Power-of-Attorney.aspx).
You can also find out more about [What if my next-of-kin did not make a Lasting Power of Attorney?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/what-if-my-next-of-kin-did-not-make-a-lasting-power-of-attorney-)']

question: How much can I withdraw under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme?
answer:
['Under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, you can withdraw a lump sum of up to $5,000\* or more, depending on the extent of your reduced life expectancy as certified by an [accredited doctor](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/who-is-considered-an-accredited-doctor).
You may also need to keep a reduced retirement sum in your Retirement Account from which you will receive regular monthly payouts.
\*The amount you can withdraw depends on your available CPF balances, excluding top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme, government grants and your MediSave Account savings.']

question: If I have withdrawn under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, can I continue to use my Ordinary Account savings to service my housing loan?
answer: ['Yes, you can continue to use your Ordinary Account savings to service your housing loan, subject to existing housing rules, even if you have withdrawn under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme.']

question: If I have withdrawn under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, can I still apply to withdraw a lump sum at age 55 and payout eligibility age for my immediate retirement needs?
answer: ['No, you will no longer be able to [withdraw a lump sum at age 55 and payout eligibility age for your immediate retirement needs](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/withdrawing-for-immediate-retirement-needs) as the withdrawal savings are already paid out to you earlier under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme.']

question: What happens to my CPF LIFE plan if I am approved to withdraw under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme?
answer:
['If you are approved to withdraw your retirement savings under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, you can decide whether to:
(i) terminate your CPF LIFE plan and receive a refund of the premium balance (if applicable); or
(ii) keep your CPF LIFE plan and receive monthly payouts for as long as you live.']

question: How do I apply for withdrawal under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme?
answer:
['To apply for withdrawal under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, you will need to:
1. Mail the original\*√Ç¬†[medical certification form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/MGS_MedicalCertificationForm.pdf)√Ç¬†completed by an√Ç¬†[accredited doctor](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/who-is-considered-an-accredited-doctor)√Ç¬†to:
CPF Board Retirement Withdrawals Department (RWD) Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060 Singapore 905060
\* If you are mailing your documents from overseas, all documents must be witnessed/certified true by an official of a√Ç¬†[Singapore Overseas Mission](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/what-is-a-singapore-overseas-mission-)√Ç¬†with his official seal/stamp duly attached.
2. Then submit the√Ç¬†[online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/WithdrawMyCPFOnMedicalGrounds/ContinueToNotesPage).']

question: What if my next-of-kin did not make a Lasting Power of Attorney?
answer:
['You can apply to the court to be appointed as the member's Deputy under the Mental Capacity Act if your next-of-kin did not make a Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) and has lost his mental capacity to make decisions. As a guide, you may wish to include the [suggested clauses](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/SuggestedClauses.pdf)√Ç¬†in the court order if you want to be empowered to manage all of the member's CPF matters.
The Family Justice Courts has also introduced a simplified application process for specific categories of applications. This process generally restricts the use of monies to $60,000 and below. For more information, please visit the [Family Justice Courts' website](https://www.judiciary.gov.sg/family/deputyship).
To give the family time to apply for the court order, the member's caregiver may approach CPF Board to withdraw up to $10,000 of the member's CPF savings for the costs of the member's maintenance.']

question: How long does it take to process the application for withdrawal under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing withdrawal under Reduced Life Expectancy:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal processing time** |
| Withdraw under Reduced Life Expectancy scheme | We will update the status of your application within seven working days after we receive both your application and original certification form.After your application is approved, you will receive your CPF savings via Interbank GIRO within the next two working days. |']

question: If I am eligible to receive monthly payouts under the Reduced Life Expectancy scheme, when will the monthly payouts be paid to me?
answer:
['You will receive the monthly payouts in your bank account√Ç¬†generally√Ç¬†on the 2nd or 3rd day of each month, if your bank supports Fast And Secure Transfer (FAST).
Otherwise, you will receive your payouts later, via Inter-bank GIRO (IBG).']

question: Why am I not allowed to use my bank account with a non-local bank to receive my CPF monies from my withdrawal on reduced life expectancy?
answer:
['We can better protect you from scams by only accepting bank accounts from banks that offer automated verification. This ensures payments are made only to your bank account.
Currently, only POSB, DBS, OCBC and UOB have such an arrangement with us. We would be happy to work with other banks to set up similar arrangements with us.']

question: How can I change my bank details for payments under withdrawal on reduced life expectancy?
answer: ['You can change your bank account details by submitting an√Ç¬†[**online application**](https://cpf.gov.sg/ChangeBankAccountFormSG).']

question: When can I withdraw my CPF savings?
answer:
['You can apply to withdraw a portion of your CPF savings anytime from 55 whenever you have immediate needs for cash. There is no limit to the number of withdrawals you can make. Find out [how much you can withdraw](/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-withdraw).
If you do not have an immediate need, you can leave your savings in your CPF accounts as rainy day funds while enjoying [interest rates of up to 6% p.a.](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest), and withdraw them only when you need to. With PayNow, you can generally receive your withdrawn monies almost instantaneously.']

question: Can I withdraw my CPF savings before I turn 55?
answer: ['You can apply to withdraw your CPF savings earlier if you have a medical condition that [reduces your life expectancy or causes you to be permanently unfit for work or lack mental capacity permanently](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/can-i-withdraw-my-savings-earlier-if-i-am-sick).']

question: How much CPF savings can I withdraw?
answer:
['You can check the amount you can withdraw by logging in to your√Ç¬†[**Retirement dashboard**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/retirement).
Generally, when you turn 55, you can withdraw at least $5,000 or any amount in excess after setting aside your√Ç¬†[**Full Retirement Sum (FRS)**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-).
If you are born in 1958 and after, when you turn 65, you can withdraw an additional amount of up to 20% of your retirement savings. [**See more details on the withdrawal rules**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/withdrawal-rules-table.pdf).
You can also [**apply to withdraw your Retirement Account savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/conditions-to-withdraw-part-of-ra-savings-using-my-property)√Ç¬†if you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older. You have the flexibility√Ç¬†to set aside your FRS with a mixture of property (up to half your FRS, which is the BRS) and cash.
Please note that you cannot withdraw cash top-ups or CPF transfers, as well as government grants such as CPF LIFE Bonus or Deferment Bonus as they are designed to boost your retirement payouts. Find out√Ç¬†[**how your withdrawable amount is computed**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-is-the-withdrawable-amount-computed).']

question: Can I still withdraw my CPF savings if I do not have the Full Retirement Sum?
answer:
['Yes, you can still withdraw some of your CPF savings even if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum.
If you are born in 1957 or after, you can withdraw additional amount from your Retirement Account from 65. [Check how much CPF savings you can withdraw](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-withdraw).']

question: Can I make a partial withdrawal of my CPF savings?
answer:
['Yes, you can withdraw your savings partially and leave the remaining in your respective CPF accounts to earn risk-free [interest rates\* of up to 6% per annum](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest). Your withdrawable savings can be withdrawn any time when you need them.
If you decide to withdraw a partial amount, your savings will be paid from your CPF accounts in the following order:
1. Retirement Account (if applicable)
2. Special Account
3. Ordinary Account
\* Based on the interest rate floor of 4% per annum on Special/Retirement Account.']

question: How often can I withdraw from my CPF savings?
answer:
['There is no limit to the number of withdrawals you can make, as long as you are√Ç¬†[eligible and have withdrawable savings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-withdraw).
You can view your [Retirement dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/retirement) to check your eligibility and the amount you can withdraw.']

question: What are the benefits in keeping the savings in my CPF accounts?
answer:
['If you don't need the funds, keeping your savings in your CPF accounts lets you earn risk-free [interest rates\* of up to 6% per annum](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest), allowing your savings to grow with compound interest.
You can also [use your CPF savings to increase your monthly payouts in retirement](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-can-i-increase-my-monthly-payouts-with-my-cpf-savings). Check out the options to increase your monthly payouts using your withdrawable savings under the √¢¬Ä¬úWithdraw for immediate retirement needs√¢¬Ä¬ù section in your√Ç¬†[Retirement dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/retirement).
\* Based on the interest rate floor of 4% per annum on Special/Retirement Account.']

question: How can I increase my monthly payouts with my CPF savings?
answer: ['You can view your√Ç¬†[Retirement dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/retirement) to check the options you have to increase your monthly payouts using your withdrawable savings under the √¢¬Ä¬úWithdraw for immediate retirement needs√¢¬Ä¬ù section.']

question: I am currently using my CPF savings to service my housing loan. Can I continue to use my withdrawable CPF savings for housing payments?
answer:
['Yes, you can use your Ordinary Account savings, including any withdrawable amounts, to pay for your housing loan.
You can view your [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership) to check the savings you can use for your housing payments under the "Amount allowed for this property" section. This will give you a clear idea of how much more you can use before reaching the usage limits.
While you use your CPF savings for housing, it is also important to consider the impact on your retirement savings and ensure that you have enough for your retirement needs.']

question: How can I check my withdrawable amount?
answer: ['You can check the amount you can withdraw by logging in to your [Retirement dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/retirement).']

question: Can I choose which CPF account to withdraw from?
answer:
['You cannot choose the CPF account to withdraw from. Your savings will be paid from your CPF accounts in the following order:
1. Retirement Account (if applicable)
2. Special Account
3. Ordinary Account
Accounts with higher interest rates typically require you to lock in your savings for a longer period of time. This is similar to fixed deposits in the market, which also offer higher interest rates if savings are locked in for a set period, compared to savings deposits which are withdrawable anytime.']

question: How is the withdrawable amount computed?
answer:
['The amount you can withdraw is computed based on the balances in your CPF account and the year you are born. For members born in 1958 and after:
Amount you can withdraw from 55
| | |
| --- | --- |
| Savings in your Special (SA) and Ordinary Account (OA) | Amount you can withdraw from 55 |
| $5,000 or less | All your Special and Ordinary Account savings |
| Between $5,000 and your Full Retirement Sum | (i) $5,000; and√Ç¬†(ii) Any Retirement Account savings\* above√Ç¬†your Basic Retirement Sum, if you own a property with remaining lease that can last you to at least 95 years old. |
| More than your Full Retirement Sum | (i) $5,000, or your Special and Ordinary Account savings above your Full Retirement Sum, whichever is higher; and√Ç¬†(ii) Any Retirement Account savings\* above the Basic Retirement Sum, if you own a property with remaining lease that can last you to at least 95 years old. |
\* Excluding interest earned, any government grants received and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme.
See [examples of how the withdrawable amount is computed](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/examples-on-computation-of-cpf-withdrawal-jun22.pdf).
Additional amount you can withdraw from 65
The additional withdrawable savings from 65 is computed based on 20% of your Retirement Account savings excluding any cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants, less the unconditional $5,000 which you can withdraw from 55. This ensures that you do not deplete your retirement savings further, so that you will have a stream of monthly payouts for your living expenses in old age.
Example: A member born in 1958
| | |
| --- | --- |
| Retirement Account balance at 651 | $107,400 (A) |
| Cash top-ups/CPF transfers made under Retirement Sum Topping-Up scheme2 | $ 20,000 (B) |
| Government grants2√Ç¬†Examples of government grants are Deferment Bonus, matching grants under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme etc. | $ 600 (C) |
| Unconditional $5,000 withdrawable from 55 | $5,000 (D) |
| Additional withdrawal amount from 65 [(A - B - C) x 20%] - D | $ 12,360 |
Notes:
1 If you are an existing CPF LIFE member who had joined the scheme before you turned 65, the balances used to compute your additional withdrawable savings from 65 will include your CPF LIFE premium balance.
2 Cash top-ups, CPF transfers and government grants are meant to be streamed out to you as monthly payouts in retirement.']

question: I did not use my CPF savings for my property. Can I withdraw my Retirement Account savings using my property?
answer:
['If the property is able to last you until age 95, you can choose to set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with a mixture of property (up to half the FRS) and cash, and withdraw your Retirement Account (RA) savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum\* by pledging your property. By doing so, you will have to refund the amount withdrawn when you sell or transfer the property in future. A charge will be created on the property to secure the refund.
The amount you can withdraw depends on a few factors:
* your property√¢¬Ä¬ôs market value;
* outstanding mortgage loan(s);
* your co-owner(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô CPF usage for the property; and
* the manner of holding of your property (e.g. sole ownership, joint tenancy, tenancy-in-common in equal shares, tenancy-in-common in unequal shares).
If you are not the sole owner of the property, you will need to get the consent of all co-owners to create a charge on the property, as the refund of your withdrawn savings will affect their share of the sales proceeds.
You can refer to the√Ç¬†[examples](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/examples-illustrating-the-ra-savings-that-can-be-withdrawn-with-property-pledge.pdf)√Ç¬†provided to see how your withdrawal amount is calculated.
\* Excluding interest, any government grants and top-ups made under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme.']

question: How do I check if my property lease is able to last me until I am 95?
answer: ['You can check the remaining lease of your HDB property via the [Housing and Development Board (HDB) website](https://www.hdb.gov.sg), or the [Singapore Land Authority (SLA) website](https://www.sla.gov.sg) for private property.']

question: How would my CPF savings be paid to me?
answer:
['You can receive your CPF savings to your:
* PayNow NRIC-linked bank account
With [PayNow](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/what-is-paynow), you can generally receive your CPF savings **almost instantly.** Find out more about the [benefits of PayNow](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/what-are-the-benefits-of-receiving-my-cpf-savings-via-paynow).
However, please note that you won't be able to withdraw your CPF savings via PayNow if you have√Ç¬†[unpaid taxes, MediShield Life premiums](/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/can-i-withdraw-my-cpf-savings-if-i-have-unpaid-taxes-or)√Ç¬†or [outstanding divorce matters](/member/faq/other-schemes/division-of-cpf-related-assets-in-matrimonial-proceedings/what-are-the-member-s-obligations-after-the-court-order-is-issue).
* Other bank accounts
To protect you from any potential scams, we will only accept bank accounts where the bank is able to provide automated bank account verification to us. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to you. Currently, only POSB, DBS, OCBC and UOB are able to provide this service.
If your bank does not provide this service, you may wish to write to your bank to request that they do so. Alternatively, you may wish to sign up for PayNow (NRIC) with your bank so as to receive payments from us.']

question: How can I change my bank account details?
answer:
['You can change your bank account details either via:
* PayNow NRIC-linked bank account
You can change your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account through your ibanking app.
* Other bank accounts
You can change your bank account details by submitting an√Ç¬†[**online application**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/ChangeBankAccount).
To protect you from any potential scams, we will only accept bank accounts where the bank is able to provide automated bank account verification to us. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to you. Currently, only POSB, DBS, OCBC and UOB are able to provide this service.
The same bank account will also be used for any payment due to you:
1. under the CPF Act and its subsidiary legislation; and
2. from the Government in respect of which CPF Board is the administrator, agent or trustee, to the Account.
Your bank account details will be updated generally within five working days after we receive your application.']

question: How can I check my withdrawal transactions?
answer: ['You can view your latest withdrawal by logging in to "[Past Withdrawals for Retirement](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement/past-withdrawals-for-retirement)" page. If you want to view your earlier withdrawals, you can find them in your [transaction history](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history).']

question: Do I need to pay taxes for the amount I withdraw from my CPF accounts?
answer:
['No, CPF savings withdrawn are not taxable.
However, please note that if you have any [unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/can-i-withdraw-my-cpf-savings-if-i-have-unpaid-taxes-or), we may recover the unpaid amount from the CPF savings you are withdrawing.
This is done to ensure that everyone fulfils their tax obligations and has sufficient coverage under MediShield Life.']

question: Can I withdraw my CPF savings if I have unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums?
answer: ['If you have unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums, we may be appointed by IRAS to recover the unpaid amount from the CPF savings you are withdrawing. If we are appointed to do so, you will receive an appointment notice from IRAS and we will pay IRAS the outstanding amount from your withdrawable savings to settle your unpaid taxes or MediShield Life premiums before the balance (if any) is paid to you.']

question: What is PayNow?
answer:
['PayNow is a secure fund transfer service that generally allows you to receive payment **almost instantly**. It adopts the same high security standards as other trusted funds transfer services like FAST and GIRO. Best of all, PayNow is free and available 24/7, 365 days a year to customers of participating banks in Singapore.
For more information on PayNow and participating banks, you can contact your bank or visit the Association of Banks in Singapore√¢¬Ä¬ôs√Ç¬†[website](https://www.abs.org.sg/consumer-banking/pay-now).']

question: What are the benefits of receiving my CPF savings via PayNow?
answer: ['With PayNow, you can generally receive your CPF savings in your [NRIC-linked bank account](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-do-i-register-for-paynow)√Ç¬†**almost instantly**. It is also hassle-free as you do not need to provide bank account details or supporting documents for us to verify your bank account.']

question: How long will it take for me to receive my CPF savings via PayNow?
answer: ['If your application is successful, you will generally receive the payment in your NRIC-linked bank account√Ç¬†**almost instantly**.']

question: How do I register for PayNow and receive my CPF savings?
answer:
['You can do so by following the steps below:
1. Set up internet/mobile banking with your bank.
2. Log in to your bank√¢¬Ä¬ôs internet/mobile banking application.
3. At the PayNow registration screen, link your√Ç¬†**Singapore NRIC**√Ç¬†to your bank account.
4. To make a CPF withdrawal, you may submit an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/withdraw-cpf-retirement-needs).
5. You can refer to the√Ç¬†[**instructional video**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/infohub/educational-resources/how-to-make-cpf-withdrawal-after-55)√Ç¬†in your preferred language.
If you are an existing bank account holder with POSB/DBS, UOB or OCBC, you can refer to the steps listed in the pdfs below:
For POSB/DBS account holder
To register for PayNow with POSB/DBS Digibank Mobile, please refer to the steps listed in the pdfs below:
| |
| --- |
| **Language** |
| [English](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-Digibank-Eng.pdf) |
| [Chinese](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-Digibank-Chi.pdf) |
| [Malay](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-Digibank-Malay.pdf) |
| [Tamil](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-Digibank-Tamil.pdf) |
For UOB account holder
To register for PayNow with UOB TMRW, please refer to the steps listed in the pdfs below:
| |
| --- |
| **Language** |
| [English](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-UOB-Eng.pdf) |
| [Chinese](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-UOB-Chi.pdf) |
| [Malay](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-UOB-Malay.pdf) |
| [Tamil](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-UOB-Tamil.pdf) |
For OCBC account holder
Registering for PayNow with OCBC can be done via the OCBC Digital App, SMS or OCBC Internet Banking. Please refer to the steps listed in the pdfs below:
| |
| --- |
| **Language** |
| [English](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-OCBC-Eng.pdf) |
| [Chinese](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-OCBC-Chi.pdf) |
| [Malay](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-OCBC-Malay.pdf) |
| [Tamil](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/Register-for-PayNow-with-OCBC-Tamil.pdf) |']

question: Why do I need to link my NRIC FIN number to my PayNow registered bank account?
answer: ['Unlike mobile numbers, the NRIC/FIN number is an unchanged proxy issued by the government and is the only accepted proxy for government payments via PayNow. Linking your NRIC/FIN number to your PayNow registered bank account ensures that government payments will be made correctly to you.']

question: Is there a maximum amount that can be received via PayNow? What should I do if I want to withdraw more than the limit?
answer:
['There is a maximum amount of $200,000 that you can receive via PayNow, subject to daily and monthly limits set by your bank.
If you need to withdraw more than $200,000, you will need to submit another application. For instance, if you want to withdraw $300,000, you can submit two applications: one for $200,000 and another for $100,000. Alternatively, you can opt to receive your payment via Interbank GIRO, which will require a longer processing time.']

question: Can I submit more than one application a day to withdraw my CPF savings via PayNow?
answer: ['Yes, you can submit more than one application a day to withdraw your savings via PayNow, as long as you have withdrawable CPF savings.']

question: Will I be notified when my CPF savings have been paid to me via PayNow?
answer:
['Yes. With PayNow, you will be notified when your CPF savings have been paid to you.
If you have registered an email address under √¢¬Ä¬úMy Notifications√¢¬Ä¬ù, you will receive an email when the status of your online application is updated.
If you do not have a registered email with us**,** but have a mobile number in our record, you will receive an SMS notification.
You can also check the status of your application under "My Activities."
In addition, if you have opted to receive SMS alerts with your bank, you will receive an SMS notification on your mobile number registered with your bank when the payment is made to your PayNow registered NRIC-linked bank account.']

question: How long will it take for the withdrawal amount to be refunded to my CPF account if the PayNow transaction was unsuccessful?
answer: ['The amount will be returned to your CPF account generally within two working days.']

question: Do I earn interest for the balances in my CPF accounts up to the date of my withdrawal?
answer:
['You will earn interest for the withdrawable amount up to the month before your withdrawal.
The interest earned will be credited into your CPF account at the beginning of each year and can be withdrawn from then on.
Find out√Ç¬†[how your CPF interest is calculated](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/cpf-interest-rates/how-is-my-cpf-interest-computed-and-credited-into-my-accounts).']

question: What is the PayNow registered bank account that is linked to my NRIC?
answer:
['With PayNow-NRIC, your bank account information is kept private. Hence, it is best to check with your bank directly on the specific bank account that is linked to your NRIC.
The sender (CPF Board in this case) only needs to use your NRIC to send you the money.']

question: What is the CPF planner - retirement income?
answer: ['The [CPF planner - retirement income](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/planners/cpf-planner-retirement-income) is a tool that helps members set their retirement income goals, visualise their projected retirement savings and payouts, and receive personalised suggestions on the steps to achieve their goals. With the planner, retirement planning is easy with just 3 steps, and takes only minutes to complete.']

question: Who can use the CPF planner - retirement income?
answer:
['The [CPF planner - retirement income](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/planners/cpf-planner-retirement-income) is currently available for members between age 16 and 53.√Ç¬†We hope to expand this service to more age groups in the future.
Older members who are reaching important CPF milestones can view their personalised retirement planning information through the links below:
[If you are reaching 55](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/CRPS)[If you are reaching or have reached 65](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/payout)']

question: Why do I need to log in with my Singpass to access the CPF planner - retirement income?
answer:
['To use the CPF planner - retirement income, you need to log in using Singpass because:
1. Your latest Special Account balance is used to project your retirement savings and payouts; and
2. The retirement income goals or details you provide will be saved for future visits to the planner, making it easier for you to keep track of your retirement planning.']

question: What is the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['The permanent Silver Support (SS) Scheme is part of a wider suite of schemes (e.g. healthcare subsidies, GST voucher) that the Government has put in place to give seniors greater assurance in retirement.
It provides a quarterly cash supplement to seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement. The Government reviews the Scheme periodically to ensure that it continues to target deserving seniors.
Seniors who qualify for SS will automatically receive their cash supplement. There is no need to apply.']

question: Do I need to apply for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['There is no need to apply for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.
CPF Board will automatically review your eligibility for the SS Scheme every year. Eligible seniors will automatically receive SS every quarter.
Seniors who qualify will receive a notification from CPF Board in December of the preceding year.']

question: Do I qualify for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is meant to support seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement. To identify this target group, three criteria are used in tandem √¢¬Ä¬ì lifetime wages, housing type, and the level of household support.
Singapore citizens aged 65 and above will be eligible for the SS Scheme if they meet all of the following criteria:
1. Low lifetime wages√Ç¬†- Total CPF contributions\*√Ç¬†of not more than $140,000 by age 55. Self-employed persons should also have an average annual net trade income#√Ç¬†of not more than $27,600 when they were between the ages of 45 and 54; and
2. Housing type√Ç¬†- Live in a 1- to 5-room HDB flat; and do not own, or have a spouse who owns, a 5-room or larger HDB flat, private property or multiple properties; and
3. Low household support√Ç¬†- Live in a household with a monthly income per person of not more than $1,800.
CPF Board will automatically review your eligibility for SS every year. Seniors who qualify for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme will receive a notification in December of the preceding year.
Eligible seniors turning age 65 will be notified of their eligibility in December of the year before they turn 65. They will start receiving SS in the quarter they turn 65.
In addition to the notification, all Singaporeans aged 65 and above can check their SS eligibility by logging in to the SS [e-Services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/cds/sss/login) using their Singpass.
\*Total CPF contributions refers to the total sum in an individual√¢¬Ä¬ôs Ordinary Account and Special Account, including the amounts withdrawn for housing, education and investment.
#Net trade income refers to the gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by IRAS.']

question: How much Silver Support will I receive?
answer:
['Eligible seniors will receive Silver Support (SS) every quarter, depending on their household monthly income per person, and the type of HDB flat that they live in. Those living in smaller flats will receive higher SS.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **HDB Flat Type** | **Silver Support Per Quarter^** |
| **Household earns √¢¬â¬§$1,300 per person** | **Household earns $1,301-$1,800 per person** |
| **1- and 2-Room** | $900 | $450 |
| **3-Room** | $720 | $360 |
| **4-Room** | $540 | $270 |
| **5-Room\*** | $360 | $180 |
\*Live in and do not own a 5-room HDB flat.
^All Singaporeans aged 65 and above who are ComCare Long Term Assistance (LTA) recipients will receive SS of $360 per quarter, regardless of their flat type.
Eligible seniors will receive Silver Support (SS) according to the following schedule.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Payment Date** | **For period** |
| 31 December√Ç¬†of the preceding year | January - March |
| 31 March | April - June |
| 30 June | July - September |
| 30 September | October - December |
Those who turn 65 in the year will start receiving SS in the quarter they turn 65.']

question: Can Permanent Residents qualify for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer: ['The Silver Support Scheme is given only to Singapore Citizens.']

question: I am a Pioneer Generation member. Will I automatically qualify for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['Pioneer Generation members do not automatically qualify for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.
The SS Scheme is meant for seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement.
The Pioneer Generation Package is a one-off scheme meant for the special generation who contributed to Singapore√¢¬Ä¬ôs nation-building in our early years.
Pioneer Generation members will be means-tested for SS like all other seniors aged 65 and above, and those who meet the eligibility criteria will receive SS.']

question: I am a Public Assistance (also known as ComCare Long Term Assistance) recipient who is receiving Silver Support. Can I qualify for higher Silver Support?
answer:
['Seniors aged 65 and above on the ComCare Long Term Assistance (LTA) Scheme will automatically qualify for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme and receive a flat amount of $360 per quarter, regardless of their HDB flat type.
The SS supplements the monthly cash assistance provided by the ComCare LTA Scheme, which currently covers the recipient's daily living expenses, free medical treatment and highly subsidised social services if needed. ComCare LTA beneficiaries also receive medical assistance at polyclinics and government/restructured hospitals, free or highly subsidised social services such as home help, or senior activity centres funded by the government.']

question: How can I receive SMS notifications on my Silver Support Payments?
answer:
['We will send SMS notifications on Silver Support (SS) payments to the mobile number that you have registered with CPF Board.
To receive SMS notifications on your SS payments, you may update your mobile number via *my cpf* digital services √¢¬Ä¬ì [Account settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/general-information---useful-tips/electronic-services/how-can-i-inform-cpf-board-of-a-change-in-my-mobile-number-or-email-address) with your Singpass.']

question: Why are my total CPF contributions used as a reflection of my lifetime wages in the assessment of eligibility of the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['CPF contributions are proportionate to a person√¢¬Ä¬ôs wage. They thus serve as an indicator of one√¢¬Ä¬ôs ability to save.
We will look at the senior√¢¬Ä¬ôs total CPF contributions by the age of 55 to assess his/her eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme. This refers to the sum of contributions to the Ordinary Account (OA) and Special Account (SA), as well as any CPF savings that had been withdrawn for housing, investment and education.']

question: Why is the age cut-off for total CPF contributions set at 55 for the assessment of eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['For the assessment of eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme, we do not look at CPF contributions after the age of 55, so as to encourage older Singaporeans to continue working and saving for retirement.
We have also set the cut-off age at 55 to provide a meaningful comparison across cohorts, which experience different sets of CPF withdrawal rules and wage adjustments after age 55.']

question: Why is the threshold for total CPF contributions set at $140,000 to be eligible for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['An eligibility criterion of $140,000 set for the Silver Support Scheme would include seniors who were earning lower wages through their working lives, and those who did not work due to reasons such as care-giving responsibilities and medical conditions.
The Total CPF Contributions threshold was increased from $70,000 to $140,000 in 2021 to strengthen support for seniors with lesser means. The Government will review the criteria from time to time, to ensure that the Silver Support Scheme is able to reach those who need it most.']

question: How can I check how much total CPF contributions I have at age 55 for assessing my eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['Only Singaporean seniors aged 65 and above can be assessed for eligibility for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.
You may request to find out your total CPF contributions (TCC) used for the SS Scheme by contacting us at [cpf.gov.sg/contact-us](http://cpf.gov.sg/contact-us).']

question: I am a self-employed person. How will the Government assess my eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['As it is not mandatory for self-employed persons to contribute to their Ordinary and Special Accounts, self-employed persons would naturally have made less CPF contributions than employees.
For seniors who were self-employed in their working years, we will consider their average annual net trade income, as determined by their annual income tax assessments, in addition to the total CPF contributions they made by the age of 55.
To qualify for the Silver Support Scheme, their average annual net trade income must not be more than $27,600 between the ages of 45 and 54. The average annual net trade income threshold was increased from $22,800 to $27,600 in 2021 to strengthen support for seniors with lesser means. The Government will review the threshold from time to time, to ensure that the Silver Support Scheme is able to reach those who need it most.']

question: What is net trade income?
answer: ['Net trade income is your gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS).']

question: Why is household monthly income per person used as an indication of my household support for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is meant for seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement.
To automatically identify seniors who are eligible for SS, the Government has to rely on available data as broad indicators of an individual√¢¬Ä¬ôs ability to save for retirement, access to resources and family support.
We have relied on the household monthly income per person as a broad indicator of the level of family support available.']

question: Why is the threshold for household monthly income per person set at $1,800 to be eligible for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['The Silver Support (SS) Scheme is meant for seniors who had low incomes during their working years and now have less in retirement.
The threshold of $1,800 enables seniors who have little or no family support to benefit from SS.']

question: Who should be considered as a member of my household for the computation of my household income used for assessing my eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['Only family members related by blood, marriage and/or legal adoption (e.g. spouse, parents, children, grandparents, grandchildren, siblings, uncles, aunts, cousins and in-laws) and who live at the same residence are considered members of your household for the computation of your household income used for assessing your eligibility for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.
Domestic helpers, unrelated tenants, godparents and friends living at the same address are not considered members of your household. Family members not living at your address are not considered members of your household.
If there are recent household changes that you want us to take into account to reassess your SS eligibility, please [write in](http://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) to CPF Board and we will work with the Household Means Eligibility System (HOMES) to have your household means tested.']

question: How will the household monthly income per person be determined for assessing one√¢¬Ä¬ôs eligibility for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['In general, annual income from work from all household members will be used.
If there are recent changes to your circumstances that you want us to take into consideration to reassess your Silver Support Scheme eligibility, please [write in](http://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) to CPF Board and we will work with the Household Means Eligibility System (HOMES) to have your household means tested. The following supporting documents will be required from you.
**Salaried Employees:**
For those who are salaried employees, their income will be based on either:
a. the average monthly income over the last available 12-month period, including bonuses, as derived by the CPF Board; or
b. the average monthly income from work (sum of net employment income and annual trade income before losses brought forward) assessed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for the latest available assessment year.
**Self-Employed:**
For those who are self-employed, their income will be based on either:
a. the average monthly income from work (sum of net employment income and annual trade income before losses brought forward) assessed by Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for the latest available assessment year; or
b. the income declared to the CPF Board within the last 2 years.']

question: How do you determine my housing type to be eligible for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer: ['The housing type to be eligible for the Silver Support Scheme is based on your address as registered in your NRIC.']

question: Why is a senior not eligible for the Silver Support Scheme if he and/or his spouse together own a 5-room or larger HDB flat, private property or multiple properties?
answer:
['The type of home owned is an indicator of the senior√¢¬Ä¬ôs resources. Those who own a 5-room or larger HDB flat, private property or multiple properties are more likely to have more resources and access to additional retirement income. They would be less likely to require assistance through the Silver Support (SS) Scheme.
There are other schemes to help seniors cope with daily expenses, finance their healthcare needs and increase their retirement savings. Even if you do not qualify for the SS, you can still benefit from many of these schemes.
Those who need additional support can turn to other forms of assistance such as ComCare and MediFund. They may wish to approach a nearby Social Service Office for assistance.']

question: Will the Silver Support Scheme cover seniors living in residential facilities (e.g. Nursing Homes/ Welfare Homes/ Home for the Aged and Adult Disability Home)?
answer: ['Seniors aged 65 and above, including those living in [residential facilities that provide long-term care](/content/dam/web/member/faq/retirement-income/documents/List%20of%20Approved%20Homes%20for%20SS%20Scheme.pdf), will be assessed for the Silver Support (SS) Scheme. Seniors whose NRIC address reflects one of these facilities will receive SS if they meet all the other eligibility criteria. Seniors whose NRIC address does not reflect one of these facilities will receive SS based on the housing type of their NRIC address, if they meet all the other eligibility criteria.']

question: How will I receive my Silver Support?
answer:
['You will receive your Silver Support (SS) via your PayNow-NRIC linked bank account. To check your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account details, please approach your bank.
If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore but have provided your DBS/POSB, OCBC or UOB bank account number to the Government previously, you will receive your SS via bank transfer. You can check and update your bank account details registered with us by logging in to our e-services with your Singpass.
Otherwise, your SS will be credited to you via GovCash. GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singaporeans to receive their benefits from Government agencies more quickly and conveniently. Starting from December 2022, we will not be issuing cheques for SS. You are encouraged to link your NRIC to PayNow with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your benefits earlier.']

question: How can I change my bank details for Silver Support?
answer:
['You are encouraged to register for PayNow-NRIC with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your Silver Support (SS) earlier. Payment will be made by default to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.
If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account, you can update your bank account details by logging in to our e-services with your Singpass.
If you are eligible and have updated your bank account details, the instruction will only take effect from the next quarter of SS, if you continue to be eligible.']

question: My mobile number is already registered to my bank account on PayNow. Can the Government credit my Silver Support payments to me via PayNow-Mobile instead of via PayNow-NRIC?
answer:
['We can only credit your Silver Support payments to you via your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account. NRIC is an unchanged proxy issued by the Government, compared to mobile numbers which may be easily changed. To ensure that the money is credited to the correct recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account, only NRIC will be accepted as the proxy for Government benefits via PayNow.
Eligible seniors who have linked their NRIC to PayNow, with a PayNow-GIRO-participating bank will receive the benefits in this bank account.']

question: What is GovCash?
answer: ['GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singapore citizens to withdraw their Government benefits in cash from over 500 OCBC ATMs located across Singapore. Singaporeans who prefer to seek assistance with their GovCash withdrawals can visit the ATMs located within OCBC's branches during operating hours, where OCBC Digital Ambassadors will be present to guide them. In addition, GovCash also allows recipients to use the scan-and-pay function and PayNow transfer option through the LifeSG mobile app.']

question: Can Silver Support be paid on a monthly basis instead of a quarterly basis?
answer:
['Silver Support (SS) payments are made ahead of the quarter, as shown below:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Payment Date** | **For period** |
| 31 December√Ç¬†of the preceding year | January - March |
| 31 March | April - June |
| 30 June | July - September |
| 30 September | October - December |
Paying ahead in 3-month tranches gives the recipients greater flexibility to manage their expenses. Monthly payments will reduce such flexibility.']

question: Can I appeal for the Silver Support Scheme?
answer:
['There may be some seniors on the margins who do not qualify automatically, but may still be deserving of Silver Support (SS). These seniors can [write in](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index) to CPF Board for a review of their case.
Even if you do not qualify for SS, there are other schemes in place to help you, if you are in need of assistance.
You may qualify for SS in future years if your circumstances warrant additional retirement support.']

question: Who is HOMES?
answer: ['The√Ç¬†[Household Means Eligibility System (HOMES)](https://va.ecitizen.gov.sg/cfp/customerpages/homes/explorefaq.aspx) is a Government system supporting public schemes, including the Silver Support Scheme, in their conduct of means-tests as part of their assessment in determining the level of assistance for them.']

question: I received a call/email/letter claiming they are from the Household Means Eligibility System (HOMES). Are they legitimate?
answer:
['HOMES is a Government system supporting the Silver Support (SS) Scheme in conducting household means-tests, which are used to assess a senior√¢¬Ä¬ôs eligibility for the SS Scheme. If you or your family member had asked for a reassessment of SS eligibility, and there is a need for further clarification regarding your household information, the HOMES team may contact you via phone, email or letter to find out more on your household circumstances.
If you are unsure of the authenticity of the mobile number that you have received, please call their hotline 6818 1422 for confirmation.
If you have any query on HOMES, you may visit [HOMES website](https://www.homes.gov.sg/eservice/?csrt=12652996593597543606) to provide your contact details and a brief description of your query.']

question: What is PayNow and how do I link my NRIC to PayNow?
answer:
['PayNow is a secure funds transfer service that allows customers to receive money into their bank account via NRIC/FIN and/or mobile number.
With PayNow, the recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank information will be kept private. The recipient will need to provide their mobile number or NRIC/FIN to the sender to send money. Other PayNow users will not have access to your personal details unless it is provided by you.
To receive government benefits via PayNow, you will need to link your NRIC to PayNow. PayNow-Mobile number is not accepted. You can register for PayNow-NRIC if you have a bank account with the following participating banks in Singapore:
| **Bank** |
| --- |
| [Bank of China](https://www.bankofchina.com/sg/custserv/cs6/201804/t20180426_12102708.html) |
| [CIMB](https://www.cimb.com.sg/en/business/digital-banking/paynow-corp.html) |
| [Citibank](https://www.ipb.citibank.com.sg/english/static/online-payment-transfers.htm) |
| [DBS Bank / POSB](https://www.dbs.com.sg/personal/support/bank-ssb-paynow-register-profile.html) |
| [HSBC Bank](https://www.hsbc.com.sg/ways-to-bank/transfers/paynow/) |
| [ICBC](https://v.icbc.com.cn/userfiles/Resources/ICBC/haiwai/Singapore/download/2021/PaynowIndividualFAQ.pdf) |
| [Maybank](https://www.maybank2u.com.sg/en/personal/payments/local/fund-transfers/paynow.page) |
| [OCBC](https://www.ocbc.com/personal-banking/digital-banking/paynow) |
| [Standard Chartered Bank](https://www.sc.com/sg/bank-with-us/paynow/) |
| [UOB](https://www.uob.com.sg/personal/eservices/ebanking/paynow.page) |
You may refer to your respective bank's website for specific details on how to link your NRIC to PayNow. If you do not have internet or mobile banking, you can contact your bank directly to register for PayNow-NRIC.
If you do not have a PayNow NRIC-linked account, and wish to receive your payment via bank crediting, you may provide your bank account details to us by logging in to our e-services with your Singpass.']

question: How do I make regular monthly or yearly top-ups conveniently via GIRO?
answer:
['If you are a DBS/POSB or OCBC bank customer, you can set up your GIRO arrangement online for your top-up application by following the steps below:
**Step 1: Apply for a GIRO Arrangement with DBS/OCBC**
1. Login to cpf.gov.sg with your Singpass
2. Click on √¢¬Ä¬úMy Requests√¢¬Ä¬ù
3. Select √¢¬Ä¬úBuilding Up My/ My Recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings√¢¬Ä¬ù
4. Select √¢¬Ä¬ú[Apply/Change GIRO for cash top-up to my own/ recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs Retirement/Special Account under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/GiroApplication/LandingPage?scheme=GTP)√¢¬Ä¬ù
5. Follow the instructions to complete the online application
Once the above GIRO application has been approved, submit the Standing Instruction to start the top-ups:
**Step 2: Set up a Standing Instruction**
1. Click on the √¢¬Ä¬úRelated Link(s)√¢¬Ä¬ù > √¢¬Ä¬úStanding Instruction to make cash top-up to my own/ recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs Retirement/Special Account under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme√¢¬Ä¬ù in the acknowledgement page of the approved GIRO application
2. Follow the instructions to complete the online application
Alternatively, follow the steps below:
1. Click on √¢¬Ä¬úMy Requests√¢¬Ä¬ù
2. Select √¢¬Ä¬úBuilding Up My/ My Recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings√¢¬Ä¬ù
3. Select √¢¬Ä¬ú[Standing Instruction to make cash top-up to my own/ recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs Retirement/Special Account under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/StandingInstructionRetirementSumToppingUp/CoverPage)√¢¬Ä¬ù
4. Follow the instructions to complete the online application
Ensure you have completed **both** steps for a successful GIRO deduction to take place.
If you are not a DBS/POSB or OCBC bank customer, find out how you can [apply for a GIRO arrangement](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-can-i-set-up-a-giro-arrangement-for-my-top-up-if-i-m-not-a-dbs-posb).']

question: Why are CPF transfers not eligible for tax relief?
answer:
['CPF contributions are tax-deductible. Therefore, when they are transferred from one CPF account to another, they will not enjoy tax benefits.
Consider [topping up using cash](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/cash-top-ups-and-cpf-transfers-for-retirement) to enjoy tax relief while boosting your retirement payouts. Find out [the conditions to enjoy tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).']

question: How can I check my top-up limits?
answer:
['You can check your top-up limit in your [Retirement Dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement).
Find out [how the top up limit is computed](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive).']

question: What is the maximum amount of top-ups I can receive?
answer:
['The maximum amount of top-ups you can receive depends on your age and amount of CPF savings as a recipient. You can check your top-up limit in your [Retirement Dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement).
![The maximum amount of top-ups you can receive depends on your age and the amount of CPF savings you have.
If you are below 55, the amount that you can receive is the difference between the Current Full Retirement Sum and the sum of your Special Account balance, including the amount withdrawn from your Special Account for investments that have not been completely disposed of.
If you are 55 and above, the amount that he can receive is the difference between the Current Enhanced Retirement Sum and your Retirement Account savings. Your Retirement Account savings exclude interest earned, any government grants received, plus amounts withdrawn through monthly payouts and immediate retirement needs.
You can check your top-up limit in your Retirement Dashboard.](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/images/RSTU_top_up_limit_graphic.jpg)
See [examples of how the maximum top-up amount is computed](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/Computation_of_amounts_for_recipients.pdf). (PDF, 55.3KB).']

question: Why am I not able to top up my Special/Retirement Account beyond the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) (below 55) or Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) (55 or above)?
answer:
['CPF savings are meant to provide for a basic level of retirement.
If you are below 55, you can top up your Special Account up to the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) to build up your retirement savings. If you wish to save beyond the FRS, you can choose to tap on the [Supplementary Retirement Scheme](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/basics-of-individual-income-tax/special-tax-schemes/srs-contributions), where contributions are also eligible for tax relief.
If you are 55 or above, retirement becomes a higher priority. As such, members have the option to voluntarily top up beyond the FRS up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum for higher payouts. This could help the middle-income group better meet their retirement needs.
Find out more about [what the retirement sums are](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-brs-frs-ers-).']

question: Is there a limit to the number of top-ups I can make or receive in a year?
answer:
['There is no limit to the number of top-ups you can make or receive,√Ç¬†[as long as the recipient can still receive top-ups](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive).
It is important to note that once you make a top-up, it cannot be reversed. Therefore, we advise you to review that you have sufficient cash or CPF savings for other expenses before making the top-up.']

question: Am I eligible for tax reliefs when I make a cash top-up to my/my loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô retirement savings?
answer:
['You can enjoy tax relief if you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident and make cash top-ups within the current Full Retirement Sum for yourself, your [loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-)√Ç¬†or employees.
Find out more about√Ç¬†[the amount of tax relief you can enjoy](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-much-tax-relief-can-i-enjoy).
Find out more on the [conditions to qualify for tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).']

question: How much tax relief can I enjoy when I make cash top-ups?
answer:
['You can enjoy an equivalent amount of tax relief for cash top-ups made in each calendar year of up to:
* $8,000 if you make a top-up to yourself; and
* an additional $8,000 if you make a cash top-up to your [loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-).
Please note that only cash top-ups up to the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) are eligible for tax relief. [Log in with your Singpass](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement) to find out how much you can top up to yourself.√Ç¬†If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, please note that the tax relief does not apply to your recipients. Find out the [conditions to qualify for tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).
If you are an employer making cash top-ups on your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô behalf, you will receive an equivalent amount of tax deductions for the cash top-ups. Additionally, your employee can receive up to $8,000\* of tax relief per calendar year.
\* Includes any tax relief that the employee would enjoy for cash top-ups made to himself.']

question: When should I submit my top-up application if I want to be eligible for tax relief in the next assessment year?
answer:
['Your online top-up application and payment will need to reach us by 31 December of the year.
It is important to note that the tax relief is granted based on the calendar year in which the top-up is made, regardless of the actual date of submission.
We would also encourage you to top up earlier in the year. Find out√Ç¬†[why you should top up as early as possible](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/when-is-the-best-time-to-top-up-to-maximise-the-growth-of-my-sav).']

question: What actions do I need to take to file and claim tax relief for my cash top-up?
answer:
['You do not need to file or claim tax relief for your cash top-up as we will automatically inform Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) if you are eligible.
Please note that only givers who make cash top-ups are eligible for tax relief. If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, the tax relief does not apply to your receipients. Find out [the conditions to enjoy tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).']

question: What is the personal income tax relief cap and why is there a cap on this relief for cash top-ups made?
answer:
['The [personal income tax relief cap](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/basics-of-individual-income-tax/tax-reliefs-rebates-and-deductions) sets a limit on the total amount of tax relief you can claim.
Even though each relief serves a good purpose, some individuals may end up with a significantly reduced taxable income when multiple reliefs are combined. Therefore, tax relief on cash top-ups is also subjected to the personal income tax relief cap.']

question: How can I find out if I have reached the personal income tax relief cap?
answer: ['You can use the [tax calculator](https://www.iras.gov.sg/quick-links/calculators)√Ç¬†on Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website to find out if you have reached your personal income tax relief cap.']

question: Why is there no tax relief for top-ups made to my children or non-immediate family?
answer:
['Tax relief is an incentive given to encourage members to build up retirement savings for themselves or their immediate family members, particularly older Singaporeans who may have less retirement savings.
Your children have more time to accumulate savings in their working years for their own retirement needs. Hence, there is no tax relief for top-ups made to your children or non-immediate family members.']

question: I have made top-ups to my Special Account before 55. What will happen to the top-ups when I turn 55?
answer:
['The top-ups to your Special Account and accrued interest earned before you turn 55 will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) when you turn 55, up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS).
Top-up monies are meant to build up the recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs retirement savings and cannot be withdrawn for other purposes. Read more on [how the top-ups will be used](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-will-the-top-ups-to-my-retirement-savings-be-used-).
If you have savings in excess of the FRS, you can apply to [withdraw them for your immediate needs](/member/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/withdrawing-for-immediate-retirement-needs), as and when you need it. Alternatively, you can choose to set aside more retirement savings (up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum) by making top-ups to your RA to enjoy higher monthly payouts in retirement.']

question: Can I withdraw the top-up monies if I have the Full Retirement Sum, or the Basic Retirement Sum if I own a property?
answer: ['No. Higher interest rates and tax incentives are given to encourage members to top up beyond their Basic Retirement Sum. Allowing withdrawals after allowing members to enjoy these incentives would defeat the purpose of offering them.']

question: How will my monthly payouts change after topping up?
answer: ['If you are on [CPF LIFE](/member/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/cpf-life), the top-ups will allow you to enjoy higher monthly payouts for life. If you are on the [Retirement Sum Scheme](/member/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/non-cpf-life), you may enjoy higher payouts or receive your payouts for a longer time.']

question: Can I reverse my top-up?
answer: ['No, cash top-ups and CPF transfers are irreversible. The top-ups/CPF transfers to your Special Account or Retirement Account savings earn a higher [interest rate](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest)√Ç¬†as the savings are locked in for the long term. This is similar to the market practice where the interest earned on fixed deposits are higher compared to interest earned on savings deposits that are withdrawable anytime.']

question: Will my cash top-ups or CPF transfers be refunded to me if the recipient passes away?
answer: ['Cash top-ups and CPF transfers will generally be treated as gifts to the recipient. Any unused cash top-ups and CPF transfers will be paid to the recipient's nominees based on his√Ç¬†[CPF nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/account-services/providing-for-your-loved-ones/making-a-cpf-nomination). This is subject to [safeguards to prevent premature withdrawals](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-does-cpf-board-guard-against-premeditated-early-cpf-withdrawals).']

question: How can I check the status of my cash top-up and/or CPF transfer application?
answer:
['You can check the status of your online application via [My Activities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivity). If your application is successful, the transaction will be reflected under the Retirement Sum Topping-Up History√Ç¬†in your [Retirement Dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement).
If you have made **multiple**√Ç¬†applications, do check the status of all your applications under [My Activities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivity) to see which transactions have been successfully processed, and make a new application if necessary.']

question: My top-up is not reflected in my CPF account. Was the top-up unsuccessful?
answer:
['We will process your application within our [normal processing time](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-long-will-it-take-for-my-top-up-application-to-be-processed).
If your top-up is still not reflected after the expiry of our normal processing time:
1. You may have missed out in making payment for your cash top-up application. [Find out how to submit a new application](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-do-i-apply-to-make-a-top-up-).
2. You may have missed out in submitting supporting documents for first-time CPF transfers to a loved one. [Find out what are the required supporting documents](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-supporting-documents-would-i-need-if-i-m-making-a-first-time-cpf-transfer-).
3. We may need more time to verify your application. We√¢¬Ä¬ôll contact you within five working days to request for more information.']

question: How can I set up a GIRO arrangement for my top-up if I am not a DBS/POSB or OCBC bank customer?
answer:
['The online GIRO application for top-ups to retirement savings is only available for DBS/POSB or OCBC customers. We have plans to make the service available for the other banks in the future.
Meanwhile, you may complete the latest [Top Up Retirement Sum Using GIRO](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/FORM_RSTU_GIROandSI.pdf) (PDF, 1.5MB), if you are not a DBS/POSB or OCBC bank user.']

question: How can I revise or terminate my GIRO arrangement for my top-up application?
answer:
['**Revise GIRO arrangement for top-up application**
You can revise your existing GIRO arrangement such as the amount and frequency of top-ups by submitting [this form](https://form.gov.sg/61d3f3863cff1000129eb9c2).
**Terminate GIRO arrangement for top-up application**
You can√Ç¬†terminate your GIRO arrangement by submitting [this form](https://form.gov.sg/#!/5ed0a5e8de28b70011650031).']

question: Can I set up more than one GIRO arrangement to make regular top-ups?
answer:
['Yes, you can set up more than one GIRO arrangement if you wish to make regular top-ups to more than one recipient. Simply submit a [Standing Instruction](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/StandingInstructionRetirementSumToppingUp/CoverPage) provided you have an existing GIRO arrangement that has been approved by the bank. If you do not have an existing GIRO arrangement, [find out how to do so](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-do-i-make-regular-monthly-or-yearly-top-ups-conveniently-via-giro).
However, please note that you can only have one GIRO bank account for your GIRO arrangements for your various top-up recipients.']

question: How long does it take for my GIRO arrangement for my top-up to take effect?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our normal processing time for GIRO arrangement for top-ups:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Type of application** | **Normal processing time** |
| **Processing** | **Deduction and crediting** |
| Online GIRO application (DBS/POSB or OCBC bank users) | * Your GIRO application will be processed almost instantly.
* Your GIRO instruction will take effect in the same month If you submit **both**:
+ GIRO application;√Ç¬†**and**
+ Standing Instruction
within the first seven days of the month. | * We will deduct the monies from your bank account on the 15th of the month (or the next working day if 15th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).
* Your top-up will be credited within seven working days after we receive your payment.
Note: Ensure that you maintain sufficient funds in your bank account for GIRO deductions. Some banks may charge an administrative fee for each unsuccessful deduction. |
| Hardcopy GIRO application (Other bank users) | * Your GIRO application will be processed within 21 working days after we receive your application.
* Your GIRO arrangement will take effect from the following month after your application is processed.
|']

question: Why are there no deductions from my bank account for my top-up even though I have set up a GIRO arrangement online?
answer:
['The possible reasons for not having deductions in your bank account for your top-up could be due to the following:
* You have not submitted your Standing Instruction to start the top-ups. Ensure that you have completed the [steps](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-do-i-make-regular-monthly-or-yearly-top-ups-conveniently-via-giro).
* The GIRO deduction date has not commenced. Check our [service standards](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-long-does-it-take-for-my-giro-arrangement-for-my-top-up).']

question: What are the benefits of making top-ups via the PayNow QR?
answer:
['Making payment via PayNow QR for your top-up is hassle-free.
You would only need to scan the QR code at the end of the online application. There is no need for you to key in any details manually as the required details (e.g. payment amount, type of transaction) are contained in the QR code. In this way, payments are completed in a hassle-free manner.']

Once the QR code expires, you would need to submit a new application which would come with a new QR code.
You can watch the [instructional video](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/infohub/educational-resources/how-to-make-retirement-sum-top-up-online-via-paynowqr) in your preferred language on how to make a top-up via PayNow QR.

question: What is the maximum amount I can top up via PayNow QR?
answer: ['The maximum amount you can top up via PayNow QR is $200,000, subject to daily and monthly limits set by your bank. [See guides on how to change your bank√¢¬Ä¬ôs transfer limits](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-can-i-increase-my-internet-or-mobile-banking-transfer-limit-).']

question: How long would it take for my top-up to be credited via PayNow QR?
answer: ['Cash top-ups via PayNow QR will generally be credited almost instantly, upon successful payment.']

question: What if my banking app is unable to scan the PayNow QR for my top-up application?
answer: ['You should check with your bank if you are unable to scan the PayNow QR for your top-up application.']

['**Cash top-up**

question: When should I submit my application for my top-up to be processed within the same month?
answer:
['**If you are making a cash top-up**
Both your application and payment should be made by the following timings:

| --- | --- |
| **Payment mode** | **When payment should be made** |
| PayNow QR | Within last day of the month |
| OCBC PayAnyone (available for applications via CPF Mobile App only) |
To have your cash top-up processed quickly, we encourage you to make the payment via PayNow QR or OCBC PayAnyone. Your cash top-up is credited **almost instantly** upon successful payment.
**If you are making a CPF transfer**
You should submit your application before the 5th√Ç¬†last working day of the month.']

question: What is the fastest way to make a cash top-up?
answer: ['The fastest way to make a cash top-up would be via PayNow QR or OCBC PayAnyone (for applications via CPF mobile app or [online form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/cash-top-ups-and-cpf-transfers-for-retirement)). Your cash top-up will generally be credited **almost instantly** upon successful payment.']

question: What supporting documents would I need if I√¢¬Ä¬ôm making a first-time CPF transfer to my loved ones?
answer:
['You would need to submit the following documents for **first-time** transfers to your loved ones in the [top-up application form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/cash-top-ups-and-cpf-transfers-for-retirement).
*Supporting documents are not required for cash top-ups.*
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **CPF transfer to** | **Supporting documents** |
| Spouse | Marriage certificate, if your marriage is registered overseas |
| Parent(s) | Your birth certificate |
| Grandparent(s) | Your and your parent(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs birth certificates |
| Sibling(s) | Your and your sibling(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs birth certificates |
| Parent(s)-in-law | Your overseas marriage certificate\* and your spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs birth certificate |
| Grandparent(s)-in-law | Your overseas marriage certificate, your spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs and your spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs parent(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs birth certificates |
\*Not required if your marriage is registered in Singapore']

question: Why should I top up my retirement savings?
answer:
['There are several reasons why you should consider topping up your retirement savings:
**1. Higher monthly payouts in retirement**
By topping up your Special Account (SA) (if you are below 55) or Retirement Account (RA) (if you are 55 or above), you are growing your retirement savings and will enjoy [higher monthly payouts](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-will-the-top-ups-to-my-retirement-savings-be-used-) when you retire.
**2. Risk-free interest rates\* of up to 6% per annum**
By topping up your SA or RA, you can earn risk-free [interest rates\* of up to 6% per annum](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest) on your savings.
For instance, if you save $100 a month for 15 years on your own, you would have saved $18,000. On the other hand, if you top up $100 a month to your SA or RA for the same amount of time, you would have saved over $24,000\*. If you continue to top up for another 10 years, your savings would grow even more, reaching over $50,000\* with compound interest.
**3. Enjoy tax relief and matching grant for cash top-ups**
By topping up with cash, you can also benefit from:
