* [Tax relief of up to $16,000](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/can-i-claim-tax-reliefs-when-i-make-a-cash-top-up-to-my-my-loved).√Ç¬†[Terms and conditions apply](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).
* Matching dollar-for-dollar grant from the Government if you are eligible for the [Matched Retirement Savings Scheme](/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/matching-grant-for-seniors-who-top-up). [Terms and conditions apply](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/who-is-eligible).
\*Computed using the [interest rate](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest) floor of 4% per annum on your Special/Retirement Account.']

question: How will the top-ups to my retirement savings be used?
answer:
['Top-up monies will form part of your [retirement sum](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-happens-to-my-cpf-savings-when-i-turn-55) and give you [higher monthly payouts in retirement](/member/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/cpf-life). As such, top-up monies cannot be withdrawn as a lump sum, withdrawn from your Retirement Account savings√Ç¬†using property, or transferred to your loved ones.
Additionally, top-up monies cannot be used for other CPF schemes, such as√Ç¬†[withdrawal for immediate retirement needs](/member/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/withdrawing-for-immediate-retirement-needs/withdrawal-of-cpf-savings-for-property-owners), [withdrawal on exemption from setting aside a retirement sum](/member/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/cpf-life/exemption-from-cpf-life), and other CPF schemes for education, investment, insurance, housing etc.']

question: Can I top up using cash or CPF transfers?
answer:
['Yes, you can top up your retirement savings using cash or by making CPF transfers. Please take note that [CPF transfers do not qualify for tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/why-are-cpf-transfers-not-eligible-for-tax-relief) or [matching grant from the government under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/why-are-cpf-transfers-not-eligible).
If you wish to increase your own or your loved ones' retirement savings, you can find out more here:
* [Who you can make top-ups to](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-can-i-make-top-ups-to-)
* [Who you can receive top-ups from](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-can-i-receive-top-ups-from--)
* [How much you can top up√Ç¬†via cash](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive)
* [How much you can top up via CPF transfer](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-transfer-to-myself-or-my-loved-ones-)']

question: Who can I make top-ups to?
answer:
['**Cash top-ups**
You can make cash top-ups to any Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. [Find out the amount of cash top-ups you can make to a recipient](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive).
**CPF transfers**
You can only make CPF transfers to yourself or your [loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-). CPF transfers can only be made to a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. [Find out the amount of CPF transfers you can make to yourself or your loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-transfer-to-myself-or-my-loved-ones-).']

question: Who can I receive top-ups from?
answer:
['**Cash top-ups**
You can receive cash top-ups from anyone, including yourself, your family, employers or any member of the community.
**CPF transfers**
You can receive CPF transfers only from yourself or your√Ç¬†[loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-).
You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident to receive a top-up.']

question: Who are considered my loved ones?
answer: ['Your loved ones refer to your parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, spouse and siblings.']

question: Is there a minimum or maximum age for making or receiving top-ups?
answer:
['There is no maximum age for making or receiving top-ups.
However, you will need to be at least 16 years old to be a giver of cash top-ups.
You can make cash top-ups to a child who is not yet 16 years old, and you can find out how to do so [here](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-can-i-make-cash-top-ups-to-my-child).']

question: Can I still receive top-ups if I have started my monthly retirement payouts?
answer:
['Yes, you can receive top-ups as long as you have not reached the [current Enhanced Retirement Sum](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-).
Find out [how much top-ups you can receive](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive).']

question: What are the differences between topping up my retirement savings, making a Voluntary Housing Refund and topping up my MediSave Account?
answer:
['Find out what are the differences between the various types of top-ups below:
| | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| | **[Topping up your retirement savings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-to-enjoy-higher-retirement-payouts)** | **[Voluntary Housing Refund](/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/make-a-voluntary-housing-refund)** | **[Topping up√Ç¬†MediSave Account (MA)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-your-medisave-savings)** |
| Top up/refund to | * Special Account√Ç¬†(SA) for members below 55; or
* Retirement Account√Ç¬†(RA) for members 55 and above
| * OA; and/or
* RA for members 55 and above and have not met their Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in their RA
| * MA
|
| Base[interest√Ç¬†rate](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest)p.a. | * SA: 4.01%
* RA: 4%
| * OA: 2.5%
* RA: 4%
| * MA: 4.01%
|
| Eligible for tax relief | [Cash top-ups made to self or loved ones up to the current FRS are eligible for tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/can-i-claim-tax-reliefs-when-i-make-a-cash-top-up-to-my-my-loved). | Not eligible for tax relief | For non self-employed persons:* For voluntary top-up to MediSave Account, you get to enjoy√Ç¬†[tax relief](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/top-up-your-medisave-account-to-save-more-for-healthcare-needs/do-i-get-tax-relief-for-my-voluntary-top-up-to-my-medisave).
You will also enjoy tax relief if you are topping up your CPF accounts voluntarily as a√Ç¬†[self-employed person](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/self-employed-scheme/what-benefits-do-self-employed-persons-enjoy-by-making-medisave). Find out more on√Ç¬†[IRAS website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/self-employed/deductions-for-individuals/personal-reliefs-and-tax-rebates/cpf-provident-fund-relief-for-self-employed-employee-who-is-also-self-employed). |
| Limit to top up | [What is the maximum amount of top-ups a member can receive?](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive)√Ç¬†If you are below 55, the maximum amount you can have in your SA is the current FRS.√Ç¬†If you are 55 and above, the maximum amount you can have in your RA is the current Enhanced Retirement Sum.√Ç¬†You can check your top-up limit in your Retirement Dashboard. | [How much voluntary housing refund can I make?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/voluntary-housing-refund/how-much-voluntary-housing-refund-can-i-make-) You can make a refund of any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property, along with the accrued interest. You may check the amount that you can refund through the [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership). Do note that after making a full voluntary housing refund of the CPF savings withdrawn and accrued interest, all CPF withdrawals including monthly housing loan instalments (if any) for the property will stop. | [What is the voluntary top-up limit to my MediSave Account?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/top-up-your-medisave-account-to-save-more-for-healthcare-needs/what-is-the-voluntary-top-up-limit-to-my-medisave-account) The maximum amount you can voluntarily top up to your MediSave Account is the difference between your [Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)](/member/faq/healthcare-financing/basic-healthcare-sum/what-is-the-basic-healthcare-sum) and your current MediSave balance. Once your BHS has been reached, no further voluntary top-ups can be made to your MediSave Account. If you exceed your BHS from the top-up, the full amount of your top up will be refunded to you.√Ç¬†You can check your top-up limit [with these steps](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/top-up-your-medisave-account-to-save-more-for-healthcare-needs/how-do-i-check-my-voluntary-top-up-limit-to-my-medisave-account). |
| Withdrawal | Top-ups are meant to boost your retirement income. They will be streamed out to you as monthly payouts and cannot be used for other purposes. | You can continue to use your OA savings for the current or next property after making a voluntary housing refund.√Ç¬†However, if you would like to use your OA for the same property, after making a voluntary refund of the full principal amount used and the accrued interest, you will need to re-apply to use your CPF savings.√Ç¬†After turning 55 and setting aside the FRS, you can withdraw the remaining balance in your OA and SA in full or in part at any time. | From 55, you can make retirement withdrawals from your OA and SA in full or in part, at any time for your immediate needs, provided you have set aside your FRS.√Ç¬†MA savings are meant for your healthcare needs and cannot be withdrawn as cash. |
| Application | Top-ups can be made using cash and/or CPF transfers.√Ç¬†[How do I apply to make a top-up?](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-do-i-apply-to-make-a-top-up-) | Refund can only be made via cash.√Ç¬†[I am not selling my property. How can I make a voluntary refund of the housing amount withdrawn?](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/voluntary-housing-refund/i-am-not-selling-my-property-how-can-i-make-a-voluntary-refund) | Top ups can only be made via cash.√Ç¬†[How can I top up my, my children or my loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô CPF Account(s)?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/top-up-your-medisave-account-to-save-more-for-healthcare-needs/how-to-top-up-to-my-cpf-accounts-or-on-behalf-of-someone-else) |']

question: When is the best time to top up to grow my savings?
answer:
['You should top up as early as possible to benefit from the power of compound interest over the years.
You can also earn more interest if you top up earlier in the year. For example, if you top up in January each year instead of in December, you can earn up to 20% more interest on your top-ups in 10 years.
![Earn up to 20 percent more interest on your top-ups in 10 years if you top up in January instead of December each year](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/images/topping_up_early1.jpg)
\* Based on Retirement Account [interest rates](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest)√Ç¬†of up to 6% per annum, with $8,000 annual top-up, and $0 starting CPF balances.
Top up early to avoid potential delays in the processing of your application during the year-end rush.']

question: When will the top-ups received in my CPF Special/Retirement Account start to earn interest?
answer:
['If you receive a cash top-up this month, it will start earning interest in the next month.
For CPF transfers of existing CPF savings, you will start earning interest in your account from this month. However, if the CPF savings are fresh injections, it will start earning interest in your account from the next month.']

question: If I am 55 and would like to make a CPF transfer, in what order will my savings be transferred?
answer:
['**CPF transfers to your Retirement Account (RA)**
If you are 55 or above, your CPF savings will be transferred to your RA in the following order:
1. Special Account (SA)
2. Ordinary Account (OA)
**CPF transfers to your√Ç¬†[loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-)**
If you are 55 or above, your CPF savings will be [transferred to your loved ones](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-transfer-to-myself-or-my-loved-ones-) in the following order:
1. OA
2. SA
3. RA\*
\*If you use your RA savings for the transfer, you may no longer have enough savings to meet your Full Retirement Sum (FRS). In that case, the next time you apply for a withdrawal from your OA and SA, a portion or all of the savings will be used to meet your FRS in the RA.']

question: If I am 55, can I transfer my Ordinary Account savings to my Special Account to earn a higher interest rate?
answer:
['No, you will not be able to make CPF transfers to your Special Account (SA) after you turn 55. Instead, your transfers will be made to your Retirement Account (RA), which was created for your retirement needs.
***Did you know?** If you wish to earn higher [interest](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest) on your Ordinary Account (OA) savings (which earns at least 2.5% interest per annum) and boost your monthly payouts, you can [make a CPF transfer](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/cash-top-ups-and-cpf-transfers-for-retirement) to your RA (which earns at least 4% interest per annum), up to the current Enhanced Retirement Sum. Do note that for CPF transfers to RA, your SA savings (if any) will be transferred first followed by your OA savings.*']

question: Why am I not allowed to transfer my CPF savings to my children?
answer:
['Your CPF savings are meant to support your retirement needs. Your children would be able to accumulate savings in their working years. Hence, it is more important to prioritise your own retirement savings and ensure that you have sufficient funds to support your retirement needs.
Find out [how you can use cash to top up your child's CPF account](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-can-i-make-cash-top-ups-to-my-child).']

question: What are the conditions for me to enjoy tax relief?
answer:
['The conditions for you to enjoy tax relief when you make cash top-ups to yourself, your loved ones or employees are as follows:
* You can enjoy tax relief of up to $8,000 if you make a top-up to yourself; and an additional $8,000 if you make a cash top-up to your [loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-) or employees.
* For cash top-ups to self and your loved ones, tax relief is only up to the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS). [Log in with your Singpass](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement) to see how much you can top up to yourself.
* There is a personal income tax relief cap of $80,000, which applies to all tax reliefs, including tax relief on cash top-ups made to your CPF accounts.
* The tax relief cap will be shared for cash top-ups to Special Account (SA)/Retirement Account (RA) and/or cash top-ups to MediSave Account (MA) \*. Find out more about [the amount of√Ç¬†tax relief you can enjoy](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-much-tax-relief-can-i-enjoy).
* If you make cash top-ups to your loved ones, please note that tax relief does not apply to your recipients.
* Your loved ones include parents, parents-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, spouse and siblings.
* If you are making cash top-ups to a spouse or sibling, you will only be eligible for the tax relief if the recipient's income in the previous year does not exceed $4,000 or if the recipient is handicapped^. In this instance, income would include income from bank interest, dividend and pension, investment income/rental income/directorship income. An example of a handicapped person is someone with visual-impairment, loss of hearing, loss of limb and dementia.
* If you are making a cash top-up to the SA/RA of your employee on his behalf, you will be eligible for an equivalent amount of tax deductions for the cash top-ups made. While such a cash top-up will be included in your employee's taxable income, your employee will receive tax relief of up to $8,000 for cash top-ups made in each calendar year. The tax relief that your employee will receive also takes into consideration any cash top-ups that he has made to his own SA/RA and MA.
* If you would like to make a CPF contribution to your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs MA as an employer, please do so under the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme (AMCS) to be eligible for tax deduction on your contribution. AMCS contributions are tax-free for employees.
You can learn more about tax relief [here](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/basics-of-individual-income-tax/tax-reliefs-rebates-and-deductions).
\*The changes related to cash top-ups to MA do not apply to MA contributions made in the capacity of a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MA contributions in the capacity of a SEP, visit the [Self-Employed Scheme page](/member/growing-your-savings/cpf-contributions) for more information on topping up your MA.
^This refers to people who are incapacitated because of physical or mental infirmity.']

question: What are the changes to the tax relief cap for cash top-ups?
answer:
['For cash top-ups made on or after 1 January 2022, you can enjoy annual tax relief of:
* up to $8,000 (previously $7,000) when you top up to your Special/Retirement Account and/or√Ç¬†[MediSave Account](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-your-medisave-savings)\*; and
* an additional tax relief of up to $8,000 (previously $7,000) when you top up your loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô Special/Retirement Account and/or√Ç¬†[MediSave Account](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-your-medisave-savings).
For example, if you top up $6,000 to your Special/Retirement Account and $2,000 to your MediSave Account, you will enjoy $8,000 in tax relief.
As per today, only cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account within the current Full Retirement Sum are eligible for tax relief.
You can find out more on:
* [When will the changes in tax relief cap come into effect?](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/when-will-the-changes-in-tax-relief-cap-come-into-effect-)
* [Why is there a combined tax relief cap for cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account?](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/why-is-there-a-combined-tax-relief-cap-for-cash-top-ups)
* [What are the conditions to qualify for tax relief for your retirement savings top-ups?](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-to-qualify-for-tax-relief-for-your-retir)
\*The changes related to cash top-ups to MediSave Account do not apply to MediSave contributions made in the capacity of a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MediSave contributions in the capacity of a SEP, visit the[Self-Employed Scheme page](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/cpf-contributions/saving-as-a-self-employed-person)for more information on topping up your MediSave Account.']

question: When will the changes in tax relief cap come into effect?
answer:
['The [new tax relief cap](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-changes-to-the-tax-relief-cap-for-cash-top-ups) will apply to cash top-ups made on or after 1 January 2022 to your retirement savings and [MediSave Account](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-your-medisave-savings).
Currently, only cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account up to the current Full Retirement Sum are eligible for tax relief.√Ç¬†The changes related to cash top-ups to MediSave Account do not apply to√Ç¬†MediSave contributions made in the capacity of a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MediSave contributions in the capacity of a SEP, visit the [Self-Employed Scheme page](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/cpf-contributions/saving-as-a-self-employed-person) for more information on topping up your MediSave Account.']

question: Why is there a combined tax relief cap for cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account from 1 January 2022?
answer:
['The [combined tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-changes-to-the-tax-relief-cap-for-cash-top-ups) for cash top-ups to the Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account was introduced for greater consistency across CPF schemes. This allows members to better understand and take action to benefit from these schemes. The tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups made before 1 January 2022 had differed1 for top-ups to retirement savings and top-ups to MediSave Account for√Ç¬†employees.√Ç¬†With this change2, the tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups made on or after 1 January 2022 across both schemes were aligned.
1.√Ç¬†Before 1 January 2022, the tax relief eligibility conditions for cash top-ups differed between both schemes in terms of (i) tax beneficiary [giver for Retirement Sum Topping-Up (RSTU); recipient for Voluntary Contribution to MediSave Account (VCMA)]; and (ii) tax relief cap for top-ups to self/loved ones (capped at $7k/$7k for RSTU, tax relief cap for VC-MA depended on both the Basic Healthcare Sum and the amount of mandatory CPF contributions for the year).
2. The changes related to cash top-ups to MediSave Account do not apply to MediSave contributions made in the capacity of a self-employed person (SEP). If you would like to make MediSave contributions in the capacity of a SEP, visit the√Ç¬†[Self-Employed Scheme page](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/cpf-contributions/saving-as-a-self-employed-person)√Ç¬†for more information on topping up your MediSave Account.']

question: What are the conditions to qualify for tax relief for your retirement savings top-ups?
answer: ['Find out more about [the conditions to qualify for tax relief for your retirement savings top-ups](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).']

question: How much CPF savings can I transfer to myself or my loved ones?
answer:
['The amount of CPF savings you can transfer depends on your age and to whom you are making the CPF transfer.
The tables below show the maximum amount of CPF savings you can transfer to yourself and your loved ones. However, the actual amount of CPF savings you can transfer may also depend on the amount your recipient can receive, based off their available [top-up limit](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-is-the-maximum-amt-of-top-ups-i-can-receive).
**If you are below 55**
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **CPF transfer to** | **Amount of CPF transfer** |
| Self | Any amount of your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to your Special Account (SA) |
| Spouse | Your OA savings after setting aside the current Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)1[Example](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/ComputationOfAmts_CPFTrfrsToSpouse.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 60.7KB) |
| Parents and/or grandparents | Your OA savings after setting aside the current BRS1, provided you can meet the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS) with your OA savings, SA savings, and the net amounts withdrawn for investments and property2. If you do not own a property2, you can transfer your OA savings after setting aside the current FRS with your OA savings, SA savings, and net amounts withdrawn for investments.[Example](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/ComputationOfAmts_CPFTrfrsToParentGrandparent.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 71.6KB) |
| Siblings, parents-in-law and/or grandparents-in-law | Your OA savings after setting aside the current FRS1.[Example](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/ComputationOfAmts_CPFTrfrsToInLawsSiblings.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 60.1KB) |
Find out what are the [current retirement sums](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-).
**If you are 55 and above**
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **CPF transfer to** | **Amount of CPF transfer** |
| Self | Any amount of your CPF savings\* to your RA |
| Spouse | Your CPF savings4√Ç¬†after setting aside your BRS3.[Example](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/ComputationOfAmts_CPFTrfrsToSpouse.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 60.7KB) |
| Parents and/or grandparents | Your CPF savings4√Ç¬†after setting aside your BRS3, if you can meet your FRS with your OA savings, SA savings, RA savings6, net amounts withdrawn for investments, and property2. If you don√¢¬Ä¬ôt have a property2, you can transfer your CPF savings4 after setting aside your FRS3 using your OA savings, SA savings, RA savings6√Ç¬†and net amounts withdrawn for investments.[Example](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/ComputationOfAmts_CPFTrfrsToParentGrandparent.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 71.6KB) |
| Siblings, parents-in-law and/or grandparents-in-law | √¢¬Ä¬ãYour OA savings after setting aside your FRS3.[Example](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/documents/ComputationOfAmts_CPFTrfrsToInLawsSiblings.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 60.1KB) |
Find out what are the [retirement sums applicable to you](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-).
1 Can be set aside using your OA savings, SA savings and net amount withdrawn for investments5.
2 CPF savings used for property, including accrued interest (P+I).
3 Can be set aside using your OA savings, SA savings, RA savings6, and net amount withdrawn for investments5.
4 Your OA savings will be transferred first, followed by your SA savings and then your RA savings, if applicable. You can write to CPF Board to specify the CPF accounts to transfer from. If you use your RA savings for the transfer, you may not have enough savings to meet your FRS. When you make a withdrawal from your OA and SA, a portion of the savings will be used to meet your FRS in the RA.
5 Investments refer to amounts withdrawn for (i) an active investment account under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)-OA, and (ii) investments under the CPFIS-SA and discounted Singtel shares that have not been completely disposed of.
6 RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received) plus retirement withdrawals.
\* Your SA savings will be transferred first, followed by your OA savings.']

question: How does CPF Board guard against premeditated early CPF withdrawals?
answer: ['There are policy safeguards to ensure givers' retirement adequacy before they can make CPF transfers to their loved ones. In addition, we have put in place a set of mechanism to detect potential premature withdrawals. When detected, instead of the recipient (for closure of CPF account upon leaving Singapore permanently) or the recipient's beneficiaries (for deceased cases) receiving the CPF transfers in cash, they will be refunded to the giver√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF account.']

question: What should I know about topping up my retirement savings?
answer:
['Here are the 3 things you need to know about topping up your retirement savings. Tax relief is subject to [terms and conditions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-me-to-enjoy-tax-relief-).
![3 things to know about topping up your retirement savings](/content/dam/web/member/retirement/images/RSTU_illustration_6Apr.png)']

question: What happens if I scan the generated PayNow QR code multiple times?
answer: ['Subsequent or duplicate payments made using the same PayNow QR code will be refunded. To ensure that your cash top-ups are processed successfully, please only scan the PayNow QR code and make payment once. You will need to submit a new application each time you wish to make another top-up.']

question: How can I make cash top-ups to my child√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF retirement savings?
answer:
['Simply indicate your NRIC as the giver of the cash top-up. Please note that givers of [cash top-ups need to be at least 16 years old](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/is-there-any-age-limit-for-making-or-receiving-top-ups-). Next, indicate your child√¢¬Ä¬ôs birth certificate number as the recipient and select the relationship as √¢¬Ä¬úOthers√¢¬Ä¬ù.
Cash top-ups to children will not qualify for tax relief.Find out more about the types of [cash top-ups which can enjoy tax relief.](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/can-i-claim-tax-reliefs-when-i-make-a-cash-top-up-to-my-my-loved)']

question: My child is below 16 years old. How do I transfer his Ordinary Account savings to his Special Account on his behalf?
answer: ['Please complete this [application](https://form.gov.sg/#!/61b8089daa0a700013f5d488) if you are a parent making an application on behalf of your child who is below 16 years old.']

question: What happens to my unused CPF transfers and cash top-ups to my recipient upon my demise or if I close my CPF account upon leaving Singapore?
answer: ['Cash top-ups and CPF transfers will generally be treated as gifts to recipients.√Ç¬†When the recipient passes away or closes his CPF account and withdraws his CPF savings upon√Ç¬†leaving Singapore, any unused cash top-ups or CPF transfers will be paid to his beneficiaries (for deceased members) or the recipient (upon successful withdrawal). This is subject to [safeguards to prevent premature withdrawals](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-does-cpf-board-guard-against-premeditated-early-cpf-withdrawals).']

question: I have received a notification on topping up my and/or my loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô retirement savings. How do I know that this notification is indeed sent by CPF Board?
answer:
['Emails sent by us will end with @cpf.gov.sg or @e.cpf.gov.sg. For SMS, we will only send such messages with the ID √¢¬Ä¬úCPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ù.
Sometimes, we may include links to the CPF website in our notifications. You should always check that the domain of such links end with √¢¬Ä¬ú.gov.sg√¢¬Ä¬ù before clicking on them. If you receive any suspicious calls or digital notifications claiming to be from CPF Board, please report them through our [CPF official hotline](/member/contact-us/call-us) or [Write-to-us](/member/contact-us/write-to-us).
To learn more about how to protect yourself from phishing scams or harmful links, please refer to the below resources:
1. [How to avoid falling prey to phishing scams](/member/faq/general-information---useful-tips/protection-against-scams/how-do-i-avoid-falling-prey-to-phishing-scams)
2. [How to protect yourself from phishing links](/member/infohub/educational-resources/how-to-protect-yourself-from-phishing-links)']

question: Why do I have to log in via Singpass to do a cash top-up?
answer: ['It is a more convenient and secure way to make the cash top-up after logging in via Singpass. After logging in with your Singpass, your personal details (such as NRIC) will be automatically populated in the form. [Find out](https://www.singpass.gov.sg/home/ui/support) how you can get a Singpass account.']

question: I used to be able to make a top-up on behalf of someone else, with them being a giver. I am no longer able to do so as I have to log in with my Singpass. How do I do so now?
answer:
['If you are unable to make a top-up on behalf of someone, you can get the intended applicant to submit the top-up application via Singpass.
As a giver, there are important Terms and Conditions that he or she has to be aware of, and has to acknowledge before making a cash top-up.']

question: I am making a top-up from overseas to myself. How can I set up a Singpass account if I do not have a mobile phone number registered in Singapore?
answer: ['If you wish to set up a Singpass account for your top-up application but do not have a mobile phone number registered in Singapore, you may call the Singpass helpdesk at +65 6335 3533 or email [support@singpass.gov.sg](mailto:support@singpass.gov.sg) for assistance.']

question: I have made a PayNow QR payment but I am not able to see an immediate update to my CPF balance(s). Why is my CPF account balance(s) not updated immediately?
answer: ['Such cases are extremely rare and may arise due to intermittent network connectivity issues beyond CPF Board's control. As a result, the status of your PayNow payment may be delayed, and your CPF account balance(s) may not be updated instantly. Please do not worry as your CPF account balance(s) will be updated within 3-5 working days and you will receive an email notification if you have registered your email address with us. Please check your CPF account balance(s)/E-form status again after 3-5 working days and alert us immediately if your payment is still not updated.']

question: What is the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: ['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme aims to help senior Singaporeans who have yet to reach the current√Ç¬†[Basic Retirement Sum](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-brs-frs-ers-)√Ç¬†save more for their retirement. [Eligible CPF members](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/who-is-eligible)√Ç¬†will receive a matching grant for every dollar of cash-top ups received in their Retirement Account, up to $600 per year.']

question: What are the benefits of the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer:
['Under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme, you will enjoy:
* dollar-for-dollar matching grant for cash top-ups received in your Retirement Account (RA), up to $600 per year
* [interest rates\* up to 6% per annum](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest) on your cash top-ups, allowing you to enjoy higher monthly payouts in retirement
* [tax relief](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/can-i-claim-tax-reliefs-when-i-make-a-cash-top-up-to-my-my-loved)√Ç¬†if you√¢¬Ä¬ôre making the cash top-up to yourself or your loved ones. If you are an employer who√¢¬Ä¬ôs making cash top-ups for your employees, you will also qualify for tax deductions.
For example, if you have $40,000 in your RA when you turn 55 in 2021 and receive a yearly cash top-up of $600 to in your RA for five years, you will receive a total matching grant of $3,000 from the government. Coupled with [interest rates\* of up to 6% per annum](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest), you will accumulate an additional $8,300 in your RA by the time you turn 65, allowing you to enjoy $45 more in CPF monthly payouts for life.
\*Based on the interest rate floor of 4% per annum on Special/Retirement Account.']

question: Who can make cash top-ups to recipients who are eligible to receive the matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: ['Anyone, including yourself, [loved ones](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/who-are-considered-my-loved-ones-), employers or members of the community, can make cash top-ups to eligible members under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.']

question: How do I check if I am eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer:
['You can check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme via:
* Your [Retirement Dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/retirement); or
* The [Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) eligibility checker](/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/matching-grant-for-seniors-who-top-up/matched-retirement-savings-scheme-eligibility-checker) (no login required)']

question: Who is eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer:
['You will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if you√¢¬Ä¬ôre a **Singapore Citizen** and meet the following criteria. Your eligibility is assessed annually.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| √¢¬Ä¬ã**Age** | 55 to 70 (both inclusive)√Ç¬†as of 31st December of the assessment year. |
| √¢¬Ä¬ã**Retirement Account (RA) Savings\*** | √¢¬Ä¬ãLess than $99,400^. |
| √¢¬Ä¬ã**Average Monthly Income** | √¢¬Ä¬ãNot more than $4,000.This covers a majority of senior workers. |
| √¢¬Ä¬ã**Annual Value of Residence** | √¢¬Ä¬ãNot more than $13,000. |
| √¢¬Ä¬ã**Property Ownership** | √¢¬Ä¬ãOwn not more than one property. |
*\* RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any governments grants received), plus retirement withdrawals. If you are turning 55 in the assessment year and your RA has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be assessed instead.*
*^Current Basic Retirement Sum for 2023.*
Learn more on [how to check your eligibility](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/how-do-i-check-if-i-am-eligible).']

question: I am turning 55 later this year. Will I still be eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer:
['Yes, you will still be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme as long as you are 55 in the assessment year and you meet the rest of the [eligibility criteria](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/who-is-eligible).
If you are turning 55 this year and your Retirement Account has not yet been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be assessed instead.']

question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if I am older than 70 years old?
answer:
['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to boost the retirement payouts of older Singaporeans who have not started or are just starting their retirement payouts, by helping them to accumulate more savings. Doing this at a younger age allows top-ups to benefit from compound interest for a longer period and have a bigger impact on their eventual payouts.
Most seniors above 70 would have already started receiving their payouts. The government provides support for them in many other ways. For example, as members of the Pioneer Generation, they enjoy enhanced healthcare support. Seniors who own an HDB flat can tap on the [Lease Buyback Scheme](/member/faq/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/what-is-the-lease-buyback-scheme)√Ç¬†or [Silver Housing Bonus Scheme](/member/faq/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/what-is-the-silver-housing-bonus-scheme) to receive a cash bonus and a stream of retirement income for life. Seniors may also be eligible for the [Silver Support Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/retirement-income/government-support/silver-support-scheme). Seniors who need additional help to manage daily costs of living can also apply for direct financial assistance via [ComCare](https://www.msf.gov.sg/Comcare/).']

question: I am eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year. Will I still be eligible if there are changes to my circumstance during the year?
answer:
['Yes, you will still be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the year even if there are changes to your circumstances (e.g. increase in monthly income), unless you renounce your Singapore citizenship.
There are√Ç¬†[conditions which you need to meet](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/what-conditions-must-i-meet-in-order-to-receive-and-retain-the-matching-grant)√Ç¬†to receive and retain the matching grant.']

question: Why are CPF transfers not eligible for matching grant under Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer:
['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is designed to encourage cash top-ups to older Singaporeans who have yet to meet the current Basic Retirement Sum, to help them accumulate more retirement savings. Thus, only cash top-ups to eligible members will be matched.
Members can make CPF transfers in addition to cash top-ups to further benefit from the CPF interest rates.']

question: How do I make a cash top-up?
answer:
['You can make a cash top-up to your Retirement Account or that of your loved ones via the [CPF website or CPF mobile app](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-do-i-apply-to-make-a-top-up-).
Consider making regular monthly or yearly top-ups by [setting up a GIRO arrangement](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-do-i-make-regular-monthly-or-yearly-top-ups-conveniently-via-giro)√Ç¬†and save the hassle of completing the application form every time you make a top-up.']

question: I√¢¬Ä¬ôm turning 55 later this year. How can I top up if my Retirement Account hasn√¢¬Ä¬ôt been created?
answer: ['If your Retirement Account has not been created, you can top up to your Special Account (SA).√Ç¬†Cash top-ups to√Ç¬†your SA will be considered for matching grants under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.']

question: When will I receive the matching grant?
answer: ['You will receive the matching grant in your Retirement Account at the beginning of the following year.']

question: Can I withdraw the matching grant?
answer: ['In keeping with the objective of the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme, the grants and top-ups are used to boost your retirement savings for more monthly payouts. As such, the matching grants, along with the cash top-ups, cannot be withdrawn in a lump sum and will be paid out to you as part of your monthly payouts in retirement.']

question: What conditions must I meet in order to receive and retain the matching grant?
answer:
['To receive the matching grant, you must:
1. be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the year,
2. have received cash top-ups to your Retirement Account (RA) during the year, and
3. still be a Singapore Citizen when the matching grant is given.
Do note that cash top-ups to the RA are irreversible. Read√Ç¬†more√Ç¬†about the [irreversibility condition](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/can-i-reverse-my-top-up-0).
In an unlikely event where the cash top-up is reversed and the matching grant has been given to you, the√Ç¬†unused√Ç¬†grant and any interest earned on it will be recovered from your CPF account.']

question: How can I check if the matching grant has been credited to me?
answer:
['To find out if your matching grant has been credited, you can check your [Transaction History](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history) by logging in with your Singpass, or check your Transaction History in the CPF mobile App.
[Find out when you will receive the matching grant](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/when-will-i-receive-the-matching-grant).']

question: If I am eligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year, will I be automatically eligible in the following years?
answer: ['Your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is assessed annually. You will be informed at the beginning of the year if you are eligible in that year.']

question: What if I pass away before receiving the matching grant?
answer: ['The matching grant will be credited to your CPF account and paid out to your nominees together with any remaining CPF savings based on your [CPF nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/account-services/providing-for-your-loved-ones/making-a-cpf-nomination).']

question: How does the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme work?
answer:
['We will assess your [eligibility](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/who-is-eligible)√Ç¬†for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme annually and notify you at the beginning of the year if you are eligible. If you are eligible and receive top-ups in your Retirement Account (RA) anytime in the year, you will receive the matching grant in your RA at the beginning of the following year.
Find out [how you can check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/how-do-i-check-if-i-am-eligible).']

question: When will my eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme be assessed and do I need to apply?
answer:
['We will assess your [eligibility](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/who-is-eligible)√Ç¬†for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme annually at the beginning of the year. You do not need to apply as your eligibility is automatically assessed.
We will notify you via e-mail, WhatsApp or post if you are eligible. [You can also check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme√Ç¬†online](/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/matching-grant-for-seniors-who-top-up/matched-retirement-savings-scheme-eligibility-checker).']

question: What do I need to do to receive the matching grant under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer: ['If you are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme this year, simply make a cash top-up to your Retirement Account anytime within the year. The cash top-up can be made by anyone, including yourself, your family, employers or members of the community.']

question: Is there a minimum amount I need to top up to be eligible for the matching grant?
answer: ['There is no minimum amount of cash top-up needed to be eligible for the matching grant. However, you are encouraged to top up at least $600 to benefit from the maximum grant. The larger the top-up amount, the more your savings will grow through compound interest, giving you higher monthly payouts at retirement.']

question: Do I have to top up in a lump sum to be eligible for the matching grant?
answer: ['No, you can make smaller cash top-ups throughout the year to be eligible for the matching grant. The matching grant is based on the total amount of top-ups you have received in the year, up to $600 per year.']

question: Will I still receive the full matching grant of $600 if my retirement savings exceed the current Basic Retirement Sum after topping up?
answer: ['Yes, you will receive the full matching grant of $600 if your total amount of cash top-ups received is at least $600.']

question: How long will the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme last?
answer: ['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme was implemented in 2021 and will last for 5 years for a start.']

question: What is the online application form to make a top-up for myself/my loved ones under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme?
answer:
['The √¢¬Ä¬ú[Cash top-ups and CPF transfers for retirement](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/cash-top-ups-and-cpf-transfers-for-retirement)√¢¬Ä¬ù form allows members to make cash top-ups or CPF transfers to their retirement savings. You can also [check if you or your loved ones are eligible](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/matched-retirement-savings-scheme/how-do-i-check-if-i-am-eligible) for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.
You can make a cash top up by selecting either of the options within the form:
1. Cash top-up via PayNow QR and your top-ups will be processed almost instantly
2. Cash top-up via GIRO to make small and regular monthly top-ups']

question: I have received a notification on topping up my and/or my loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô retirement savings. How do I know that this notification is indeed sent by CPF Board?
answer:
['Emails sent by us will end with @cpf.gov.sg or @e.cpf.gov.sg. For SMS and WhatsApp messages, we will only send such messages with the ID √¢¬Ä¬úCPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ù.
This notifications may contain links to the CPF website. You should always check that the domain of such links end with √¢¬Ä¬ú.gov.sg√¢¬Ä¬ù before clicking on them. Do report any suspicious call or digital notifications spoofing CPF Board via our [CPF official hotline](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/call-us) or [Writetous](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous).
Please refer to the following resources for more information on [how to avoid falling prey to phishing scams](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/general-information---useful-tips/electronic-services/how-do-i-avoid-falling-prey-to-phishing-scams) and [how to protect yourself from phishing links](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/infohub/educational-resources/how-to-protect-yourself-from-phishing-links).']

question: How can I make a voluntary housing refund of the housing amount withdrawn if I am not selling my property?
answer:
['You can refund any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property with the accrued interest. There are two ways to submit your application:
1. [Online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/make-a-voluntary-housing-refund)√Ç¬†by following the steps below: √¢¬Ä¬¢ Read the disclaimer by clicking the checkbox. √¢¬Ä¬¢ Click √¢¬Ä¬úStart√¢¬Ä¬ù√Ç¬†and log in with your Singpass. √¢¬Ä¬¢ Select a payment method √¢¬Ä¬¢ Select a property, enter a refund amount, and click √¢¬Ä¬úNext√¢¬Ä¬ù √¢¬Ä¬¢ Read and accept the declaration by clicking the checkbox and then click √¢¬Ä¬úConfirm√¢¬Ä¬ù √¢¬Ä¬¢ Make the payment
2. Through the CPF Mobile app by following these steps: √¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in to the CPF Mobile app with your Singpass √¢¬Ä¬¢ Select √¢¬Ä¬úServices√¢¬Ä¬ù √¢¬Ä¬¢ Select √¢¬Ä¬úVoluntary Housing Refund√¢¬Ä¬ù and click "Continue" √¢¬Ä¬¢ Select the property, key in a refund amount, and click √¢¬Ä¬úNext√¢¬Ä¬ù √¢¬Ä¬¢ Read and accept the agreement, and click √¢¬Ä¬úNext√¢¬Ä¬ù √¢¬Ä¬¢ Select the payment method √¢¬Ä¬¢ Make the payment If you make the refund by PayNow using the QR code or OCBC PayAnyone, the transaction will be shown in your transaction history immediately after the payment.√Ç¬†If you are unable to submit your application online or through the CPF Mobile app, you can write to us at [cpf.gov.sg/writetous](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) for√Ç¬†assistance.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings for the same property after effecting a voluntary housing refund to my account?
answer: ['You can use your Ordinary Account savings for the same property after effecting a voluntary housing refund to your account so long as you still have an outstanding loan.']

question: Is my voluntary housing refund used to set aside my Retirement Sum if I am 55 and above?
answer:
['If you are 55 and above and have made a voluntary housing refund, the refunded amount will be used to meet your cohort's Full Retirement Sum (FRS).
The FRS helps to meet your retirement needs and ensure that you receive monthly payouts during your retirement. Any refunds that exceed your cohort√¢¬Ä¬ôs FRS in your Retirement Account will remain in your CPF Ordinary and/or Special accounts.
This means that your voluntary housing refund can help meet your retirement needs and provide a steady stream of income during your retirement years.']

question: Do I have to refund the housing grant to my CPF account when I make a voluntary housing refund of the monies withdrawn for my property?
answer:
['When you make a voluntary housing refund, you can refund up to the principal CPF withdrawn towards the property (including the CPF Housing Grant) plus its accrued interest to your CPF account.
Generally, the housing grant will be refunded to your Ordinary Account. If you have received more than $30,000 in housing grants, part of the housing grants may be credited to your Special Account/Retirement Account and MediSave Account. Check your√Ç¬†[Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)√Ç¬†to see the amount that will be credited to your Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account. These savings that are credited to your Special Account/Retirement Account and MediSave Account can then be used for approved purposes under the various CPF approved schemes to help you with your healthcare and retirement needs.']

question: How much voluntary housing refund can I make?
answer:
['You can refund any amount, capped at the full principal amount you have withdrawn for the property with the accrued interest.
You may check the amount that you can refund through your [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership).']

question: I have made a voluntary refund. Do I still need to refund to my CPF account when I sell my property?
answer:
['The√Ç¬†amount that you have to refund upon selling your property depends on how much you have voluntarily refunded:
* If√Ç¬†you have fully refunded all the CPF savings you have withdrawn for your property with accrued interest, you do not need to make any refunds
* If√Ç¬†you have partially refunded the CPF savings you have withdrawn for your property with accrued interest, you will need to refund the balance CPF savings you have used with interest
When a property is sold, the selling price will generally will be used to pay the following in this order:1. Outstanding housing loan
2. Required CPF refund
3. Other sale expenses, e.g., legal fees
If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to make the required CPF refund, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash as long as the property is sold at market value.
However, the option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner√¢¬Ä¬ôs and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.
The refunded amount will be returned to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts in the following proportions:
Amount returned to owner A√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF Account: ![formula for amount to be refunded for owner A](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/VHR%20refund%20for%20owner%20A%20updated%201.jpg)Amount returned to owner B√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF Account: ![formula for amount to be refunded for owner B](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/VHR%20refund%20for%20owner%20B%20updated%201.jpg)']

question: How can I view the status of my voluntary housing refund application?
answer:
['You can check the status of your voluntary housing refund application online via [My Activities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivity). Once your application has been successfully processed, the refunded amount will be credited to your CPF account. You can then view the details in your 15-months Transaction History by logging in to[*my cpf* digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history) or [CPF Mobile app](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/cpf-mobile-app) via your Singpass.√Ç¬†Additionally, you will receive an email notification once your application has been processed.
Please note that the amount refunded will be used to reduce the principal amount withdrawn for your property and its accrued interest.']

question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) comprises the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA). The scheme gives CPF members an option to invest their CPF savings, while meeting the long term objective of financial security in their old age.√Ç¬†**Important Notes:**
Members are advised to exercise prudence when they invest their CPF savings under the CPFIS. No one can guarantee that investments will always be profitable or that investment products included under CPFIS will always earn a profit. The CPF Board does not specifically endorse any product providers or investment products included under the CPFIS. All investments come with risk and you may lose all or a portion of the amount invested.
CPF members have to decide for themselves how to invest their savings and what risks to accept. If members are not confident of investing on their own or do not wish to risk their savings, they can always keep their money with the CPF Board and earn the risk-free interest.']

question: What is the objective of CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['The Central Provident Fund (CPF) offers a comprehensive range of schemes and services. The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) gives you the opportunity to invest your CPF savings in a wide range of investments to enhance your retirement nest egg. Investment objectives and goals differ from person to person. The CPFIS reflects this by making different types of investments available to CPF members. Under the CPFIS, you can invest your CPF savings in shares and loan stocks, unit trusts, government bonds, statutory board bonds, bank deposits, fund management accounts, endowment insurance policies, investment-linked insurance policies, exchange traded funds and gold.
However, the CPF Board does not specifically endorse any product providers or investment products included under the CPFIS. All investments come with risk and you may lose all or a portion of the amount invested. If you are not confident of investing on your own, you may consider leaving your money in your CPF accounts, which earns risk-free interest.']

question: What enhancements relating to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) were announced during the FY2018 Committee of Supply Debate?
answer:
['Second Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo announced the following enhancements to the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS):
1. [Introduction of Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ)](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/SAQ_FAQ.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.6MB)
2. [Removal of sales charge for products offered under CPFIS](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/Sales_charge_FAQ.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.6MB)
3. [Reduction of maximum wrap fee chargeable on CPFIS investments](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/Wrap_fees_FAQ.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.5MB)
Please refer to our [webpage](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/infohub/news/cpf-related-announcements) for more details of the enhancements.']

question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Withdraw My CPFIS Investments Upon Meeting CPF Withdrawal Conditions | Online: within 1 working dayManual: within 3 working days |
| Update Stock / Gold Limits | Within 2 working days |
| Transfer CPFIS Sale Proceeds (Division of CPF-related Matrimonial Assets) | Within 10 working days |']

question: What is risk-return tradeoff?
answer: ['All investments are subject to risk. Risk refers to the possibility that an investment could lose value or not gain any additional value because of swings in the financial markets. ![The risk and return tradeoff of investments](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/images/risk_return_tradeoff.png) All investments have a risk-return tradeoff. Historically, lower-risk investments √¢¬Ä¬î like cash equivalent (e.g., fixed deposit) investments √¢¬Ä¬î have typically offered lower potential for long-term growth and investment return. Higher-risk investments √¢¬Ä¬î like stock investments √¢¬Ä¬î have typically offered greater potential for long-term growth and investment return. By understanding the risk associated with various investment options, you can choose investments that best match your risk tolerance and personal circumstances.']

question: How do I decide how to invest?
answer: ['You need to establish a balance between risk and return that you are comfortable with. When establishing this balance, you should consider all the followings: **Your risk tolerance**√Ç¬†- the amount of risk you are comfortable with and can afford to take. Can you still sleep at night if your investments have temporary short-term losses? Do you have enough savings that you can financially afford to take some investment risk? **Your investment time horizon**√Ç¬†- How long will your assets be invested? Your CPF savings are for the long term. Unless you are close to retirement or have a short-term investment time horizon for other reasons, you should generally invest for the long term, but you need to decide what "long" means to you. **Your overall financial situation** - How much money will you need to sustain your lifestyle during retirement? Do you have other assets set aside for retirement besides your CPF savings? How are all of those assets invested? What are your financial commitments?']

question: How much risk am I willing to take for my investments?
answer: ['As investment objectives and goals differ from person to person, the question of how much "risk" to take is a personal one - no one answer is correct for everyone. Only you can decide what risk/return tradeoff you are comfortable with - but the [Risk Tolerance Questionnaire](/content/dam/web/member/growing-your-savings/documents/Risk_Tolerance_Questionaire.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB) may help you assess your tolerance for risk.']

question: How do I know if I am investing for the short term or long term?
answer: ['The number of years you have to save and invest is called your **"INVESTMENT TIME HORIZON"**√Ç¬†- it is the amount of time between when you invest and when you need to spend the proceeds of your investments. This spending can be for your retirement or for other financial commitments which you need to meet, such as to purchase a house or to pay for your children's education expenses.']

question: How does diversification helps to limit my risk in investing?
answer:
['Diversification, or spreading your assets among several investments, helps you smooth out potential ups and downs of your investment returns. Even if one investment does poorly, the others may do better, thereby potentially improving your overall return. You can diversify your investments at two distinct levels by spreading your investments among:
* different asset classes √¢¬Ä¬î cash equivalents (e.g., fixed deposits),bonds and stocks and/or
* different markets √¢¬Ä¬î geographic regions, foreign countries, foreign currencies, industries and companies.']

question: Should I maintain a consistent strategy in investing?
answer:
['Once you have decided on the right investment mix to meet your investment objectives and goals, you should try to maintain a consistent strategy. In general, you should only change your strategy if your personal circumstances have changed. As tempting as it may be to "bail out" if your investments take a dive, financial experts generally suggest that you stay fully invested. If you try to "time the market" you run the risk of getting caught in the trap of "buying high" and "selling low." If you hold on to your investment, chances are good that its value may eventually go back up, and that it may end up being worth more than when its value dropped.
![As illustrated in this chart, John lost money on his investment because he sold it at a loss. Kim, on the other hand, made a gain because she decided to hold out and not panic when the stock market took a tumble.](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/images/Investment.png)']

question: Who is eligible to participate in the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['All CPF members who
* are at least 18 years old;
* are not undischarged bankrupts; and
* have more than $20,000 in their Ordinary Account (for investment under CPFIS-Ordinary Account) and/or√Ç¬†have more than $40,000 in their Special Account (for investment under CPFIS-Special Account).
From 1 October 2018, as a new CPFIS investor, you will need to take the [Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/CPFISSelfAwarenessQuestionnaire/Declaration) before you can start investing under CPFIS.']

question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ)?
answer:
['The CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)√Ç¬†[Self-Awareness Questionnaire](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/CPFISSelfAwarenessQuestionnaire/Declaration) (SAQ) helps you assess if you have basic financial knowledge and whether CPFIS is suitable for you. The SAQ starts with learning modules on investment concepts, products and charges under CPFIS. You will then log in with your Singpass to attempt a quiz.
From 1 October 2018, if you are a new CPFIS investor, you will need to take the SAQ before you can start investing under CPFIS. Agent banks and product providers will require you to declare your SAQ status and/or ask to view a copy of your SAQ status for verification. You can participate in the CPFIS once you have taken the SAQ, regardless of your SAQ results. You can√Ç¬†[check your SAQ status](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/CpfisSelfAwarenessQuestionnaire/StatusMain/)√Ç¬†via my cpf digital services.
If you already have a CPFIS account, while you are not required to take the SAQ, you are still strongly encouraged to do so.']

question: Which of my CPF accounts can I use to participate under CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) or CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA)?
answer: ['You can only use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings for investments under CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA), and your Special Account (SA) savings for investments under CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA). The instruments available for investments under CPFIS-OA and CPFIS-SA are different. You may not combine savings from your OA and SA to buy a product. However, you can transfer funds from your OA to your SA\* to invest under CPFIS-SA. Such transfers are irreversible. The total savings in the SA including the amount withdrawn under CPFIS-SA cannot exceed the current full retirement sum after the transfer.√Ç¬†\* Applicable only to members below age 55.']

question: What is the difference between the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA)?
answer:
['Under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA), investments may only be made using Ordinary Account savings while under CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA), investments may only be made using Special Account savings. The instruments available for investments under CPFIS-OA and CPFIS-SA are different.
To find out how much CPF savings you can invest and what instruments you can invest in, you can refer√Ç¬†to the [list of instruments available for investment under the CPFIS](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_InstrumentsunderCPFIS.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB).']

question: How do I check how much CPF I can invest?
answer:
['To check how much you can invest, you can view your CPF Statement by:* logging in to [*my cpf*√Ç¬†digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment)√Ç¬†with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment
* accessing the '*CPF Mobile'*√Ç¬†app√Ç¬†with your Singpass, or
* visiting any [CPF Service Centres](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/visit-us) personally with your identity card.
Your stock and gold limits will be updated on the 11th of every month, based on your previous month-end balances. The limits will be updated on the 12th, if the 10th is a Sunday/Public Holiday. If you would like to know your limits based on your current balances, please contact the Board for an ad-hoc update of your limits. Please only proceed to invest after receiving our confirmation on the updated limits, which will be sent within two working days from the date of your request. For further details, please refer to this [example](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexB.pdf) (PDF, 66KB). Note: Before you commit to an investment, you should consider the other transactions that may affect your Ordinary Account and Special Account balances (e.g. outstanding investment transactions, monthly housing instalments, lump-sum housing payments, etc) as they could change your amount available for investment. Should you invest beyond your current limits, you will not be able to use your CPF monies to settle your trade. You may then have to settle the trade using cash and incur additional transaction fees.']

question: Whom should I approach to buy or sell my investments under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['You may approach the following Service/Product Providers to buy or sell your investments:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Instruments** | **Service/Product Providers** |
| Fixed Deposits | Deposits Banks |
| Singapore Government Bonds | Bond Dealers or Brokers |
| Singapore Government Treasury Bills | Bond Dealers |
| Statutory Board Bonds | Bond Dealers or Brokers |
| Bonds Guaranteed by Singapore Government | Brokers |
| Annuities Endowment Insurance Policies Investment - Linked Insurance Products | Insurance Companies |
| Unit Trusts | Fund Management Companies Investment Administrators |
| Fund Management Accounts | Fund Management Companies |
| Shares Property Funds Corporate Bonds Exchange Traded Funds | Brokers |
| Gold√¢¬Ä¬¢Gold ETFs √¢¬Ä¬¢Other Gold products | √¢¬Ä¬¢For Gold ETFs: Brokers√¢¬Ä¬¢For other Gold products: - Sell through your Agent Bank - Buy through UOB Agent Bank and you need a UOB investment account. |
For more information on the various investment products, you may approach the [product providers](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexC.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) included under CPFIS or the [broking firms](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/SDS_AnnexESGXBrokingFirmsforRetailClients.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 51KB).']

question: What is the role of agent banks under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
answer: ['The agent banks are appointed to maintain members' CPF Investment Accounts under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) as they have an extensive network of branches and facilities to support the investment and settlement of shares and bonds listed on the Singapore Exchange. The agent banks' electronic banking services such as ATMs are easily accessible and allow members to conveniently apply for shares or bonds during an IPO. The banks are also able to handle the complex processing of corporate actions such as bonus and rights issues, dividend payments and schemes of arrangement under the CPFIS-OA.']

question: Can I participate in the CPF Investment Scheme while I am overseas?
answer: ['You can participate in the CPF Investment Scheme while you are overseas. However, there are some investments which would require you to be personally present. You may have to authorise someone to act on your behalf by way of a Power of Attorney if you are not able to handle the transactions yourself.']

question: Do I have to incur any charges for CPF Investment Scheme investments?
answer: ['You will√Ç¬†incur charges which are payable from your CPF savings. Please refer to the [list of typical charges](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexD.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.2MB) that may be incurred√Ç¬†when you invest your CPF in various instruments.']

question: Can I continue to use my CPF monies to pay for the quarterly bank charges even if I do not have $20,000 in my Ordinary Account?
answer: ['You can use your Ordinary Account balance to pay for the quarterly agent banks charges, even if your Ordinary Account balance is below $20,000. The restriction on the use of the first $20,000 in Ordinary Account for CPF Investment Scheme √¢¬Ä¬ì Ordinary Account only applies to new investments, including payments for recurring single premiums (for insurance) and regular savings plans (for unit trusts).']

question: Can I top-up my CPF Investment Account under CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account with cash if I do not have sufficient CPF savings for investment?
answer: ['Cash top-ups are not allowed, except in the case of taking up entitlements (e.g. rights shares) or conversion of entitlements. You may top-up your CPF Investment Account through your agent bank if you have insufficient CPF savings or stock limit to subscribe for the entitlements or conversion. However, such cash top-ups are not withdrawable or refundable, even if your applications are unsuccessful.']

question: How do I use my CPF to apply for shares, property funds or corporate bonds offered during an Initial Public Offering (IPO) under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
answer:
['You may apply for the IPO in any of the available ways.
1. Use your agent bank's ATMs for your application;
2. Use your agent bank's internet banking for your application; or
3. Obtain a CPF cashier's order from your agent bank's counter and attach it to your IPO application form.
The amount of CPF needed will be transferred automatically from your Ordinary Account to your CPF Investment Account.']

question: Can I engage in contra trading under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['CPF savings cannot be used for contra trading as it may encourage speculative trading, and investors bear a higher risk of losing their monies. Hence, it is not suitable for long term investment and for retirement planning.']

question: Can I invest in shares listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) as long as they meet the inclusion criteria under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer: ['The Board welcomes the inclusion of shares listed on the SGX Mainboard as long as they meet the inclusion criteria. However, some companies who meet the inclusion criteria have not applied to be included under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), and CPF savings cannot be used for these shares. You can refer to√Ç¬†[SGX website](https://www.sgx.com/securities/stocks-under-cpf-investment-scheme)√Ç¬†for the list of shares included under the CPFIS.']

question: Can I purchase a regular premium insurance policy under CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['With effect from 1 January 2001, CPF savings cannot be used for new regular premium insurance policies. Only Single Premium or Recurring Single Premium insurance policy is allowed under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account.']

question: Can I continue to use my Ordinary Account savings to service my regular premium insurance bought before 1 January 2001, even if my balance falls below $20,000?
answer: ['You can continue to service the future premiums using your Ordinary Account savings, even if your balance falls below $20,000. This applies to you even after age 55 as long as you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum or the Basic Retirement Sum with sufficient property charge/pledge in the Retirement Account.']

question: How will the restriction on investments for the first $20,000 in Ordinary Account and the first $40,000 in Special Account affect me?
answer: ['The first $60,000 of your combined CPF accounts earns an extra 1% interest. To enable members to earn extra interest, only monies in excess of $20,000 in your Ordinary Account (OA) and $40,000 in your Special Account (SA) can be invested. However, you can continue to service your agent bank fees and regular premium insurance policies (excludes recurring single premium insurance policies or regular savings plans for unit trusts) even if your OA balance falls below $20,000. If you have already made investments using your OA or SA balances, you are not required to sell these investments.']

question: What are the options available to me if I foresee that I do not have sufficient CPF to continue paying the instalments on my regular premium insurance policy?
If I have an existing regular premium insurance policy bought using cash, can I continue to service the future premiums using CPF under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
answer: ['With effect from 1 January 2001, CPF savings cannot be used for new regular premium insurance policies, regardless of whether the policies are converted from cash or newly bought from insurance companies.']

question: If I have terminated my insurance policy bought using CPF, can I reinstate the policy and pay the outstanding premiums and future premiums using CPF?
answer: ['You need to liaise with your insurance company on the reinstatement of the policy. Upon reinstatement, you may pay the outstanding and future premiums using CPF. However, no CPF can be used to pay any outstanding interest owing to the insurance company.']

question: Can I invest in Fixed Deposit in foreign currency under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['Foreign currency Fixed Deposits are not included under the CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: Is there a minimum interest rate for CPF Investment Scheme Fixed Deposit (FD) that FD Banks must offer?
answer: ['With effect from 1 May 2007, Fixed Deposit (FD) Banks must offer a minimum effective interest rate that is at least the prevailing CPF interest rate for new placements or roll over of any CPF Investment Scheme FDs. In this way, members will not be worse off than leaving their monies in the CPF Accounts.']

question: I have forgotten my CPF Investment Account Number. How can I go about checking this?
Can I transfer my CPF Investment Account under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account from one agent bank to another? If so, must I sell my investments first?
answer: ['You may transfer your CPF Investment Account from one agent bank to another. You need not sell your investments, except for your investment in gold bought from your agent bank (excluding gold Exchange Traded Funds). All your investments and cash balances will be transferred along with your CPF Investment Account. To transfer your CPF Investment Account, you need to apply at the bank which you intend to transfer your account to.']

question: How do I close my CPF Investment Account under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account?
answer: ['You will have to sell all your investments first before instructing your agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account.']

question: If there are adjustments under CPF Investment Scheme in my Ordinary or Special Account, what interest rate will be used?
answer: ['Any adjustments under the CPF Investment Scheme in your Ordinary or Special Account will be based on the CPF interest rates for the respective account. The interest rate will not include the extra 1% interest that is paid on the first $60,000 of your combined balances.']

question: Can I accept gifts and/or rebates from my service providers when investing under CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['All gifts and/or rebates arising from investing under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) must be converted to cash and refunded back to your CPF Ordinary and Special Accounts respectively. You are not allowed to receive gifts and/or rebates direct from your service provider as this will result in a leakage of CPF funds.
