Alternatively, you may also receive rebates in the form of additional units of investments under the CPFIS.']

question: What is Wrap fee?
answer:
['Wrap fee is an ongoing fee charged by a financial adviser to an investor, for providing bundled investment services, including advisory, brokerage and administrative. The fee is usually charged as a percentage on the market value of asset under management of the financial adviser.
Wrap fee is consumptive and erodes returns on investment funds. As CPF monies are meant for retirement and to prevent our members from paying excessive wrap fees, CPF Board has capped wrap fees at 0.4% per annum with effect from 1 October 2020. This is in line with the Board's continuing efforts to lower the cost of investment for our members.']

question: What should I do if my wrap account currently charges me a wrap fee of more than 0.4% per annum?
answer: ['With effect from 1 October 2020, your wrap fee payable will be capped at 0.4% per annum. You should contact your financial adviser or Investment Administrators if you continue to pay more than the capped rate after 1 October 2020.']

question: What type of investor will be affected by the wrap fee cap?
answer: ['The wrap fee cap will affect CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investors who have wrap accounts with any of the 4 CPFIS-included Investment Administrators.']

question: How will this wrap fee cap affect my investments?
answer: ['Wrap fee is typically paid by redemption of units in your CPF-funded unit trust investment. With effect from 1 October 2020, you should not be paying more than 0.4% per annum in wrap fee from your CPF-funded investment.']

question: How do I attend (and vote at) a Company's Annual/Extraordinary General Meetings (AGMs/EGMs) as a CPF investor?
answer:
['CPF investors should refer to the company announcements on SGXNet (or Company website) for instructions on attending AGMs/EGMs.
**Special Arrangements due to Covid-19 Measures**Companies would not be able to proceed with physical general meetings during the Circuit Breaker period due to the Safe Distancing measures in place. Companies that hold AGMs/EGMs during this period may have special arrangements (e.g. √¢¬Ä¬úlive√¢¬Ä¬ù webcast). CPF investors who wish to participate in these meetings and/or vote on meeting resolutions should take note of the following: **Attendance**CPF investors should refer to the company announcements on SGXNet (or Company website) for instructions on how to attend the virtual meeting. CPF investors should take note of the pre-registration deadlines (including the submission of questions to the Company which will be addressed publicly before or during the virtual meeting). **Voting**Since CPF investors cannot physically attend general meetings to vote, they can instead vote through their respective CPF Agent Banks. CPF investors must submit their voting instructions to their agent banks at least seven working days before the general meeting. CPF investors should contact their respective Agent Banks (DBS, OCBC, UOB) to find out more about how to submit their voting instruction(s).']

question: How do I transfer the cash balance from my CPF Investment Account to my Ordinary Account (OA)?
answer: ['You can do the transfer via your agent bank's ATMs, internet/phone banking or over the counter. Please note that if your CPF Investment Account has been inactive (i.e. no investment transactions) for two consecutive months, your agent bank will automatically transfer the cash balance to your Ordinary Account (OA) by month end\*. Likewise, if you have been unsuccessful in your Initial Public Offering (IPO) application, your agent bank will automatically transfer the unused CPF monies to your OA by month end\*. \* The monies will be transferred on the third last working day of the month. In the event that the third last working day falls on a Saturday, the transfer will take place on the second last working day of the month.']

question: I have transferred money from Investment Account back into my CPF Ordinary Account. When does the CPF interest computation start?
answer: ['When you transfer money from your Investment Account to your Ordinary Account, you will start to earn CPF interest on the transferred amount from the following month onwards.']

question: Do I need to pay accrued interest if I used my CPF savings for CPF investments?
answer: ['You do not need to pay back the accrued interest on√Ç¬†the CPF savings used for your CPF investments.']

question: Will my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments be sold or liquidated when I apply to withdraw my CPFIS investments upon meeting CPF withdrawal conditions?
answer: ['Applying to withdraw your CPFIS investments will not result in liquidation of your investment holdings. If your withdrawal application is approved, your agent bank and/or√Ç¬†product providers will contact you on the transfer of your investments to you.']

question: How do I transfer my shares, bought under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), to my Central Depository (CDP) account?
answer:
['You may apply to close your CPF Investment Account and transfer your shares to your own CDP account after you have reached 55 years old and have set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS)√Ç¬†in the Retirement Account (RA). The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property.
Please refer to this [FAQ](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-happens-to-my-cpf-savings-when-i-turn-55) for more information on how the retirement sum is set aside at age 55.√Ç¬†To apply for closure of CPF Investment Account, please√Ç¬†submit an [e-application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/InvestmentWithdrawal/Declaration) to√Ç¬†us.']

question: Can I continue to invest under the CPF Investment Schemes beyond age 55?
answer:
['You can continue to invest even after age 55, as long as you have set aside√Ç¬†your Full Retirement Sum (FRS)√Ç¬†in the Retirement Account. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property.√Ç¬†In addition, you will not be able to invest the first $20,000 in your Ordinary Account and the first $40,000 in your Special Account. Please also note that the [stock and gold limits](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexB.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) applicable to you may change.
Please refer to this [FAQ](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-happens-to-my-cpf-savings-when-i-turn-55) for more information on how the retirement sum is set aside at age 55. To check your available CPF amount for investment, you can:
* login into [*my cpf* digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment)√Ç¬†with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment,
* access the '*CPF Mobile*' app with your Singpass, or
* visit any [CPF Service Centres](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us) personally with your identity card.']

question: What will happen to my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments if I leave Singapore permanently and withdraw all my CPF monies?
answer:
['.For CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA), we will inform the agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account. The agent bank will contact you for the withdrawal of your investments and cash balance (if any) in your CPF Investment Account. Your investments will be transferred\* to your own name and you may thereafter continue servicing your investments using cash or liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.
*\* Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (√¢¬Ä¬úCDP√¢¬Ä¬ù) imposes a transfer fee of $10.00 (excluding GST) for every share counter transferred from your CPF Investment Account to your CDP Account.*
For CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA), we will inform your product provider(s) to transfer your investments to your own name and you may thereafter liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.
Once withdrawn, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.']

question: How can I find out my own profit/loss on CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['You may refer to the portfolio statement sent to you by your agent bank or your product provider. If you have sold your investments, the difference between the cost and sale proceeds is your profit/loss. If you have not sold your investments, the difference between the cost and market value is your profit/loss.']

question: What happens if I make a loss on my investments? Do I have to make good the loss?
answer: ['You need not make good your investment loss. However losses will reduce your retirement nest egg.']

question: Can I withdraw my investment profits?
answer: ['Profits made from investments under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account and/or CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account are not withdrawable as the purpose of investing is to grow your savings for retirement. However, the profits can be used for other CPF schemes, subject to the terms and conditions of these schemes.']

question: Are my investment profits, interest earned from investments and dividends received taxable?
answer: ['Your investment profits, interest earned from investments and dividends are not taxable under the CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: What does the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Total Profits/Losses statistic measure?
answer: ['The CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)√Ç¬†Total Profits/Losses statistic provides a complete representation of the investors√¢¬Ä¬ô total portfolio performance. It takes into account not only the realised profits or losses of investments that were sold, but also the unrealised profits or losses of investments that members held during the reporting period.']

question: How is members' investment performance in the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
answer: ['Please refer to the [CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)√Ç¬†Profits/Losses Report](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/CPFIS_OA_PL_Report.pdf)√Ç¬†if you wish to view members' investment performance in the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA).']

question: Where can I find a copy of the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) Profits/Losses Report?
answer: ['Please refer to the√Ç¬†[CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)√Ç¬†Profits/Losses Report](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/CPFIS_OA_PL_Report.pdf).']

question: What constitutes "offences" under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['Manipulating investment transactions so that a member may siphon his CPF savings in cash thereby withdrawing the savings prematurely, is an offence under CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: How are manipulative investment transactions detected?
answer: ['CPF Board continually monitors the trend of various CPF Investment Scheme transactions. The Singapore Exchange also monitors irregularities in share transactions. Transactions that look suspicious are referred to the Commercial Affairs Department for investigation.']

question: What will CPF Board do with members or third parties who are found to have conducted manipulative transactions?
answer: ['Under the law, CPF Board is empowered to recover CPF savings that is siphoned or withdrawn prematurely under such circumstances, with interest. The member could also be prohibited from making further withdrawals for a period of one year or more as the Board may determine, from the date of the contravention or from the date of the making of any false representations or furnishing of false information. The Board takes a serious view on any attempts to siphon CPF savings prematurely and will not hesitate to take legal action against CPF members and intermediaries or other parties who collaborate to do this. Third parties will be charged under the Penal Code.']

question: Will I be charged if my friend conducts manipulative share trading using my CPF and trading accounts (given by me previously) without my knowing?
answer: ['This will depend on the outcome of investigations. However, you should always protect your password and not allow other people to transact in your name without your knowledge or your approval.']

question: Will I run the risk of unknowingly breaching CPF laws while trading or investing under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['As long as your intention is to invest for the medium to long term, and you did not siphon out any CPF savings by receiving cash for your investment transactions whether through manipulated transaction prices or cash rebates, it is unlikely that you will breach the CPF laws for manipulative transactions.']

question: What will happen to my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme investments if I did not open a CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account in time for the transfer?
answer: ['As indicated in the National University of Singapore (NUS) letter to you, if you did not open a CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account by 27 December 2007, NUS is unable to transfer your Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme √¢¬Ä¬ì Ordinary Account (ASPFAIS-OA) investment holdings and Part V insurance policies. As the Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) scheme has closed down, your ASPFAIS Investment Account has been frozen and you will no longer be able to use your ASPF monies to transact under the ASPFAIS and service the premiums of your insurance policies bought under the ASPF Part V Scheme. You can still open a CPFIS Investment Account at any agent bank i.e. DBS, OCBC and UOB, and instruct NUS to transfer your ASPFAIS investments and Part V insurance policies to your newly-opened CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Investment Account **after 1 January 2008**. However, this transfer will be effected only on a monthly basis and any payments to be made in the meantime, including insurance premiums, would have to be paid in cash. For your investments bought under Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme √¢¬Ä¬ì Special Account (ASPFAIS-SA), NUS would have transferred them over to CPF Investment-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) as long as you have a CPF Account. No CPFIS Investment Account is needed for the transfer of investment holdings under the SA.']

question: Will I receive any notifications after the transfer of my investments from my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme to CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['You will receive a letter from your agent bank, informing you of the details of the investments being transferred from your Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Investment Account to your CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) Investment Account. You will also receive a letter from National University of Singapore after the transfer. You can also view your Special Account (SA) investment holdings (combination of ASPFAIS-SA and CPFIS-SA) in your SA portfolio statement anytime using your Singpass via *my cpf* Online Services at [www.cpf.gov.sg](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/).']

question: After the merger of Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) and CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), will the transfer be reflected in any of my CPFIS statements?
answer: ['The transfer will be reflected through the change to **the net amount withdrawn**. Your net amount withdrawn under the Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (ASPFAIS-OA) will be merged with your net amount withdrawn under the CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA). A footnote will be permanently shown in your "CPFIS Stock & Gold Limits Computation" statement, informing you of the amount transferred from your ASPFAIS-OA. For your investments made under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme -Special Account (ASPFAIS-SA), they will be transferred to your CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA). You are able to view your combined investment holdings in your SA portfolio statement.']

question: What will happen to my stock & gold investment limits arising from the merger of Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme and CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['Your Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme stock & gold investment limits will be merged with your CPF Investment Scheme stock & gold investment limits.']

question: Arising from the merger of Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme and CPF Investment Scheme, do I need to inform my broker or any of the product providers of my new CPF Investment Account number?
answer: ['Your agent bank will inform the respective product providers, except stockbrokers, of your new Investment Account number. Agent banks would not be able to inform the stockbrokers on your behalf because agent banks do not know which stockbrokers you have trading accounts with. You will need to inform all your stockbrokers about your new CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account number. If your stockbrokers use the outdated investment account number, your CPF trades will fail and you will need to settle your trades using cash.']

question: After the transfer of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme investments to CPF Investment Scheme, what will happen to the sale proceeds if I subsequently sell those investments?
answer: ['All the sale proceeds will be refunded to your CPF Accounts. You can subsequently withdraw the monies subject to CPF withdrawal rules.']

question: Will all my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V Insurance Policies be transferred to CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['All your Part V insurance policies will be transferred to your CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account with the agent bank.']

question: Why do I need to open a CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account now to 'hold' my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Investment?
answer: ['The Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) Part V Scheme does not fall under the purview of the ASPF Investment Scheme. Under the ASPF Part V Scheme, the policies were bought under the name of National University Singapore (NUS). NUS had been paying the premiums directly to the insurance companies, after deducting the monies from members' ASPF Ordinary Accounts, without going through the agent banks. As the CPF Board does not have such a scheme, Part V insurance policies have to be transferred to the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) instead. Under the CPFIS-OA, you need to have a CPFIS Investment Account to hold your investments, including the transferred Part V insurance policies.']

question: Can I use my CPF monies to service the premiums of my Part V Insurance Policy under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS)?
answer: ['You can use your CPF monies in your Ordinary Account to service the future premiums of your policies (including endowment, whole life or rider policies, and regular premium policies).']

question: Can I increase or decrease the premiums to be paid for my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policies?
answer: ['Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) members are not allowed to make any changes to their Part V insurance policies that will cause an **increase** in premiums with effect from 28 December 2006 (i.e. the date that National University Singapore issued the official √¢¬Ä¬úDissolution Notice√¢¬Ä¬ù to all its members). However, if the increase in premiums is due to attained age at renewal of the policies1, or conversion of the policies2, you can use your CPF monies to pay the higher premium. ASPF members can make any changes to their Part V insurance policies that will result in a **decrease** in premiums, as long as the insurance companies allow it. 1When a member exceeds a certain age, he may have to pay a higher premium to renew his insurance policy. In such an instance, he can continue to use his CPF monies to pay the higher premiums. 2A member√¢¬Ä¬ôs insurance policy contract may allow him to convert: (1) a rider to a new whole life policy, endowment policy or investment-linked insurance product (ILP); or (2) a whole life policy to an endowment policy or vice versa.']

question: Can I take a policy loan on my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy?
answer: ['Policy loans are not allowed for Part V insurance policies under the CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: Can I pledge my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy?
answer: ['Pledging of Part V insurance policies is not allowed under the CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: Can my insurance policy continue to run on Automatic Premium Loan (APL) and/or Extended Term Insurance (ETI) after the transfer to CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['Automatic Premium Loan and Extended Term Insurance are allowed to continue after the transfer of your Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy to CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: How may I repay the Automatic Premium Loan (APL) of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy?
answer: ['You may repay the Automatic Premium Loan (APL) by paying cash to the insurance company directly. The cash balance in your CPF Investment Scheme Investment Account cannot be used to repay the APL.']

question: Can I change the life insured under my Part V insurance policy under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS)?
answer: ['The life insured must be the CPF member whose CPF savings are used to pay premiums.']

question: Can I nominate beneficiaries to the proceeds of my Part V insurance policy under Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS)?
answer:
['You may nominate beneficiaries as long as: 1. No legal or equitable trust, including but not limited to statutory trusts under any written law, is created over the Part V insurance policy; and
2. Your insurer allows you to do so.']

question: What is a Unit Trust (UT)?
answer: ['Under the CPF Investment Scheme, you can invest in various Unit Trusts (UTs). A UT is an investment fund managed by a professional investment manager. It consists of investments in one or more of the three basic asset classes √¢¬Ä¬î cash, bonds and stocks. The combination of assets for each UT is determined by the investment objective of the particular UT. For information on the investment objectives of the various UTs, please contact the relevant investment managers. They will be able to provide you with the prospectus and fact sheet for the UT.√Ç¬†Alternatively, you may visit the [Fund Singapore](https://www.fundsingapore.com/) website, which provides comprehensive information about UTs (and investment-linked life insurance products) available in Singapore. UTs offer investors a cost-efficient way to diversify or spread their investments. As the savings of individual investors are pooled into a UT, the UT can buy a greater variety of investments than is possible for an individual investor, thus making greater diversification possible. UTs may also allow you to access markets and investments which you may not be able to access through direct personal investment.']

question: What is an Investment-Linked Insurance Policy (ILP)?
answer: ['Under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), you can invest in various Investment-Linked Insurance Policies (ILPs). An ILP is made up of an insurance component coupled with an investment fund managed by a professional fund manager. Insurers usually set up two or more sub-funds for each ILP with differing investment objectives to suit the risk appetite of different types of policyholders. These underlying ILP sub-funds are similar to unit trusts. The allocation of premiums across these sub-funds may be fixed by the insurer or decided by the policyholder, depending on the structure of the ILP. The advantage of an ILP is that it effectively combines investments in a unit trust with purchase of insurance coverage. This is also its disadvantage. An investor might prefer a more flexible combination of insurance coverage and unit trust investment that is not offered by any of the ILPs included under the CPFIS.']

question: How will I know whether I am ready to invest?
answer: ['Once you have an understanding of the amount of risk you are comfortable with and of your investment time horizon, you are ready to make some investment decisions. The CPF Board has classified unit trusts, Investment-Linked Insurance Policies (ILPs) and Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) permitted under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) into the Risk Classification System. There is a wide range of investments available under the CPFIS to help you achieve your investment objectives and goals. The Risk Classification System is intended to help you determine which of these may be most appropriate for your investment circumstances.']

question: What are the CPF schemes that contribute towards asset enhancement?
answer: ['The CPF Investment Scheme and the Special Discounted Shares Scheme contribute towards asset enhancement.√Ç¬†You can refer to the [Frequently Asked Questions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/cpf-investment-schemes) for more details on the schemes.']

question: What are the criteria for inclusion of Shares under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['In considering the inclusion of shares under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), the Board uses the following criteria:
1. The shares are offered by a company that is incorporated in Singapore;
2. The shares are listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Mainboard as primary listing; (The shares are not new Catalist shares or shares transferred from SGX Main Board to Catalist except for former SESDAQ shares. Please√Ç¬†refer to the [FAQs on√Ç¬†Transformation of SESDAQ to Catalist](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/FAQsonTransformationofSESDAQtoCatalist.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB)√Ç¬†for details.)
3. The shares are traded in Singapore Dollars;
4. The company allows Agent Banks to appoint all CPF shareholders of the company as proxies to attend and vote at meetings; and
5. The shares are not placed in the SGX watch-list.
You can refer to the [SGX website](https://www.sgx.com/securities/stocks-under-cpf-investment-scheme)√Ç¬†for the list of shares included under the CPFIS.']

question: What are the criteria for inclusion of Property Fund under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
What are the criteria for inclusion of Corporate Bonds under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
What are the criteria for inclusion of Fixed Deposit Banks under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['In considering the inclusion of Fixed Deposit Banks under CPF Investment Scheme, the Board uses the following criteria: 1. The bank must be locally incorporated with minimum capital funds of S$1.5 billion and good credit rating; or
2. The bank must be a subsidiary of a locally-incorporated bank which meets the criteria at (i). The bank must continue to be a subsidiary of the locally-incorporated bank; or
3. If the bank is a foreign bank, it must be accorded the Qualifying Full Bank privileges']

question: What are the criteria for inclusion as an Investment Administrator under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
Why is there revised criteria for new funds under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer: ['Currently, new funds applying for admission under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) are evaluated based on a number of factors such as the capability of the fund managers, the investment philosophy of the fund, its key decision makers, the appropriateness and quality of its research and analysis, its portfolio construction and implementation, and its past performance. While this screening mechanism has helped to ensure a minimum standard for the funds under the CPFIS, more stringent criteria have been introduced so that funds under the CPFIS would better meet the objectives of CPFIS, which is to help members invest for the long-term for financial security in old age. In addition to setting a higher evaluation benchmark based on the current screening mechanism, the Board will also consider the funds' expense ratio. The latter will help lower the investment cost for members over the longer term. Funds submitted for admission under the CPFIS should also preferably have a performance track record of at least 3 years as this will allow the Board to better assess whether the funds are able to give consistently good performance against the benchmark.']

question: What are the reasons for the Board selecting these new criteria for new funds which wants to be included under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer: ['The new criteria cover issues that the Board is most concerned with, such as quality, consistency of performance relative to peer group and investment costs.']

question: What proportion of funds applying for admission into CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) has been successful? What is the target under the revised criteria?
answer: ['Fund managers would generally assess the quality of their funds using the published CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) evaluation criteria before applying for inclusion under CPFIS. Thus far, funds within the top 50 percentile in their global peer group1 have been successful in their application for admission into CPFIS, and the majority of funds that have applied for admission into CPFIS have been admitted. New funds will need to meet a higher criterion - i.e. they must be among the top 25 percentile of funds. Going forward, we do not expect a significant change in the success rate of application as managers would continue to assess the quality of their funds against the CPFIS evaluation criteria before application. 1This refers to comparison of funds of similar asset class/strategy on a world-wide basis.']

question: Will the funds that have already submitted their applications for inclusion under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) be affected by the revised criteria?
answer: ['The revised criteria will only apply to fund applications received by the Board from 1 February 2006 onwards.']

question: What is an expense ratio?
answer: ['The expense ratio refers to the ongoing costs of operating a fund by fund managers/insurers expressed as a percentage of the fund's average net assets. Operating costs include investment management fees, trustee fees, and audit fees, etc.']

question: What are the new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
answer:
['The new Total Expense Ratio1 (TER) caps are as follows:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Risk Categories** | **New TER Caps (%)** |
| Higher Risk | 1.75 |
| Medium to High Risk | 1.55 |
| Low to Medium Risk | 0.95 |
| Lower Risk | 0.35 |
For CPF Investment Scheme List A funds, fund managers/insurers are not allowed to charge expenses more than the TER caps.
1 Guidelines on the computation of expense ratio can be found in the [Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS) website](http://www.imas.org.sg/uploads/media/2012/10/25/19_200505_-_IMAS_Revised_Guidelines_on_Expense_Ratio.pdf).']

question: Why is CPF Board reducing the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
answer: ['Reducing the Total Expense Ratio caps is part of CPF Board's continuous efforts to lower the cost of investing under the CPF Investment Scheme. This would help enhance returns, hence enable CPF members who have invested in the fund to accumulate their retirement savings faster.']

question: How are the new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps determined?
answer: ['The new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps are determined based on the FY2012 **median** TERs (for the relevant risk categories) of CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) List A funds, and taking into account industry feedback. Median TERs were also used in 2008 when CPF Board first implemented TER caps for funds under the CPFIS.']

question: How will CPF investors benefit from the reduced Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
answer:
['Expenses on investment have a significant impact on returns. Hence, reducing Total Expense Ratio caps will lower the expenses that CPF investors have to bear and increase a fund's per-unit net asset value. This will enable CPF members who have invested in the fund to accumulate their retirement savings faster. The following example illustrates the impact of expense ratio: Amount invested: $10,000 over 30 years, with annual return of 5%1. Total expense ratio of the Fund decreases from 1.95% to 1.75% Savings = **$1,475** (or 6% more in his retirement savings)
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| | **Expense Ratio of 1.95%** | **Expense Ratio of 1.75%** |
| Net investment value after 30 years | $24,629 | $26,104 |
| Savings | **$1,475** |
1 Assumes no front end load']

question: What actions do I (as a CPFIS investor) need to take due to reduction in Total Expense Ratio caps?
answer:
['**You do not have to take any action unless the fund(s) you have invested in cannot comply with the reduced Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps.** In which case, the relevant parties (i.e. Fund Management Companies/insurers/investment administrators) will notify you by letters. As existing funds which are unable to comply with the new TER caps from 2016 will be downgraded to List B and will not be allowed to take in **new**CPF monies from then, you will be given the following options by the relevant parties:
1. Free switches to other funds included under CPF Investment Scheme within a specified period from the date of the letter (around one month),
2. Redeem the units,
3. Continue to remain invested in these funds (if you choose this option, no further action is required from you).
*Note: Cash investors would not be affected. For info - List of funds will be updated when necessary.*[List A and B unit trusts](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSUT.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.2MB) [List A and B Investment Link Products (ILPs) Sub-funds](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSILP1.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.1MB)']

question: Will there still be a range of funds for CPF investors to choose from?
answer: ['The lowering of the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps would not have significant impact on the choices of investment under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS). The Board will work with industry players towards complying with the new TER caps, to give CPF members continued choice in terms of the range of funds available under the CPFIS.']

question: Is the 3 years track record for new funds applied at the fund level or based on the experience of Fund Management Companies?
answer: ['The preference for a 3 year performance track record is generally applied at the fund level. Fund managers should preferably show a minimum track record so that they can be better assessed on their ability whether they are able to give consistently good performance against the benchmark for the specific fund they manage. In the case of indexed funds or Exchange Traded Funds, the 3 year track record is applied differently. The focus will be on the fund management company's technology or systems and processes that they have established to perform the rebalancing functions to track indexes closely1 and their ability to consistently maintain a low cost structure for the index funds they have under management. 1Low tracking error']

question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) admission criteria for funds?
answer:
['The admission criteria for the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) funds are:
1. Top quartile of global peer group
2. Total Expense Ratio lower than the median of CPFIS funds in respective risk class
3. 0% sales charge
4. Preferably track record of 3 years
These criteria aims to raise the quality and lower cost of investments for funds included under the CPFIS. You can refer to the [reports](https://imas.org.sg/education/fundsingapore/)√Ç¬†on the performance of the CPFIS funds.']

question: How does CPF Board currently assess whether funds admitted are still suitable to remain in CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer: ['When determining if a product is suitable to be under CPF Investment Scheme, the emphasis so far has been on past performance and the competency of its investment professionals. Re-evaluation will be required for Fund Management Companies/Funds that have undergone material changes in the organisational structure, fund structure or management team.']

question: Will the new admission criteria be applied to existing funds under CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['The new criteria will apply to existing funds from 1 January 2011. To help members make better informed investment decisions, the Board will, in due course, step up its member education efforts and also avail relevant information on the performance and expense ratios of existing funds.']

question: What can members do if the funds in which they have already invested do not meet the new standards set by the Board following re-evaluation?
answer: ['Members who have already invested in such funds can continue to remain invested in the funds, or consider switching to other funds or selling out of the funds if the funds no longer meet their investment objective.']

question: What is the rationale of harmonising the criteria for new and existing funds under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['CPF Board ("CPFB") has, since 2006, taken measures to improve the quality of funds in CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) and lower the costs of investing. From 1 February 2006, new Unit Trusts and Investment-Linked Products (collectively known as "funds") must meet the stricter criteria1 before being admitted into CPFIS2. From 1 January 2011, all funds in the CPFIS must meet the stricter criteria to continue to take in new CPF monies. This is part of CPFB's ongoing efforts to lower cost and improve the quality of CPFIS funds to benefit CPF members who seek to invest their CPF savings for higher returns. 1(i) Top quartile of global peer group (ii) Total Expense Ratio lower than the median of CPFIS funds in respective risk class (iii) Sales charge not exceeding 3% and (iv) Preferably track record of 3 years. 2Prior to 1 February 2006, the admission criterion was top 50 percentile of global peer group.']

question: How will this harmonisation affect the funds included under CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['All CPF Investment Scheme funds that have not met the stricter admission criteria and that wish to be able to take in new CPF monies from 1 January 2011 need to be re-evaluated.']

question: How will the re-evaluation affect the funds that I am holding under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer: ['Re-evaluation will not affect the funds that you are holding. However if by December 2010, the funds which you are holding do not meet the stricter criteria, or if your Fund Management Company (FMC)/ insurer chooses not to have the funds re-evaluated, you will not be able to purchase more units of such funds with your CPF monies.']

question: Is it compulsory to keep switching funds under the CPF Investment Scheme if the funds which I am holding do not meet the stricter criteria?
answer: ['You can opt to hold on to your existing funds without switching.']

question: If I hold a fund under the CPF Investment Scheme that does not meet the stricter criteria, when must I exercise the switching option?
answer: ['Funds that are unable to meet the stricter criteria can only take in new CPF monies till December 2010, and you will be given up till 30 June 2011 to exercise the switching option. In addition, a fund may decide to cease taking in new CPF monies earlier. If this happens, you have to exercise the switching option within the timeframe stipulated by the Fund Management Company/insurer in its communication letter to you.']

question: How will I know whether the funds that I am holding under the CPF Investment Scheme do not meet the stricter criteria by December 2010?
answer: ['If the funds do not meet the stricter criteria by December 2010, the respective Fund Management Company(FMC)/insurer will be required to inform their CPF clients in writing, and to offer their clients three options, by December 2010.']

question: What should I do if the funds that I am holding under the CPF Investment Scheme do not meet the stricter criteria by December 2010?
answer: ['You will be given options by the Fund Management Companies (FMCs) or insurers to hold, redeem or switch your units, for free, into other CPF Investment Scheme funds that are eligible to take in new CPF monies from 1 January 2011. If you decide to switch funds, please consider whether the new funds match your investment objective and [risk profile](/content/dam/web/member/growing-your-savings/documents/Risk_Tolerance_Questionaire.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.2MB).']

question: Where can I find more information on Singtel's Scrip Dividend Scheme, as announced by Singtel on 12 November 2020?
answer:
['For financial year ending 31 March 2021, Singtel has paid interim dividend at dividend rate of $0.051 per share.√Ç¬†The scrip shares were offered at $2.422 per share. For more information, please visit the√Ç¬†[Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/dividends/scrip-dividend).
If you had opted for scrip shares, the number of scrip shares issued to you, in respect of your shareholdings as at 27 November 2020 (√¢¬Ä¬òRecord Date√¢¬Ä¬ô), was calculated as follows:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| Number of scrip√Ç¬†shares issued = | Number of discounted Singtel shares (at Record Date) x Dividend rate |
| Issue price of scrip share |']

question: What is Special Discounted Shares Scheme?
answer: ['The Special Discounted Share Scheme is part of the Government√¢¬Ä¬ôs asset enhancement programme to make Singapore a share-owning society, thus giving Singaporeans a greater stake in the country.']

question: Where can I find more information about discounted Singtel shares?
answer: ['You can refer to the [Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/share-information/singtel-share-history) for more information.']

question: Where can I check the number of discounted Singtel shares in my CPF account?
answer: ['You can login to√Ç¬†[*my cpf* Online Services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment)√Ç¬†with your Singpass and check the "Discounted Singtel shares" section in the Investment dashboard.']

question: Why are my current discounted Singtel shareholdings different from the quantity I purchased in 1993 and/or 1996 even though I did not sell the shares?
answer: ['Singtel performed capital reductions on 1 September 2004 and 1 September 2006. In the 2004 capital reduction, Singtel cancelled 1 in every 14 of its shares, with the resultant shareholding rounded-up to the nearest 10 shares, where applicable. Singtel then reimbursed you S$2.36 for each cancelled share. In the 2006 capital reduction, Singtel cancelled 1 in every 20 of its shares, with the resultant shareholding rounded-up to the nearest 10 shares, where applicable. Singtel reimbursed you $2.74 for each cancelled share. Both reimbursements were credited into your CPF Ordinary Account. You were then informed, in writing, of the capital reductions in September 2004 and September 2006.']

question: Why are my discounted Singtel shares not reflected in my Central Depository (CDP) statement?
answer: ['Your discounted Singtel shares are held by the Board on your behalf. Your discounted Singtel shares would therefore be reflected in your CPF Statement of Account.']

question: How would I know if I would make a gain or loss if I were to sell my discounted Singtel shares now?
answer: ['For sale of discounted Singtel√Ç¬†shares, you can use the [weighted average cost (WAC) method](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/SDS_ExampleA.pdf) (PDF, 15KB) to determine whether you would make a gain or loss.']

question: What are the dividends rates declared by Singtel for the discounted Singtel shares to-date?
answer: ['You may refer to [Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/dividends)√Ç¬†or our√Ç¬†[dividend table](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/Dividend%20Rates_SDS.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.1MB) for rates declared by Singtel.']

question: Are the dividends received from the discounted Singtel shares subject to tax?
answer: ['Dividends received from your discounted Singtel shares are not taxable.']

question: Can I transfer my discounted Singtel shares to another person?
answer: ['Your discounted Singtel shares can only be transferred into a CDP securities account under your name after you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in your Retirement Account at age 55.']

question: What happens when I sell my discounted Singtel shares?
answer: ['When you sell your discounted Singtel shares, the sale proceeds will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account and form part of your CPF savings.']

question: Can I withdraw my sale proceeds or investment profits from my discounted Singtel shares?
answer:
['The sale proceeds and investment profits form part of your CPF savings. You can apply to withdraw them from age 55 if you meet the [withdrawal conditions](/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-much-cpf-savings-can-i-withdraw).
For more information on how you can withdraw your CPF retirement savings, please refer to this [FAQ](/member/faq/retirement-income/retirement-withdrawals/how-can-i-withdraw-my-cpf-savings).']

question: Will my discounted Singtel shares be sold or liquidated when I apply to withdraw my discounted Singtel shares upon meeting CPF withdrawal conditions?
answer: ['Withdrawing your discounted Singtel shares will not result in liquidation of your shares. It is a request to the Board to transfer the discounted Singtel shares to your CDP securities account. Once the shares have been transferred, you will receive a statement from CDP and the Board.']

question: How can I transfer my discounted Singtel shares for division of matrimonial assets?
answer: ['To obtain an application form to transfer your discounted Singtel shares for division of matrimonial assets, please login to *my cpf Online Services*with your Singpass and select My Requests > Investment > [Apply to transfer√Ç¬†Discounted Singtel Shares√Ç¬†(Division of Matrimonial Assets)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/MemberPortalServices).']

question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to discounted Singtel shares?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to√Ç¬†discounted Singtel shares.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Withdraw My Discounted Singtel Shares Upon Meeting CPF Withdrawal Conditions | Within 15 working days *(this includes the Central Depository's (CDP) processing time)* |
| Transfer Discounted Singtel Shares (Division of CPF-related Matrimonial Assets) | Within 15 working days\* *\* Transferee must have a CPF investment account with agent bank* |']

question: Do top-up monies form part of the required $40,000 that needs to be set aside before I can invest my Special Account monies?
answer: ['Top-up monies form part of the $40,000 that needs to be set aside in the Special Account (SA) before you can use the excess for your investment. However, top-up monies cannot be used for investment. For example, if you have $100,000 in your SA, of which $90,000 are top up monies you received in your SA, only monies in excess of the $90,000 (i.e. $10,000) can be invested. Please refer to this√Ç¬†[FAQ](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-will-the-top-ups-to-my-retirement-savings-be-used-)√Ç¬†for further information on usage of top-up monies.']

question: What happens when I sell my investments under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['The sale proceeds from your investments under the CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA) are handled differently.
Are you selling the investments under your
CPFIS-OA?
When you sell your investments, the sales proceeds will automatically be credited into your CPF Investment Account. The monies will remain there, unless you instruct your agent bank to transfer the amount into your OA.√Ç¬†Do cater processing time required for the settlement of each application (applicable to both the purchase and sale of investments). You can check with the respective service / product providers directly for the processing time required.
Your agent bank will also automatically transfer the cash balance held in your CPF Investment Account to your OA (at the end of the month\*) if your Investment Account has been inactive (i.e. if there had been no investment transactions) for two consecutive months.
*\* The monies will be transferred on the third last working day of the month. In the event that the third last working day falls on a Saturday, the transfer will take place on the second last working day of the month.*
CPFIS-SA?
When you sell your investments, the sales proceeds will automatically be credited into your SA.√Ç¬†Do cater processing time required for the settlement of each application (applicable to both the purchase and sale of investments). You can check with the respective service / product providers directly for the processing time required.
We know that some members use √¢¬Ä¬òSA Shielding√¢¬Ä¬ô (i.e. investing their SA savings shortly before age 55 and liquidating it after age 55), to retain more CPF savings in the SA and enjoy its attractive interest rates.
The use of √¢¬Ä¬òSA Shielding√¢¬Ä¬ô comes with costs and investment risks √¢¬Ä¬ì there may be transaction fees involved in using CPF for investment and you may lose a portion of the amount invested.
A better option for members who want to enjoy the attractive CPF interest rates is to top-up their Retirement Account up to the Enhanced Retirement Sum through the Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme instead.
We will continue to monitor the √¢¬Ä¬òSA Shielding√¢¬Ä¬ô trend closely and take appropriate action if necessary. Financial advisers and insurance brokers who promote √¢¬Ä¬òSA Shielding√¢¬Ä¬ô without highlighting the costs and investment risks may be guilty of mis-selling, and should be reported to the√Ç¬†[Monetary Authority of Singapore](https://www.mas.gov.sg/contact-us).']

question: How do I apply to use my CPF savings under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
answer:
['If you are a new CPFIS investor, you will need to take the Self-Awareness Questionnaire (SAQ) before you can start investing under CPFIS. The SAQ helps you to assess if you have basic financial knowledge and whether CPFIS is suitable for you.
The process for applying to use your CPF savings under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) are different.
Please select:
CPFIS-OA
For CPFIS-OA, you will need to open a CPF Investment Account with one of the following CPFIS agent banks:
* DBS Bank Ltd (DBS)
* Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Ltd (OCBC)
* United Overseas Bank Ltd (UOB)
Only UOB offers gold products (excluding gold ETFs). If you wish to invest in gold, you will need an investment account with UOB.
You will need to bring along your identity card and a copy of your CPF statement for the agent bank to verify your CPF account number. The agent bank will also require you to declare your SAQ status and/or ask to view a copy of your SAQ status.
Once you have successfully opened a CPF Investment Account, you may approach the product providers directly to buy or sell your investments.
Your agent banks will liaise with the Board and the various product providers to settle your purchase and sale of investment, and keep track of your investment holdings and transactions in your CPF Investment Account. Do cater processing time required for the settlement of each application (applicable to both the purchase and sale of investments). You can check with the respective service / product providers directly for the processing time required.
Note that you can only maintain one CPF Investment Account at any one time.
For more information, you can contact the [Service/Product Providers](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexC.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) included under the CPFIS.
CPFIS-SA
For CPFIS-SA, no CPF Investment Account is required.
You may approach the product providers directly to buy or sell your investments.
You will need to bring along your identity card and a copy of your CPF statement for the product provider to verify your CPF account number. The product provider will also require you to declare your SAQ status and/or ask to view a copy of your SAQ status. Do cater processing time required for the settlement of each application (applicable to both the purchase and sale of investments). You can check with the respective service / product providers directly for the processing time required.
CPF Board will liaise with the various product providers to settle your purchase and sale of investment, and keep track of your investment holdings and transactions.
For more information, you can contact the [Service/Product Providers](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexC.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) included under the CPFIS.']

question: Can CPF monies be used for rights and/or warrants?
answer: ['You cannot use your CPF monies to purchase rights/warrants directly from the marketplace. However, if you are issued rights/warrants that arise from shares/investments that you currently hold, you may use your CPF monies to pay for the exercise price of these rights/warrants provided the underlying investments being taken up are included under the CPF Investment Scheme, subject to your available stock limit. For such cases, your agent bank will reach out to you on the details of the application.']

question: How to sell my discounted Singtel shares?
answer:
['There are three ways to sell your discounted Singtel shares:
via Online Sale Facility
Log in to my cpf Online Services with your Singpass. Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment, look under √¢¬Ä¬úDiscounted Singtel Shares√¢¬Ä¬ù section and click on √¢¬Ä¬úSell your shares√¢¬Ä¬ù.
You will be directed to POEMS - an online trading platform managed by Phillip Securities Pte Ltd (√¢¬Ä¬òPhillip Securities√¢¬Ä¬ô). Once you have submitted your online instruction, Phillip Securities will sell your discounted Singtel shares. The proceeds of sale will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account within 6 working days.
You can find out more information on selling your discounted Singtel shares through the Online Sale Facility in this [document](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/FAQ%20for%20Online%20SDS%20Sale%20Facility.pdf) (PDF, 0.6MB).
via Singapore Post Office
Visit any [Singapore Post Offices](https://www.singpost.com/locate-us?catid=36&id=45) (√¢¬Ä¬òSingPost√¢¬Ä¬ô). For SingPost to process your instruction, you need to sell a minimum quantity of 10 shares. You would also need to produce the following documents at SingPost:
* Your identity card; and
* The latest copy of your CPF Statement of Account, which indicates the number of discounted Singtel shares held in your CPF account.
If you are unable to sell your discounted Singtel shares in person, you may authorise a third party to sell the shares on your behalf. Your authorised person must bring the following documents to SingPost:
* A completed and signed √¢¬Ä¬òAccount Opening and Authorisation for The Sale of STA & ST2 Shares Form√¢¬Ä¬ô. All sections including √¢¬Ä¬òThird Party Authorisation√¢¬Ä¬ô are to be completed. This application form is available at all SingPost branches;
* Identity cards belonging to both authorised person and you; and
* The latest copy of your CPF Statement of Account, which indicates the number of discounted Singtel shares held in your CPF account.
You can find out more information on selling your discounted Singtel shares through SingPost in this [document](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/FAQ%20for%20SDS%20sale%20through%20SingPost.pdf) (PDF, 0.8MB).
via Singapore Exchange (SGX) Retail Broker
Please approach your broker if you have a trading account with them. If you do not have a trading account, you can open one with any [SGX broking firm](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/SDS_AnnexESGXBrokingFirmsforRetailClients.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB).
Internet trading platforms for most brokers do not cater for sale of discounted Singtel shares. Please check with your broker before selling your discounted Singtel shares.']

question: How can I check my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) details?
answer:
['There are various ways in obtaining the details of your investments under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).
Would you like to check the CPFIS details for your:
CPFIS-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)?
You can either refer to your CPF Investment Scheme statement sent by your agent bank or contact them directly.
CPFIS-Special Account (CPFIS-SA)?
You can view the details of your investments by:
* logging into [my cpf digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment) with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment ,
* accessing the 'CPF Mobile' app with your Singpass, or
* visiting any [CPF Service Centres](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/visit-us) personally with your identity card.']

question: Can I withdraw my discounted Singtel shares when I reach 55 years old?
answer:
['You are required to set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in your Retirement Account (RA), before you can withdraw your discounted Singtel shares. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property.
Have you met your CPF withdrawal conditions?
Yes
Log in to [my cpf Online Services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment) with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment, look under √¢¬Ä¬úDiscounted Singtel Shares√¢¬Ä¬ù section and click on √¢¬Ä¬úWithdraw your shares√¢¬Ä¬ù.
We will process your application within 15 working days once we receive your application.
After your discounted Singtel shares have been transferred to your CDP securities account, they will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.
No
You can only withdraw your discounted Singtel shares if you have set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in your Retirement Account at age 55. However, you can sell your discounted Singtel shares, in which the sale proceeds will be credited into your CPF Ordinary Account.
To sell, please log in to [my cpf Online Services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment) with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment, look under √¢¬Ä¬úDiscounted Singtel Shares√¢¬Ä¬ù section and click on √¢¬Ä¬úSell your shares√¢¬Ä¬ù.']

question: How soon can I sell my investments which are traded on the Singapore Exchange after I buy them under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account?
answer:
['You can sell your investments (e.g. shares or property funds) which are listed on the Singapore Exchange one trading day after the purchase date provided:
* Your stock broker has keyed the purchase trade on the day the purchase contract is made; and
* You have sufficient investible funds in your CPF Investment and/or Ordinary Account to settle the purchase.
Your available stock limit or gold limit will be updated on the 2nd trading day (i.e. T+2) based on the cost of the shares, property funds, corporate bonds or gold exchange traded funds (ETFs) sold when the sale transaction is settled. Please refer to this [example](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexB.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) to see how the stock limit and gold limit are computed.
Can I reinvest the full sale proceeds immediately?
If you intend to buy another share, property fund, corporate bond or gold ETF during this T+2 period, please check with your agent bank on your available stock limit or gold limit first. You will need to have sufficient investible funds in your CPF Investment and/or Ordinary Account to settle the new purchase before the settlement deadline.
Why can't I reinvest my full sale proceeds immediately?
You have to ensure that you have the sufficient limits, and monies to reinvest when your sale proceeds have been refunded. Unlike cash trades, stock investment using CPF is subject to the CPF stock limit which may change with CPF contributions, withdrawals, crediting of CPFIS sale proceeds, new CPFIS investments etc. Hence, to err on the safe side, it may be better for you to reinvest after your fund position is firmed up on T+2, in line with SGX settlement framework.']

question: When will the maturity proceeds of my investments be credited to my CPF accounts?
answer:
['The maturity proceeds for investments under CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) are handled differently.
Please select
Ordinary Account (OA)
Upon maturity of your CPFIS-OA investments, the proceeds will be credited into your CPF Investment Account generally within one week. You can check with your agent bank to know if the proceeds have been credited.
Special Account (SA)
Upon maturity of your CPFIS-SA investments, the proceeds will be credited into your SA generally within one week. To check whether the proceeds have been credited, you can view your CPFIS statement by logging into:
* the [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member) with your Singpass, or
* the 'CPF Mobile' app with your Singpass.']

question: Can I withdraw my CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments when I reach 55 years old?
answer:
['You can apply to the Board to withdraw your CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) investments as well as the cash balance in your Investment Account, as long as you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in the Retirement Account (RA). The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property. Your CPF Investment Account will be closed once you apply to withdraw your investments.
However, if you are unable to set aside your FRS in the RA, your investments will not be transferred to you. Upon liquidation of your investments, the sale proceeds will be credited to your CPF Investment Account for CPFIS-OA or Special Account for CPFIS-SA.
Please refer to this [FAQ](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-happens-to-my-cpf-savings-when-i-turn-55) for more information on how the retirement sum is set aside at age 55.
To apply for the withdrawal, please submit an [e-application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyRequest/MyRequestLanding) to us.
To find out what would happen after you have applied for withdrawal of investments under the CPFIS, please select
CPFIS-OA
We will inform the agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account. The agent bank will contact you for the withdrawal of your investments and cash balance (if any) in your CPF Investment Account. Your investments will be transferred\* to your own name and you may thereafter liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.
Once withdrawn, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.
*\* Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (√¢¬Ä¬úCDP√¢¬Ä¬ù) imposes a transfer fee of $10.00 (excluding GST) for every share counter transferred from your CPF Investment Account to your CDP Account.*
CPFIS-SA
We will inform your product provider(s) to transfer your investments to your own name and you may thereafter liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.
Once withdrawn, your CPFIS investments will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.']

question: How does the Board treat the maturity proceeds by the insurer after I reached 55 years old?
answer:
['The maturity proceeds from your insurance policies under the CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA) and the CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA) are handled differently.
Are your insurance policies under the
CPFIS-OA?
For CPFIS-OA policies, the proceeds would be refunded to your CPF Investment Account with your agent bank. You can instruct your bank to transfer the monies back to your CPF Ordinary Account. You can apply for withdrawal of the monies subject to the prevailing CPF withdrawal rules.
For policies that have already been transferred to your name earlier when you applied for withdrawal of your CPFIS investments, it would be considered as cash policies and the insurance companies would pay the proceeds directly to you.
CPFIS-SA?
For CPFIS-SA policies, the proceeds would be refunded to your CPF Special Account. You can apply for withdrawal of the monies subject to the prevailing CPF withdrawal rules.
For policies that have already been transferred to your name when you applied for withdrawal of your CPFIS investments, it would be considered as cash policies and the insurance companies would pay the proceeds directly to you.']

question: What is the CPF Investment Scheme Risk Classification System?
answer:
['The Risk Classification System is developed to help you determine which of the various investment options may be most appropriate for your investment circumstances, through better understanding of the level and type of risk associated and your risk tolerance. It splits the investment risk associated with [Unit Trust](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSUT.pdf), [Investment-Linked Products](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSILP1.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) and [Exchange Traded Funds](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSETF.pdf) (PDF, 40KB) included under CPF Investment Scheme Funds into two broad categories, i.e. "Equity Risk" and "Focus Risk".
The CPF Board does not give any consideration to nor has made any investigation on the investment objectives, financial situation or particular needs of the reader, any specific person or any group of persons. Accordingly, no warranty whatsoever is given and no liability whatsoever is accepted for any loss arising whether directly or indirectly as a result of the reader, any person or any group of persons acting on any information, opinion or statement expressed in these FAQs.
Read more on:
What is Equity Risk?
Equity Risk is related to exposure to the "riskier" types of investments in the Funds. The greater the proportion of assets invested in stocks, the higher the Equity Risk (i.e. higher risk category). Conversely, the greater the proportion of investments in bonds and cash, the lower the Equity Risk (i.e. lower risk category).
What is Focus Risk?
Focus Risk reflects how focused the investments of the Funds are in particular geographical regions, foreign countries, foreign currencies, industries or individual companies. A Fund that invests in shares of companies from around the world would have lower Focus Risk (i.e. broadly diversified) than a fund that invests in shares of companies from one country only (i.e. narrowly diversified).']

question: What is an Exchange Traded Fund (ETF)?
answer:
['Under the CPF Investment Scheme, you can invest in Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs).
An ETF is an investment fund that is listed and traded on an Exchange. It is designed to track an index of markets and sectors or a fixed basket of stocks. It is bought and sold in the same way stocks are bought and sold on the Exchange.
Investors can track the ETF's performance by monitoring the particular underlying index's performance.
What are the benefits of an ETF?
Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) offer investors the benefit of diversification as investors need only to buy an ETF share to gain exposure to a diversified portfolio of domestic or international stocks. ETFs have low annual management fees and investors may buy or sell ETFs at prevailing market prices during trading hours in the Exchange. Investors are also able to see what stocks they are buying as ETFs offer transparency in its composition.']

question: When should I invest in broadly diversified investments and when should I invest in narrowly focused investments?
answer:
['After you have made your decision on how much to invest in the three basic types of investments: cash, bonds and stocks (i.e. based on the amount of equity risk you are comfortable with), for most CPF members, investing in broadly diversified investments within that equity risk category should generally help minimise investment risk. In other words, investing in broadly diversified investments should help reduce risk compared with investing in narrowly focused investments in the same equity risk category.
However, there could also be reasons for investing in narrowly focused investments:
Find out more
You enjoy riskier investments, even when the odds are not necessarily in your favour. You are happy to take on the extra downside risk of not diversifying because of the potential for higher returns, although you are aware that a positive result is not guaranteed.
For investments in the same equity risk category, it is reasonable to expect potential rewards over the long term to be very roughly the same for both a broadly diversified investment and a narrowly focused investment. However, you may want to accept the higher downside risk of a narrowly focused investment if you think that a narrowly focused investment may give better results in the short term.
For example, if you are confident about the recovery of the Japanese economy in the short term, you may wish to invest in a Japan focused unit trust even though this unit trust has higher risk than a better diversified global equity unit trust.']

question: What are the basic investment classes?
answer:
['Most investments fall into one of three basic asset classes √¢¬Ä¬î cash equivalents, bonds and stocks (also called shares or equities).
To read more about these three basic asset classes, please select:
Cash equivalents
Cash equivalent (e.g. fixed deposit) investments are usually investments which have low risk of losing value but offer relatively low potential returns. Cash equivalents are typically used to hold money that will be needed in the near future or to hold assets temporarily while considering how to invest the assets for the long term.
Bonds
Bonds, often referred to as fixed income securities or debt securities, are loans to a corporation or government to finance its operations. A bond represents the corporation's or government's promise to repay at a specified date (at maturity) the amount borrowed from investors. The bond generally earns interest. Bonds also increase or decrease in value based on market conditions.
Examples of bonds include government bonds and corporate bonds.
Stocks
Stocks represent ownership in a corporation. If you own stock in the XYZ Corporation, you are part owner of that company. Stocks may provide income in the form of dividends. Stock investments increase in value when the price of the share goes up and vice versa. Historically, over periods of several years or more, many types of stocks have increased in value. However, past performance is no guarantee of future results.']

question: What are the criteria for inclusion of Gold Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)?
What are the different evaluation factors for admission into CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) under the old and new entry criteria?
If I run out of CPF monies to pay the premiums of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policies, what should I do?
answer:
['You have the following options:
1. Use cash to pay the premiums;
2. Convert your Part V insurance policies to a paid-up mode1; or
3. Activate the Automatic Premium Loan (APL)2 or Extended Term Insurance (ETI)3 feature(s) of your Part V insurance policies, if they have such features and if your insurance company allows you to do so.
1Converting a policy to paid-up mode means that the policyholder will not need to pay premiums anymore. The sum assured of a paid-up policy is usually lower than that of the original policy. All supplementary riders attached will be terminated.
2APL means that once the policy has accumulated sufficient cash value, if the policyholder is unable to pay the premium, he can borrow from the cash value. However, he is required to pay back the loan and compound interest. Once the loan plus compound interest exceeds the cash value of the policy, the policy will lapse.
3ETI means that if the policyholder still wants the insurance protection but doesn't want to pay any more premiums, the existing cash value of his policy is treated as a single premium which is used to buy protection for future years. The number of years of protection he will get varies directly with the quantum of the cash value.
What is the difference between a paid-up policy and ETI?
The difference between a paid-up policy and ETI is that:
* A paid-up policy has lower sum assured than the original policy but ETI has the same or higher sum assured than the original policy (assuming no indebtedness);
* A paid-up policy will mature on the same date as the original policy, whereas for ETI, the maturity date may or may not be the same date as the original policy as the period of cover depends on how much cash value there is in the original policy and the policyholder's age on the date of premium default.']

question: How will the proceeds of my Academic Staff Provident Fund Approved Investment Scheme (ASPFAIS) Part V insurance policy and/or rider be distributed?
answer:
['In general, premiums of Part V insurance policies and riders (if any) paid using Academic Staff Provident Fund (ASPF) monies or cash prior to the transfer of the policy to CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) would be treated as though the premiums were paid using CPF monies. This is because Section 22 of the First Schedule of the National University Singapore (Corporatisation) Act provides that all premiums paid or deemed to have been paid with ASPF moneys in respect of ASPF Approved Investment Scheme Investments and Part V Assurances shall, on and after the dissolution date, be deemed to have been paid with CPF monies. Hence, the proportion of the proceeds (except death benefits) corresponding to such premiums would be refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account.
However, the distribution of the full proceeds would depend on the premium payment mode after the transfer of the Part V policy to CPFIS. If, after the transfer of your policy to CPFIS:
All the premiums of your Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using your CPF Ordinary Account savings
If all the premiums of your Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using your CPF Ordinary Account savings, all proceeds would have to be refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account.
Your CPF monies are exhausted and you then use cash to pay the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider
If your CPF monies are exhausted and you used cash to pay the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider, the proceeds would be pro-rated based on CPF savings vis-√É¬†-vis cash used to pay for the premiums after the transfer. The CPF portion and cash portion of the proceeds will be respectively refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account and to you.
All the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using cash
If all the premiums of the Part V insurance policy and rider are paid using cash, the proportion of the proceeds corresponding to the premiums paid in cash after the transfer of the policy to CPFIS would be refunded to you in cash. The remaining proceeds would be refunded to your CPFIS Investment Account.']

question: What are trailer fees?
answer:
['Trailer fees are fees payable to distributors (including financial advisors) who sell the fund to the investors. The trailer fees are generally paid out from a fund√¢¬Ä¬ôs annual management fees (which is part of the total expense ratio1) by the fund manager or product provider to distributors. As such, trailer fees are **not additional cost** to end investors.
![The total expense ratio of a fund includes investment management fees, trustee fees, audit fees etc.](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/images/trailer-fees.png)
*1√Ç¬†The expense ratio refers to the ongoing costs of operating a fund by fund managers/insurers expressed as a percentage of the fund's average net assets. Operating costs include investment management fees, trustee fees, and audit fees, etc.*']

question: How is CPF Board enhancing the disclosure of trailer fees?
answer:
['Currently, fund managers pay trailer fees to their distributors who sell their funds to investors. Fund Managers disclose the trailer fees range in their products√¢¬Ä¬ô sales documents which distributors (including financial advisors) generally relied upon when selling their products to investors. Such trailer fees range could be too wide to be meaningful to investors. As such, more trailer fees information i.e. the median would be more useful to investors.
**From 1 October 2022**, Fund Management Companies (FMCs), Insurers, Investment Administrators (IAs), financial advisors and insurance agents are required to disclose trailer fees information (i.e. range and median) in their CPFIS products√¢¬Ä¬ô sales documents in order to help CPF investors make informed decision on their investment purchase.']

question: How would I benefit from the enhanced disclosure of trailer fees?
answer: ['**You would be able to understand how much trailer fees that your insurance agents and financial advisors receive.** The trailer fees information would be presented to you in the sales documents e.g. the funds√¢¬Ä¬ô Product Highlight Sheet, prospectus, Policy Illustration for Investment-linked Products (ILPs), subscription forms by your financial advisors.']

question: Do all CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)-included Unit Trusts/ILP sub-funds charge trailer fees?
answer: ['Trailer fees is subjected to the business agreements between product providers and their distributors (including financial advisors). Some funds may not have trailer fees payable to distributors.']

question: Do I need to pay additional fees due to trailer fees disclosure by my product/service providers? Is there any action required of me (as a CPFIS investor)?
answer: ['You do not need to pay any additional fees. No action is required from you (as a CPFIS investor) given that trailer fees are paid by the fund manager or product provider to distributors.']

question: Who can I approach if I want to know more on the trailer fees of the CPF Investment Scheme products?
answer: ['You can approach your product/service provider or financial advisors for more information on trailer fees.']

question: How do I use my CPF to apply for Singapore Government Bonds and Treasury Bills (T-bills) at primary auctions? Can the application be submitted using online or ATM services?
answer:
['| | |
| --- | --- |
| **For CPF Investment Scheme-Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)** | Please apply for the bonds and T-bills through your CPFIS-OA agent bank.
