Application is restricted to your CPFIS-OA agent bank to facilitate the settlement process for bonds and T-bills purchased under CPFIS-OA.√¢¬Ä¬¢ **DBS/POSB**: Apply through DBS/POSB's internet banking portal.√¢¬Ä¬¢ **OCBC**: Apply through OCBC√¢¬Ä¬ôs internet banking portal or OCBC Digital application.√¢¬Ä¬¢ **UOB**: Apply for SGS bonds in person at any UOB branch. Apply for T-bills through UOB√¢¬Ä¬ôs internet banking portalAfter the T-bills auction closes, you can check the aggregate results of the auction at the Monetary Authority of Singapore√¢¬Ä¬ôs [website](https://www.mas.gov.sg/bonds-and-bills/auctions-and-issuance-calendar). If your application is successful, the T-bills allotted to you will be reflected in the CPF investment account statement sent by your agent bank. |
| **For CPF Investment Scheme-Special Account (CPFIS-SA)** | You may apply for the bonds and T-bills via any of the CPFIS bond dealers (i.e. DBS, OCBC or UOB).√¢¬Ä¬¢ **DBS/POSB**: Apply in person at any DBS/POSB branch.√¢¬Ä¬¢ **OCBC**: Apply through OCBC√¢¬Ä¬ôs internet banking portal or OCBC Digital application.√¢¬Ä¬¢ **UOB**: Apply in person at any UOB branch.After the T-bills auction closes, you can check the aggregate results of the auction at the Monetary Authority of Singapore√¢¬Ä¬ôs [website](https://www.mas.gov.sg/bonds-and-bills/auctions-and-issuance-calendar). If your application is successful, the T-bills allotted to you will be reflected in your [Special Account investment portfolio statement](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment/investment-portfolio). |']

question: Can I use CPF savings to place Fixed Deposits under the CPF Investment Scheme?
answer:
['You can use your CPF savings to place Fixed Deposits (FD) with any of the four Fixed Deposit Banks (DBS, Maybank, OCBC and UOB) under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).
Please approach the Fixed Deposit Banks directly to check if they are offering any FD under CPFIS, their FD rates and for placement of the FD. You can place the FD even if the Fixed Deposit Bank is not your CPFIS-OA agent bank.']

question: Where can I see my special dividend as declared by Singtel on 10 November 2022?
answer:
['Singtel declared a special dividend of $0.05 per share for financial year ending 31 March 2023. According to Singtel, the special dividend will be paid in tranches. The first S$0.025 will be paid along with the interim dividend in December 2022, while the remaining S$0.025 will be paid out together with Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs final dividend in August 2023. The special dividend in both tranches is payable based on their respective book closure dates. For more information on Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs special dividend, you can refer to [Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/dividends).
If you have discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account during these periods, you will receive Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs special dividend along with your interim/final dividend in your Ordinary Account. Please check your CPF statement.']

question: How much Singtel dividends did I receive in 2022?
answer: ['Singtel declared and paid dividends in January, August and December. If you had discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account during these periods, you would have received Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividends in your Ordinary Account. Please check your CPF statement.']

question: Why did Singtel pay interim dividend in December 2022?
answer: ['For financial year ending 31 March 2023, Singtel has decided to pay interim dividend earlier in December, instead of the following January. From 2023 onwards, Singtel will declare and pay dividends in August and December. For more information on Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividend payments, you can refer to [Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/dividends).']

question: Why is Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividend rate(s) not reflected in my Yearly Statement of Account?
answer: ['You can find Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividend rates in [Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/dividends) or the [dividend table](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/Dividend%20Rates_SDS.pdf) on CPF website. If you have discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account, you would have received Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividends in your Ordinary Account. Please check your CPF statement.']

question: Where can I find details of all Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividends paid in 2022?
answer: ['You can find Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividend rates in [Singtel website](https://www.singtel.com/about-us/investor-relations/dividends) or the [dividend table](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/Dividend%20Rates_SDS.pdf) on CPF website. If you have discounted Singtel shares in your CPF account, you would have received Singtel√¢¬Ä¬ôs dividends in your Ordinary Account. Please check your Ordinary Account transaction history for dividend(s) received.']

question: Who is a self-employed person?
answer:
['A self-employed person (SEP) is someone who performs work for others under a contract for service.
If you earn an income by buying and selling goods or from providing professional or personal services, you√¢¬Ä¬ôre an SEP. Examples of SEPs include hawkers, taxi drivers, freelancers, sole proprietors or a partner in a partnership.
Visit the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/self-employed/new-to-self-employed-income/am-i-a-self-employed-person) to read more on the definition of an SEP.']

question: Where can I find the application forms pertaining to self-employed matters?
answer: ['You can find the list of application forms applicable to the Self-Employed Scheme at√Ç¬†[CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member)√Ç¬†> Tools and services > Forms and e-applications > Growing Your Savings >√Ç¬†[CPF√Ç¬†contributions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications).']

question: Do I need to register myself as a self-employed person?
answer:
['You do not need to register your self-employed status with CPF Board.
You will be automatically registered as a self-employed person if you√¢¬Ä¬ôve applied for a trade/vocational licence or declared your self-employed income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) or CPF Board.']

question: How much MediSave do I need to contribute as a self-employed person?
answer:
['All self-employed persons (SEPs) who are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents and earn an annual net trade income (NTI) of more than $6,000 need to contribute to MediSave.
NTI is your gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS).](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/employees/deductions-for-individuals/personal-reliefs-and-tax-rebates/compulsory-and-voluntary-medisave-contributions)
Your MediSave contribution depends on your age and annual NTI. Use the [Self-Employed MediSave Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/SelfEmployedMedisaveContribution/SelfEmployedMedisaveContributionLanding) to calculate the amount of MediSave to contribute or refer to the [MediSave contribution rates for self-employed persons.](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/self-employed-scheme/what-are-the-medisave-contribution-rates-for-self-employed)']

question: Why is MediSave important for self-employed persons?
answer: ['MediSave can be used for healthcare needs, such as to pay for MediShield Life premiums or hospitalisation cost. It is therefore important that self-employed persons set aside a portion of their income to build up their MediSave savings, in anticipation of their future healthcare needs, especially during old age when they have stopped working.']

question: What benefits do self-employed persons enjoy from making MediSave contributions?
answer:
['When you contribute to MediSave, you enjoy:
* Up to 6%√Ç¬†interest1 per annum on your MediSave savings
+ Savings in the MediSave Account earn 4%√Ç¬†interest1 per annum, and the first $60,000 of your combined CPF balances earns an additional 1% interest per annum. Members aged 55 and above will also enjoy an additional 1% interest per annum on the first $30,000 of their combined CPF balance from 1 January 2016.
* Tax relief of up to 37% of your annual net trade income (NTI), the CPF Annual Limit of $37,740 or the actual amount contributed by you, whichever is lower. No tax relief is given if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.
* [Use of MediSave savings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/healthcare-financing/using-your-medisave-savings) to pay for a variety of medical expenses
* Hassle-free licence application and renewal
You may also be eligible for√Ç¬†[Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/government-support/workfare-income-supplement)√Ç¬†payouts of up to $2,667 annually.
1 Based on the current 4% interest rate floor for MediSave savings. Refer to [CPF interest rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest) for the current rates.']

question: How do I declare my annual net trade income online as a self-employed person?
answer:
['If you have received Form B from the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS), please complete and submit Form B to IRAS directly.
If you did not receive Form B from IRAS, you can declare your self-employed net trade income (NTI) online by logging in to the CPF website with your Singpass to complete and submit the√Ç¬†[Self-Employed Person Income Declaration Form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/IncomeDeclarationBySelfEmployedPersonForMedisaveLiability/LandingPage)**by 18 April 2023**.
**From Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwards**
Your Net Trade Income (NTI) may be declared to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) by filing a tax return. IRAS'√Ç¬†[myTax Portal](https://mytax.iras.gov.sg/ESVWeb/default.aspx) will be available from 1 March 2024 to 31 October 2024 to e-File a tax return.
Once the Board has received your income declaration, you can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the√Ç¬†[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)√Ç¬†with your Singpass.']

question: What if I had declared my net trade income (NTI) wrongly as a self-employed person or employee income?
answer:
['If you have wrongly declared your net trade income (NTI) to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS), please email IRAS at [se@iras.gov.sg](mailto:se@iras.gov.sg) or call them at 1800-356 8300. Once IRAS has updated your income for that year, you will receive a revised Notice of Computation (NOC) informing you of the revised MediSave payable. IRAS will also transmit the updated NTI records to the CPF Board.
If you have wrongly declared your NTI to the Board , please re-declare your NTI by re-submitting the [Self-Employed Person Income Declaration Form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/IncomeDeclarationBySelfEmployedPersonForMedisaveLiability/LandingPage).
Once the Board has received your income declaration, you can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the√Ç¬†[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)√Ç¬†with your Singpass.']

question: I am registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) as a partner for my business. Am I considered a self-employed person or an employee of the partnership?
answer: ['For more information on Partnerships, please visit the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/partnerships/new-to-partnerships/types-of-partnerships).']

question: How can I check whether I have any MediSave payable as a self-employed person?
answer:
['You can check your MediSave payable by logging in to the [Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment) using your Singpass.
You can apply for your [Singpass online](http://www.singpass.gov.sg/) if you do not have one.']

question: I am a Board Member/ Director. Am I considered a self-employed person, and do I have to contribute to my CPF?
answer:
['It depends on the nature of your relationship with the company, and the nature of the moneys received.
If you√¢¬Ä¬ôre engaged as a Board Member or Director under a contract of employment (or Contract of Service) with the company, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll have to contribute to your CPF as an employee.
If you√¢¬Ä¬ôre engaged in a business, profession or vocation of providing services as a Board Member or Director to companies, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll have to contribute to your MediSave as a self-employed person (SEP).
Please visit the√Ç¬†[Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/self-employed/new-to-self-employed-income/am-i-a-self-employed-person)√Ç¬†for the differences in treatment between employees and SEPs.']

question: How do I deregister my self-employed status with CPF Board if I am no longer self-employed?
answer:
['You do not need to deregister your self-employed status with CPF Board.
You will only need to make MediSave contributions if you earn an annual Net Trade Income (NTI) of more than $6,000. Your MediSave payable will be computed based on your age and NTI declared.
If you are no longer in self-employment, please note that you will still need to settle any outstanding MediSave payable, as it is compulsory under the CPF Act to contribute to your MediSave Account for the years that you were self-employed.
If you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, please refer to this [FAQ](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/what-happens-to-my-cpf-contributions0).']

question: What if my net trade income for the year is zero or negative?
answer:
['If your net trade income (NTI) is zero or negative for the year, you do not need to make any MediSave contribution for the year.
You will still be required to pay your outstanding MediSave payable for the years you were self-employed.
If you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, please refer to this [FAQ](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/what-happens-to-my-cpf-contributions0).']

question: I am holding two types of licences (e.g. LTA and ACRA). Do I have to contribute to MediSave for both licences?
answer: ['The MediSave payable is based on your annual net trade income (NTI) derived as a self-employed person and not the number of licences. If you have a total yearly NTI of more than $6,000 from your licence(s), you are required to make contributions to your MediSave Account.']

question: What are the MediSave contribution rates for self-employed persons (SEPs)?
answer:
['Your MediSave payable is based on your age and net trade income for the year. You can use the [Self-Employed MediSave Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/SelfEmployedMedisaveContribution/SelfEmployedMedisaveContributionLanding) to calculate the amount of MediSave you need to contribute.
View the MediSave rates applicable from [2016 onwards](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2016.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [2015](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2015.pdf) (PDF, 23KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [2014](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2014onwards.pdf) (PDF, 60KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [2013](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2013.pdf) (PDF, 54KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [2012](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2012.pdf) (PDF, 52KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [2011](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2011.pdf) (PDF, 28KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [2010](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates2010.pdf) (PDF, 28KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [the years 2007 to 2009](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates20072009.pdf) (PDF, 19KB).
View the MediSave rates applicable for [the years 1992 to 2006](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/MARates19922006.pdf) (PDF, 19KB).']

question: How do I request a refund of my excess MediSave contributions?
answer:
['You may request a refund of your excess MediSave contributions if your:
1. net trade income is reassessed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)\*, or
2. payment is made in error^; or
3. voluntary CPF top ups were made in excess of the CPF Annual Limit for the year.
Please complete the [Refund of CPF/MediSave Contributions by Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplicationForRefundOrMedisaveContributions/RefundOrMedisaveContributionsCoverPage) form using your Singpass.
\*Requests for refund due to reassessment of income by IRAS must be made within one year from the date of the revised Notice of Assessment.
^Requests for refund due to payment made in error must be made within one year from the date of contribution.']

question: How do I apply to adjust my CPF Contributions from the firm√¢¬Ä¬ôs account to a self-employed person√¢¬Ä¬ôs account?
answer:
['You may submit an online application via [*my cpf*digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyRequest/MyRequestLanding) using Singpass to adjust your CPF Contributions from the firm√¢¬Ä¬ôs account to your self-employed account.
The adjustment request must be made within one year from the date of payment.']

question: I am a self-employed person. Can I contribute to my MediSave together with my employees√¢¬Ä¬ô CPF using the CPF Payment Form (CPF 91)?
answer:
['You√¢¬Ä¬ôre required to make your MediSave payable separately from your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô CPF. This is because payments made using the CPF Payment Form (CPF 91) will be credited as employer contributions and will not be recognized as self-employed payments.
If you would like to make CPF contributions as a self-employed person, there are [various ways](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/self-employed-scheme/how-can-i-make-my-medisave-contributions) to do so.']

question: What are the benefits of contributing to MediSave by GIRO?
answer:
['GIRO allows you to contribute to your MediSave Account over a period of 12 monthly instalments. It is most convenient as the contributions are automatically deducted from your bank account and you can easily monitor them. Contributing to MediSave by GIRO also provides a hassle-free licence application and renewal process.
You may apply to pay via GIRO online (if you have a bank account from OCBC / DBS / POSB) or by mail (for other banks).
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Payment mode** | **Details** |
| GIRO | Using *my√Ç¬†cpf*√Ç¬†digital services (for OCBC/DBS/POSB bank account)1. Log in with your Singpass.
2. Submit the√Ç¬†[Apply / Change GIRO for Mandatory MediSave Contributions and Voluntary Contributions by Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/GiroApplication/LandingPage?scheme=SE)√Ç¬†application.
3. Check the status of your GIRO application via My activities.
Mail (for other banks)1. Download and complete the [Apply for GIRO for Mandatory Contributions or Voluntary Contributions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/tools/documents/FORM_GIRO_SEVC.pdf)√Ç¬†form (FORM GIRO SE/VC (PDF, 0.6MB)).
2. Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form.
3. We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it.
|']

question: How do I change my bank account for GIRO instalments for my MediSave contributions?
answer:
['If your bank account is with DBS/POSB or OCBC, please complete the [Apply / Change GIRO for Mandatory MediSave Contributions and Voluntary Contributions by Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/GiroApplication/LandingPage?scheme=SE)√Ç¬†using your Singpass. You will be re-directed to DBS/POSB or OCBC√¢¬Ä¬ôs ibanking portal to complete the application. You can check the status of your online application through[*my cpf* digital services - My activities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/CpfMemberPortalServices) with your Singpass.
If you would like to use an account from other banks, please download and submit the [Apply for GIRO for Mandatory Contributions or Voluntary Contributions (FORM GIRO SE/VC)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/tools/documents/FORM_GIRO_SEVC.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) to the Board. Deduction will be made from the existing bank account until the new GIRO arrangement takes effect.']

question: Why does CPF Board take self-employed persons to court for not contributing to their MediSave?
answer:
['Self-employed persons (SEPs) are required under the CPF Act to contribute to their MediSave. This ensures that SEPs have enough MediSave savings for their healthcare needs, especially during old age when they have stopped working. SEPs without enough MediSave savings and MediShield Life cover may need to tap on other sources of funds such as their family members√¢¬Ä¬ô MediSave savings should they be hospitalised.
The CPF Board will continue to be flexible towards those with genuine financial difficulties. SEPs can request [instalment plans](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/self-employed-scheme/can-i-settle-my-outstanding-medisave-contributions-by-instalment) to settle the outstanding amounts over a reasonable period. The CPF Board will only take recalcitrant defaulters to court as the last resort.']

question: Why do I still need to contribute to MediSave as a self-employed person even though I have already bought insurance for myself?
answer:
['All working Singapore residents are required to contribute to their MediSave as a form of savings for their own and their loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô healthcare needs.
Many Singaporeans have bought private hospital insurance plans in the form of Integrated Shield Plans, or IPs. IPs comprise of two parts √¢¬Ä¬ì MediShield Life (MSL) which is a universal basic health insurance plan, and additional private insurance coverage. MediSave can be used to pay the premiums for both MSL and private insurance, up to the current withdrawal limit.
Hence, private medical insurance serves to complement rather than replace your MediSave savings.']

question: If I do not earn any net trade income for the year, can I renew my licence?
answer: ['You can renew your licence so long as there is no outstanding MediSave payable or you have signed up to pay your MediSave payable via monthly GIRO instalments.']

question: If I do not intend to renew my licence, do I need to settle my outstanding MediSave payable?
answer: ['You√¢¬Ä¬ôre required to pay your outstanding MediSave payable even if you do not intend to renew your licence.']

question: I have a partnership firm. Do all partners need to make MediSave contributions before renewing the business licence?
answer: ['All partners (if they derive trade income) must fulfil their MediSave payable before the business licence can be renewed.']

question: Do I have to pay my MediSave payable when I am no longer self-employed?
answer:
['You√¢¬Ä¬ôre still required to settle any outstanding MediSave payable, as it is compulsory under the CPF Act to contribute to your MediSave Account for the years that you were self-employed.
If you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, please refer to this [FAQ](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/what-happens-to-my-cpf-contributions0).']

question: Do I still have to contribute to MediSave as a self-employed person even though my MediSave balance has reached the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS)?
answer:
['As a self-employed person (SEP), you are still required to make MediSave contributions even if you have met the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). This is the same for employees.
The MediSave amount above the BHS will be transferred to your CPF Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA), which have interest rates equal or higher than that of the MediSave Account. The BHS cap and overflow arrangement are intentionally planned to avoid over savings in MediSave and to supplement your retirement savings. These overflows which end up in your SA or RA can be withdrawn according to the withdrawal guidelines. For members who have met the Full Retirement Sum in their SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.']

question: I have substantial balances in my Ordinary and Special Accounts. Can I use the available funds to offset my MediSave payable?
answer: ['The three CPF accounts, Ordinary, Special and MediSave Accounts, serve different purposes. While Ordinary and Special Account savings are meant for retirement, your MediSave Account savings are for your healthcare needs. Thus, the balances in your Ordinary and Special accounts cannot be used to settle your MediSave payable.']

question: Why do I still need to contribute to MediSave even though I already have enough savings for my healthcare needs?
answer: ['With rising healthcare costs, it is important to have enough savings for your healthcare needs. Contributing regularly to MediSave will help you build up your savings over your working life. These savings can help you meet your own as well as your loved ones√¢¬Ä¬ô hospitalisation expenses under unforeseen circumstances.']

question: What is the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: ['The Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme is a tripartite co-contribution scheme initiated by the National Taxi Association (NTA) and the taxi industry, and supported by the Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board. DAS aims to enhance the welfare of all taxi principal hirers.']

question: Who is eligible for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: ['Under the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme, all taxi principal hirers who make regular contributions to their MediSave Account are eligible to receive co-contributions from their taxi operators.']

question: How do I register for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer:
['No registration is required for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme.
Taxi principal hirers who contribute at least $20 monthly to their MediSave Account will be eligible to receive a co-contribution of $20\* monthly from their taxi operators.
\*Terms and conditions apply']

question: What sources of MediSave contributions are eligible for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution?
answer: ['MediSave contributions made by the taxi principal hirer as a self-employed person will qualify him/her for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution. CPF contributions received as an employee (from both employer and self) for taxi principal hirers who are concurrently employed, as well as government top-ups are excluded.']

question: Will I receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions if I make a lump sum payment?
answer: ['You√¢¬Ä¬ôll receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions of $20 monthly, provided you have contributed at least $240 into your MediSave Account in the past 12 months.']

question: How does each taxi operator know the Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution amount?
answer: ['Every month, CPF Board will inform the participating taxi operators of the details of eligible taxi principal hirers who have qualified for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions. Exact contribution amounts will not be revealed.']

question: Can taxi drivers who are not liable to make a MediSave contribution qualify for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution from their taxi operators?
answer:
['Taxi drivers who do not have outstanding MediSave payable can still receive Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions if they make:
* a voluntary top-up of at least $20 to their MediSave Account monthly, or
* a lump sum MediSave contribution of at least $240 in the past 12 months.']

question: If I participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme, will my Taxi Vocational Licence (TDVL) be automatically renewed?
answer:
['No, your Taxi Driver Vocational Licence (TDVL) will not be automatically renewed if you participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme.
Taxi principal hirers must have fully paid their MediSave contributions or are making monthly payments via GIRO to renew their TDVLs.
Your MediSave contributions and the co-contributions from your taxi operators will go towards meeting your self-employed MediSave payable.']

question: How does regular MediSave co-contributions received under the Drive and Save (DAS) benefit me?
answer:
['Under the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme, the regular MediSave co-contributions from your taxi operator can:
* Offset your mandatory MediSave contributions under the Self-Employed Scheme
* Earn up to 6% interest per annum (p.a.) on your MediSave savings This includes an additional 1% interest p.a. on the first $60,000 of your combined balances (with up to $20,000 from the Ordinary Account). CPF members aged 55 and above will also earn an additional 1% interest p.a. on the first $30,000 of their combined CPF balances.
* Pay MediShield Life/ Integrated Shield Plan premiums for you and your loved ones (spouse, children, parents, grandparents or siblings)
* Qualify to receive√Ç¬†[Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)](/member/growing-your-savings/government-support/workfare-income-supplement) payouts in cash and in your MediSave Account. Terms and conditions apply.']

question: Can I settle my outstanding MediSave payable by instalments through GIRO?
answer:
['You can settle your outstanding MediSave payable by instalments through GIRO.
If your bank account is with DBS/POSB or OCBC, please complete the "[Apply / Change GIRO for Mandatory MediSave Contributions and Voluntary Contributions by Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/GiroApplication/LandingPage?scheme=SE)√¢¬Ä¬ù using your Singpass. You will be re-directed to DBS/POSB or OCBC√¢¬Ä¬ôs ibanking portal to complete the application. You can check the status of your online application through [*my cpf*√Ç¬†digital services - My activities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/CpfMemberPortalServices) with your Singpass.√Ç¬†If you wish to use an account from other banks, please download and submit the [√¢¬Ä¬úApply for GIRO for Mandatory Contributions or Voluntary Contributions√¢¬Ä¬ù (FORM GIRO SE/VC)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/tools/documents/FORM_GIRO_SEVC.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) to the CPF Board. Deduction will be made from the existing bank account until the new GIRO arrangement takes effect.
After your GIRO application is approved, we will inform you about your upfront and monthly instalment amounts via a notification. You can also view your GIRO instalment plan details via [Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment) after logging in with your Singpass.
If you are facing financial difficulties and need to defer your MediSave contributions, please contact us via our [Online Enquiry Form](http://cpf.gov.sg/writetous).']

question: How do I submit a request to re-activate my existing GIRO arrangement for my MediSave contributions?
answer: ['To reactivate your GIRO arrangement for your MediSave contributions, you can submit an online application [Reactivate Existing GIRO Arrangement for Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ReactivateGiro/CoverPage)√Ç¬†using your Singpass.']

question: How do I terminate my GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person?
answer: ['You may submit an online application [Termination of GIRO Arrangement for Mandatory and/or Voluntary Contributions for Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/TerminationOfGiroForEmployee/CoverPage?RequestType=1)√Ç¬†using your Singpass if you wish to terminate your GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person.']

question: How can I request a copy of my GIRO instalment plan for MediSave contributions?
answer:
['You can view your GIRO instalment plan details by logging in to [Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment) using your Singpass.
You can [apply for your Singpass online](http://www.singpass.gov.sg/) if you do not have one.']

question: What do I need to do to reactivate my GIRO arrangement as a self-employed person?
answer: ['You would have received a notification informing you to make good the missed deductions and reactivate your GIRO arrangement within 14 days of the notification. To reactivate your GIRO arrangement, please complete the [Re-activate Existing GIRO Arrangement](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ReactivateGiro/CoverPage) form using your Singpass. You can also check the status of your online application through [*my cpf*digital service](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/MemberPortalServices)√Ç¬†√¢¬Ä¬ì My activities with your Singpass.']

question: What is the status of my appeal to make self-employed MediSave contributions via monthly instalments?
answer:
['We will keep you informed about the status of your appeal to make self-employed MediSave contributions via monthly instalments, once it has been processed.
Please note our normal processing time:
√Ç¬∑ Requests made via online appeal and chat form: 12 working days
√Ç¬∑ Manual transactions: 15 working days
If you have submitted your appeal through the chat form, please note that it is currently in its pilot phase. You can check the status of your appeal by clicking on this [link](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivityHardcopyActivities).
Alternatively, you can log in to your [Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment "https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment") using your Singpass to view your approved GIRO instalment plan details.']

question: Why was my MediSave instalment amount changed?
answer: ['The instalment amount for self-employed contributions will change if the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has assessed/reassessed your net trade income, or there are ad hoc MediSave contributions which have been used to offset your MediSave payable.']

question: If I contribute to all three CPF accounts as a self-employed person, do I still have to top up my MediSave Account?
answer:
['Only the portion credited to your MediSave Account can be used to offset your MediSave payable as a self-employed. If there is still outstanding MediSave payable, you are required to contribute to your MediSave to meet the shortfall.
Contributions to your CPF Ordinary and Special accounts are voluntary and cannot be used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable or transferred to your MediSave Account to meet the MediSave shortfall.']

question: How do I submit a Standing Instruction to make voluntary top-ups via GIRO as a self-employed person?
answer:
['You can submit an online application√Ç¬†[**Standing Instruction (SI) for Voluntary Contributions via GIRO for Self-Employed Person**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/StandingInstructionForVoluntaryContribution/CoverPage)√Ç¬†together with the√Ç¬†[**Apply / Change GIRO for Mandatory MediSave Contributions and Voluntary Contributions by Self-Employed Person**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/GiroApplication/LandingPage?scheme=SE)√Ç¬†using your Singpass. You will be re-directed to DBS or OCBC's ibanking portal to complete the GIRO application. You can check the status of your online application through√Ç¬†[***my cpf*√Ç¬†digital services**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/MemberPortalServices)- My activities using your Singpass.
If you wish to apply GIRO using other bank accounts, please download and submit the√Ç¬†[**Apply for GIRO for Mandatory Contributions or Voluntary Contributions form (FORM GIRO SE/VC) (PDF, 0.1MB)**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/tools/documents/FORM_GIRO_SEVC.pdf)√Ç¬†to the Board.']

question: Can I enjoy tax relief as a self-employed person when I transfer the savings in my Ordinary and/or Special accounts to my MediSave Account?
answer:
['You can only enjoy tax relief as a self-employed person if you make voluntary cash top-ups and not through transfer of savings in your Ordinary and/or Special Account(s) to your MediSave Account.
There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed net trade income for the year of assessment is zero or negative.
Alternatively, you can also receive tax relief when making cash top-ups via the [Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-to-enjoy-higher-retirement-payouts).']

question: How long does it take to process applications relating to the Self-Employed Scheme?
answer:
['The applications relating to the Self-Employed Scheme will generally be processed within the service standards as stated in the table below. We strive to process all submitted applications within the service standard and will let you know if more time is needed.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing time** |
| **Appeal for Instalment Payments by Self-Employed Person** | **Online**: 12 working days**Manual**: 15 working days |
| **Refund of CPF/MediSave Contributions by Self-Employed Person** | **Online**: 12 working days**Manual**: 15 working daysThis includes time needed to liaise with other parties or seek clarification on your refund application. |
| **Adjust Self-Employed Contributions** |
| **Make Contribution to CPF Accounts for Self-Employed Person** | a. Payment via PayNow /OCBC Pay Anyone: Will generally be processed almost instantlyb. Cash/Cheque Payment: 10 working days |
| **Make Contribution to MediSave Account for Self-Employed Person** |
| **Self-Employed Person Income Declaration Form** | **Online**: Eight working days**Manual**: 10 working days |
| **Re-activate Existing Giro Arrangement for Self-Employed Person** | **Online**: Next working day**Manual**: Five working days |']

question: I am not a self-employed person. Why did I receive a Notice of Computation (NOC) from IRAS?
answer:
['You are registered as a self-employed in our records as the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) had transmitted your net trade income to the Board, under your occupation as a Commission Agent. Examples of Commission Agents are Property Agents, Insurance Agents, Multi-Level Marketing Members, etc. Please note that if you are receiving commission for your services, you are considered a self-employed person (SEP).
SEPs will receive a Notice of Computation (NOC) from IRAS informing them of the MediSave payable (if any), after IRAS has completed the income assessment for the year.
If you disagree/require further clarification on the assessed income by IRAS, you can email them through the secured√Ç¬†[MyTax Mail](https://mytax.iras.gov.sg/). Should IRAS re-classify your income, your self-employed status and MediSave payable (if any) will also be updated accordingly.']

question: I have more than one source of trade income. Do I have to contribute to MediSave for all of them?
answer:
['Your MediSave contributions are based on the annual net trade income (NTI) from all your trades. If you have a yearly NTI of more than $6,000 from all your trades, you√¢¬Ä¬ôre required to make contributions to your MediSave Account.
You can refer to this [example](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/Example%20of%20MediSave%20computation%20for%20SEP.pdf) of how MediSave payable is computed on multiple sources of NTI.']

question: How can I make my MediSave contributions?
answer:
['There are several ways you can contribute to your MediSave. The most convenient way is via GIRO, which allows automatic monthly deductions from your bank account.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| Payment mode | Details |
| GIRO | Using√Ç¬†*my cpf*√Ç¬†digital services (for OCBC/DBS/POSB bank account)1. Log in with your Singpass.
2. Submit the√Ç¬†[Apply / Change GIRO for Mandatory MediSave Contributions and Voluntary Contributions by Self-Employed Person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/GiroApplication/LandingPage?scheme=SE)√Ç¬†application.
3. Check the status of your GIRO application via My Activities.
Mail (for other banks)1. Download and complete the [Apply for GIRO for Mandatory Contributions or Voluntary Contributions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/tools/documents/FORM_GIRO_SEVC.pdf)√Ç¬†form (FORM GIRO SE/VC (PDF, 0.6MB)).
2. Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form.
3. We will notify you of your GIRO application status once the bank has processed it.
|
| [e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage) | - Make payment via PayNow and your payment will generally be processed almost immediately. |
| NETS/ CashCard | - Pay by NETS or CashCard at√Ç¬†any SingPost branches |
You may log in with your Singpass to check that your MediSave contribution is reflected in the√Ç¬†[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)√Ç¬†or check the transaction status under√Ç¬†*Transaction*√Ç¬†*History*(if you have paid via e-Cashier).']

question: What is the approach taken by CPF Board in enforcing MediSave contributions from self-employed persons?
answer: ['Each year, self-employed persons (SEPs) are notified by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) via the Notice of Computation (NOC) to pay their MediSave payable in full or by monthly instalments through GIRO. The CPF Board may enforce payments from SEPs only if they have failed to make payments after repeated reminders.']

question: What if self-employed persons do not respond to the Notice of Computation (NOC)?
answer:
['If self-employed persons (SEPs) do not respond to the NOC, the CPF Board may issue them a Letter of Demand and Offer which requires them to pay up their outstanding MediSave contributions, together with the payment of the composition amount offered. If there is still no payment, the Board may issue them a Notice to Attend Court.
SEPs who are brought to court may face a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment of up to 6 months or both for first time offenders, and up to $10,000 or imprisonment of up to 12 months or both for subsequent offences.']

question: How do I make voluntary top-ups as a self-employed person?
answer:
['You can make voluntary top-ups via [e-Cashier as a self-employed person](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage). The steps are listed below.
1. Key in your NRIC number
2. Under 'Paying as a' select √¢¬Ä¬òSelf-Employed√¢¬Ä¬ô
3. Under 'Payment for' select 'Contribute to my three CPF accounts' or √¢¬Ä¬òContribute to my MediSave√¢¬Ä¬ô
4. Verify that you are not a robot and click √¢¬Ä¬òNext√¢¬Ä¬ô
5. Read the important notes and click 'Start'
6. Key in the amount and click 'Next' to pay using PayNow QR with your PayNow participating bank√¢¬Ä¬ôs app. Please note that the transaction amount is capped at your PayNow limit with your bank.
Note: If the voluntary top-ups to the MediSave Account are less than your MediSave payable as a self-employed, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll need to top up the difference in cash. You√¢¬Ä¬ôll not be able to transfer your voluntary top-ups from your Ordinary or Special accounts to meet the MediSave shortfall.']

question: Can I enjoy tax relief as a self-employed person when I make voluntary top-ups?
answer:
['Self-employed persons (SEPs) can enjoy tax relief on their mandatory and voluntary CPF contributions based on their annual net trade income (NTI). However, there is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.
You can enjoy tax relief on your mandatory and voluntary contributions based on whichever is lower:
* 37% of assessable income; or
* CPF Annual Limit of $37,740; or
* Actual amount contributed by you
Please note that there will be a personal income tax relief cap of $80,000 which will apply from Year of Assessment 2018. This cap applies to the total amount of all tax reliefs claimed, including any relief on voluntary contributions made on or after 1 January 2017.
As accepted voluntary CPF top-ups cannot be refunded, you should evaluate whether you would benefit from tax relief on your voluntary CPF top-ups and make an informed decision. Please visit the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/employees/deductions-for-individuals/personal-reliefs-and-tax-rebates/compulsory-and-voluntary-medisave-contributions) for more information.']

question: What is the cut-off date for self-employed CPF contributions to be eligible for tax relief?
answer:
['To be eligible for tax relief for the year, the mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions made by self-employed persons must be credited to their CPF accounts by the last working day of the year.
If you have made mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions during the year, the contribution amounts will be automatically transmitted to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for tax relief in the following year.
There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed net trade income for the year of assessment is zero or negative.
For more details on tax deductions, please visit the [IRAS website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/individual-income-tax/employees/deductions-for-individuals) or call the Individual Income Tax / Property Tax Helpline at 1800-356-8300.']

question: As a self-employed person, can I make voluntary top-ups to the Ordinary and Special accounts?
answer:
['As a self-employed person, you can make voluntary top-ups to your three CPF accounts. The voluntary top-ups will be apportioned and credited to your Ordinary, Special and MediSave accounts. Please refer to the [CPF Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-contribution-calculator) for more details.
The total voluntary and mandatory contributions made for the calendar year should not exceed the current [CPF Annual Limit](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/top-up-your-cpf-accounts-to-build-your-savings/what-is-the-voluntary-top-up-limit-to-my-three-cpf-accounts). The Board must receive the voluntary top-ups by the last working day of the year for it to be counted towards the year√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF Annual Limit. Backdating of voluntary top-ups to previous years is not allowed.
Once your mandatory and voluntary contributions reach the current CPF Annual Limit, no further voluntary top-ups can be made. Any voluntary top-ups made in excess of the CPF Annual Limit will be refunded without interest.']

question: Can I renew/apply my licence if I have outstanding MediSave payable?
answer:
['Licensing authorities will only process your licence renewal/application if your MediSave payable are up-to-date.
You can check your MediSave contribution status, make full/partial payments or apply GIRO by logging onto the [Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment) using your Singpass.
There is no need to show proof of payment to the licensing authorities as we will update them on your MediSave contributions status.
You can [apply for your Singpass online](http://www.singpass.gov.sg/) if you do not have one.']

question: What are the conditions for applying to limit my MediSave payable as a self-employed person?
answer:
['You can apply to limit your MediSave payable if your total employment income (excluding Additional Wages) for the year exceeds $72,000.
Additional Wages are wage supplements which are not granted wholly and exclusively for the month. Examples are the annual bonus, leave pay, incentive and other payments made at intervals of more than a month.
Please refer to the table below for the total employment income (excluding Additional Wages) that qualifies you to limit your MediSave contributions as a self-employed person.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Year** | **Total Annual Income** |
| 1993 √¢¬Ä¬ì 2003 | $72,000 |
| 2004 | $66,000 |
| 2005 | $60,000 |
| 2006 √¢¬Ä¬ì 2010 | $54,000 |
| 2011 | $56,000 |
| 2012 √¢¬Ä¬ì 2015 | $60,000 |
| 2016 onwards | $72,000 |']

question: Do I still have to contribute to my MediSave if I am both a self-employed person as well as an employee working in another company?
answer:
['If you earn an annual [net trade income](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/self-employed-scheme/what-is-net-trade-income) of more than $6,000, you are required to contribute to your MediSave Account as a self-employed person (SEP).
CPF contribution is based on your total income. Therefore, an SEP who is also an employee at the same time, is required to contribute to MediSave as an SEP. This is the same for employees who hold more than one job and are required to pay CPF contributions for all the wages they receive.
However, you can apply to limit the MediSave payable on your self-employed income if your total employment income (excluding Additional Wages\*) for the year exceeds $72,000. You may refer to this [FAQ](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/self-employed-scheme/what-are-the-conditions-for-applying-to-limit-my-medisave) for more information on the conditions for this application.
\*Additional Wages are wage supplements which are not granted wholly and exclusively for the month. Examples are the annual bonus, leave pay, incentive and other payments made at intervals of more than a month.
To limit your MediSave contributions, you may write to us via our [Online Enquiry Form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index) or [My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyMailbox/MyMailboxLanding) using your Singpass.']

question: How do I check my voluntary top-up limit to my three CPF accounts as a self-employed person?
answer:
['You can use our√Ç¬†[e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage)√Ç¬†to check the amount of voluntary top-ups you can make. Follow the steps below:
* Key in your NRIC number
* Select paying as a √¢¬Ä¬òSelf-employed√¢¬Ä¬ô and making payment for √¢¬Ä¬òContribute to my three CPF Accounts√¢¬Ä¬ô or √¢¬Ä¬òContribute to my MediSave√¢¬Ä¬ô
* Click √¢¬Ä¬òNext√¢¬Ä¬ô
* Read and accept the Terms and Conditions, and click √¢¬Ä¬òStart√¢¬Ä¬ô
* Click √¢¬Ä¬òCheck Allowable Contribution'
* Log in with your Singpass
You will see a message on the amount you can contribute. This result is valid only if you do not expect to receive any more mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary top-ups before the end of the year.
If the total mandatory CPF contributions and voluntary top-ups exceed the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, any excess voluntary top-ups will be refunded without interest. Therefore, do remember to consider your mandatory CPF contributions which you will be receiving for the calendar year, before making voluntary top-ups.']

question: Do I still have to pay my outstanding MediSave contributions if I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency?
answer: ['With effect from 1 March 2024, the outstanding MediSave payable will be waived automatically when you renounce your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.']

question: How can I declare my net trade income from Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) onwards?
answer:
['Your Net Trade Income (NTI) may be declared to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) by filing a tax return. IRAS'√Ç¬†[myTax Portal](https://mytax.iras.gov.sg/ESVWeb/default.aspx)√Ç¬†will be available from 1 March 2024 to 31 October 2024 to e-File a tax return.
If you wish to declare NTI for work years prior to 2023, you may still do so via the Self-Employed Income Declaration Form which is available on *[my cpf online services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/IncomeDeclarationBySelfEmployedPersonForMedisaveLiability/LandingPage)*.']

question: What is Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['Under the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme, a MediSave contribution is required as and when a self-employed person (SEP) earns a service fee. Every time a service fee is paid to the SEP, the corporate service buyers (CSBs) or intermediaries making the payment will first deduct and credit a portion of the service fee to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account, before paying the remainder of the service fee to the SEP.
CAYE does not change the amount of MediSave contributions SEPs have to make based on their net trade income.
SEPs who provide services to government agencies are automatically enrolled into CAYE.']

question: As a self-employed person, how will I benefit from participating in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['Through making smaller and more regular MediSave contributions as and when you receive a service fee, Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) makes saving for your healthcare needs through your MediSave Account (MA) easier. MediSave savings can be used to pay for your out-of-pocket healthcare expenses and MediShield Life premiums.
As a self-employed person (SEP), there are many issues that require your attention. CAYE is an easy and hassle-free way to help free up more of your time. For your convenience, your CAYE contributions are automatically deposited into your MA whenever you get paid. This would also be helpful for SEPs whose income may be seasonal. CAYE can also help grow your money as you can start to earn an interest of up to 5% on your MediSave savings earlier.']

question: How will participating in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) affect my MediSave contributions payable?
answer:
['Self-employed persons (SEPs) are required to contribute to their MediSave Account (MA) if their annual Net Trade Income (NTI) is more than $6,000. Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) does not change the amount of MediSave contributions you have to make based on your NTI. The only change concerns how the contributions are made. Under CAYE, the agency/company you provided a service to will help you contribute into your MA each time it makes a service payment to you.
Your CAYE contributions are based on your estimated annual revenue and expenses. Thus, CAYE contributions are an estimate of your MediSave payable. After you declare your NTI for the year, your MediSave payable will be computed.
If your total Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions are higher than your MediSave payable for the latest year, your excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years1. Any remaining CAYE contributions will then be refunded to you.
If your total CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll be required to top up the remaining amount. You√¢¬Ä¬ôll be notified accordingly, and you can choose to make payment via lump-sum payment(s) or sign up for GIRO instalments.
1This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Please [write to us](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.']

question: As a self-employed person, how will the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme affect me?
answer: ['Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) helps you save for your healthcare needs through smaller and more regular MediSave contributions each time you receive a payment. There is no change to your MediSave contributions payable as it would still be based on your actual Net Trade Income.']

question: What if I am in financial hardship and is unable to set aside monies for MediSave via the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme?
answer: ['We understand that some self-employed persons (SEPs) may be facing financial difficulties and may not be able to cope with Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE). Thus, if you do not have outstanding MediSave payable or are contributing via GIRO instalments, you may set your CAYE contribution rate to 0%. This means that you√¢¬Ä¬ôll receive your service payment in full, and CAYE contribution will not be deducted from your service payment. Please write to us at self-employed@cpf.gov.sg if you wish to apply for a 0% CAYE contribution rate. CPF Board will assess your eligibility and inform you of the outcome in writing.']

question: Who must participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['SEPs who are individual freelancers or sole proprietors and were awarded jobs with Government agencies will automatically be enrolled into CAYE.
Private companies are also encouraged to voluntarily onboard CAYE to help the SEPs who they have contracted with, save for their healthcare and retirement needs in an easier manner.']

question: As a self-employed person who provides services to Government agencies, how will I be enrolled into Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['You√¢¬Ä¬ôll be automatically enrolled into Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) when you receive a service payment from a Government agency you have provided services to as a self-employed person (SEP). You√¢¬Ä¬ôll receive a notification from CPF Board when you receive your first payment via CAYE. Subsequently, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll also receive a notification each time you receive a payment via CAYE.']

question: I have already contributed up to the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). Why am I still required to participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['As a self-employed person, you√¢¬Ä¬ôre still required to make MediSave contributions even if you have met the Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). This is from the same for employees.
The MediSave amount above the BHS will be transferred to your CPF Special Account (SA) or Retirement Account (RA), which have interest rates equal or higher than that of the MediSave Account. The BHS cap and overflow arrangement are intentionally planned to avoid over savings in MediSave and to supplement your retirement savings. These overflows which end up in your SA or RA can be withdrawn according to the [withdrawal guidelines](/member/retirement-income).√Ç¬†If you√¢¬Ä¬ôve met the Full Retirement Sum in your SA or RA, the savings in excess of the BHS will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA). Savings in the OA can be used for other purposes such as housing repayment.']

question: I have contributed up to the maximum mandatory contributions for the year. Do I still have to make Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer:
['If you√¢¬Ä¬ôve made Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions up to the maximum MediSave payable for the year, your applicable CAYE contribution rate will be 0%. This means that you will receive your service fee in full, and CAYE contribution will no longer be deducted from your service fee.
However, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll still be required to make good your outstanding MediSave payable (if any) via lump-sum payment(s) or GIRO instalment plan.']

question: Will self-employed persons who provide services to the private sector be mandated to participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['The Government, as a service buyer, has piloted Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) since 1 January 2020. There are currently no plans to extend CAYE into the private sector. Nonetheless, companies in the private sector are encouraged to voluntarily adopt CAYE.']

question: What if I prefer making MediSave contributions through the current payment modes (e.g. GIRO)?
answer:
['The small and regular MediSave contributions made through Contribute-As-You-earn (CAYE) help self-employed persons (SEPs) to reduce the MediSave contributions payable in the following year (after SEPs declare their Net Trade Income and have their MediSave payable computed).
If you√¢¬Ä¬ôve made your MediSave contributions in full or are on GIRO instalment plan, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll be allowed to set your CAYE contribution rate to 0% and receive your service fee in full.']

question: What if I do not wish to participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['Self-employed persons (SEPs) who have completed a job with Government agencies will be automatically enrolled into CAYE. CAYE will not apply to SEPs who completed jobs with the private sector.
The√Ç¬†CAYE scheme helps SEPs save for their healthcare needs through smaller and more regular MediSave contributions each time they receive a service payment. This helps to reduce the MediSave payable in the following year (after SEPs declare their Net Trade Income and have their MediSave payable computed).√Ç¬†CAYE will help with the upkeep of current MediSave obligations and prevent snowballing of the payable.
You can choose to set your CAYE contribution rate to 0% if you√¢¬Ä¬ôve made your MediSave contributions in full or are on GIRO instalment plan.
If you√¢¬Ä¬ôre in financial hardship and unable to set aside monies for your CAYE contributions, you may [write to√Ç¬†us](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous). We will assess your request and inform you of the outcome in writing.']

question: Under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), how much MediSave contribution would I have to make from my service fee?
answer:
['Under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), the amount of MediSave contribution deducted from your service fee is based on your estimated annual revenue and expenses for the year.
Your CAYE contribution rate is determined by the following formula:
| |
| --- |
| CAYE contribution rate = **(A x B) / C**where **A** is the MediSave contribution rate for your estimated annual Net Trade Income (NTI)1 and age for the year;**B** is your estimated annual NTI1 for the year2; and**C** is your estimated annual revenue for the year21 Your estimated annual NTI is derived using your estimated annual revenue less estimated annual expenses for the year.2 If you did not provide your estimated annual revenue and expenses for the year, it will be based on your actual revenue and expenses assessed by IRAS two years ago. |
A floor CAYE contribution rate of 2% will apply if you have earned more than $6,000 two years ago.
To ensure that your CAYE contribution rate reflects your business outlook for the year accurately, please estimate your revenue and expenses by logging in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)*using your Singpass, under *Contribute-As-You-Earn > Update contribution rate*. You can adjust your CAYE contribution rate as and when there are changes to your estimated revenue and expenses.√Ç¬†Generally, your updated rate will apply to payments made from the next day.
Otherwise, a personalised default CAYE contribution rate computed based on your NTI assessed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) two years ago will apply.
[Example on how the CAYE contribution rate will be computed](/content/dam/web/member/faq/growing-your-savings/documents/Example%20on%20how%20the%20CAYE%20contribution%20rate%20will%20be%20computed.pdf)']

question: How do I estimate my annual revenue and expenses for the year?
answer: ['You can estimate your annual revenue and expenses for the current year based on the actual revenue and expenses you earned last year. You can adjust your estimated annual revenue and expenses whenever you foresee any changes in revenue (e.g. increase in number of jobs in the current year) or expenses (e.g. increase in business cost).']

question: How do I adjust my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
answer: ['If there are changes to your estimated revenue or expenses for the year, you may update and re-compute your Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate by logging in to the [*Self-employment dashboard*](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment) using your Singpass, under√Ç¬†*Contribute-As-You-Earn > Update contribution rate*.√Ç¬†Generally, your updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to payments made from the next day.']

question: When should I adjust my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
answer: ['You can adjust your Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate by updating your estimated revenue or expense whenever you foresee any changes in revenue (e.g. increase in number of jobs in the current year) or expenses (e.g. increase in business cost).']

question: I have adjusted my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate. When will the updated rate take effect?
answer: ['Generally, your updated Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate will apply to service fees paid from the next day.']

question: As a self-employed person, what if I incurred expenses by engaging other people to assist in my jobs (e.g. hire assistant coaches to assist or cover for lessons)?
answer: ['You can update your estimated expenses for the year to include the service fees paid to others for your jobs by logging in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)* using your Singpass, under *Contribute-As-You-Earn > Update contribution rate*. Your Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate will then be re-computed.√Ç¬†Generally, the updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to service fees paid from the next day.']

question: Why are different Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rates applied to different service fees?
answer: ['Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rates may change when you (i) update your CAYE contribution rate or (ii) are no longer required to make CAYE contributions.√Ç¬†Generally, the updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to service fees paid from the next day.']

question: Will the estimated income that I have provided for the computation of my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate be used as the income to compute my MediSave payable for the year?
answer:
['The income information you provided for Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) is only used to compute the CAYE contribution rate. It will not be used as your actual income to compute your MediSave payable for the year.
You√¢¬Ä¬ôll still need to declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) or CPF Board the following year. Your MediSave payable for the year will then be computed based on that NTI.']

question: How do I know if the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution amount and net service fee payment amount are made correctly?
answer:
['You can check your payment records by logging in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)*√Ç¬†using your Singpass, under *Contribute-As-You-Earn > Show all payments*.
If you√¢¬Ä¬ôve previously informed CPF Board of your contact details, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll also receive a notification whenever a contribution to your MediSave Account has been made via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE).√Ç¬†If you wish to update your contact details, you can do so via logging on to [*my cpf* digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings)√Ç¬†using your Singpass.']

question: Who do I contact for further details on my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee payment amount?
answer:
['To view your Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions and other payment details, you may log in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)*using your Singpass, under *Contribute-As-You-Earn > Show all payments*.√Ç¬†You can also [contact us through these channels](/member/contact-us).
For more details on the net service fee, please contact the company or agency you have contracted with directly. If there are any non-payment, short payment or late payment of service fees, you may wish to take up the dispute directly with your buyer and seek mediation through the [Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM)](https://www.tal.sg/tadm/Know-your-options "Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM)") or other industry facilitated mediation services.']

question: How does the company I contracted with know my Net Trade Income information and/or Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate?
answer: ['The company which you have contracted with will not have access to your Net Trade Income information. CPF Board will only inform the company of the amount that they would have to deduct from your service fee and transmit to your MediSave Account.']

question: What should I do if the company I contracted with did not pay my service fees?
answer: ['For any disputes on non-payment, short payment or late payment of service fees, you may wish to take up the dispute directly with the company or agency you have contracted with and seek mediation through the [Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM)](https://www.tal.sg/tadm/Know-your-options "Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM)") or other industry facilitated mediation services.']

question: Why do I still need to declare my income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board when I have already done so on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) digital services?
answer: ['The revenue and expenses information on the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) digital services is an estimate of your business outlook for the year and used only to compute your CAYE contribution rate. It is not a declaration of your actual Net Trade Income (NTI) and you are still required to declare your actual NTI in the following year to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) / CPF Board to compute your mandatory MediSave payable.']

question: Will I get into trouble if my actual income declared to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board in the following year is different from the income estimated on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) digital services?
answer: ['No, as the revenue and expenses information on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) digital services is an estimate of your business outlook for the year. You are still required to declare your actual Net Trade Income to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS)/ CPF Board to compute your MediSave payable for the year.']

question: Why do I still have outstanding MediSave payable when I am already on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Your Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions is an estimate of your MediSave payable for the year and may be lower or higher than your MediSave payable for the year. If your CAYE contributions are lower than your MediSave payable for the year, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll be required to top up the shortfall. You√¢¬Ä¬ôll also be required to make MediSave contributions for any outstanding MediSave payable incurred in previous years.']

question: Can I choose to retain my excess Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions in my MediSave Account?
answer: ['Yes, you can choose to retain your excess Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions in your MediSave Account. You may apply to do so by logging in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)* using your Singpass.']

question: How do I inform CPF Board of a different bank account to credit the refund of my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions in excess of my outstanding MediSave payable?
answer: ['You can inform CPF Board of your latest bank account to credit refund of excess Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions by logging in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)* using your Singpass.']

question: Can I use my excess Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions to offset my outstanding MediSave payable?
answer:
['CAYE contributions in excess of your MediSave payable for the year will be automatically used to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, if any1. Any excess thereafter will be refunded to your bank account.
You can also choose to boost your healthcare savings by retaining the excess CAYE contributions in your MediSave Account to earn up to 5% interest per annum, and to offset future MediSave payable. To do so, please apply via the√Ç¬†*[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)*√Ç¬†using your Singpass.
1This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. Please [write to us](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if you do not wish to use your CAYE contributions to offset your outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.']

question: Can I renew my licence if I have been making Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer: ['You can renew your licence so long as you have no outstanding MediSave payable or have made arrangements to settle your MediSave payable via monthly GIRO instalments.']

question: Why do I need to make other payment arrangements in order to renew my licence when I am already on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Your Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions are only based on an estimate of your MediSave payable for the current year. To renew your licence, you will need to pay your MediSave payable incurred in previous years via lump-sum payment(s) or monthly GIRO instalments.']

question: Where can I find guides on how to make Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) transactions?
answer: ['If you need assistance on how to make Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) transactions, you can refer to the [step-by-step guides](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/corporate-service-buyers/documents/Guide%20to%20using%20CAYE%20digital%20services%20(20211222).pdf), or call the CPF hotline.']

question: Who is eligible to receive the dollar-for-dollar matched MediSave contribution from the Government?
answer: ['Self-employed persons who have made contributions from 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2021 under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) are eligible to receive the one-off matched MediSave contributions.']

question: How much MediSave contributions will be matched for self-employed persons who made contributions under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Every dollar of contributions made for each self-employed person (SEP) from 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2021 under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) will receive dollar-for-dollar matched MediSave contribution from the Government. The total amount of matched MediSave contributions an SEP may receive is capped at $600 across both years.']

question: When will the matched MediSave contributions be paid?
answer:
['The matched MediSave contributions will be paid in four tranches, based on the following schedule:
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Tranche** | **Based on Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions made between** | **To be paid in** |
| 1 | 1 January 2020 and 30 June 2020\* | 3rd√Ç¬†quarter 2020 |
| 2 | 1 July 2020 and 31 December 2020\* | 1st√Ç¬†quarter 2021 |
| 3 | 1 January 2021 and 30 June 2021\* | 3rd√Ç¬†quarter 2021 |
| 4 | 1 July 2021 and 30 December 2021\* | 1st√Ç¬†quarter 2022 |
\* Both dates inclusive
CPF Board will notify the eligible self-employed persons of the payment via a notification. If you wish to update your contact details, you can do so via logging on to [*my cpf* digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings) using your Singpass.']

question: How do I check if the amount of matched MediSave contributions paid is accurate?
answer: ['You can check the amount of matched MediSave contributions you√¢¬Ä¬ôve received and the contributions you√¢¬Ä¬ôve made under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) by logging into the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)* using your Singpass, under *Contribute-As-You-Earn > View matched amount*.']

question: I have set my Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) to 0%. Can I still participate in CAYE and receive the matched MediSave contributions?
answer:
['To make contributions under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), you can update your CAYE contribution rate.
You can do so by logging in to the *[Self-employment dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/self-employment)* using your Singpass, under *Contribute-As-You-Earn > Update contribution rat*e. Your updated CAYE contribution rate will apply to payments made from the next day, and you√¢¬Ä¬ôll be eligible to receive matched MediSave contributions based on the CAYE contributions you make.']

question: I am a self-employed person making MediSave contributions. Why am I not given the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme?
answer: ['The Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme is only for eligible self-employed persons (SEPs) who participate in the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) pilot. This is because the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme is meant to help SEPs make a one-off transition to CAYE, which represents a change from the previous contribution model (yearly MediSave contribution after Notice of Assessment) to the CAYE model (smaller regular contribution as and when SEP receives payment from Government agencies as their corporate service buyers). SEPs who did not make any contributions under CAYE will not receive the matched contributions.']

question: Why was the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme (MMCS) extended for another year until 31 December 2021?
answer: ['Many self-employed persons (SEPs) had to defer their income and MediSave contributions due to the extraordinary circumstances in 2020. This resulted in a longer transition to Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) than expected. The extension of the qualifying period for another year, till 31 December 2021, will allow more SEPs to fully benefit from the Matched MediSave Contribution Scheme (MMCS).']

question: Does Contribute-As-You Earn (CAYE) contributions qualify for tax relief?
answer:
['Similar to other forms of self-employed CPF contributions, Contribute-As-You Earn (CAYE) contributions will qualify for tax relief based on the date of payment. CAYE contributions made in a calendar year will qualify for tax relief in the following year. For example, relief on CAYE contributions made between 1 January 2022 and 31 December 2022 will qualify for tax relief in the Year of Assessment (YA) 2023 subject to the assessable net trade income (NTI) for this YA.
The CPF relief allowable to self-employed persons (SEPs) for his MediSave and voluntary CPF contributions, including CAYE contributions, will be capped at 37% of his NTI assessed or CPF relief cap of $37,740 or the actual amount contributed by SEP whichever is the lowest.√Ç¬†There is no tax relief for your mandatory or voluntary CPF contributions if your assessed NTI for the year of assessment is zero or negative.']

question: How will the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme affect my income declaration to IRAS for tax purposes?
answer: ['There will be no change to√Ç¬†Self-Employed Person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs declaration of income for tax purposes. SEPs should continue to declare his annual income earned up to 31st December of the preceding year in the Income Tax Return for the current Year of Assessment (YA). For example, the SEP needs to declare his gross income for services provided between 1 January 2022 and 31 December 2022 in Income Tax Return for YA2023, even if it is invoiced only in January 2023. This is regardless of when the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions for the said services are made.']

question: What happens if the MediSave contributions I made via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) are lower than my MediSave payable for the year?
answer:
