question: I am a homemaker/caregiver/babysitter. Can I qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
answer: ['Allowances received for carrying out family support roles such as babysitting and caregiving for dependants are considered transfers within the family. They are not external sources of income derived from employment, hence it would not be appropriate to consider these transfers for Workfare Income Supplement scheme. The Government recognises that such family roles are important. There are other forms of government support for these roles, such as the [Marriage and Parenthood package](https://go.gov.sg/mpbooklet)√Ç¬†which provides broad-based support for couples to raise and care for their children.']

question: I am a freelancer/conducting a home business (e.g. baking, sewing). Can I qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
answer: ['To qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme, please declare your net trade income as a self-employed person and contribute to your MediSave Account. You will also need to meet the [WIS eligibility criteria](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/workfare-for-lower-wage-workers/am-i-eligible-for-the-workfare-income-supplement--wis--scheme-) in order to qualify for WIS. To conduct a home business, you need to follow the guidelines under HDB's Home-Based Small-Scale Business Scheme. Please refer to the [Housing & Development Board's website](http://www.hdb.gov.sg/cs/infoweb/residential/living-in-an-hdb-flat/home-business) for more information.']

question: My net trade income in a work year was negative. Can I trade the losses to offset my income in the following year to qualify for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
answer: ['Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is based on your actual net trade income earned in the work year and does not include previous year's losses.']

question: I have made the required MediSave contribution to qualify for Workfare Income Supplement, why is my payment still not reflected in the MediSave Payable page after logging into e-Services?
answer: ['Contributions made each month will be updated in e-Services on the 9th working day of the following month.']

question: I worked as both an employee as well as a self-employed person (SEP) in the work year. When will I receive my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) for the work year?
answer:
['You will receive monthly Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payments based on your employee income if you meet the WIS eligibility criteria for the work year (WY).
If you are also an eligible dual status worker (DSW) who has worked concurrently as an SEP and employee in the year, you may receive additional WIS if your combined employment and net trade income results in a higher WIS payment. You will receive the additional WIS payment after you have declared your income and made the required MediSave contributions.
You will receive WIS once a year for work done as an SEP in the preceding year. The earliest payment for SEPs/DSWs for a particular WY will be on 30 April WY+1\*.
\*Payment via PayNow NRIC-linked bank account or bank crediting will be credited by end of the month while payment via GovCash will be on the 3rd of the following month.']

question: To qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS), what is considered income?
answer:
['Employee income is based on the definition of Gross Wages under the CPF Act:
Total Gross Wages = Total Ordinary Wages + Total Additional Wages
Where:
Ordinary Wages (OW) are wages due or granted wholly or exclusively in respect of an employee's employment in that month, and payable before the due date for payment of CPF contributions for that month e.g. monthly salary.
Wages which are not classified as OW will be Additional Wages (AW) for the month e.g. annual performance bonus.
Total Wages are the total amount of an employee's wages for any calendar month, which is the sum of his OW for the month and the AW paid to him in that month.']

question: How is the 12-month average monthly income (AMI) criterion computed?
answer:
['The 12-month average gross monthly income is defined as:
*Sum of income earned in the past 12-month period √É¬∑ Total number of months worked in the past 12-month period*
To qualify for WIS:
a) Your 12-month average gross monthly income must not exceed $2,500; and
b) Your gross monthly income must not exceed $2,500.']

question: What is the Annual Value (AV) of a property and why is the AV of my place of residence used to assess my eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
answer:
['Annual Value (AV) is the estimated gross annual rent of the property if it were to be rented out, excluding furniture, furnishings and maintenance fees. It is determined based on estimated market rentals of similar or comparable properties. It can be found on the property tax bill you receive each year.
AV serves as a housing criterion that targets lower-wage workers from lower income households. Using AV instead of housing type is a fairer way to determine property value as some applicants may be staying in smaller and less expensive private properties with an AV similar to a larger Housing & Development Board flat.
For more information on the computation of AV, please visit the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) website](https://www.iras.gov.sg/irashome/Property/Property-owners/Learning-the-basics/About-Annual-Value/).']

question: How is the Annual Value (AV) requirement for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) decided and what address is used to determine the AV in WIS?
answer:
['The Annual Value (AV) threshold of $13,000 covers all HDB flats, as well as some smaller private residences. In general, Singaporeans staying in larger properties with AV above the cut-off tend to have greater access to household wealth, and therefore would not be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme.
The AV will be based on the address reflected in your NRIC. Under the National Registration Act, you must report a change of address within 28 days of moving at the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) [website](https://www.ica.gov.sg/documents/ic/update_residential_address).']

question: What constitutes a second property for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
answer: ['All types of properties e.g. Housing & Development Board flat, private property and non-residential property, are taken into account in determining the eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme.']

question: I am renting a room/whole unit in the property that I stay in. Am I eligible for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
answer:
['If you are renting the entire property unit, the annual value of that property unit will be used to assess your eligibility.
If you are renting only a room or some rooms in the property, please [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) with your tenancy agreement and particulars (name, NRIC, telephone number, address and the nature of your appeal).
You can also write to us via [My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyMailbox/MyMailboxLanding) (Singpass required) and skip the hassle of keying in your personal particulars.
We will review your WIS eligibility after we have received your request and the supporting documents.']

question: Do residents in welfare homes qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
answer: ['Residents in welfare homes registered with the National Council of Social Service/ Ministry of Health/ Ministry of Social and Family Development will qualify for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) if they meet all of the other [WIS eligibility criteria](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/workfare-for-lower-wage-workers/am-i-eligible-for-the-workfare-income-supplement--wis--scheme-).']

question: Why is my spouse's income and property ownership used to determine my eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
answer:
['To ensure that Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is targeted at recipients with limited access to household wealth, you will not qualify for WIS if:
o the assessable income of your spouse for the preceding Year of Assessment exceeds $70,000; or
o you and your spouse together own two or more properties.']

question: Why is my spouse's Assessable Income for the preceding Year of Assessment used to determine my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) eligibility for the current work year?
answer:
['This is to allow potential Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) recipients to receive WIS earlier despite the time needed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for the processing and transmission of Assessable Income (AI) to the CPF Board.
The AI for the previous Year of Assessment (YOA) is used to assess one's WIS eligibility for the current year. E.g. we will use your spouse's AI for YOA 2021 to assess your eligibility for 2022 WIS.']

question: My mobile number is already registered to my bank account on PayNow. Can the Government credit Workfare payments to me via PayNow-Mobile instead of via PayNow-NRIC?
answer:
['We can only credit your Workfare payment to you via your PayNow- NRIC-linked bank account. NRIC is an unchanged proxy issued by the Government, compared to mobile numbers which may be easily changed. To ensure that the money is credited to the correct recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account, only NRIC will be accepted as the proxy for government benefits via PayNow.
Eligible Singaporeans who have linked their NRIC to PayNow, with a PayNow-GIRO-participating bank, will receive the benefits in this bank account.']

question: What is GovCash?
answer: ['GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singapore citizens to withdraw their Government benefits in cash from over 500 OCBC ATMs located across Singapore. Singaporeans who prefer to seek assistance with their GovCash withdrawals can visit the ATMs located within OCBC's branches during operating hours, where OCBC Digital Ambassadors will be present to guide them. In addition, GovCash also allows recipients to use the scan-and-pay function and PayNow transfer option through the LifeSG mobile app.']

question: How do I check my GovCash balance?
answer: ['To check your GovCash balance, please visit any OCBC ATMs with your 8-digit Payment Reference Number (PRN). Upon successful authentication, you will be able to view your GovCash balance. Alternatively, you may login to the LifeSG mobile app using your Singpass to view your GovCash balance and transaction history. You may refer to the [step-by-step guide](https://www.gstvoucher.gov.sg/files/GC%20insert%20AP.pdf) for detailed instructions.']

question: What should I do if my facial recognition at the ATM with GovCash functions is unsuccessful?
answer: ['Should the ATM be unable to verify your identity via Singpass Face Verification after repeated tries, you may visit a NEW ATM located at selected OCBC branches (refer to [OCBC website](https://www.ocbc.com/group/gateway) for latest list of NEW ATMs) during the branch operating hours, and OCBC's Digital Ambassadors will be available to assist you with your GovCash transactions.']

question: What should I do if I do not want to receive my payments via GovCash?
answer:
['There are two options for you if you do not wish to receive your payments via GovCash:
**Option 1: Register for PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account**
We encourage you to register for PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account with your preferred bank. You may contact your bank for specific details on how to register your NRIC on PayNow.
If you have linked your NRIC to PayNow, your future cash payments (if any) will be automatically credited to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account. You may contact your bank to check if you are registered on PayNow-NRIC.
**Option 2:****Register your bank account details**
Alternatively, you can choose to receive your payments via crediting to your bank account. To do so, you may login to the [e-services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/wf/workfare/login) using your Singpass, select √¢¬Ä¬úBank Account Submission√¢¬Ä¬ù and update your POSB/DBS, OCBC or UOB bank account details.']

question: Why is the option to withdraw GovCash only available in $10 denominations and what can I do with my balance GovCash?
answer: ['Currently, the minimum withdrawal amount at the ATMs is $10. Hence, GovCash withdrawals can also be made in $10 denominations. If the balance in your GovCash is less than $10, you can accumulate your balance monies before your next withdrawal. Alternatively, you can also transfer the balance to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account or utilise them to make payments at any merchants with PayNow/NETS QR code, or transfer to your friends by scanning the PayNow QR code using the LifeSG mobile app. You may refer to the√Ç¬†[step-by-step guide](https://www.gstvoucher.gov.sg/files/GC%20insert%20AP.pdf)√Ç¬†for detailed instructions.']

question: Why does the majority of the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payment take the form of CPF contributions?
answer:
['Other than providing a cash supplement to help lower-wage workers cope with their daily needs, it is also important that WIS helps them to build up their CPF savings for their healthcare and retirement needs. Furthermore, savings in the CPF accounts can earn an interest rate of up to 5% per annum if you are below 55, and up to 6% per annum if you are 55 and above.
Visit [here](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest?utm_source=fcb&utm_medium=vd&utm_campaign=bau) for more information on CPF interest rates.√Ç¬†Terms and conditions apply.']

question: How will I receive the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payment?
answer:
['You will receive the cash portion of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) via your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.√Ç¬†To check your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account details, please approach your bank.
If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore but have provided your DBS/POSB, OCBC or UOB bank account to the Government previously, you will receive your cash portion of WIS via bank transfer. You can check and update your bank account details registered with us by logging in to our [e-services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/cds/ap/login) with your Singpass.
Otherwise, the amount will be credited to you via GovCash. GovCash is a payment mode that allows Singaporeans to receive their benefits from Government agencies more quickly and conveniently. You are encouraged to link your NRIC to PayNow with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your benefits earlier\*.
\*If you have linked your NRIC number to your bank account after the 16th of the month or submitted your bank account details after the 14th of the month, your updates will only be effective in the following month.']

question: How can I change the mode of payment for my Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
answer:
['You are encouraged to register for PayNow-NRIC with a PayNow-GIRO-participating local or foreign bank in Singapore to receive your WIS payments earlier. Payment will be made by default to your PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account.
If you do not have a PayNow-NRIC-linked bank account, you can update your bank account details by logging in to our [e-services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/cds/ap/login) with your Singpass.√Ç¬†Payment instructions received will be used for future government benefits.']

question: How and when will I receive Workfare notification on the amount I am receiving?
answer: ['You will be notified via letters and/or SMS nearer to the payment dates. You can also login to the√Ç¬†[e-Services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/wf/workfare/login)√Ç¬†with your Singpass to check your payment. To receive the notification earlier via SMS, please log in to the√Ç¬†[e-Services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/wf/workfare/login)√Ç¬†with your Singpass and select "Notification" to opt-in to receive SMS.']

question: How can I receive SMS notifications and stop receiving hardcopy notifications for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
answer:
['To receive SMS notifications, register your mobile number with CPF Board via *my cpf* digital services - [Account Settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings) with your Singpass.
If you wish to receive notifications of your Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) by SMS instead of hardcopy letters, please log in to the√Ç¬†[e-Services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/wf/workfare/login)√Ç¬†with your Singpass and opt-in to SMS at √¢¬Ä¬úNotification√¢¬Ä¬ù.']

question: How can I provide or update my mobile number to receive SMS notification on my Workfare payment?
answer: ['We will only send SMS notifications on Workfare payments to the mobile number that you have registered with CPF Board. To receive SMS notifications, you may update your mobile number via *my cpf* digital services -√Ç¬†[Account Settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings)√Ç¬†with your Singpass.']

question: How can I tell if the Workfare SMS I received is authentic?
answer:
['With the recent rise in scam and phishing attempts, it is important to verify that the message received is genuinely sent by an official source.
From 1 August 2022, we will send SMSes from the ID √¢¬Ä¬úCPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ù. The SMS sender ID √¢¬Ä¬úSG-Workfare√¢¬Ä¬ù will no longer be in use.
![Example of a Workfare SMS sent from CPF Board](/content/dam/web/member/growing-your-savings/images/SampleWorkfareSMS.png)
This is only an example of a Workfare SMS. The actual SMS received may be different.
Here are some tips on how you can protect yourself against phishing SMSes purporting to be sent from CPF Board:
* Check the SMS is sent by √¢¬Ä¬òCPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ô to the mobile number registered with CPF Board. If you are unsure of whether you had registered your mobile number, please login to the CPF website with your Singpass and check your√Ç¬†[account settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings).
* Verify the last four characters of the masked NRIC number are the same as your NRIC number.
* If the SMS contains an URL, make sure that the domain of the URL ends with a ".gov.sg" before clicking on it.
We will never ask you to reply to the Workfare SMS nor direct you to a non-Government website. Do report any suspicious SMS spoofing to√Ç¬†[CPF Board](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us).
Be Cautious, Pay attention to scam and don't be the next victim of Fraud.']

question: Why is the government sending SMS notifications instead of hardcopy letters?
answer: ['Moving to SMS notifications is part of the Government's efforts to provide timelier and more responsive services to the public. It also allows us to be more environmentally friendly. With SMS notifications, you can quickly and easily receive details of your Workfare payments, including the mode of payment and payment date, instead of having to wait for hardcopy letters. If you are on hardcopy notification and would like to switch to SMS notification, please log in to the√Ç¬†[e-Services](https://www.govpayouts.gov.sg/wf/workfare/login)√Ç¬†with your Singpass and opt-in to receive SMS at "Notification".']

question: Why are overtime pay and bonuses included in Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) assessment?
answer: ['Basic salary, overtime pay, and bonuses are part of a worker√¢¬Ä¬ôs total income that will help support the worker and his or her family. Given that the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) is intended to supplement the income of lower-wage workers, it is most useful to assess the total income in determining one√¢¬Ä¬ôs eligibility for WIS.']

question: Can the minimum income criterion be waived for workers who want to work more but are unable to?
answer:
['The minimum income criterion of $500 per month was introduced from 2023 to encourage all workers, part-time and full-time, to work more regularly or take up higher-paying jobs.
$500 per month is a reasonable and achievable wage for most regular workers. At an hourly wage of $9 per hour1, workers who work 3-hr daily shifts for 20 days a month would already earn around $540 per month.
However, we recognise that there may be some who want to work more but are unable to do so due to their personal circumstances or are in greater need of support, such as Persons with Disabilities (PWDs), low-income workers who qualify for ComCare Short-to-Medium-Term Assistance and caregivers of care recipients2. Such workers will continue to qualify for concessionary WIS, even if they earn less than $500 per month.
1 based on Local Qualifying Salary
2 This will generally include caregivers residing with care recipients who are medically certified to have permanent moderate to severe disabilities. More details on the concessionary WIS for caregivers will be provided later.']

question: I am a Person with Disability/Comcare Short and Medium Term Assistance recipient who is earning less than $500 per month. How much Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will I receive?
answer: ['You will continue to qualify for concessionary Workfare Income Supplement (WIS), even if you earn less than $500 per month. We will notify you of the amount nearer to the payment dates.']

question: What is PayNow and how do I link my NRIC to PayNow?
answer:
['PayNow is a secure funds transfer service that allows customers to receive money into their bank account via NRIC/FIN and/or mobile number.
With PayNow, the recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank information will be kept private. The recipient will need to provide their mobile number or NRIC/FIN to the sender to send money. Other PayNow users will not have access to your personal details unless it is provided by you.
To receive government benefits via PayNow, you will need to link your NRIC to PayNow. PayNow-Mobile number is not accepted. You can register for PayNow-NRIC if you have a bank account with the following participating banks in Singapore:
| **Bank** |
| --- |
| [Bank of China](https://www.bankofchina.com/sg/custserv/cs6/201804/t20180426_12102708.html) |
| [CIMB](https://www.cimb.com.sg/en/business/digital-banking/paynow-corp.html) |
| [Citibank](https://www.ipb.citibank.com.sg/english/static/online-payment-transfers.htm) |
| [DBS Bank / POSB](https://www.dbs.com.sg/personal/support/bank-ssb-paynow-register-profile.html) |
| [HSBC Bank](https://www.hsbc.com.sg/ways-to-bank/transfers/paynow/) |
| [ICBC](https://v.icbc.com.cn/userfiles/Resources/ICBC/haiwai/Singapore/download/2021/PaynowIndividualFAQ.pdf) |
| [Maybank](https://www.maybank2u.com.sg/en/personal/payments/local/fund-transfers/paynow.page) |
| [OCBC](https://www.ocbc.com/personal-banking/digital-banking/paynow) |
| [Standard Chartered Bank](https://www.sc.com/sg/bank-with-us/paynow/) |
| [UOB](https://www.uob.com.sg/personal/eservices/ebanking/paynow.page) |
You may refer to your respective bank's website for specific details on how to link your NRIC to PayNow. If you do not have internet or mobile banking, you can contact your bank directly to register for PayNow-NRIC.
If you do not have a PayNow NRIC-linked account, and wish to receive your payment via bank crediting, you may provide your bank account details to us by logging in to our e-services with your Singpass.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for my housing loan after I turn 55?
answer:
['You can continue to use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for your housing loan after you turn 55. However, on your 55th birthday, a Retirement Account (RA) will be created for you and savings up to your Full Retirement Sum from your Special Account and OA will be transferred to your RA.
You can continue to use the following from your OA to pay your housing loan:
* Your savings which you have applied to reserve in your OA before your 55th birthday. This reserved amount 1will not be transferred to your RA. Hence,√Ç¬†you can continue to use it to pay your housing loan after turning 55 years old. To reserve your OA savings, please log on using your Singpass to [*my cpf* Online Services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/WelcomePage) > Click on √¢¬Ä¬úMy Requests√¢¬Ä¬ù > Select √¢¬Ä¬úRetirement (eg. Retirement Sum & Age 55 applications)√¢¬Ä¬ù > Select √¢¬Ä¬úDecide on my CPF options for members reaching 55√¢¬Ä¬ù;
* Your new CPF contributions to your Ordinary Account (if you continue working after 55).
1When you start your monthly payouts under CPF Life or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your RA if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer increases your RA savings and will enhance your monthly payouts.']

question: How do I apply to reserve my Ordinary Account (OA) savings, so that they will not be transferred to the Retirement Account and remain in the OA for my housing payments after I turn 55 years old?
answer:
['If you want to reserve your Ordinary Account savings to pay for your existing property, please log on to√Ç¬†[***my cpf*√Ç¬†Online Services**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/WelcomePage)√Ç¬†using your Singpass, go to "My Requests" and select √¢¬Ä¬úRetirement (eg. Retirement Sum & Age 55 applications)√¢¬Ä¬ù, then select "Decide on my CPF options for members reaching 55".
If you do not own a property, but plan to purchase one in the future, you can still reserve your OA savings by submitting your request via√Ç¬†[**Write to us**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous). You do not need to submit any documents now, but you must provide your Option to Purchase or Sale and Purchase Agreement separately after you have committed to a property purchase. If you have already committed to a property purchase, please attach a copy of your Option to Purchase or Sale and Purchase Agreement in your request.
Your request should reach the Board at least three weeks before your 55th√Ç¬†birthday.
It is important to note that when you start receiving monthly payouts under CPF Life or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer will increase your Retirement Account savings and enhance your monthly payouts.']

question: How much can I reserve in my Ordinary Account for my housing payments?
answer: ['You can request to reserve all or part of your Ordinary Account (OA) savings. When you start your monthly payouts under CPF LIFE or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer increases your RA savings and enhance your monthly payouts.']

question: If I reserve an amount in my Ordinary Account to pay for my house, will it affect the amount that I can withdraw?
answer:
['Yes, the amount that you can withdraw from your CPF savings will be affected if you have reserved an amount in your Ordinary Account to pay for your house. This is because the savings reserved for your housing payments cannot be withdrawn in cash.
It is also important to note that the amount reserved for housing will not be transferred to your Retirement Account to make up your retirement sum. This may affect your monthly payouts when you reach your payout eligibility age. Therefore, it is important to plan your finances carefully and consider the impact of reserving funds for housing on your future retirement plans.']

question: What is the CPF Housing Scheme?
answer:
['| |
| --- |
| The CPF Housing Scheme enables CPF members to use only their CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings to:√Ç¬†* Buy Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats
* Buy or build private residential properties in Singapore
It's important to keep in mind that your Special Account (SA) and Retirement Account (RA) savings are intended to provide you with a source of income during retirement and cannot be used for purchasing a flat or any other property. |']

question: How long does it takes to process applications relating to housing matters?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to housing matters.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Commence CPF monthly instalment / use CPF savings for arrears payment, partial or full repayment of housing loan | **Online**: Within five working days |
| Revise / cease CPF monthly instalment for housing loan taken from banks/ financial institutions | **Online**: Within one working day (Application has to be submitted at least five working days before deduction date) |
| Make voluntary cash refund of CPF savings used for property | **Online**: Almost instantly (PayNow QR and OCBC PayAnyone)**Manual**: Within seven working days |']

question: Can I use my Ordinary Account savings to service the housing loan taken by my parent(s) and/or sibling?
answer: ['You can use your Ordinary Account savings to service the housing loan only if you are the co-owner of the property.']

question: Can I transfer my Ordinary Account (OA) savings to my parents' OA so that I can help them pay their outstanding housing loan?
answer: ['You cannot transfer your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to your parents' OA to help them pay their outstanding housing loan. You can only use your OA savings to service a housing loan if you are an owner of the property.']

question: Where can I find the list of the Board's panel of law firms?
answer: ['You can refer to the [list of law firms appointed by the Board](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/CPFConveyancingPanel.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) to find a firm to handle legal matters relating to your property.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay stamp duty, survey and other related fees when I buy a property?
answer:
['Your CPF savings can be used to pay the stamp duty and survey fees. However, monthly service and conservancy charges, along with other charges related to the use of the property, including taxes, cannot be paid with your CPF savings.
As stamp duty is payable within 14 days from the date of the sale and purchase agreement or the date of acceptance of the option to purchase, you may need to use cash to pay the stamp duty first. Subsequently, you can apply for a one-time reimbursement from your CPF account together with your application to use your CPF savings to buy a property.\*
* For completed properties, you should apply for the one-time reimbursement of stamp duty and CPF lump sum drawdown on completion at the same time.
* For properties under construction, you should apply for the one-time reimbursement of stamp duty on/or before the date of the legal completion.
Keep in mind that if the developer of your property has already paid the stamp duty, you cannot seek reimbursement of the stamp duty from your CPF savings.
\*If you are taking an HDB loan, it is important to check with HDB on your eligibility to apply for a one-time reimbursement of stamp duty from your CPF account.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the transaction fee and lodgement fees when I buy a property?
answer:
['You can use your√Ç¬†Ordinary Account√Ç¬†savings to pay for the following when you purchase a property:
* Transaction fee levied by the lawyer's appointed bank
* Lodgement fees levied by the Singapore Land Authority for the holding and disbursing of your CPF savings
Check with your lawyers to learn more about other relevant costs and fees.
They can provide additional information and help you understand the costs involved in the process.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the Housing & Development Board upgrading costs?
answer: ['You can use your√Ç¬†Ordinary Account√Ç¬†savings to pay the upgrading costs incurred under the Housing & Development Board Upgrading Programmes and Town Council Lift Upgrading Programme.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings for renovation and repairs of my property?
answer:
['CPF savings cannot be used for renovation, improvement or repair work for your property.
If you are planning to renovate or repair your property, you will need to use your own cash savings to cover the costs. It is important to plan your finances accordingly and ensure you have enough cash savings to cover these expenses.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay the seller's stamp duty when I sell my property?
answer:
['CPF savings cannot be used to pay your seller's stamp duty. The seller's stamp duty will have to be paid with cash.
It is important to plan your finances accordingly and ensure that you have enough cash savings to cover the seller's stamp duty and other related costs when purchasing a property.']

question: Am I able to use my CPF savings to buy properties overseas?
answer:
['CPF savings can only be used to buy properties in Singapore.
If you are looking to buy a property in another country, you will not be able to use your CPF savings to fund the purchase. It is important to keep this in mind when planning your property purchase and to ensure you have enough savings or financing options available for a property purchase outside of Singapore.']

question: What if I am overseas and I am not able to personally handle the transactions when I buy a property?
answer:
['You may appoint someone with the legal authority to act on your behalf under the Power of Attorney.
By appointing someone under the Power of Attorney, you can ensure that your CPF savings and property matters are being taken care of even when you are unable to do so yourself.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to purchase a short-lease 2-room Flexi Flat?
answer: ['You must first set aside your [Basic Retirement Sum](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-)√Ç¬†in your CPF accounts before you can use any excess Ordinary Account savings to purchase a short-lease-2-room Flexi Flat. This ensures that you have a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during your retirement.']

question: What are the terms and conditions to use my CPF savings to buy a Housing & Development Board flat or a private property?
answer: ['You can refer to the [terms and conditions](/member/tnc/t-c-for-use-of-cpf-under-cpf-housing-scheme) to use your CPF savings to buy a property.']

question: What is the Memorandum of Mortgage?
answer: ['The [Memorandum of Mortgage](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/Housing_RPS_Memorandum.pdf) (PDF, 77KB) sets out the priority arrangement between the Board and the bank in respect of the refund of proceeds arising from a disposal of the property where the mortgagee bank has the first charge. The Memorandum of Mortgage has been registered with Singapore Land Authority (SLA) under the registration number: IA/991901M.']

question: What are the changes to the use of CPF for housing effective from 10 May 2019?
answer: ['Please refer to the [press release](https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-releases/2019/0509-more-flexibility-to-buy-a-home-for-life) for information on the changes to the use of CPF for housing effective from 10 May 2019.']

question: How does CPF Board compute the CPF usage limits for properties which do not cover the buyers to the age of 95?
answer:
['The maximum amount of CPF savings that can be used is pro-rated depending on the√Ç¬†remaining lease of the property that can cover the youngest buyer to the age of 95. This will help buyers set aside sufficient CPF savings for their housing needs during retirement (e.g. a replacement property).
Make an informed decision on your property purchase by using the [CPF housing usage calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-housing-usage).
This useful tool lets you compute the allowable CPF usage you can use for your next property purchase.']

question: I am currently paying my mortgage, but my flat only lasts me till 85 years. Will there be a change in the amount of CPF that I can use to pay for my mortgage?
answer: ['There will be no change to the amount of CPF that you can use to pay for your mortgage for your existing property as the changes will apply only to properties purchased from 10 May 2019.']

question: I am in the midst of finalising my property transaction. How do I know if I fall under the old rules or the new rules?
answer:
['The new rules will apply to you if:
- For HDB flats: Your date of application on the HDB website is from 10 May 2019.
- For private properties: Your Option to Purchase or Sale & Purchase Agreement (in the absence of an Option to Purchase) exercised date is from 10 May 2019.']

question: Why did the Government review the rules on CPF usage for purchase of residential properties with shorter leases?
answer:
['The rules on CPF usage for purchase of residential properties with shorter leases were updated to meet the changing needs and higher life expectancy of Singaporeans. Instead of focusing on the remaining lease of the property, the rules focuses on whether the remaining lease of the property can cover the youngest buyer until age 95.
This change gives Singaporeans greater flexibility to purchase a home that can last for life, while ensuring that their retirement adequacy is protected.']

question: Why do I need to have lease coverage until age 95 for maximum CPF usage?
answer:
['The required lease coverage of at least 95 years recognises the increasing life expectancy of Singaporeans.
Nevertheless, if the remaining lease of the property does not cover the youngest co-owner until the age of 95, you can still use your CPF savings at a pro-rated amount.']

question: Why is our CPF usage capped based on the youngest co-owner's age? When the youngest co-owner relinquishes ownership of the flat, will our CPF usage limit increase?
answer:
['CPF usage is capped based on the age of the youngest co-owner that purchased the property using his/her CPF. This encourage families to buy properties with sufficient lease to cover all co-owners for life.
If the youngest co-owner decides to relinquish his or her ownership of the flat, we will update the CPF usage limit based on the age of the next youngest co-owner and will send a written notification to all co-owners.']

question: Why is the minimum lease period set at 20 years? Why am I not allowed to use my CPF savings to buy a property with a lease of less than 20 years when it can last me till 95?
answer: ['We recognise that the previous minimum lease period (MLP) of 30 years for CPF usage contributed to anxieties on the saleability of older properties and have lowered this to 20 years. This is the same as the MLP for obtaining a HDB loan. There will still be a MLP of 20 years to ensure prudent use of CPF savings. Nevertheless, most properties today are still young and far away from this MLP of 20 years.']

question: What is the maximum monthly instalment amount that can be used for my property?
answer: ['The total monthly CPF deduction for all owners must not exceed the total monthly repayment amount approved by your financier.']

question: If I had bought two private properties, which property will my CPF savings be used to service the monthly instalment first?
answer: ['There is no specific order of deduction on which property will be paid first. We will deduct the amount from your Ordinary Account to pay the monthly instalments as requested by you. It is important to ensure that you have enough savings in your CPF account to cover the monthly instalment deductions.']

question: How long does it take to process the refund of the excess payment made to the Housing & Development Board or the bank of my housing loan?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standard for processing refund of the excess payment made to HDB or the bank.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Process the refund of excess payment made to HDB or the bank | **The funds and refund details are transmitted through the electronic link-ups with HDB or the banks**: One working day**The funds and/or refund details are transmitted to us by other means**: Seven working days |']

question: When is the monthly housing loan deducted from my CPF account?
answer:
['The date of deduction for your monthly housing loan from your CPF account depends on the type of property and loan you have.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Type of property and loan taken** | **Date of next deduction** |
| Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat (HDB loan) | The deduction is on the Sunday between 6th and 12th (including both dates) of the month. |
| HDB flat (Bank loan) | The deduction is between the 11th and 14th (including both dates) of the month. |
| Private property / Executive Condominium | The deduction is on the first or last working day of the month, depending on the bank√¢¬Ä¬ôs due date. |
Note: If you are using your CPF savings to pay for the upgrading cost of your HDB flat, the deduction is on the Sunday, between the 6th and 12th (including both dates) of the month.']

question: Will I be informed if I do not have enough CPF savings for the monthly housing loan deduction?
answer:
['You will not be informed if you do not have enough CPF savings for the monthly housing loan deduction.
It is important to keep track of your CPF savings to ensure that you have enough for your monthly housing loan deduction.
You can check the amount deducted for your housing loan by viewing your CPF online statement. This statement provides a detailed breakdown of your CPF contributions and withdrawals, including any deductions made for your housing loan.']

question: Does the Board impose a penalty for unsuccessful housing deductions?
answer: ['The Board does not impose a penalty for unsuccessful housing deductions.']

question: If I do not have enough CPF savings to pay for my property, can I top up my CPF account with cash to make up the shortfall?
answer:
['If you do not have enough CPF savings to pay for your property, you can still make a voluntary contribution to your CPF account. This is subject to the CPF Annual Limit.
The voluntary contributions will be apportioned and credited to your Ordinary, Special, and MediSave accounts and is based on the CPF allocation rates.
As only Ordinary Account savings can be used for housing repayments, you may consider paying the shortfall in cash to your bank (if you are taking a bank loan) or to the Housing & Development Board (HDB) (if you are taking an HDB loan) directly.']

question: Can the Board automatically deduct the monthly instalment shortfall for my property from my co-owner's CPF account?
answer:
['We are not authorised to automatically deduct the monthly instalment shortfall from your co-owner's CPF account for your property.
It is important for all owners to communicate and come to an agreement regarding the division of payment responsibilities.']

question: What should I do if I wish to refinance the housing loan for my property?
answer:
['You will have to authorise your lawyer (by signing the Letter of Authorisation, Declaration, Consent & Agreement) to submit your application on your behalf if you wish to refinance the housing loan for your property.
The following documents are required:
1. Final/latest statement from the existing financier; and 2. Letter of offer from the new financier stating the type and quantum of the new loan.
Please note that your current CPF monthly instalment payment to the existing financier (if any) will cease upon the approval of the application submitted by your lawyer.√Ç¬†If you are an HDB flat owner intending to use your CPF savings for the monthly instalment payment, but are not currently covered under the [Home Protection Scheme (HPS)](/member/home-ownership/protecting-against-losing-your-home "Home Protection Scheme (HPS)"),√Ç¬†you will need to submit an HPS application online using your Singpass after receiving notification that your application has been processed. Your eligibility for HPS cover is subject to approval and your good health. While your HPS application is being processed, you can use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing loan instalments.√Ç¬†If you are already insured by HPS or exempted from HPS, you can find out more below:
[What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I have refinanced my housing loan?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/what-will-happen-to-my-home-protection-scheme-cover-if-i-have-refinanced-my-housing-loan)']

question: How do I check the amount to be refunded to my CPF account upon the sale of my property?
answer: ['You can check the amount to be refunded to your CPF account after selling your property by accessing your√Ç¬†[Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)√Ç¬†on the CPF website.']

question: If I did not use my CPF savings for my property, do I have to top up my Retirement Account upon sale of my property?
answer: ['You do not have to top up your Retirement Account as you have never used your CPF savings for the property purchase.']

question: If my late parent(s) had used their CPF savings for their property, do I need to refund the CPF savings used by them upon disposal of the property?
answer: ['No, you do not have to refund the CPF savings used by your late parent(s) and the accrued interest to their CPF accounts upon disposal of their property.']

question: I have withdrawn my CPF savings on Reduced Life Expectancy. Why do I need to refund the CPF principal amount and accrued interest when I sell my property?
answer: ['The CPF savings that you had previously withdrawn for your property did not form part of the amount approved for withdrawal of CPF on Reduced Life Expectancy. Therefore, upon the sale of your property, the CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property and the accrued interest will need to be refunded to your CPF account. You can apply to withdraw the refunded amount under Reduced Life Expectancy if you are eligible to.']

question: I have withdrawn my CPF savings on Reduced Life Expectancy. Can I withdraw any further CPF savings after refunds from the sale of my property are credited?
answer:
['Once refunds from the sale of your property have been credited, you can submit an√Ç¬†[online request](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyMailbox/MyMailboxLanding)√Ç¬†to CPF for an assessment of your eligibility for further withdrawal under Reduced Life Expectancy.
If you have previously withdrawn your CPF savings on Reduced Life Expectancy, you may be eligible to withdraw further savings from your Special and Ordinary accounts. However, this is subject to your medical condition remaining unchanged.
We will review your request and inform you of your eligibility status.']

question: Do I have to refund the housing grant to my CPF account upon sale of my property?
answer:
['When you sell your property, you will have to refund the principal CPF withdrawn towards the property (including the CPF Housing Grant) plus its accrued interest to your CPF account.
Generally, the housing grant will be refunded to your Ordinary Account. If you have received more than $30,000 in housing grants, part of it may be credited to your Special Account/Retirement Account and MediSave Account. You can check the amount that will be credited to your Special/Retirement Account and MediSave Account by viewing your√Ç¬†[Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership).
These savings can be used for approved purposes under various CPF schemes to help you with your retirement and healthcare needs.']

question: Is there any accrued interest on the amount of CPF savings used for my property?
answer: ['Interest will accrue on the amount of CPF savings that you have used for your property. You are required to refund the accrued interest together with the CPF principal amount withdrawn when you sell, transfer or dispose your property.']

question: How does the Board calculate the accrued interest on the amount of CPF used for my property?
answer: ['Accrued interest is the interest amount that you would have earned if your CPF savings had not been withdrawn for housing. The interest is computed on the CPF principal amount withdrawn for housing on a monthly basis (at the current CPF Ordinary Account interest rate) and compounded yearly. You can view the [applicable CPF interest rates](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/cpf-interest-rates/what-are-the-cpf-interest-rates) for the various periods.']

question: I am 55 and above. I understand that my CPF refund will be used to meet my Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in my Retirement Account and the balance housing refunds will be paid to me in cash. Can I choose to refund only up to my FRS when I sell my property?
answer: ['Yes, you can choose to refund up to your Full Retirement Sum so that you can receive the balance housing refunds without waiting for the pay-out. If you have already met your Retirement Sum, no refund is required. To proceed, please submit a request via√Ç¬†[My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyMailbox/MyMailboxLanding) two weeks before the completion of the sale of your property.√Ç¬†Alternatively, if you would like to keep the balance housing refunds in your Ordinary Account (OA) to pay for another property - you can also submit a request via My Mailbox two weeks before the completion of the sale of your property and indicate your intention to retain the balance housing refunds in your OA.']

question: I am aged 55 and above. Can I receive the excess housing refunds via a different bank account or different payment mode?
answer:
['If you are aged 55 and above and would like to update the payment mode to receive your excess housing refunds, please submit an online application via [*my cpf* Online Services - My Requests](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyRequest/MyRequestLanding)√Ç¬†using your Singpass at least two weeks before the completion of your property sale.
To better protect members from scams, we will only accept bank accounts where the bank is able to provide automated bank account verification to CPF Board. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to the member. Currently, only POSB, DBS, OCBC and UOB are able to provide this service. We welcome any other bank to set up similar arrangements with us.
The same bank account will also be used to credit the Account for any payment due to you:
1. under the CPF Act and its subsidiary legislation; and
2. from the Government in respect of which CPF Board is the administrator, agent or trustee, to the Account.']

question: I am aged 55 and above. When will I receive the excess housing refunds after selling my flat?
answer:
['If you are aged 55 and above and have sold your flat, you will receive the excess housing refunds in your CPF account. The refunds will be credited to your bank account (which is maintained in our records) within five working days.
If there are no bank account records maintained with us, you will receive a cheque about 10 working days after the housing refunds are credited into your CPF account.
[Find out how more about how you can update your payment mode to receive your excess housing refunds](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/housing-scheme/i-am-aged-55-and-above--can-i-opt-to-receive-the-balance-housing).']

question: If my selling price is not enough to pay my housing loan, why did I receive a letter informing that I may receive some balance housing refunds upon sale of flat?
answer:
['The information on your selling price and outstanding loan were not available when the letter was sent to you.
If you are aged 55 and above, we will inform you if you do not have any balance housing refunds after the top up to your Retirement Account, upon completion of the sale of your property.']

question: Do I need to refund my ex-spouse's CPF account if I take over the property?
answer:
['If you take over a property from your ex-spouse, he/she will have to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn for the property, along with the accrued interest, when he/she is no longer the owner of the property.
However, the CPF laws were revised from 1 October 2007 to allow for more flexibility in such cases. The Court can now make an order for the property to be transferred from a member to his/her ex-spouse without requiring the full CPF refund to be made into the member's CPF account.
Should the ex-spouse sell the property, he/she is required to refund into his/her own CPF account the amount withdrawn from the member's CPF account (which were not refunded upon transfer) as well as the principal amount withdrawn from his/her own CPF account for the purchase of the property with accrued interest.
It would be for the Court to decide whether court orders extracted before 1 October 2007 could be amended or varied to benefit from the existing CPF laws. In this respect, please consult your lawyers.']

question: How can I discharge a CPF charge that was created when I bought my private property with CPF savings?
answer:
['If you used your CPF savings to buy a private property, a CPF charge would have been created. To discharge this charge, you need to refund the amount used for the property and the accrued interest to your CPF account. You can do so by:
* Voluntarily refunding the amount used to your CPF account. After the refund is made, you will need to engage a lawyer to lift the CPF charge on your property. Please note that you will have to pay any legal cost incurred for this discharge.√Ç¬†If you are above 55 and wish to withdraw your Retirement Account savings above the Basic Retirement Sum by pledging the property in future, a fresh CPF charge will be lodged to secure the refund of the withdrawal amount when the property is sold/transferred in future. Please note that the cost of lodgement of charge will be borne by you.
* Refunding the amount used to your CPF account when you sell your property. Your lawyers handling the sale will complete the discharge as part of the sale transaction.']

question: How long does it take to process the refunds from sale of my property to my CPF account?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing the refunds from the sale of your property to your CPF account
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Process refund from sale of property to CPF account | Within five working days upon receipt of fundsThis includes the time to clear cheque/cashier's order. |']

question: Does CPF Board disburse the CPF Housing Grant (CHG) and who is eligible for the CPF housing grant?
answer: ['The CPF Housing Grant (CHG) is disbursed by HDB. If you are looking for information on CHG and the eligibility criteria to apply for CHG, visit [HDB's website](http://www.hdb.gov.sg/).']

question: I do not have enough CPF savings to buy my next property as I am waiting for the CPF refunds from sale of my property. What can I do?
answer:
['You can consider taking a bridging loan from any banks so long as HDB and/or the bank allows. It is important to note that the total amount of CPF savings withdrawn and the loan (including the bridging loan) cannot be more than the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase, whichever is lower.
Once you sell your existing property, your CPF savings will be refunded to your CPF accounts. You can then use the funds to pay off the bridging loan after completing the legal documentation and settling any outstanding cash amount.']

question: What is joint-tenancy?
answer: ['A joint-tenancy is a form of property ownership where all co-owners have an equal interest in the property, regardless of the individual owner's contribution to the property purchase. This means that upon the death of a joint-tenant, his interest in the property will automatically pass on to the remaining co-owner(s), regardless of whether he has made a will.']

question: I am buying an HDB flat and selling my existing flat at the same time. Can I apply for a contra facility?
answer: ['If you are interested in using the refund from the sale of your current HDB flat to buy a new flat, you may check with HDB to see if you are eligible to apply for a contra facility. This will allow you to use the refund to offset the purchase price of your new flat.']

question: What is tenancy-in-common?
answer:
['A tenancy-in-common is a form of property ownership where each co-owner holds a separate and definite share in the property. However, all co-owners are entitled to the enjoyment of the whole property regardless of their share in the property.
In a tenancy-in-common arrangement, each owner can have a different ownership interest in the property. For example, one owner may own 50% of the property, while the other two owners own 25% and 25% respectively.
When a tenant-in-common dies, their share in the property does not automatically go to the other owners. Instead, it will be passed on according to their will. If they do not have a will, it will be distributed according to the Intestate Succession Act.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to build my own house?
I have an overdraft to buy a private property. Can I use my CPF savings to redeem the overdraft?
answer:
['You can use your CPF savings to repay the overdraft if it was used solely to purchase the private property. To do so, you need to authorise your lawyer (by signing the Letter of Authorisation, Declaration, Consent & Agreement) to submit an online application on your behalf. Your lawyer will need to attach the following documents in the application:
1. Financier's letter of offer.
2. Financier's letter to confirm that the overdraft was used strictly to buy the property or was partially used to buy the property. If the overdraft was used partially to buy the property, please attach the monthly statement of account of the overdraft account from the time it was disbursed for payment of the property to the date of application to use CPF savings.
3. Financier's statement showing the current outstanding amount of the overdraft.
Once the application is approved, you will need to get your financier to convert the overdraft facility to a housing loan.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to buy a SOHO (Small Office Home Office) unit?
answer:
['CPF savings can only be used to buy residential properties. It is important to note that Small Office Home Office (SOHO) developments are approved by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) for either office or residential use, but not for both.
You may use your CPF savings to purchase a SOHO unit if URA has approved it for residential use. However, if the unit is approved for office use, your CPF savings cannot be used for its purchase. Therefore, you are advised to check the approved use of the property before committing to any purchase.']

question: I have used cash to pay for my housing monthly instalment shortfall. Can I apply to pay with my CPF savings, and get a cash refund from my financier?
answer: ['Yes, you can apply to use your CPF savings to pay the monthly instalment shortfall. However, please note that getting a cash refund from your financier is not guaranteed and is subject to their approval. It is important to check with your financier directly to see if they are able to refund the cash paid before you apply to use your CPF savings.']

question: Am I allowed to reserve my Ordinary Account savings prior to turning 55 years old for possible housing payments after I turn 55 years old?
answer:
['To help members plan ahead, members who intend to reserve their Ordinary Account (OA) savings for housing payments beyond age 55 may submit a request to the CPF Board before the monies are transferred to the Retirement Account (RA). This applies to members who own an existing property, as well as those who have yet to purchase a property. Your request should reach the Board at least three weeks before your 55th√Ç¬†birthday.
However, when you start your monthly payouts under CPF LIFE or the Retirement Sum Scheme, your reserved OA savings will be transferred to your RA if you have not set aside your Full Retirement Sum. This transfer increases your RA savings and enhance your monthly payouts.
[Find out how to apply to reserve your OA savings for your housing payment.](/member/faq/home-ownership/housing-scheme/how-do-i-apply-to-reserve-my-ordinary-account-savings-so-that)']

question: How much CPF savings can I use for my property purchase?
answer:
['If√Ç¬†you have already used your Ordinary Account (OA) savings towards the subject property,√Ç¬†please view your [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership) to find out your latest usage and usage limit for your property.
If you are planning to buy a property, please confirm the following:
The remaining lease of the property covers the youngest owner who is using OA savings to at least 95 years old
You and your co-owners (if any) may use your respective Ordinary Account savings to pay your HDB loan.
You and your co-owners (if any) may use your respective Ordinary Account (OA) savings up to the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. Thereafter, if your housing loan is still outstanding, you can continue to use your OA savings to pay for the housing loan if you can set aside the applicable [Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-) in your CPF accounts to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement. Savings in your Retirement Account (if you are above 55), Special Account and OA can be used to meet your BRS requirement. If you are below age 55, the BRS applicable to you is the current BRS. This condition also applies to your co-owners (if any).
You and your co-owners (if any) may use your respective Ordinary Account (OA) savings up to the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. Thereafter, if your housing loan is still outstanding, you can continue to use your OA savings to pay for the housing loan if you set aside the applicable [Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-) in your CPF accounts to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement. Savings in your Retirement Account (if you are above 55), Special Account and OA can be used to meet your BRS requirement. If you are below age 55, the BRS applicable to you is the current BRS. This condition also applies to your co-owners (if any).
The total amount all owners are allowed to use for your property will increase by 20% of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter.
You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings after setting aside the applicable [Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-) in your CPF accounts to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement, until the total CPF usage by all owners reaches the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. Savings in your Retirement Account (if you are above 55), Special Account and OA can be used to meet your BRS requirement. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter. If you are below age 55, the BRS applicable to you is the current BRS.
You and your co-owners (if any) may use your respective Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for the purchase, up to the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter.
You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings after setting aside the applicable [Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-) in your CPF accounts to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement, until the total CPF usage by all owners reaches the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. Savings in your Retirement Account (if you are above 55), Special Account and OA can be used to meet your BRS requirement. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter. If you are below age 55, the BRS applicable to you is the current BRS.
The remaining lease of the property does not cover the youngest owner who is using OA savings to at least 95 years old
You and your co-owners (if any) may use your respective Ordinary Account (OA) savings up to a percentage of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. The amount of CPF savings allowed for your property depends on the extent that the remaining lease of the property can cover the youngest owner up to age 95. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter. This gives Singaporeans more flexibility to purchase a home for life, while safeguarding their retirement adequacy. Use the [CPF housing usage calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-housing-usage)√Ç¬†to estimate the amount of CPF savings that you can use.
You can use your Ordinary Account savings for your property after setting aside the applicable [Basic Retirement Sum (BRS)](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-) in your CPF accounts to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement. Savings in your Retirement Account (if you are above 55), Special Account and OA can be used to meet your BRS requirement. If you are below age 55, the BRS applicable to you is the current BRS.
The total amount of CPF savings all owners are allowed to use for your property is capped at a percentage of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. The amount of CPF savings allowed for your property depends on the extent that the remaining lease of the property can cover the youngest owner up to age 95. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter. Use the [CPF housing usage calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-housing-usage)√Ç¬†to estimate the amount of CPF savings that you can use.
You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your property after setting aside the applicable [Full Retirement Sum (FRS)](/member/faq/retirement-income/general-information-on-retirement/what-are-the-retirement-sums-applicable-to-me-) in your CPF accounts to provide you with a monthly income to support a basic standard of living during retirement. Savings in your Retirement Account (if you are above 55), Special Account and OA can be used to meet your FRS requirement. If you are below age 55, the FRS applicable to you is the current FRS.
The total amount of CPF savings all owners are allowed to use for your property is capped at a percentage of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase. The amount of CPF savings allowed for your property depends on the extent that the remaining lease of the property can cover the youngest owner up to age 95. No further CPF usage is allowed thereafter. Use the [CPF housing usage calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-housing-usage)√Ç¬†to estimate the amount of CPF savings that you can use.']

question: How do I apply to use my CPF savings for my housing loan monthly instalments?
answer:
['The application process to use your CPF savings for your housing loan monthly instalments depends on the type of your property and loan you have taken.
For HDB flat with HDB loan
There are two ways for you to commence your housing monthly deduction.
1. Submit√Ç¬†an online application under My Flat > Purchased Flat > Financial Info > Other Related Services > Commence/Vary Monthly CPF deduction at [HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](http://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage) with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
2. Complete√Ç¬†the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Do note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment using the [e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/). Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB. Note: You have to be insured under [Home Protection Scheme (HPS)](/member/home-ownership/protecting-against-losing-your-home) if you are using your CPF savings to pay your housing loan monthly instalments for HDB flats.√Ç¬†Your eligibility for an HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health. While we are processing your HPS application, you can proceed to use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing loan instalments.
For HDB flat with bank loan
You can submit an√Ç¬†[online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/MonthlyHousingInstallments/Property) with your Singpass at least five working days before the monthly instalment deduction date.
Note: You have to be insured under [Home Protection Scheme (HPS)](/member/home-ownership/protecting-against-losing-your-home) if you are using your CPF savings to pay your housing loan monthly instalments for HDB flats.√Ç¬†Your eligibility for an HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health. While we are processing your HPS application, you can proceed to use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing loan instalments.
For private property
You can commence your housing monthly deduction by submitting an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/MonthlyHousingInstallments/Property) with your Singpass. Please submit your application at least five working days before monthly instalment deduction date.']

question: How can I make changes to my housing monthly deduction?
answer:
['The application process to change your housing monthly deduction depends on the type of loan you have taken.
For HDB loan
There are two ways for you to make changes to your housing monthly repayment arrangement.
1. Submit√Ç¬†an online application under My Flat > Purchased Flat > Financial Info > Other Related Services > Commence/Vary Monthly CPF deduction at√Ç¬†[HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](http://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage)√Ç¬†with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
2. Complete√Ç¬†the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment using the√Ç¬†[e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/). Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
For Bank loan
You can change your housing monthly deduction amount by√Ç¬†submitting an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/MonthlyHousingInstallments/Property) with your Singpass.
Please submit your application at least five working days before monthly instalment deduction date.']

question: How do I stop my housing monthly deduction for my housing loan?
answer:
['The application process to stop your housing monthly deduction depends on the type of loan you have taken.
For HDB loan
There are two ways for you to stop your housing monthly deduction.
1. Submit√Ç¬†an online application under My Flat > Purchased Flat > Financial Info > Other Related Services > Commence/Vary Monthly CPF deduction at [HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](http://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage) with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
2. Complete√Ç¬†the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment using the [e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/). Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
For Bank loan
You can stop your housing monthly deduction for your housing loan by submitting an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/MonthlyHousingInstallments/Property) with your Singpass.
Your application will be processed by the next working day.']

question: If I have outstanding housing arrears payments, how do I apply to use my CPF savings to pay for it?
answer:
['The application process to use your CPF savings for outstanding arrears payment depends on the type of loan you have taken.
For HDB loan
There are two ways to pay your outstanding arrears payment.
1. Submit an√Ç¬†online application under My Flat > Purchased Flat > Financial Info > Payment of Outstanding instalment by CPF at [HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](http://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage) with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
2. Complete√Ç¬†the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment using the [e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/). Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
For Bank loan
You can pay your outstanding arrears by submitting an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/MonthlyHousingInstallments/Property) with your Singpass.
Your application will be processed within three working days.']

question: How do I make partial repayment or full repayment of my housing loan?
answer:
['The application process to use your CPF savings to make partial repayment or full repayment of your housing loan depends on the type of loan you have taken.
For HDB loan
Check that you have enough CPF Ordinary Account savings and the maximum amount of CPF savings that you can use for your property.
There are two ways to make a partial repayment or full repayment of your housing loan.
1. Submit an online application under My Flat > Purchased Flat > Financial Info > Other Related Services> Partial Capital Repayment/Redemption of Housing Loan at [HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](https://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage) with your Singpass. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
2. Complete√Ç¬†the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Please note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment using the e-Appointment system. Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
For Bank loan
To make partial or full repayment of your housing loan, you will need to:
1. Seek√Ç¬†approval from your housing loan financier.
2. Check that you have enough CPF Ordinary Account savings and the maximum amount of CPF savings that you can use for your property. You can view your [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership) to find out your latest usage and usage limit for your property.
3. Submit√Ç¬†an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/MonthlyHousingInstallments/Property) with your Singpass.
For full repayment of housing loan, you will need to upload a copy of the bank√¢¬Ä¬ôs redemption statement and a copy of your lawyer√¢¬Ä¬ôs legal bill (if any) in the application.
Your application will be processed within five working days.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the legal fees incurred when I buy a property? If so, how should I go about doing it?
answer:
['You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for the legal fees incurred when you buy a property.
You will need to [apply](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/home-ownership/using-your-cpf-to-buy-a-home/apply-to-use-cpf-for-your-property) through HDB if you are taking an HDB loan, or through your lawyer if you are taking a bank loan.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings to pay for the recess area of my HDB flat? If so, how should I go about doing it?
answer:
['The application process to use your CPF savings to pay for the recess area of your HDB flat will depend on the type of loan you have taken.
HDB loan
There are two ways for you to pay for the recess area of your HDB flat.
1. Submit√Ç¬†an online application at [HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](https://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage) with your Singpass. Upon logging in, look under √¢¬Ä¬òe-Services > Residential > Living in a HDB flat > Application to Purchase Recess Area. Your application will be processed within three working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
2. Complete√Ç¬†the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Do note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit HDB Branches, you can book an appointment using the [e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/). Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
Bank loan
Please [make an appointment](/member/contact-us/visit-us) to submit your request at any of our service centres. Do note that counter services at CPF Service Centres are available by appointment only.']

question: How can I check my outstanding housing loan?
answer:
['The process to check your outstanding housing loan depends on the type of loan you have taken.
For HDB loan
There are two ways to check your outstanding housing loan.
1. Login with√Ç¬†your Singpass at [HDB√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](https://www.hdb.gov.sg/myhdbpage)√Ç¬†and look under My Flat > Purchase Flat > Financial Info.
2. Visit the HDB Branch managing your flat. Do note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit a HDB Branch, you can book an appointment using the [e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/).
For Bank loan
You can check with your bank on your outstanding loan.']

question: What should I do if I would like to use the CPF Housing Top-Up Grant for my Housing & Development Board flat?
answer:
['The steps to use the CPF Housing Top-Up Grant to pay for your HDB flat depends on the loan you have taken.
HDB loan
Please complete the CPF withdrawal form (PHS9) at HDB Branch. Do note that services at HDB office and Branches are by appointment only. If you wish to visit HDB Branches, you can book an appointment using the [e-Appointment system](https://services2.hdb.gov.sg/webapp/BF13AWAppointmentWeb/branch/). Your application will be processed within three to five working days upon the receipt of your request from HDB.
Bank loan
Please [make an appointment](/member/contact-us/visit-us) to submit your request at any of our service centres. Do note that counter services at CPF Service Centres are available by appointment only.']

question: I am not taking any loan to buy my property. Must I still produce a valuation report if I want to use my CPF savings to buy my property?
answer:
