['Even if you are not taking a loan to buy your property, you will still need to produce a valuation report if you want to use your CPF savings to purchase the property. This report helps us determine the maximum amount of CPF savings you can use for your property.
If you are buying an HDB flat, we will only accept the valuation determined by HDB, which should not be more than three months from the date of your application.
If you are buying a private property, we will only accept a valuation report conducted by a licensed valuer, which should also not be more than three months from the date of your property purchase.']

question: Is there any deadline for me to pay for the monthly instalment shortfall for my property?
answer: ['It is important to pay off your monthly instalment shortfall for your property as soon as possible to avoid penalty fees from your financier. We recommend that you check with your financier directly to confirm any specific deadline for payment. Late or non-payment of instalments can result in additional fees and charges, so it's best to stay on top of your payments to avoid any unnecessary financial burden.']

question: Can I use the valuation report done by a bank's valuer when I buy my property?
answer:
['Whether you can use the valuation report done by a bank√¢¬Ä¬ôs valuer depends on the type of property you are buying.
HDB flat
It is HDB's requirement that you can only use the value of the flat determined by HDB.
Private property
You can use the valuation report done by a bank's valuer.']

question: Can I use my CPF savings for the down payment of my property?
answer:
['The amount of CPF savings you can use for your property√¢¬Ä¬ôs down payment depends on the type of your property you are buying and loan you are taking.
HDB flat with HDB loan
If you are buying an HDB flat directly from HDB, you can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for the initial 10% downpayment as well as the balance of the purchase price. You would have to pay for the option fee in cash first at the time of booking an HDB flat.
If you are buying a resale HDB flat, you will have to pay for the deposit, i.e., option fee and option exercise fee, in cash.
HDB flat with bank loan
You can only use your Ordinary Account savings to pay for the property after you have paid the following in cash:
1. minimum cash downpayment of at least 5% of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase; and
2. the portion of the purchase price that is above the market value of the property; and
3. the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase, less the housing loan and approved CPF lump sum that will be paid towards the property; and
4. option fee at the time of booking an HDB flat (if you are buying the flat directly from HDB) or option fee and option exercise fee (if you are buying a resale flat)
You may refer to the [Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) website](https://www.mas.gov.sg/) for more information on the minimum cash downpayment that you have to pay.
Private property
You can only use your Ordinary Account savings to pay for the property on completion of all legal documentation and after you have paid the following in cash:
1. a minimum cash downpayment of at least 5% of the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase; and
2. the portion of the purchase price that is above the market value of the property; and
3. the lower of the purchase price or the valuation price of the property at the time of purchase less the housing loan and approved CPF lump sum that will be paid towards the property.
You may refer to the [Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)√Ç¬†website](https://www.mas.gov.sg/) for more information on the minimum cash downpayment that you have to pay.']

question: What do I need to do before I sell or transfer my property?
answer:
['If you are planning to sell or transfer your property, there are a few matters you need to complete beforehand. The steps you need to take depend on the type of property you own.
For HDB flat
You will need to check with HDB to see if you are eligible to sell or transfer your flat. Once you have received their consent, either HDB or your lawyer (if you have one) will check with the Board on the amount, if any, that needs to be refunded to your CPF account.
For Private property
You will need to instruct your lawyer to obtain consent from the Board before you sell or transfer your property.']

question: How much do I need to refund to my CPF account if I am either selling my whole property, transferring or selling my share of the property to another party?
answer:
['In order to determine the amount that you need to refund to your CPF account, you will need to confirm if you are selling your whole property, transferring, or selling your share of the property to another party.
Selling your whole property
You will need to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn plus the accrued interest ("**P+I**").
If you have reached 55 and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum, you will need to refund the pledged amount on top of the P+I. The amount refunded will be used to top up your Retirement Account, up to your Full Retirement Sum. After this, any balance housing refunds will be paid to you in cash.
If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to fully refund your required CPF refund, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash, provided that the property is sold at market value. However, the option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.
The refunded amount will be returned to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts in the following proportions:
Amount returned to owner A's CPF Account:
![formula for amount to be refunded to owner A](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/VHR%20refund%20for%20owner%20A%20updated%201.jpg)
Amount returned to owner B's CPF Account:
![formula for amount to be refunded to owner B](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/VHR%20refund%20for%20owner%20B%20updated%201.jpg)
Transferring your share of the property to another party
You will need to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn plus the accrued interest ("**P+I**").
If you have reached 55 and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum, you will need to refund the pledged amount on top of the P+I. The amount refunded will be used to top up your Retirement Account, up to your Full Retirement Sum. After this, any balance housing refunds will be paid to you in cash.
Selling your share of the property to another party
You will need to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn plus the accrued interest ("**P+I**").
If you have reached 55 and have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum, you will need to refund the pledged amount on top of the P+I. The amount refunded will be used to top up your Retirement Account, up to your Full Retirement Sum. After this, any balance housing refunds will be paid to you in cash.
If the part share selling price less your share of the outstanding housing loan is insufficient to fully refund your required CPF refund, and provided that the part share transaction is conducted at market value, your will need to refund the higher of the below two figures, capped at your P+I\*, calculated by the formulae below:
![](/content/dam/web/member/home-ownership/images/partshare_formula.jpg)
\*If you have pledged the property to make up your retirement sum, the amount will be capped at the sum of P+I and the pledged amount.']

question: What will happen to my sales proceeds after the sale of my property?
answer:
['The distribution of sale proceeds depends on the type of your property and loan taken.
Private properties bought on or after 1 September 2002 or refinanced on or after 1 September 2002 and HDB flats
Generally, the selling price will be used to pay for the following in this order:
1. Outstanding housing loan
2. Required CPF refund
3. Other sale expenses, e.g., legal fees
If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to make the required CPF refund, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash, provided the property is sold at market value. However, the option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner√¢¬Ä¬ôs and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.
The refunded amount will be returned to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts in the following proportions:
Amount returned to owner A's CPF Account:
![formula for amount to be refunded for owner A](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/VHR%20refund%20for%20owner%20A%20updated%201.jpg)
Amount returned to owner B's CPF Account:
![formula for amount to be refunded for owner B](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/VHR%20refund%20for%20owner%20B%20updated%201.jpg)
Private properties bought before 1 September 2002 and not refinanced after 1 September 2002
The selling price will be used to pay for the following in this order:
1. CPF principal amount withdrawn up to 80% of the lower of the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase plus the CPF savings used for the legal and stamp fees
2. On equal ranking:
* CPF principal amount withdrawn for the remaining 20% of the lower of the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase
* Bank's outstanding housing loan and interest
3. CPF principal amount withdrawn beyond the lower of the purchase price or valuation price of the property at the time of purchase and the accrued interest
If the sale proceeds (including the option monies) are not enough to make up the required CPF refund and the outstanding housing loan, the sale proceeds will be used to settle the required CPF refund and the outstanding housing loan in the order agreed by you, your bank and the Board. Any option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of the selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.']

question: After I have sold my property, can I use the refunded CPF savings to buy the next property or redeem another housing loan with my CPF savings?
answer:
['The amount of refunded CPF savings that you can use for your next property depends on your age at the time of sale of your property.
If you are below 55
You can use your Ordinary Account, including the refunded amount, to buy the next property or redeem another housing loan.
If you are 55 and above
You can use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to buy the next property or redeem another housing loan.
The refunds from the sale of your earlier property will be used to top up your Retirement Account, up to your Full Retirement Sum. After this, any balance housing refunds will be paid to you in cash within one week after the CPF refunds are paid into your CPF account. Alternatively, you can request (at least 2 weeks before the completion of the sale of your property) for the balance housing refunds to remain in your OA to pay for the next property or redeem another housing loan.']

question: How much should I refund to my CPF account if I have a Court order extracted before 1 January 2013 directing a sale / transfer / disposal of my property?
answer:
['If you have a Court Order extracted before 1 January 2013, the amount to be refunded depends on your age at the time of sale, transfer or disposal of your property.
If you are below 55
You will need to refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn plus accrued interest upon sale, transfer or disposal.
If the selling price (including the option monies) after paying the outstanding housing loan is not enough to fully refund the CPF principal amount withdrawn together with the accrued interest, you do not need to top up the shortfall in cash, provided the property is sold at market value. However, any option monies (e.g. option fee and option exercise fee) received from your buyer in cash upon the sale of your property are considered part of selling price and need to be refunded to your co-owner's and your CPF accounts before the transaction can be completed.
If you are 55 and above
Please check with us on the amount to be refunded upon sale, transfer or disposal.']

question: Can I use my Special Account savings to pay my housing loan?
answer: ['As your Special Account savings are meant for retirement, only your Ordinary Account savings can be used for housing payments such as mortgage payments, down payments, and monthly instalments.']

question: How can I get back my title deed if I have fully redeemed my housing loan?
answer:
['To get back your title deed, the procedure depends on the type of property you bought and the loan you took.
HDB flat with HDB loan
You may wish to check with HDB directly on the title deed of your HDB flat.
HDB flat with bank loan
You may wish to check with your bank directly on the title deed of your HDB flat.
Private property
The title deed will only be printed and given to you by the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) if there are no encumbrances on the property such as outstanding mortgages, CPF charges and other charges. The CPF charge was created at the time your CPF savings were withdrawn for the property to secure the refund of CPF principal amount withdrawn including accrued interest upon the sale of the property.
If there is still a CPF charge on the property even though the mortgage and other charges are discharged, SLA will not print the title deed. If you require a copy of the title deed, you may liaise with SLA after the mortgage and/or other charges is/are discharged.']

question: What should I look out for if I am buying a property for the first time?
answer:
['If you are buying a property for the first time, these are the 3 general things you may wish to know before buying your first home.
![3 things to know before buying your first home](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/3ThingsToBuyingYourFirstHome.jpg)
In addition, here are some things that you should also look out for.
Your eligibility to buy a property
Check if you meet the eligibility criteria at [HDB website](https://www.hdb.gov.sg/cs/infoweb/homepage).
Check if you meet the eligibility criteria at [URA website](https://www.ura.gov.sg/Corporate).
Your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) balance
It is important to find out how much Ordinary Account (OA) savings you have to finance your purchase. Your existing OA balance and your future monthly CPF contributions to your OA will help you decide an affordable home price. You can use our√Ç¬†[First home calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/first-home)√Ç¬†to estimate a housing loan and property price based on your income and your ability to service the loan.
You can check your CPF OA balance on [Member dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds) by logging in at our CPF website using your Singpass. Otherwise, you may visit any of the CPF Service Centre.
Your finances
Work out the amount of cash savings you have and the amount of housing loan you can get.
Encumbrances on the property that you are buying
You can check with HDB or if you are buying a resale flat from the open market, you can check with the seller that he/she will be refunding his/her CPF principal amount withdrawn and accrued interest used towards the flat so that the CPF charge (on the seller) can be lifted.
You can check with your lawyer to make sure your property is free of any charges (i.e., CPF charge, mortgage charge) upon completion.
Apply to use your OA savings
Please [apply](/member/home-ownership/using-your-cpf-to-buy-a-home/apply-to-use-cpf-for-your-property) through HDB if you are taking an HDB loan or your lawyer if you are taking a bank loan to use your OA savings for the property.']

question: How will I be kept informed on my Home Protection Scheme cover details?
answer:
['We will send you a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) certificate after your HPS cover has commenced and the premium paid.
The HPS certificate will include details such as the sum assured you are insured for, your share of cover, the policy commencement and expiry date, the address of the insured flat and your annual premium.']

question: What is Home Protection Scheme?
answer: ['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) is a mortgage-reducing insurance that protects you and your loved ones from losing your Housing & Development Board flat in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability. HPS insures members up to age 65 or until the housing loans are paid up, whichever is earlier.']

question: Can I apply to be insured under Home Protection Scheme if I do not have any outstanding housing loan?
answer: ['The Home Protection Scheme (HPS) benefits are used to pay off the outstanding housing loan in the event of a claim. If you have not taken any housing loan to buy your HDB flat, HPS is not applicable to you.']

question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to Home Protection Scheme (HPS).
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal processing time** |
| Apply for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover / To adjust HPS cover | Five working days (Upon the receipt of your loan information from your mortgagee).√Ç¬†Longer time may be required if we need to further assess your eligibility for an HPS cover. The processing time for applications submitted at the same time by the owner and his/her co-owner may differ as each application is processed and assessed individually. |
| Termination of HPS Cover | Five working days |
| Exemption from the HPS | Five working days (Upon receipt of your HPS Exemption application from your insurer(s))Longer time may be required if: i) you are using multiple private policies from different insurers;√Ç¬†ii) you have applied for an exemption share of cover lower than 100%. |
| Request for reprint of HPS Certificate | Five√Ç¬†working days |
| Pay HPS Premium Shortfall | PayNow QR: Generally be processed almost instantly |
| Authorise the Use of Ordinary Account Savings for Insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs HPS premium | **Online**: One working day |
| Claim√Ç¬†HPS benefits on Death Ground / Medical Ground | Upon receipt of your application and supporting documents, we will write to the relevant organisations / medical institutions directly to obtain the required information within seven working days.Once all the requested information is received, we will process your application within√Ç¬†five working days. |']

question: Where can I purchase fire insurance for my HDB flat?
answer: ['The purchase of fire insurance for your HDB flat is under the purview of the Housing and Development Board (HDB). You may approach HDB directly for more information.']

question: How can I check the status of my application for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['The process to check the status of your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application status depends on whether you have submitted the HPS application form through:
CPF website (Form Ref: HPS/45)
If you have recently submitted an online application for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover (Ref: HPS/45) via the CPF website, you can check the status of your application [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivity) using your Singpass.
For existing HDB flat owners:
Upon approval of your HPS application, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) and you may view your HPS coverage status via the [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)√Ç¬†(under √¢¬Ä¬úProtection against losing your home√¢¬Ä¬ù). You will receive an HPS certificate generally within one to two weeks after premium deduction has taken place.
We will inform you if you are not eligible for an HPS cover or provide alternative options to pay the premium shortfall if you do not have sufficient funds in your OA for the premium payment.
For new HDB flat owners:
Upon approval of your HPS application, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF OA generally within two weeks after you are the legal owner of the flat and you may view your HPS coverage status via [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)√Ç¬†(under √¢¬Ä¬úProtection against losing your home√¢¬Ä¬ù). You will receive an HPS certificate within generally one to two weeks after premium deduction has taken place.
We will inform you if you are not eligible for an HPS cover or provide alternative options to pay the premium shortfall if you do not have sufficient funds in your OA for the premium payment.
HDB (Form Ref: HPS/9)
If you have recently submitted an HPS application via HDB, we will process your HPS application generally within five working days. Longer time may be required if we need to further assess your eligibility for an HPS cover.
For existing HDB flat owners:
Upon approval of your HPS application, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) and you may view your HPS coverage status via [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)√Ç¬†(under √¢¬Ä¬úProtection against losing your home√¢¬Ä¬ù). You will receive an HPS certificate generally within one to two weeks after premium deduction has taken place.
We will inform you if you are not eligible for an HPS cover or provide alternative options to pay the premium shortfall if you do not have sufficient funds in your OA for the premium payment.
For new HDB flat owners:
Upon approval of your HPS application, we will deduct the HPS premium from your CPF OA generally within two weeks after you are the legal owner of the flat and you may view your HPS coverage status via [Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)√Ç¬†(under √¢¬Ä¬úProtection against losing your home√¢¬Ä¬ù). You will receive an HPS certificate generally within one to two weeks after premium deduction has taken place.
We will inform you if you are not eligible for an HPS cover or provide alternative to pay the premium shortfall if you do not have sufficient funds in your OA for the premium payment.
You may contact us at [cpf.gov.sg/writetous](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if you require clarification on the status of your application.']

question: My co-owner and I each applied for 50% Home Protection Scheme (HPS) coverage. What should I do if my co-owner's HPS cover is rejected due to health reasons?
answer: ['You are encouraged to increase your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) to 100% share of cover. This is to ensure that HPS is able to fully cover the total outstanding loan. Any increase to your HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.']

question: What do I need to declare when I apply for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['You have to fully disclose all information regarding your health condition, including:
* All your past and current illnesses
* Any surgery/treatment/medical test that you had previously undergone or will be undergoing, and
* Any physical or mental impairment.
If you are not sure about the relevance of the information, you are advised to disclose it. This includes any medical information that you may have provided to the officer during your appointments at the HDB/financial institution or to the solicitor but not provided in your health declaration.
We may arrange a medical examination for you and/or request a copy of the medical report on your health condition.']

question: Why do I need to declare my health condition when I apply for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer: ['You must fully and truthfully declare your health condition because that is how the mortgage protection insurance works. Your eligibility for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover is subject to approval and you being in good health. This is in line with industry practice where applicants have to truthfully declare their health conditions and may even have to attend medical examination. Any HPS cover issued based on false/ misleading information could be voided at any time, and any insurance claim would be denied. In such a situation, any premiums paid will also not be refunded. To avoid this, all that members have to do is to declare fully and truthfully their health conditions when applying for HPS.']

question: What if I do not declare my health condition when I apply for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer: ['If you have not fully and truthfully declared your health condition, your Home Protection Scheme cover could be voided at any time and any claim could be denied. Refund of paid premiums or claims will not be considered.']

question: How do I qualify for the porting of my previous Home Protection Scheme cover to my new property?
answer:
['You are eligible to port√Ç¬†your previous Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover if you meet the following conditions:
1. Your previous HPS cover\* was terminated due to the sale of your previous flat after purchasing a new flat, and
2. You are not eligible for a new HPS cover√Ç¬†for the new flat due to your current health condition.
\*You must not have had√Ç¬†any serious pre-existing health condition that was not disclosed to us when you applied for your previous HPS cover.']

question: If I am eligible for the porting of my Home Protection Scheme cover, what is the sum assured that I am insured for and the period of cover?
answer:
['We will issue you a new Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover based on the lower of:
1. The remaining sum assured of your previous HPS cover or the new outstanding loan for the new flat, and
2. The remaining cover period of your previous HPS cover or the new cover period for the new flat.
The same terms and conditions for your previous HPS cover will continue to apply to your new HPS cover.']

question: Can I apply to port my Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover to my new flat, instead of applying for a HPS cover?
answer: ['We can only consider porting the previous Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover for members who are not eligible for a new HPS cover. Therefore, you must apply for a new HPS cover first.']

question: Am I still eligible for Home Protection Scheme if I have a serious medical condition?
answer: ['As member's eligibility under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) is assessed based on his/her medical condition(s), you may submit an application and we will inform you on your application outcome in due course. In general, members who are currently receiving treatment for serious medical conditions such as cancer, stroke, kidney failure, etc., are not eligible for HPS.']

question: Do I need to declare information regarding my health condition when I am not sure if the information is relevant or not?
answer:
['If you are not sure about the relevance of the information, you are advised to disclose it so that we can assess your eligibility for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover.
Refund of paid premiums or claims will not be considered if an HPS cover was issued based on false/misleading information given or member is/was not in good health before the cover commencement.']

question: Do I need to update CPF Board of my new health condition which developed after my Home Protection Scheme cover has been issued to me?
answer:
['You are only required to declare your health condition at the point of your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application. However, you must inform us immediately if there is a change in the state of your health before the HPS cover is issued to you.
You do not need to declare new conditions that have developed after the HPS cover has been issued to you.']

question: Do I need to declare my health when I apply to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['A new health declaration is required if you are adjusting your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) coverage upwards due to an increase in loan repayment period, loan quantum or share of cover. If you are not eligible for the additional coverage, you can continue to be insured under your existing cover\*.
\*You must not have had any serious pre-existing health condition that was not disclosed to us when you applied for your previous HPS cover.']

question: After I submit my Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application, do I need to declare my newly developed health condition before the HPS cover is issued to me?
answer: ['You must inform us immediately if there is a change in the state of your health before the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover is issued to you.']

question: What should I do if I have omitted to declare certain health condition in my Home Protection Scheme application?
answer:
['Please write to us via [My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/mymailbox) to declare any health condition which you have omitted in your earlier Home Protection Scheme (HPS) application. Your declaration should include details of your health condition and a copy of your medical report, if any.
We will assess your eligibility for an HPS cover based on the additional health information declared.']

question: When will my Home Protection Scheme cover start?
answer:
['Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will start when all of the following conditions are met:
1. You have obtained legal ownership of the flat i.e. legal documents are signed and keys are collected.
2. You have executed the loan document with HDB or the approved mortgagee and are legally liable for the loan.
3. You have declared your health and are accepted for cover under HPS
4. You have paid the HPS premium. Deduction of the premium from your Ordinary Account will take place usually within two weeks from the legal ownership date of your flat.']

question: How long will I be insured under Home Protection Scheme?
answer: ['You will be insured under Home Protection Scheme for the term of your loan or up to age 65, whichever is earlier.']

question: Where can I check my current Home Protection Scheme cover details?
answer:
['You can check your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) coverage status, current sum assured and the share of your Annual Premium HPS cover under √¢¬Ä¬úProtection against losing your home√¢¬Ä¬ù in the√Ç¬†**[Home ownership dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/home-ownership)**√Ç¬†using your Singpass.
You can also find comprehensive information regarding your HPS cover on your HPS certificate that was sent to you when your HPS cover was issued/adjusted.
If you have an outstanding housing loan and do not see √¢¬Ä¬úProtection against losing your home√¢¬Ä¬ù in the dashboard, this means you are currently not insured under HPS. You are strongly encouraged to apply for an HPS cover [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/HPS45), using your Singpass, to protect you and your loved ones from losing your HDB flat in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability.
Please note that you will be ineligible for a new HPS cover if:
* You are 65 years old and above, or
* Your previous application for HPS cover had been rejected due to your health condition']

question: How is the Home Protection Scheme premium calculated?
answer:
['Home Protection Scheme charges a level premium rate (i.e. same amount annually throughout the policy term), calculated based on the following factors:
* Outstanding housing loan on the flat\*
* Loan repayment period
* Type of loan (concessionary or market rate)
* Age and gender
* Percentage share of cover
\*The computation of the level premium takes into account the monthly reduction in the housing loan.
Premiums are generally higher for higher share of coverage, larger loan amounts or longer repayment periods. The premiums would be lower for younger persons and females, due to lower mortality risk.']

question: How long do I have to pay my Home Protection Scheme premium?
answer: ['You will only need to pay the premium for 90% of your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover period. For example, if your HPS cover period is 30 years, you will only need to pay premium for 27 years.']

question: How much premium do I need to pay for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['You can calculate your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium online using the [HPS Premium Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/HPSpremiumcalculator).
Find out more:
* [Where can I check the premium payable to renew my Home Protection Scheme cover?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/where-can-i-check-the-premium-payable-to-renew-my-home-protectio)']

question: What if I do not have enough savings in my CPF Ordinary Account to pay the annual premium for Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['We will inform you to top-up if you do not have enough balances in your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) to pay the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium.
You have a grace period of two months to pay the premium for your HPS policy. Your HPS cover will end if you are still unable to pay the premium by the end of the grace period.
You may top-up for your HPS premium via the following means:
1. PayNow at√Ç¬†[e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage), or
2. Cash at any Singapore Post branch offices
HPS premium top-up, which is credited to your OA is considered a voluntary contribution and is subject to the√Ç¬†[prevailing CPF Annual Limit](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/making-voluntary-contributions).
If you have incoming working contributions that will be credited into your OA within the grace period, and the amount is sufficient to cover your premium shortfall, you may choose not to take any action. We will deduct the shortfall from your new working contributions.
Alternatively, your family member (i.e. your spouse, parent, child or sibling) who co-owns the flat with you can authorise us to use his CPF OA savings to pay for your HPS premium [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCover/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCoverLanding) using his Singpass.
Your HPS cover will end if we are unable to deduct the premium by the end of the grace period.']

question: How do I top up my spouse/parent/child/sibling's outstanding Home Protection Scheme premium?
answer:
['If you co-own the flat with your spouse/parent/child/sibling, you can authorise us to use your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for the insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs premium shortfall [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCover/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCoverLanding) using your Singpass.
If your application is approved by the Board, the premium will be deducted from the available balance in the insured's CPF OA first, followed by your CPF OA.']

question: How do I top-up my Home Protection Scheme premium?
answer:
['You may top-up your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium via the following means:
* PayNow at e-Cashier, or
* Cash at any Singapore Post branch offices
HPS premium top-up, which is credited to your CPF Ordinary Account (OA), is considered a voluntary contribution and is subject to the [prevailing CPF Annual Limit](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/making-voluntary-contributions).
Alternatively, your family member (i.e. your spouse, parent, child or sibling) who co-owns the flat with you can authorise us to use his CPF OA savings to pay your HPS premium shortfall [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCover/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCoverLanding) using his Singpass.']

question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I do not pay the annual premium?
answer:
['Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will lapse and you will no longer be covered under HPS. You will lose the insurance protection and HPS claim will not be payable in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability.
You will need to reapply for an HPS cover if you wish to be covered under HPS in future. Your eligibility for the new HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health at the point of application.']

question: What should I do if my Home Protection Scheme cover has lapsed?
answer:
['You will need to apply for a new Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover, so that you can receive the financial protection provided by HPS on your outstanding housing loan.
Your eligibility for the new HPS cover is subject to approval and you being in good health.']

question: What is the priority of the Home Protection Scheme deduction if I am also using my CPF savings to pay my monthly housing instalments?
answer:
['The payment for your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium takes priority over that of your monthly housing instalments. This is to ensure that you remained financially protected by HPS for your outstanding housing loan. Hence, during the premium grace period, your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings will be reserved for the HPS premium payment. This means that you will not be able to use your OA savings for any payments, including the monthly housing instalments, until your HPS premium is paid.
During this period, we suggest that you make alternative arrangements with your mortgagee on the shortfall in your monthly housing instalments.']

question: Why is the Home Protection Scheme premium not refundable if I did not make a claim?
answer: ['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premiums paid for past policy years are not refundable. This is because you have received insurance protection during the period of cover and would have been eligible to receive the HPS benefits in the event of a claim.']

question: What is the priority of Home Protection Scheme deduction if my family member has authorised the Board to deduct my premium from his CPF Ordinary Account?
answer: ['If your family member's (i.e. your spouse, parent, child, sibling) application is approved, the Home Protection Scheme premium will first be deducted from the available balance in your CPF Ordinary Account (OA), followed by your family member's OA.']

question: Can I use more than one of my family members' CPF Ordinary Account savings to pay my Home Protection Scheme premium shortfall?
answer:
['At any point in time, only one family member (i.e. your spouse, parent, child, sibling), who is a co-owner, can help you pay the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium.
However, you can approach another family member, who is also a co-owner, to help you pay the premium for your subsequent HPS renewals.']

question: How can my family member authorise the Board to deduct my Home Protection Scheme premium from his CPF Ordinary Account?
answer: ['Your family member (i.e. spouse, parent, child or sibling) who co-owns the flat with you can authorise us to use his CPF Ordinary Account savings [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCover/TopUpSelfOrSpouseHpsCoverLanding) using his Singpass.']

question: Which CPF account would the premium be refunded to if my family member has used his CPF savings to pay for my Home Protection Scheme premium?
answer: ['If your family member (i.e. spouse, parent, child or sibling) has used his CPF√Ç¬†Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your Home Protection Scheme premium, any premium refund will be paid into your OA.']

question: Where can I check the premium payable to renew my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['The Home Protection Scheme (HPS) is a level premium plan. This means that you pay the same annual premium throughout your HPS coverage period. The premium amount is stated on your HPS certificate which was sent to you when we first issued you the HPS cover.
Your HPS premium is deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account every year during your policy anniversary month. You can check the premium payable by viewing the previous premium deductions [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history) using your Singpass or from the Yearly Statement of Account.']

question: Where can I check and view my Home Protection Scheme premium deduction?
answer: ['You can check and view the Home Protection Scheme premium deduction from your CPF Ordinary Account [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history) using your Singpass. The deduction will also be shown in your Yearly Statement of Account.']

question: Why are only certain family members allowed to pay my Home Protection Scheme premium using their CPF Ordinary Account savings?
answer:
['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premiums are consumptive in nature. When your family member (i.e. spouse, parent, child or sibling) uses his Ordinary Account (OA) savings to help with your HPS premium payment, he will have less CPF savings for retirement.
Extending the use of OA savings for premium payments to certain family members, who are co-owners of the flat, is to enable your family to secure the home while limiting the impact on your family member's retirement adequacy.']

question: Can I reserve monies in my CPF Ordinary Account to pay the annual renewal premium for my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer: ['We willreserve the monies in your Ordinary Account (OA), including your incoming CPF contributions, up to a period of 2 months, for the full Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium amount, when you do not have sufficient funds in your OA, at the time of the renewal of the HPS cover.']

question: How can I apply to be exempted from Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['You may apply to be exempted from the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) if your private insurance coverage is enough to cover your outstanding housing loan against death, terminal illness (TI) and total permanent disability (TPD) until the end of your loan term or age 65, whichever is earlier.
**Steps**
* Approach the insurer(s) of your private insurance policies to submit your application to be exempted from HPS.
* Provide to your insurer(s) supporting documents showing your current\* housing loan details, i.e. loan commencement date, balance loan amount, balance term of loan and the mortgage rate. These can generally be found on your housing loan statement.
*\*Within six months from the date the application for exemption is submitted.*
We will only accept applications submitted by insurers. Upon receipt of the application and necessary documents, we will assess your eligibility for exemption from HPS, and inform you of the outcome generally within five working days.
If you are successful in the exemption application, you will get a full premium refund into your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) provided that the exemption application is received (by the Board) within one month from the issuance of the HPS cover. Otherwise, a pro-rated refund will be credited to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover.']

question: When can I apply to be exempted from the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['You may only apply to be exempted from Home Protection Scheme (HPS) after you have obtained legal ownership of your Housing & Development Board (HDB) flat and the housing loan for the property has been disbursed.
If you have refinanced your housing loan, you may only apply for HPS exemption after the refinancing is completed and the housing loan has been disbursed by the new mortgagee.
**Please note that before applying for exemption, you need to apply for HPS first.** This is to avoid any delay in commencing the use of your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your monthly housing instalments.
If you are successful in the exemption application, you will get a full premium refund into your (OA) provided that the exemption application is received (by the Board) within one month from the issuance of the HPS cover. Otherwise, a pro-rated refund will be credited to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover.']

question: How can I be granted an exemption from the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) exemption can only be granted if the applicant has appropriate, in-force private insurance policies that are sufficient to cover the outstanding housing loan (till end of the loan term) in the event of the applicant's death, terminal illness or total permanent disability, or age 65, whichever is earlier.
The√Ç¬†types of life insurance policies (both traditional and investment-linked) that are acceptable for HPS exemption are:* Whole Life
* Term Life
* Endowments
* Life Riders (must be attached to a basic policy), and
* Mortgage Reducing Term Assurance (MRTA) / Decreasing Term Rider
The types of√Ç¬†policies that are NOT acceptable for HPS exemption are:
* Policies that are assigned or pledged as collateral
* Policies under Section 73 of the Conveyancing Law And Property Act (Cap 61) or under irrevocable nomination/trust arrangement
* Policies with loans attached
* Non-life√Ç¬†insurance policies, such as business insurance policies, legacy insurance√Ç¬†policies, health insurance policies or general insurance policies (e.g. personal accidental, fire or home contents policies)
* Policies that are priced√Ç¬†in foreign currencies
* Policies from insurance companies that are not licensed by the Monetary Authority of√Ç¬†Singapore, and
* Group policies that are not portable.']

question: If I am currently insured under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS), how much premium refund will I get if my application to be exempted from HPS is approved?
answer:
['If we receive your HPS exemption request from your insurer within one month of the issuance of your HPS cover, we will refund the full HPS premium into your Ordinary Account.
Otherwise, you will receive a pro-rated refund upon the termination of your HPS cover.']

question: May I apply to be exempted from Home Protection Scheme for my new flat with the private insurance policy that was previously used for my old flat?
answer:
['You may use the private insurance policy to apply for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) exemption for your new flat if the following conditions are met:
* The remaining policy sum assured and policy term are enough to cover your current outstanding housing loan, and
* The policy covers you in the event of death, terminal illness and total permanent disability up to the full term of loan or age 65, whichever is earlier.
Please approach the insurer(s) of your private insurance policies to submit your application to be exempted from HPS. We will only accept applications submitted through insurers.']

question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme exemption if I refinance or restructure my housing loan?
answer: ['If you refinance/restructure your housing loan or had obtained a new housing loan for part-share/transfer of ownership of the flat, you would need to assess your private insurance policy(s) to ensure that the policy(s) remains sufficient to cover the newly refinanced or restructured loan. If the current policy(s) used for HPS exemption is insufficient to cover the newly-refinanced or restructured loan, please approach your insurer(s) to purchase additional policy(s) or apply for HPS.']

question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme exemption if my private insurance policy used for the exemption is discontinued or altered?
answer:
['You will no longer be exempted from Home Protection Scheme (HPS) once your insurer informs us that your private policy is discontinued or altered.
We will automatically issue an HPS cover to you based on the declared percentage you are exempted for, subject to your eligibility for an HPS cover.
You will receive a notification on your HPS certificate when your HPS cover is issued.']

question: Can I apply to be partially exempted from Home Protection Scheme?
answer: ['You cannot be exempted from Home Protection Scheme (HPS) and insured under HPS at the same time. However, you may apply to be 50% exempted from HPS while your co-owner apply for a 50% HPS share of cover. The total share of coverage for all co-owners must add up to at least 100%. You are encouraged to be insured under your private insurance based on your share of responsibility to service your housing loan. This is to ensure that you have sufficient insurance policy coverage to settle your share of outstanding housing loan in the event of a claim.']

question: What are the types of insurance policies that are not accepted for exemption from Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['The following are examples of the types of policies that are not accepted for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) exemption purposes:
* Policies that are assigned or pledged as collateral
* Policies under section 73 of the Conveyancing Law And Property Act (Cap. 61) or under any√Ç¬†irrevocable nomination/trust arrangement
* Policies with loans attached
* Non-life insurance policies, such as business insurance policies, legacy insurance policies, health insurance policies or general insurance policies (e.g. personal accidental, fire or home contents policies)
* Policies that are priced in foreign currencies
* Policies from insurance companies that are not licensed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and
* Group policies that are not portable.']

question: How do I apply to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer: ['You may apply [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes) using your Singpass if you wish to adjust your HPS cover.']

question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I make a partial repayment of my loan?
answer:
['We will automatically adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover accordingly if
1. You made a partial repayment towards your HDB loan, regardless of whether you are using cash or CPF savings, or
2. You made a partial repayment towards your bank loan, using CPF savings.
However, if you have taken a bank loan and have used cash for the partial payment, please apply [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes) using your Singpass. We will then write to your bank to obtain your latest loan details. Your HPS cover will not be adjusted if you do not inform us that you have made partial repayment in cash. Without the appropriate adjustment, you would be over-insured or under-insured, which would not be to your benefit.
Upon adjustment, your existing HPS cover will end and any unused premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details after partial repayment. The premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.']

question: What can I do if I do not want to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['You can apply to be exempted from the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) if you already have a mortgage-reducing insurance or an appropriate life insurance policy that is enough to cover your outstanding housing loan up to the full term of loan or age 65, whichever is earlier, in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability.
**Steps**
* Approach the insurer(s) of your private insurance policies to submit your application to be exempted from HPS.
* Provide to your insurer(s) supporting documents showing your current\* housing loan details, i.e. loan commencement date, balance loan amount, balance term of loan and the mortgage rate. These can generally be found on your housing loan statement.
*\*Within six months from the date the application for exemption is submitted.*
We will only accept applications submitted by insurers. Upon receipt of the application and necessary documents, we will assess your eligibility for exemption from HPS, and inform you of the outcome within five working days.
You will get a full premium refund into your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) if the exemption application is received (by the Board) within one month from the issuance of the HPS cover. Otherwise, a pro-rated refund will be credited to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover.']

question: When do I need to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['You need to adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover if:
* The loan repayment period or loan amount has increased, or
* Your share of responsibility in repaying the loan has changed.
This is to ensure that you are not over or under-insured and that your share of HPS cover is sufficient to pay your share of the outstanding loan in the event of a claim.
Please apply [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes) using your Singpass to inform us of the changes in your outstanding housing loan.
If you are refinancing your housing loan, e.g. from a Housing & Development Board (HDB) loan to a bank loan or a change in mortgagee, you do not need to apply to adjust your HPS cover. We will automatically adjust your HPS cover if your loan quantum and/or repayment period has reduced. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details and the premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account. If there are no changes to your housing loan details, we will update our records to reflect your new mortgagee.
If your HPS cover is adjusted, the HPS premium will also be adjusted and a new HPS cover will be issued to you.
In addition, a new health declaration is required if you are adjusting your HPS coverage upwards due to an increase in loan repayment period, loan quantum or share of cover. If you are not eligible for the additional coverage, you may continue to be insured under the cover that was extended to you earlier.']

question: Why does my Home Protection Scheme cover end when I have fully redeemed my housing loan?
answer: ['You will not need insurance protection if there is no outstanding housing loan. Thus, we will end your Home Protection Scheme cover and any pro-rated premium refund (if any) will be credited to your CPF Ordinary Account.']

question: What are the Home Protection Scheme claim criteria?
answer:
['A Home Protection Scheme (HPS) claim can be made when a member passes away or is certified by an accredited doctor\* to be suffering from√Ç¬†terminal illness or total permanent disability.1. Terminal illness refers to an illness that is likely to result in the death of the member within 12 months
2. Total permanent disability refers to (i) the inability to take part in any employment permanently, or (ii) the total permanent loss of physical function of any of the following:
* Both eyes
* Two limbs, or
* One eye and one limb
A claim under (a) or (b)(ii) can be made only if the terminal illness or total permanent loss of physical function started on or after 1 May 2016.
Detailed medical report may be obtained from the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs doctor to determine his eligibility to claim HPS benefits. To qualify for claim under (b)(i), the member must also have stopped physical employment.
If the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs doctor is not from the accredited list, arrangements may be made for the member to be further examined by CPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs doctors.
\* The list of accredited doctors are those from government restructured hospitals, polyclinics or specialists.']

question: If a member suffers from terminal illness or total permanent disability, how can he/she make a claim under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['A member can make a claim by applying [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyToClaimOnPermanentIncapacity/ClaimHpsBenefit) using his Singpass.
Arrangements may be made for the member to be further examined by CPF Board's doctors to determine his eligibility to claim Home Protection Scheme benefits.
Submission of the following documents with the online application is encouraged to help shorten claim processing time:
* A doctor's memorandum or medical report on his medical condition (dated not more than six months from claim application date)
* A letter from last employer showing the employment status or a letter on the cancellation of self-employed license
* Any other documents to support the claim (e.g. claim forms from other insurance companies or police report on incapacity due to accidents, etc)']

question: My family member has passed on and was covered under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS). As the next-of-kin, how do I claim the HPS benefits?
answer:
['Once the Board is notified of the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs death by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA), we will send information on Home Protection Scheme claim application to the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs correspondence address.
You can also submit a claim [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/NotifyADeath/InsuranceClaimOnDeathGroundsNotes) using your Singpass and attach a copy of the death certificate in the online form. The Board will contact the family members if any other documents are required.']

question: What are the claim exclusions for the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Claim benefits under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) will not be payable if any of the following events occur within the first policy year of the cover:
* Member committed self-inflicted injury or suicide
* Member committed a criminal offence punishable by death, or
* The claim arose out of member's own intentional criminal act
HPS benefits is also not payable if:
* Member was not in good health before the commencement of HPS cover
* Member provided false or misleading information, or
* The claim arose from wars or any warlike operations or participation in any riot']

question: What are the restrictions imposed on the sale of my flat after I have claimed the Home Protection Scheme benefits?
answer: ['There are no restrictions and you can sell your flat after claiming the benefits under the Home Protection Scheme.']

question: Do I need to refund the sale proceeds to my CPF accounts if I sell my flat after claiming the benefits under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer: ['You will still need to refund the principal CPF amount withdrawn for the flat plus the accrued interest to your CPF accounts.']

question: If my co-owner and I are both insured under the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) for 75% each, what will happen after my co-owner has claimed the HPS benefits?
answer: ['We will pay the sum assured based on 75% share of your co-owner's Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover upon approval of the claim. Subsequently, your HPS cover will be adjusted to match the remaining 25% of the outstanding housing loan.']

question: I am currently insured under the Single Premium Home Protection Scheme (HPS). Can I now switch to the Annual Premium HPS instead?
answer: ['The Annual Premium Home Protection Scheme (HPS) only applies to those who join HPS on or after 1 March 2001.']

question: What will happen to my Single Premium Home Protection Scheme cover if there are changes to my outstanding housing loan?
answer:
['If your loan repayment period or loan amount has changed, we will terminate your Single Premium (SP) Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover, and issue an Annual Premium (AP) HPS cover to you based on your new outstanding housing loan. Any surrender value of your SP HPS will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.
However, any increase to your HPS cover arising from the changes to your housing loan, e.g. increase in cover period or sum assured, is subject to you being in good health. You will remain insured under your SP cover if you are not eligible for the additional AP cover.
[Do I need to inform the Board to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover if I make a partial repayment of my loan?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/do-i-need-to-inform-the-board-if-i-make-a-partial-repayment-of-my-loan)']

question: I am currently insured under the Single Premium Home Protection Scheme (HPS). How can I extend my HPS cover until age 65?
answer:
['Your Single Premium Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will only insure you up to age 55 or 60. If your original housing loan is still outstanding by then, we will extend your HPS cover to age 65 by issuing you an Annual Premium (AP) HPS cover when your Single Premium HPS cover expires.
If you had restructured your housing loan and had been previously rejected by CPF Board HPS for an increase to your HPS cover period or sum assured arising from the changes to your housing loan, you will not be eligible for the additional AP cover.']

question: I am currently insured under the Single Premium Home Protection Scheme (HPS). Do I have to pay extra premium when my HPS cover is extended to age 65?
answer: ['You will need to pay extra premium for the extension of your Home Protection Scheme cover to age 65. However, the premium will be paid annually.']

question: What will happen to my Single Premium Home Protection Scheme cover if I change my share of cover but there are no changes to my outstanding housing loan?
answer:
['You will remain covered under the Single Premium Home Protection Scheme (HPS) if you have changed your share of cover without any changes to your outstanding housing loan.
We will adjust your Single Premium HPS cover according to the new percentage declared once we approve the adjustment. Any increase to your HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.']

question: What is the difference between Home Protection Scheme , HDB Fire Insurance and Home Insurance?
answer:
['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) is a mortgage-reducing insurance that protects you and your loved ones from losing your Housing & Development Board√Ç¬†(HDB)√Ç¬†flat due to the inability to make mortgage payments in the event of death, terminal illness or total permanent disability. HPS, which is administered by CPFB, insures members up to age 65 or until the housing loans are paid up, whichever is earlier.
The HDB Fire Insurance Scheme, which is administered by HDB, helps to relieve flat owners of the financial burden of repair work in the event of a fire. The HDB fire insurance covers the cost of reinstating damaged internal structures, fixtures, as well as areas built and provided by HDB.
Home Insurance (also known as Home Content Insurance or Homeowners Insurance) is a type of property insurance that covers a residence and helps in paying for repair or replacing one√¢¬Ä¬ôs belongings if they are damaged by perils such as fires, vandalism, burglary and more. Home insurance can be purchased from private insurers.']

question: Who will receive the claim benefits under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['The Home Protection Scheme (HPS) claim benefits will be paid to the Housing & Development Board or the mortgagee directly, to settle the outstanding housing loan, up to the insured sum.
If the claim is admitted under death ground, HPS claim benefits will be paid in a lump sum.
If the claim is admitted under medical ground, the member's housing instalments (based on the share of HPS cover) may be paid by HPS for a period of up to two years before a review of member's eligibility to claim the remaining insured sum in full is carried out.
If the HPS sum assured is higher than the outstanding loan, the excess amount will be paid to the insured member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF Ordinary Account.
You may find out more on [what happens to the CPF savings for deceased members](/member/account-services/account-closure/paying-out-cpf-when-you-pass-away).']

question: My family member has passed on. How do I check if he/she was covered under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer: ['To check if your family member was covered under the Home Protection Scheme, you may [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) and select √¢¬Ä¬úHousing/Property√¢¬Ä¬ù as the **Subject** and √¢¬Ä¬úAppeal √¢¬Ä¬ì Home Protection Scheme√¢¬Ä¬ù as the **Category**.']

question: Do I need to be insured under Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Whether you need to be insured under Home Protection Scheme (HPS) depends on whether you are using:
CPF savings to service your monthly housing instalments
You need to be insured under HPS.
Your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.
If you are not eligible for an HPS cover due to serious pre-existing medical condition, you may still use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing instalment.
Cash to service your monthly housing instalments
HPS is optional for you. You are strongly encouraged to apply for an HPS cover if you are an owner of the flat and if you do not have adequate financial protection for your share of outstanding housing loan. Your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.']

question: What types of property can be covered under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Your eligibility for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover depends on the type of property owned:
Housing & Development Board (HDB) Flat
You are eligible to apply for an HPS cover if you own an HDB flat.
Housing and Urban Development Corporation (HUDC)
You are eligible to apply for an HPS cover if you bought your non-privatised HUDC flat before 1 November 1998. Upon privatisation, HUDC flat will be categorised as private residential property and you will no longer be eligible for an HPS cover. The HPS cover will thus be terminated. However, special concession has been made to allow you to continue your HPS coverage as long as you do not refinance your housing loan or there are no changes to ownership of your HUDC flat.
Executive Condominium (EC) or Private Property
You are not eligible for an HPS cover as EC and private properties are not considered public housing. You are encouraged to buy equivalent private insurance if you have outstanding housing loans on your EC or private property.']

question: How do I apply to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['The process to apply to be insured under Home Protection Scheme (HPS) depends on whether you are taking:
Housing & Development Board (HDB) Loan
You may apply for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover when you are applying to withdraw your CPF savings for your monthly housing instalments at HDB.
Alternatively, you may apply for an HPS cover [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes), using your Singpass.
Bank Loan
You may apply for a Home Protection Scheme cover [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes), using your Singpass, when you are applying to commence√Ç¬†your monthly housing instalments.']

question: What share of the Home Protection Scheme cover should I apply for?
answer:
['Your share of Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover depends on your share of responsibility to service the monthly housing instalments.
Paying the monthly housing instalments solely
You should be insured under HPS for 100% of the housing loan.
Paying the monthly housing instalments with other co-owners
Your share of HPS cover should at least match the proportion of the monthly housing instalment which is payable with your CPF savings and/or cash. The total share of cover per household must add up to at least 100%. However, you and your co-owner(s) can also individually choose to insure a higher share of cover, up to 100%. HPS pays benefits based on the share of the cover of the insured in the event of a claim.
A higher share of cover will result in a higher annual premium which is deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account. As such, please take into account your need for financial protection and long term retirement needs when deciding your share of cover.
Monthly housing instalment = $ 1,500 You are using $1,000 from your CPF and $200 cash. Your co-owner is paying $300 from his CPF to service the loan.
Your share of the cover should be at least: $1,200 / $1,500 x 100% = 80%
You can however, opt for up to 100% share of cover.
Your co-owner's share of the cover should be at least: $300 / $1,500 x 100% = 20%
Your co-owner can also opt for up to 100% share of cover.']

question: Why should my share of Home Protection Scheme cover minimally match my share of responsibility to service the housing loan?
answer:
['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) claims are paid based on the insured sum of the insured. If you are covered for less than your share of responsibility in servicing the housing loan and a claim event happens, the HPS payout will not be enough to cover your share of the outstanding housing loan, and your co-owner might not have the financial means to continue to service the remaining housing loan.
Example
If you are 100% responsible for the servicing of the loan and you are only covered for 50% HPS share of cover, in the event of a claim, we will only pay 50% of your outstanding housing loan up to the insured sum. Your co-owner will need to continue to service the remaining housing loan.
Both you and your co-owner may choose to be covered for 100% HPS share of cover each. In the event of a claim, we will settle 100% of your outstanding housing loan up to the insured sum. We will then end your co-owner's HPS cover and refund the unused premium to his Ordinary Account.']

question: What will happen if I am not eligible for a Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['If you are not eligible for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover due to serious pre-existing medical condition, you may still use your CPF savings to pay your monthly housing instalment.
If you are previously covered under HPS, we will assess your eligibility to port√Ç¬†your previous HPS cover to your new property.
[How do I qualify for the porting of my previous Home Protection Scheme cover to my new property?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/how-do-i-qualify-for-the-porting-of-my-previous-home-protection-)']

question: How do I pay the Home Protection Scheme premium?
answer:
['Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premium is automatically deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account (OA) annually.
You can check and view the deduction from your CPF account [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history) using your Singpass. The deduction will also be shown in your Yearly Statement of Account.
If your OA balance is not enough to pay the premium, you will be notified to top up your OA within a grace period of two months. Your family member i.e. your spouse/parent/child/sibling, who co-owns the flat with you, can authorise us to use his/her OA savings to pay your premium shortfall.
Can I pay my Home Protection Scheme premium by instalments?
The HPS premium is structured to be paid yearly so that the scheme remains viable and the premiums are kept affordable for all insured members.
Can I pay my Home Protection Scheme premium using my CPF Special Account (SA)?
HPS premiums can only be paid from the savings in CPF Ordinary Account (OA). The CPF Special Account (SA) savings are meant for members√¢¬Ä¬ô retirement needs as it may be the only source of funds that members can turn to for financing their living expenses in old age.']

question: What is the minimal mortgage rate that I need to purchase for my private Mortgage Reducing Term Assurance policy if I wish to be exempted from Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['The mortgage rate of your Mortgage Reducing Term Assurance (MRTA) policy must be higher or equivalent√Ç¬†to the assumed mortgage rate of the√Ç¬†housing loan, which√Ç¬†depends on whether you are taking:
Housing & Development Board (HDB) Loan
If you are taking an HDB loan under the concessionary rate, a mortgage rate of 3% is assumed.
If you are taking an HDB loan under the market rate, a mortgage rate of 4% is assumed.
These mortgage rates are assumed after taking into consideration the historical rates and other factors such as the rising interest rate environment. This is a prudent approach, to ensure that members are adequately covered for their outstanding housing loan over the entire loan tenor.
Bank Loan
If you are taking a bank loan, a mortgage rate of 4% is assumed, after taking into consideration the historical rates and other factors such as the rising interest rate environment. This is a prudent approach, to ensure that members are adequately covered for their outstanding housing loan over the entire loan tenor.']

question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I have refinanced my housing loan?
answer:
['After you have refinanced your housing loan, e.g. from a Housing & Development Board (HDB) loan to a bank loan or a change in mortgagee, you do not need to apply to adjust your HPS cover. We will automatically adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover if your loan quantum and/or repayment period has reduced. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details and the premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.
However, if your loan quantum and/or repayment period has increased, we will write to you\*.
If there are no changes to your housing loan details, we will update our records to reflect your new mortgagee.
*\*Any increase in your HPS coverage is subject to approval and you being in good health.*
Find out more:
* [What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme exemption if I have refinanced my housing loan?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/what-will-happen-to-my-home-protection-scheme-exemption-if-i-ref)']

question: Do I need to inform the Board to adjust my Home Protection Scheme cover if I make a partial repayment of my loan?
answer:
['The need to inform the Board depends on whether you are making a partial repayment of your:
Housing & Development Board (HDB) Loan
You do not need to inform us of the partial repayment of your housing loan, regardless of whether you are using cash or CPF savings for the partial repayment.
Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will be automatically adjusted when we are notified accordingly by HDB. Your existing HPS cover will end and any unused premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details after partial repayment. The premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.
Bank Loan
If you are using cash to make a partial repayment of your housing loan, please apply to adjust your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes) using your Singpass. We will then write to your bank to obtain your latest loan details. Your HPS cover will not be adjusted if you do not inform us that you have made partial repayment in cash. Without the appropriate adjustment, you would be over-insured or under-insured, which would not be to your benefit.
If you are using your CPF savings to make a partial repayment of your housing loan, you do not need to inform us of the partial repayment. We will adjust your HPS cover automatically.
Upon adjustment, your existing HPS cover will end and any unused premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account. A new HPS cover will be issued to you based on the latest loan details after partial repayment. The premium for the new cover will be deducted from your CPF Ordinary Account.']

question: How can I include new co-owners and insure them under the Home Protection Scheme?
answer:
['You need to contact or visit the Housing & Development Board (HDB) Branch Office managing your flat to include your new co-owners.
To apply for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover:
If you are taking HDB Loan
Your co-owner may apply for an HPS cover when he is applying to withdraw his CPF savings for his monthly housing instalments at HDB. Alternatively, he may apply for an HPS cover online using his Singpass.
If you are taking Bank Loan
Your co-owner may apply for an HPS cover when he is applying to withdraw his CPF savings for his monthly housing instalments online using his Singpass.
He may apply for an HPS cover online using his Singpass, when he is applying to commence his monthly housing instalments.']

question: How do I terminate my Home Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['You may apply to terminate your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover online using your Singpass.
The total remaining coverage for the co-owner(s) of your flat must be at least 100% after the termination of your HPS cover. Otherwise, your termination application will be rejected.
What happens after you have terminated your HPS cover?
You will get a full premium refund to your Ordinary Account (OA) if the termination application is received within one month from the issuance of your HPS cover. Otherwise, any unused premium will be refunded back to your OA upon the termination of your HPS cover. The monthly servicing of your housing loan instalments via CPF savings (if any) will cease upon the termination of your HPS cover.']

question: What will happen to my Home Protection Scheme cover if I sell my flat, fully repay my loan or buy a new flat?
answer:
['Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will be affected depending on whether you:
Sell your flat
We will terminate your HPS cover if you sell your flat. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.
Fully repay your loan
This also depends on whether you are fully repaying your:
Your HPS cover will be automatically terminated when we are notified by HDB that you have fully repaid your loan, regardless of whether you are using CPF savings or cash. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.
If you are using your CPF savings to fully repay your loan, your HPS cover will be automatically terminated when we are notified by the bank that you have fully repaid your loan. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.
However, if you are using cash to fully repay your loan, [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) to inform us of the full repayment. We will write to your bank to obtain your loan repayment details before terminating your HPS cover. Upon termination of your HPS cover, any unused premium will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account. Your HPS cover will not be terminated if you do not inform us that you have fully repaid your loan in cash.
Buy a new flat
We will terminate your HPS cover for the old flat if you buy a new flat. Any unused HPS premium will be paid to your CPF Ordinary Account.
You will need to apply for an HPS cover for your new flat. The HPS cover for your new flat is subject to your health condition. As such, you will need to declare and fully disclose all information regarding your health in your application.']

question: Do I need to inform the Board to terminate my Home Protection Scheme cover if I have fully repaid my loan?
answer:
['It depends on whether you are fully repaying your:
HDB Loan
You do not need to inform us of the full repayment of your housing loan, regardless of whether you are using CPF savings or cash. Your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will be automatically terminated when we are notified by HDB that you have fully repaid your loan. The unused premium, if any, will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account.
Bank Loan
If you are using cash to fully repay your bank loan, please [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) to inform us of the full repayment. We will write to your bank to obtain your loan repayment details before terminating your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover. Upon termination of your HPS cover, the unused premium, if any, will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account. Your HPS cover will not be terminated if you do not inform us that you have fully repaid your loan in cash.
