If you are using your CPF savings to fully repay your loan, you do not need to inform us of the full repayment. Your HPS cover will be automatically terminated and the unused premium, if any, will be refunded to your CPF Ordinary Account.']

question: How do I claim the Home Protection Scheme benefits?
answer:
['A Home Protection Scheme claim can be made when a member passes away or suffers from terminal illness or total permanent disability.
Member passes away
The family of the deceased can inform CPF Board of the passing by providing a copy of the death certificate and applying [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/NotifyADeath/InsuranceClaimOnDeathGroundsNotes) using their Singpass. CPF Board will contact the family members if any other documents are required.
Member suffers from terminal illness or total permanent disability
A member can make a claim by applying [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyToClaimOnPermanentIncapacity/ClaimHpsBenefit) using his Singpass.
Arrangements may be made for the member to be further examined by CPF Board's doctors to determine his eligibility to claim HPS benefits.
1. A doctor's memorandum or medical report on the medical condition (dated not more than six months from claim application date).
2. A letter from last employer showing the employment status or a letter on the cancellation of self-employed license.
3. Any other documents to support the claim (e.g. claim forms from other insurance companies or police report on incapacity due to accidents, etc).']

question: How can I check the status of my Home Protection Scheme exemption application?
answer:
['Please confirm with your insurers if they had submitted your application to the Board. You may request them to provide you with the application number (i.e. FormSG ID number).
If the application had been submitted, you will receive notification of the outcome of your application within 5 working days from the date of application submission by your insurer(s). Your insurer(s) will also be notified of the outcome.
However, if you did not hear from us within 5 working days, after confirmation that your insurer had submitted your application, you may [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) to check on your application status.']

question: Can I pay my Home Protection Scheme premium by instalments?
answer:
['No. The Home Protection Scheme premium is structured to be paid yearly in full to keep administrative costs low and hence keep the premiums affordable for all insured members.
You can find out more on the [available payment options](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/what-if-i-do-not-have-enough-savings-in-my-cpf-ordinary-account).
Alternatively, please [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if you need more time to make your premium payment.']

question: How can I apply for Home Protection Scheme exemption (HPS) using multiple private insurance policies from different insurers?
answer:
['You may wish to approach your insurer or use the self-help tool ([HPS exemption calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/calculators/home-protection-scheme-exemption)) to determine if one or more of your private insurance policies is needed to cover your outstanding housing loan. Should one policy be sufficient to fully cover your outstanding housing loan, you may apply for HPS exemption using one policy through a single application.
If you require multiple policies from different insurers to cover your outstanding housing loan, you will need to submit an application for each insurer. Here is how you can go about it:
* Approach the respective insurers to submit your applications **concurrently.** Please **submit one application for each insurer**.
* Attach the relevant supporting documents which show your current\* housing loan details i.e. loan commencement date, balance loan amount, balance term of loan and the mortgage rate. These can generally be found on your housing loan statement.
\*Within six months from the date of your application for HPS exemption
Upon receipt of your application(s) and the necessary documents from your insurers declared in your application forms, we will assess your eligibility for exemption from HPS, and inform you of the outcome generally within five working days. Please note that your application would be rejected if we fail to receive all your applications from your insurers generally√Ç¬†**within seven calendar days** from the date of receipt of the first application submitted by one of your insurers.']

question: Why am I required to attend a medical examination for my Home Protection Scheme application?
answer:
['Your eligibility for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover is subject to approval and you being in good health. To assess your eligibility for HPS cover, we may arrange a medical examination for you and/or request a copy of the medical report on your health condition.
You will receive a notification from the Board if you are scheduled for an HPS medical examination. You may check or reschedule your medical examination appointment online via [e-Medical Appointment Service](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/medappt).
Find out more:
* [Can I provide my own medical report instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/can-i-provide-medical-report-instead-of-attending-medical-exam)']

question: What will happen if I missed my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer:
['If you have missed your appointment for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination, the Board may not be able to assess your eligibility and process your application. The Board will notify you on the outcome of your HPS application.
If you are not eventually issued a HPS cover and wish to be re-considered for coverage under the scheme, please submit a new HPS application [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes) , using your Singpass.']

question: What tests am I required to undergo for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer:
['The medical tests required for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination depend on your health condition.
Generally, the medical examination includes the following:
1. General checks with height, weight, visual acuity, blood pressure readings and pulse rate
2. Lipid profile
3. Fasting blood glucose
4. Urinalysis
Find out more:
* [Do I have to pay for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/do-i-have-to-pay-for-the-hps-medical-examination)
* [What do I need to prepare for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/what-to-prepare-for-hps-medical-examination)']

question: Why is the premium for my new Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover higher than my old HPS cover even though I have made a partial repayment of my loan?
answer:
['Your Home Protection Scheme premium is higher than before because you had extended your repayment period to a longer tenure, after you made the partial repayment of your loan.
Find out more:
* [How is the Home Protection Scheme premium calculated?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/how-is-the-home-protection-scheme-premium-calculated-)']

question: How long does the Home Protection Scheme medical examination take?
answer: ['The entire Home Protection Scheme medical examination process generally takes up to 2 hours,√Ç¬†excluding the time needed for registration.']

question: What do I need to prepare for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer:
['You are required to fast for at least 8 hours before your Home Protection Scheme medical examination appointment. Plain water and your usual medication are fine.
For ladies, please note that urine test should be performed at least 5 days after the last date of menstruation. If you are menstruating on the day of your appointment, please inform the clinic staff or doctor as the urine test would not be accurate.
Find out more:
* [How do I reschedule my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/how-do-i-reschedule-my-appointment-for-hps-medical-examination)']

question: Do I have to pay for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer:
['The cost of the initial Home Protection Scheme medical examination will be borne by the Board.
However, if you wish to conduct any subsequent tests, examinations or obtain second opinions, the cost of such investigations would have to be borne by you. You can choose to proceed with subsequent tests at the same clinic or any other clinic of your choice.']

question: Will I be given a medical certificate for my Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer: ['The Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs panel clinics, which conduct the Home Protection Scheme medical examination, will not issue a medical certificate for the medical examination. However, you can ask the clinic to issue a time chit as evidence of your attendance and duration at the clinic.']

question: Can I provide my own medical report instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer:
['If you have an up-to-date detailed medical report\* on your health condition, you may provide it to us at your own cost. Please submit your medical report to us via [Write to Us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us).
We will assess and inform you whether the information is sufficient to conclude your Home Protection Scheme application. If the information is not sufficient, we may still require you to attend the medical examination.
\*The medical report must be from a medical institution in Singapore.']

question: Can I attend the Home Protection Scheme medical examination at my preferred clinic?
answer:
['You can choose to attend a medical examination at your preferred clinic and thereafter provide the medical report\* on your health condition to CPF Board, at your own expense. If the information is not sufficient, we may still require you to attend the medical examination for the Home Protection Scheme (HPS) with the Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs panel of clinics.
The medical examination arranged by CPF Board is with the Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs panel of clinics, which are located centrally and equipped with the facilities and trained personnel to conduct the medical examination for HPS. The cost of the initial HPS medical examination will be borne by the Board.
\*The medical report must be from a medical institution in Singapore
Find out more:
* [Can I provide my own medical report instead of attending the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/can-i-provide-medical-report-instead-of-attending-medical-exam)
* [What tests am I required to undergo for the Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/what-tests-am-i-required-to-undergo-for-hps-medical-examination)']

question: How do I reschedule my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?
answer:
['I have an upcoming appointment for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination:
You may check or reschedule your appointment for HPS medical examination online via [e-Medical Appointment Service](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/medappt).
You are not allowed to reschedule if your appointment is within the next 2 days.
I have missed my appointment for Home Protection Scheme (HPS) medical examination:
You are not able to view your appointment for HPS medical examination online or reschedule it if you have missed the appointment date.
Find out more:
* [What will happen if I missed my appointment for Home Protection Scheme medical examination?](/member/faq/home-ownership/home-protection-scheme/what-will-happen-if-i-missed-my-hps-medical-examination)']

question: Can I use the monies in my CPF Special Account to pay the annual renewal premium for my Home Protection Scheme cover if I do not have sufficient savings in my CPF Ordinary Account?
answer:
['Savings in your CPF Special Account are meant for your retirement needs.
As Home Protection Scheme (HPS) premiums are consumptive in nature, they can only be paid using the savings in the CPF Ordinary Account.']

question: Why does the status of my Home Protection Scheme cover show √¢¬Ä¬úpending renewal√¢¬Ä¬ù in the Home ownership dashboard when I have sufficient monies in my CPF Ordinary Account for the premium?
answer:
['The deduction of premiums from members√¢¬Ä¬ô Ordinary Account (OA) for the renewal of Home Protection Scheme (HPS) covers takes place on a weekly basis. If the renewal date of your HPS cover is between the weekly deduction runs, the status of your HPS cover will be √¢¬Ä¬úpending renewal√¢¬Ä¬ù in the Home ownership dashboard. The status of your HPS cover will change to √¢¬Ä¬úActive√¢¬Ä¬ù once premium has been successfully deducted.
We will inform you to top-up the premium shortfall if you do not have enough OA savings to pay the premium.']

question: If I am already exempted from Home Protection Scheme (HPS) with my private insurance policy, can I apply for HPS again?
answer:
['If you are already exempted from Home Protection Scheme (HPS) with your private insurance policy, you may still apply to be covered under HPS anytime.
To apply for an HPS cover, please submit the application [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ApplyOrAdjustHpsCover/ImportantNotes), using your Singpass.']

question: Can I commence my housing monthly instalment if my application to be covered under Home Protection Scheme has not been approved?
answer:
['Yes, you can proceed to commence your housing monthly instalment before your application for Home Protection Scheme cover has been approved.
Find out more:
[How do I apply to use my CPF savings for my housing loan monthly instalments?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/home-ownership/housing-scheme/how-do-i-apply-to-use-my-cpf-savings-for-my-housing-monthly)']

question: What is MediSave?
answer: ['MediSave is a national savings scheme which helps CPF members save for future medical expenses, especially during retirement. Saving for future medical expenses is important, as the need for medical care and hospitalisation increases significantly as one grows older. It is important that you spend your MediSave savings prudently. Besides hospitalisations, MediSave can also be used to pay for certain costly outpatient treatments like dialysis, cancer drugs and radiotherapy, as well as for treatment of a number of chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension. You can refer to the [MOH website](https://www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/medisave) for the uses of MediSave and the withdrawal limits. MediSave can also be used to pay the premiums of approved medical insurance schemes like MediShield Life. If you want additional coverage for your bills in private hospitals, or A and B1 ward types in public hospitals, you can use your MediSave to help pay for an Integrated Shield Plan from an approved private insurer. These plans are integrated with MediShield Life to provide additional medical coverage on top of MediShield Life. If you are aged 40 and above, MediSave can also be used to pay for the premiums of ElderShield and ElderShield Supplements.√Ç¬†You can visit the√Ç¬†[MOH website](https://www.moh.gov.sg/careshieldlife/about-eldershield) for more information on ElderShield and ElderShield Supplements.']

question: What is not covered under the MediSave scheme?
answer: ['MediSave generally does not cover optional and cosmetic treatments, accident and emergency (A&E) fees and non-medical treatments such as ambulance transport. Please approach the medical institution to find out whether your treatment can be covered under MediSave.']

question: Are there additional charges for using my MediSave to pay for my medical expenses?
answer: ['CPF Board does not impose any administrative fee for using MediSave.']

question: I am a foreigner. Do I have MediSave?
answer: ['As long as you have a MediSave Account, you may use your MediSave for approved treatments in local medical institutions participating in the MediSave scheme.']

question: What happens to my MediSave if I do not use it?
answer:
['Any unused MediSave savings will remain in your MediSave Account and grow with interest.
Learn more about√Ç¬†[CPF interest rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest).']

question: What is the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF)?
answer:
['When you seek medical treatment at a Medical Institution (MI) participating in the MediSave scheme, the MI staff will inform you if your MediSave can be used for the treatment as well as the amount you may use.
If you intend to use MediSave for your treatment, you will need to complete the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF) provided by the MI staff, and authorise them to submit the claim on your behalf.
There are two types of MCAF available:
**1. MCAF (Single Institution)**
To authorise a specific Medical Institution (MI) to submit MediSave claim(s) for your own and/or your family member(s) medical expenses. If you have ongoing outpatient treatments at the MI, you can provide authorisation for a specific visit, a specific time period, or a standing authorisation until you revoke it.
**2. MCAF (Multiple Institutions)**
To authorise all Public Healthcare Institutions to submit MediSave claims for your own medical expenses only. The authorisation will remain valid until you revoke it.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my siblings' insurance premiums for schemes such as MediShield Life, Integrated Shield Plans or ElderShield/ElderShield Supplement?
answer: ['Yes. Since 1 June 2019, members may use their MediSave to pay for their siblings' insurance premiums.']

question: Can I use my MediSave for my siblings' medical expenses?
answer: ['You may use your MediSave to pay for your siblings' medical expenses, as long as they are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents (SC/PR). You would have to provide proof to the medical institutions that your siblings are SC/PR (e.g. NRICs).']

question: Can I use MediSave to pay the remainder of my medical bill that is not covered under my pensioner benefits?
answer:
['You can use your own or your approved dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô (i.e. spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings) MediSave to pay the remainder of your medical bill that is not covered under your pensioner benefits, up to the MediSave withdrawal limits. The expenses incurred must be for medical treatments approved under the MediSave scheme.
If you would like to use your MediSave to pay the remainder of your medical bill, please inform the Medical Institution (MI). You will be required to complete the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF), which authorises the MI to use your MediSave to pay the bill. Please note that any amount above the MediSave withdrawal limits would need to be paid in cash.']

question: How long does it take to process applications relating to Healthcare?
answer:
['Please refer to the table below for the processing time of our various Healthcare services.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Top up or voluntary contribution to MediSave Account (to pay MediShield Life Premiums) | **PayNow QR**: Generally processed almost instantly√Ç¬†*Please note that payment via eNETS Debit is discontinued from 23 April 2023.√Ç¬†[Find out more**.**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/general-information---useful-tips/electronic-services/why-is-payment-via-enets-discontinued)* |
| Change your Payer for MediShield Life Cover | **Online**: Within three working days |
| Stop Premium Payment for your Dependant(s)' MediShield Life Cover |
| Make a Health Declaration for new Permanent Residents Applicant | **Online**: Within seven working days |
| Make a MediSave Claim | **Online**: Within three working days from the day we receive the claim from the medical institution |
| Make a MediShield Life Claim | **Online**: Within seven working days from the day we receive the claim from the medical institution/ insurer |
| Apply for MediSave/MediShield Life Reimbursement from Employers/Insurers | **Online**: Within five working days |
| Top up My/My Loved Ones√¢¬Ä¬ô MediSave Account using CPF | **Online**: Immediate |']

question: Why am I receiving digital notifications instead of the hardcopy MediSave transaction statement to inform me of a deduction from my MediSave?
answer:
['As part of our commitment to protect members against fraudulent deductions and to reduce environmental footprint, we have transitioned to digital notifications to inform you of your MediSave deduction for medical expenses. You will receive notifications via one of the following modes:
a. If your email address is registered with CPF Board, you will receive an email notification; b. If you do not have an email address registered, but have a mobile number registered, you will receive an SMS notification.
If you have installed the CPF Mobile App and enabled push notifications, you will receive push notification alerts on your mobile phone as an additional notification.
These digital notifications will ensure that you are informed of any deductions made from your MediSave in a timely manner. If you wish to update your contact details, you may do so via the [Account settings](https://cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings)√Ç¬†page on CPF website, after logging in with your Singpass.']

question: Can I choose to receive both digital notification and a hardcopy MediSave transaction statement?
answer: ['You will not be receiving hardcopies of your MediSave transaction statement once you receive notifications digitally. This will aid us in our pursuit to reduce the use of paper.']

question: Can I choose to receive the hardcopy MediSave transaction statement instead?
answer:
['Notification through hardcopy statements will result in a delay in informing you of deductions made from your MediSave account. It will also contribute to the usage of paper, which is not environmentally friendly.
We encourage members to join us in our efforts to go digital and reduce our environmental footprint, while enjoying the convenience of timely notifications.']

question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my overseas medical treatment if I am living overseas for the long term?
answer: ['As MediSave is primarily meant for medical treatment in Singapore, it does not cover overseas medical expenses for those residing overseas for the long term. This is a common feature of national healthcare systems in many countries. If you are residing overseas for the long term, please consider obtaining medical coverage to meet your overseas healthcare needs.']

question: How much MediSave can I use to pay for my own or an approved dependant's day surgery bills?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave:
* Up to $300 per day for ward charges; and
* Between $250 and $7,550 for your surgical procedures, depending on the type of procedures performed.
You can use up to the same withdrawal limit for each approved dependant. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.']

question: I am going for a day surgery. How do I know if I can use my MediSave in that clinic/hospital?
answer:
['You can refer to this [list of medical institutions or day surgery centres](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/list-of-medical-institutions-medisave-medishield-life.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) participating in the MediSave scheme.
To use your MediSave, please inform the staff handling your hospital admission that you wish to do so. The staff will submit your claim for you after your authorisation.']

question: Can I use MediSave to pay for the removal of my wisdom tooth?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave savings to pay for the removal of your wisdom tooth incurred at a participating private dental clinic under the MediSave Scheme, provided that it is a surgical procedure. The day surgery limits are:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| 1) Day surgery | Up to a maximum of $300 per day for daily hospital charges, including investigations, medicines and doctor's attendance fees. |
| 2) Operation | A fixed limit for operations ranging from $250 to $7,550 depending on the type of operations performed. |']

question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my dental implant?
answer:
['You can use MediSave to pay for your dental implant insertion or removal as long as it is a surgical procedure.
For a dental surgery with insertion or removal of dental implants, you can use MediSave to pay for your dental implants, up to the following limits:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| Insertion of Dental Implants | Number of implant(s) inserted x $950 Operation limit of Table 2C |
| Removal of Dental Implants | Number of implant(s) removed x $450 Operation limit of Table 1C |
For example, if you have to insert two dental implants, you can use up to $1,900 (2 x $950) for payment of your dental implants.']

question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my colonoscopy screening?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave to pay for colonoscopy screening at [all public healthcare institutions and approved private hospitals and medical institutions](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/List%20of%20MIs_MSV_MSHL%2015112021.pdf), provided you are aged 50 years old and above and it is a day surgery procedure. The day surgery limits are:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| 1) Day Surgery | Up to a maximum of $300 per day for daily hospital charges, including investigations, medicines and doctor's attendance fees. |
| 2) Operation | A fixed operation limit of either $950 or $1,250, depending on the type of operations performed. |']

question: I intend to seek treatment in a hospital. How do I know if I can use my MediSave in that hospital?
answer:
['Please refer to this [list of medical institutions or day surgery centres](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/list-of-medical-institutions-medisave-medishield-life.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) participating in the MediSave scheme.
To use your MediSave, please inform the staff handling your hospital admission that you wish to do so. The staff will submit your claim for you after your authorisation.']

question: What√Ç¬†types of hospital charges can be covered by my MediSave?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave for your hospitalisation, surgery, and rehabilitation charges.
![Use of MediSave for surgery, hospitalisation, rehabilitation](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/FAQ_TypesOfHospitalCharges.png)']

question: What happens if my employer or insurer is paying part of my hospital expenses?
answer: ['If you have given the hospital a Letter of Guarantee or Hospitalisation Identity Card at admission, the hospital will send the bill to your employer or insurer. Your employer or insurer will then work out the part of the bill to be paid by you. They will then ask you to sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF) if you wish to pay the amount from your MediSave Account (MA). When your employer or insurer returns the MCAF to the hospital, the hospital will arrange to deduct the amount from your MA. Some hospitals may request that you sign the MCAF at admission especially if your employer or insurer is paying only part of your hospital expenses.']

question: If I am hospitalised, how much MediSave can I use to pay for my hospitalisation expenses?
answer:
['For daily hospital charges, you can use up to $550 of your MediSave for the first two days, and $400 per day thereafter.
If you had undergone a surgery, you can use your MediSave to cover part of, or the whole surgery cost. The amount of MediSave you can use depends on the complexity of your surgery, as listed in the Table of Surgical Procedures.√Ç¬†You may refer to the [MOH website](https://www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/medisave) for more information on withdrawal limits for MediSave.
It is useful to note that you are considered hospitalised if you have been admitted for at least eight hours. This requirement does not apply to day surgeries.']

question: I do not have enough MediSave to pay for my hospitalisation expenses. Are there other ways to pay for it?
answer:
['If you do not have sufficient MediSave for your hospitalisation expenses, you may consider tapping on one or more of your approved dependants' MediSave. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident if you wish to tap on your grandchildren or sibling's MediSave.
It is important to note that while you can tap on your approved dependants' MediSave, the amount you can use is still subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits, which is applied on a per hospitalisation episode basis. If you still have outstanding hospitalisation expenses after using up to the MediSave withdrawal limit, you would have to pay the remainder in cash.
Alternatively, you or your approved dependants may use future MediSave contributions to pay for the outstanding hospitalisation bill if:
1. The payer's MediSave Account is active (MediSave contributions received within the past three months); and
2. The patient stayed in a B2 or C ward in a public hospital
You must apply to the hospital on the day of or before you are discharged. This is not allowed for outpatient treatments.
For more information, please speak to the staff at the hospital's Business Office.
You should use your MediSave prudently to provide for your own and your approved dependant's hospitalisation needs. This is because you may require more medical care in your old age.']

question: What if my hospital bill is more than what my MediSave can cover?
answer: ['The MediSave withdrawal limits are generally sufficient to cover bills incurred in B2 or C ward types in a public hospital. This restriction is necessary to prevent premature depletion of your MediSave, as your MediSave savings are to last through your lifetime. This is particularly important as elderly people may require more hospital stays and medical care than younger ones. If there is any part of the hospital bill that MediSave is unable to cover, you will need to pay in cash.']

question: Can I use more than one of my approved dependants' MediSave for my hospitalisation expenses?
answer:
['You can tap on one or more of your approved dependants' MediSave for your hospitalisation expenses. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident if you wish to tap on your grandchildren or sibling's MediSave.
While you can tap on your approved dependants' MediSave, the amount you can use is still subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits, which is applied on a per hospitalisation episode basis regardless of the number of payers. If you still have outstanding hospitalisation expenses after utilising up to the MediSave withdrawal limit, you would have to pay the remainder in cash.']

question: Can I use my MediSave for overseas treatment/hospitalisation?
answer:
['**Use of MediSave for Overseas√Ç¬†Treatment - Elective**
Patients who are Singaporeans (SC) or Permanent Residents (PR) may use their own or their approved dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô MediSave for overseas elective treatments. Approved dependants refer to spouses, children, parents, siblings and/or grandchildren.
Patients will need a referral from MediSave-accredited healthcare provider, Health Management International (HMI), if they wish to use MediSave to pay for the medical bill. The patient can contact HMI at 6334 7283 to check if they have affiliated hospital(s) in the country where they wish to receive treatment.
**Use of MediSave for Overseas Treatment√Ç¬†- Medical Emergency/Treatment not Available in Singapore**
MediSave is primarily meant to help Singaporeans and Permanent Residents pay for their major inpatient hospitalisation expenses and selected outpatient expenses locally. When travelling overseas, CPF members should consider purchasing travel insurance to protect against the risk of incurring unforeseen medical expenses.
Appeals to use MediSave for overseas emergency treatments will be considered on a case-by-case basis if the following conditions are fulfilled:
1. The patient must be a Singapore Citizen (SC) or Permanent Resident (PR) of Singapore (Please note that the patient may appeal to use his/ her or their approved dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô MediSave to pay for their own overseas hospitalisations. Approved dependants refer to a member√¢¬Ä¬ôs spouse, children, parents, siblings and/or grandparents.); and
2. The use of MediSave is only limited to inpatient admission that exceeds a minimum of eight hours or day surgery, which has been assessed to be a medical emergency by our Medical Advisors. It cannot be used for outpatient treatments.
For such cases, the following supporting documents have to be submitted to the Ministry of Health (MOH) for consideration on a case-by-case basis:
1. Original copy (Certified true copy by Hospital is accepted) of the patient's medical records - Discharge summary, operation notes (if any) or clinical notes showing the history, diagnosis and treatment plan for the patient.
2. Original copy (Certified true copy by Hospital is accepted) of the final hospital bill for the patient.
3. Passport information - showing passport holder and the entry/departure of the foreign country.
4. Bank Statement showing the bank account number and name of account holder (Only Singapore local banks are accepted).
5. Completed Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF), to authorise the use of MediSave upon an approval. You may find a copy of the MCAF on the [MOH website](https://www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/medisave).
6. NRIC √¢¬Ä¬ì Front and back copy belonging to patient and MediSave payer (if applicable).
To submit the scanned completed documents or for queries related to your use of MediSave for overseas treatments, please e-mail MOH at [MOH\_QSM@moh.gov.sg](mailto:%20MOH_QSM@moh.gov.sg).']

question: I intend to use my approved dependant's MediSave for my hospitalisation expenses. Do I need to produce any proof of my relationship with my approved dependant?
answer:
['You will not be required to produce documentary proof of your relationship with an approved dependant at the point of admission. However, your approved dependant will need to complete a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to use his/her MediSave for your hospitalisation expenses, where he/she will be asked to declare his/her relationship with you.
You and your approved dependant may subsequently be asked to submit documentary proof of your relationship as part of an audit. Please note that legal action may be taken against any member who makes a false declaration.']

question: My approved dependant is a foreigner, while I am a Singapore Permanent Resident. He/She has incurred medical expenses in Singapore. Can I use my MediSave to pay for his/her bills?
answer: ['You may use your MediSave to pay for your approved dependant's medical bills, if it is a MediSave-approved treatment incurred at any of the approved medical institutions in Singapore. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my step/adopted children's hospitalisation expenses?
answer:
['If your step children are under your custody, they are considered your approved dependants, and you can use your MediSave for their hospitalisation expenses.
To use your MediSave for your adopted children, you need to submit legal documentary proof of your relationship to the hospital. If the legal process of adoption is still underway, you should submit the following documents to the hospital:
a. A lawyer's letter stating that the legal adoption is underway, and
b. The birth certificate within one year of your child's date of birth.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for the medical treatments received by dependants other than my approved dependants (spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings)?
answer:
['MediSave is meant to help you save for your personal or approved dependant's healthcare expenses incurred in any of the participating medical institutions (MIs) under the MediSave Scheme.
You can apply to use your MediSave for a dependant who is not your approved dependant, if the dependant is receiving treatment in a public healthcare institution or voluntary welfare organisation in Singapore. Please approach the medical institution's Business Office for more details on the eligibility criteria and the application process. Such applications will be considered on a case-by-case basis.']

question: Can I use my MediSave for optional/cosmetic treatments like liposuction, orthodontics treatment or laser surgery to correct short-sightedness?
answer: ['Generally, MediSave cannot be used for optional/cosmetic treatments. Please check with your attending doctor if the cost of your treatment can be covered by your MediSave.']

question: As a bankrupt, can I still use my MediSave?
answer: ['You may use your MediSave to pay for your own or your√Ç¬†approved dependants' healthcare expenses even if you have declared bankruptcy. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.']

question: Why is there a reduction in the MediSave withdrawal limit for daily hospital charges from $450 to $400 from the third day of hospitalisation?
answer:
['The rebalanced MediSave withdrawal limits are designed to act in tandem with recent enhancements to MediShield Life to better support patients with short inpatient stays. As shown in the Table below, the total coverage under MediShield Life and MediSave for each additional day of stay has increased as a result of these changes, and patients who are covered under both schemes will not need to pay more cash for their hospitalisation bill.
| Day | MSHL claim limit (non-ICU) | MSV withdrawal limit | Total |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Previous | Current | Previous | Current | Previous | Current |
| 1 | $700 | $1,000 | $450 | $550 | $1,150 | $1,550 |
| 2 | $700 | $1,000 | $450 | $550 | $1,150 | $1,550 |
| 3 and beyond | $700 per day | $800 per day | $450 per day | $400 per day | $1,150 per day | $1,200 per day |
MediSave withdrawal limits are designed to strike a balance between improving the affordability of current treatments, and ensuring that Singaporeans retain sufficient savings for their future needs. The rebalancing of MediSave withdrawal limits for daily hospital charges as shown above ensures that MediSave balances are not prematurely depleted.']

question: What outpatient treatments can be paid using MediSave and what are the withdrawal limits?
answer: ['Please refer to the [MOH website](https://www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/medisave) for the list of outpatient treatments that can be paid using MediSave and their corresponding withdrawal limits.']

question: I visited a clinic for an outpatient treatment that can be paid by my MediSave. How do I go about utilising my MediSave?
answer:
['To use your MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment cost:
1. Inform the clinic that you wish to use MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment. The staff will require your NRIC/Passport. If you are paying for your approved dependant, please also produce his/her NRIC/Passport. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.
2. The clinic may require information on how much MediSave is available for payment of the outpatient treatment. You will be able to obtain this information by logging in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) under *my cpf* digital services with your Singpass. This is not needed if the clinic can check on your behalf.
3. You and the patient (if applicable) must sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to allow the clinic to use your MediSave to pay for the outpatient medical treatment bill.
4. If your employer or insurer is also paying for your outpatient treatment, please bring along your Letter of Guarantee or Employer Identity Pass (i.e. if your clinic has an existing arrangement with your employer or insurer).']

question: I do not have enough MediSave to pay for my outpatient treatment expenses. How else can I pay for it?
answer:
['![Use up to 500 dollars or 700 dollars of MediSave for outpatient treatments](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/FAQ_MedisaveForOutpatient.png)If you do not have sufficient MediSave for your outpatient treatment expenses, you may consider tapping on one or more of your approved dependants' MediSave. Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. You must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident if you wish to tap on your grandchildren or sibling's MediSave. You may claim up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for non-complex chronic patients) per patient per year, and each MediSave claim is subject to a 15% co-payment in cash.
While you can tap on your approved dependants' MediSave, the amount you can use is subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits, which is applied on a per patient basis regardless of the number of payers. If you still have outstanding medical expenses after utilising up to the MediSave withdrawal limit, you would have to pay the remainder in cash.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my approved dependant's renal dialysis?
answer:
['If your approved dependant√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave is insufficient for his/her own yearly renal dialysis, you may apply to use your MediSave to pay for his/her renal dialysis if you:
1. are an active MediSave contributor; and
2. have sufficient MediSave balances to support your own healthcare needs, before it is used for your approved dependant's renal dialysis expenses.
Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.
You may submit an application online by following the steps below:
1. Click √¢¬Ä¬úLogin√¢¬Ä¬ù on the [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg), and log in with your Singpass details
2. Click "*my cpf*" and select √¢¬Ä¬úMy requests√¢¬Ä¬ù
3. Click "Healthcare Matters" and select √¢¬Ä¬úApply to Use MediSave for Approved Dependant√¢¬Ä¬ôs Renal Dialysis Treatment√¢¬Ä¬ù
4. Check the box to indicate √¢¬Ä¬úI have read and accepted the Terms & Conditions above√¢¬Ä¬ù, and click √¢¬Ä¬úStart√¢¬Ä¬ù
5. Complete the E-Form and click √¢¬Ä¬úSubmit√¢¬Ä¬ù
We generally aim to inform you of the outcome of your application via our E-Form within three working days.']

question: Can I use my MediSave for Traditional Chinese Medicine?
answer: ['If you are aged 60 and above, you may withdraw up to $300 per year from your own, or your spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account under the Flexi-MediSave scheme to pay for acupuncture treatment for lower back pain and neck pain at specialist outpatient clinics in public hospitals.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for non-surgical dental treatments?
answer:
['Dental treatments are generally not claimable under the MediSave scheme unless the treatment involves surgery and is performed due to medical reasons. Non-surgical dental treatments such as extractions, crowning, dentures or braces are not MediSave-claimable.
Please check with your dentist on whether your dental treatments are claimable.']

question: What is outpatient Flexi-MediSave?
answer:
['Flexi-MediSave allows members aged 60 years old and above to use their MediSave or their spouse's MediSave (if the spouse is also aged 60 and above), up to $300 a year, for outpatient medical treatments at polyclinics, public hospital Specialist Outpatient Clinics and general practitioner clinics participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS).
Please note that the $300 is applied on a per patient basis, regardless whether you are using your MediSave or your spouse's MediSave.']

question: I am aged 65 years old, and I would like to use my Flexi-MediSave to pay for my father's outpatient medical treatment cost at a polyclinic. Can I do so?
answer: ['Flexi-MediSave can only be used for your own or your spouse's outpatient medical treatment expenses.']

question: My child is paying for my chronic disease treatment under the MediSave500/700 scheme. Can I also tap on my spouse's Flexi-MediSave to pay for the co-payment?
answer:
['If both you and your spouse are aged 60 years old or above, you can use your spouse's Flexi-MediSave for the 15% co-payment.
Also, if you have reached the withdrawal limit for chronic disease treatment, you can tap on your own or your spouse's Flexi-MediSave to continue reducing the cash payment, provided that you have not reached the $300 withdrawal limit.']

question: I've used up my Flexi-MediSave limit of $300, but my spouse needs medical treatment too. Can I use my MediSave for his/her medical bills?
answer: ['Each elderly patient can use up to $300 of Flexi-MediSave in a year. Even if you have already used up $300 from your MediSave Account for your own outpatient treatment, you can use another $300 of Flexi-MediSave for your spouse's outpatient treatment, provided that your spouse is also aged 60 and above and has not used his/her own Flexi-MediSave limit.']

question: Is there a limit to the number of times I can use Flexi-MediSave for my outpatient treatments in a year?
answer: ['There is no limit to the number of Flexi-MediSave claims you may make in a year. However, you can only use up to $300 in a calendar year.']

question: Is there a minimum bill amount before I can use Flexi-MediSave?
answer: ['There is no minimum bill amount before Flexi-MediSave can be used. However, as smaller amounts of cash payment are generally affordable, patients may wish to conserve the use of their Flexi-MediSave for larger outpatient bills, e.g. above $20 - $30.']

question: I have used my MediSave for some outpatient medical treatments this year, and would like to know how much more I can use under Flexi-MediSave. How can I do so?
answer:
['You can check how much more you can use under Flexi-MediSave through:
a. *my cpf* digital services
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) using your Singpass
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Select 'Utilisation of healthcare benefits' from the menu bar or scroll down to the 'Utilisation of healthcare benefits' section for 'Additional benefits for the elderly (Flexi-MediSave)'
b. CPF Mobile app
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Download CPF Mobile app
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in using your Singpass
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Select 'Healthcare' from the menu bar for 'Flexi-MediSave'']

question: I visited a clinic for an outpatient medical treatment that can be paid by my Flexi-MediSave. How do I go about using my Flexi-MediSave?
answer:
['To use your Flexi-MediSave for your outpatient medical treatment cost:
1. Inform the clinic that you wish to use MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment. The staff will require your NRIC/Passport. If you are paying for your spouse, please also produce his/her NRIC/Passport.
2. The clinic may require information on how much MediSave is available for payment of the outpatient treatment. You will be able to obtain this information by logging in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) under *my cpf* digital services, with your Singpass.
3. You and the patient (if applicable) will need to sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to allow the clinic to use your Flexi-MediSave to pay for the outpatient medical treatment bill.
4. If your employer or insurer is also paying for your outpatient treatment, please bring along your Letter of Guarantee or Employer Identity Pass (i.e. if your clinic already has an existing arrangement with your employer or insurer).']

question: What can I use Flexi-MediSave for?
answer:
['Flexi-MediSave can be used for outpatient medical treatments (i.e. visits that do not involve a hospital stay or day surgery) received at polyclinics, public hospital Specialist Outpatient Clinics and general practitioner clinics participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS).
Flexi-MediSave can cover consultation fees, selected tests and drugs, and other services such as physiotherapy, if ordered by your doctor for diagnosis or treatment of your medical condition.
It cannot be used for non-medical treatments, such as those for cosmetic or lifestyle purposes (e.g. hair loss, slimming etc). It also cannot be used to pay for items from the retail pharmacies, such as skincare products. Non-medical charges such as administrative fees are also not covered.
Flexi-MediSave cannot be used for dental treatments and admissions to the Accident and Emergency department.']

question: If I have used up other MediSave limits - for example, for scans or for cancer drug treatment, can I use Flexi-MediSave to pay?
answer:
['If you are already using MediSave to pay for outpatient treatment but have reached your withdrawal limit, you can use Flexi-MediSave to further lower your cash payment, provided that treatment was sought at a polyclinic, public specialist outpatient clinic or general practitioner clinic participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS).
Flexi-MediSave cannot be used for cancer drug treatments using cancer drugs that are not on the Cancer Drug List.
However, as Flexi-MediSave covers a much wider range of outpatient treatments than other limits, you may want to save the use of your Flexi-MediSave for treatments that are not already covered by MediSave so as to lower your total cash payments.']

question: I intend to seek treatment at a general practitioner (GP) clinic at my void deck. How do I know if I can use my Flexi-MediSave there?
answer:
['Flexi-MediSave can be used at
i. Polyclinics,
ii. Specialist Outpatient Clinics in the public hospitals and national specialty centres, and
iii. Medical general practitioner (GP) clinics participating in the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS) scheme.
The list of participating CHAS medical GP clinics can be found at the following websites:
* [CHAS](https://www.chas.sg/)
* [Ministry of Health](https://www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/community-health-assist-scheme)(under Healthcare Schemes & Subsidies > Community Health Assist Scheme√Ç¬†)']

question: Is Flexi-MediSave applicable only to the Pioneer Generation or all elderly?
answer: ['Flexi-MediSave applies to all elderly aged 60 and above.']

question: Why is Flexi-MediSave only applicable to elderly members aged 60 years old and above?
answer:
['MediSave is meant to help Singaporeans pay for their more costly medical expenses, especially after retirement. Older Singaporeans usually incur more healthcare expenses as outpatient medical treatments tends to be more expensive for them, while having lower or no income if they have retired. The Flexi-MediSave scheme helps them by allowing them to use MediSave more flexibly to reduce their out-of-pocket expenses for outpatient medical care.
The Ministry of Health (MOH) will regularly review Flexi-MediSave and other financing policies to ensure that outpatient care remains affordable for all Singaporeans.']

question: I√Ç¬†was told by my dentist that I cannot use my Flexi-MediSave for my dental treatments. Why is that so?
answer:
['Flexi-MediSave is meant to help with recurrent outpatient medical expenses, which many older Singaporeans have raised as a key concern due to significant accumulated bill sizes over the longer term.
Dental expenses are not covered under Flexi-MediSave as they are less frequent and patients already benefit from generous government subsidies √¢¬Ä¬ì for example, at CHAS dental clinics and public institutions such as the polyclinics and National Dental Centre.
Nevertheless, patients can use MediSave under the MediSave limits for day surgeries for selected complex dental procedures.']

question: What vaccinations can MediSave be used for?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave to pay for the [following vaccinations](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/FAQ_TypesOfVaccination.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.1MB) received at any of the approved medical institutions in Singapore. Please refer to the list of [approved medical institutions](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/list-of-medical-institutions-medisave-medishield-life.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.4MB) that provide these vaccinations.
For a list of MediSave-approved clinics under the MediSave500/700 scheme, please visit the [Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS)](https://www.chas.sg/) webpage.']

question: How much MediSave can I use to pay for approved vaccinations for myself?
answer:
['You can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave or your approved dependants' MediSave.
Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. To use your grandchildren's or siblings' MediSave, you must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. The same yearly withdrawal limit applies for approved chronic disease treatments and health screening.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for outpatient treatment of chronic diseases?
answer:
['You can use MediSave for outpatient treatments of the chronic diseases listed below.
![Use of MediSave for outpatient treatments of chronic conditions](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/CDMP_infographic.png)√Ç¬†The Ministry of Health (MOH) regularly reviews the list of conditions covered under the Chronic Disease Management Programme, to ensure that they continue to meet the needs of Singaporeans.√Ç¬†For more information, please visit√Ç¬†the [Ministry of Health](https://www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/medisave) website.']

question: How much MediSave can I use for my outpatient treatments of chronic diseases?
answer:
['You can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave or your approved dependants' MediSave.
Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. To use your grandchildren's or siblings' MediSave, you must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.']

question: Can I use MediSave to fully pay for my chronic diseases treatment?
answer: ['You only need to co-pay 15% of the bill in cash before using MediSave to pay the rest of the bill. This is to help you conserve some of your MediSave savings for future healthcare needs.']

question: I have used my MediSave for some outpatient treatments of my chronic disease this year, and would like to know how much more I can use. How can I do so?
answer:
['You can check how much more MediSave you can use for outpatient treatments of your chronic disease through:
a. *my cpf* digital services
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) using your Singpass
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Select "Utilisation of healthcare benefits" from the menu bar or scroll down to the "Utilisation of healthcare benefits" section for "Treatments for chronic illnesses (MediSave500/700)"
b. CPF Mobile app
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Download CPF Mobile app
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in using your Singpass
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Select "My Healthcare" from the menu bar for "Outpatient Treatment"']

question: I want to pay for my outpatient treatment for chronic disease using MediSave. How can I do so?
answer:
['To use your MediSave for your outpatient medical treatment cost:
1. Inform the clinic that you wish to use MediSave to pay for your outpatient medical treatment. The staff will require your NRIC/Passport. If you are paying for your approved dependant, please also produce his/her NRIC/Passport. Approved dependants refer to spouse, children, parents, grandparents and siblings. Please note that your grandparents and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.
2. The clinic may require information on how much MediSave is available for payment of the outpatient treatment. You will be able to obtain this information by logging in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) under *my cpf* digital services, with your Singpass.
3. You and the patient (if applicable) will need to sign a Medical Claims Authorisation Form to allow the clinic to use your MediSave to pay for the outpatient treatment bill.
4. If your employer or insurer is also paying for your outpatient treatment, please bring along your Letter of Guarantee or Employer Identity Pass (i.e. if your clinic already has an existing arrangement with your employer or insurer).']

question: Can I use Flexi-MediSave for my MediSave claims for chronic conditions?
answer: ['Flexi-MediSave can be used on top of the existing MediSave500/700 limit for chronic conditions. However, only the patient's own and spouse's MediSave can be used for Flexi-MediSave and both need to be aged 60 years and above. The use of Flexi-MediSave is also restricted to treatment at the public sector specialist outpatient clinics and polyclinics, and Community Health Assist Scheme clinics.']

question: How was the MediSave500/700 withdrawal limit sized?
answer: ['The MediSave withdrawal limits are generally sized to cover subsidised bills, so that the healthcare costs remain affordable.']

question: I have signed up for an approved chronic disease treatment package or an approved vaccination package with my healthcare provider. May I use my MediSave to pay for the package?
answer: ['You may use your MediSave for approved treatments under the MediSave500/700 withdrawal limit. Your healthcare provider will be able to help you to submit a MediSave claim for each treatment of the package. Please contact your healthcare provider for assistance.']

question: I heard from my healthcare provider that I can no longer use my MediSave for package claims. May I appeal to continue using my MediSave for package claims after June 2018?
answer: ['Your healthcare provider will be able to help you to submit MediSave claim for each treatment. You may contact your healthcare provider for assistance with your MediSave claims.']

question: Why is there a change in MediSave500 withdrawal limits from the per-account basis to a per-patient basis from 1 January 2021?
answer: ['The cost of treatment and amount of MediSave needed is linked closely to the complexity of a patient√¢¬Ä¬ôs chronic medical conditions. Along with the introduction of a higher withdrawal limit for patients with complex chronic conditions, this change to a per-patient basis allows√Ç¬†for more targeted support based on an individual√¢¬Ä¬ôs condition. This is similar to how the rest of the MediSave limits are structured. Should the patient have insufficient balance in his MediSave, family members can still continue to use their MediSave to pay for the patient√¢¬Ä¬ôs treatment, up to the annual limit of the patient.']

question: When will the new withdrawal limits for MediSave500 take place?
answer: ['From 1 January 2021, patients with complex chronic conditions will be able to benefit from an extension of the scheme, MediSave700, and be eligible to withdraw up to $700 per patient yearly. Non-complex chronic patients will continue to be eligible to withdraw up to $500 per patient yearly.']

question: How do I know if I am eligible for the higher withdrawal limit of $700 under MediSave500/700?
answer:
['The withdrawal limit under the MediSave500/700 is determined based on the complexity of your chronic condition(s).
You will be eligible for the higher withdrawal limit of $700 per year, if you were treated for two or more conditions listed under the Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP), or one CDMP condition with complications within a year.
You can check if you are eligible for the higher withdrawal limit of $700 through:
a. *my cpf* digital services
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) using your Singpass
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Select "Utilisation of healthcare benefits" from the menu bar or scroll down to the "Utilisation of healthcare benefits" section for "Treatments for chronic illnesses (MediSave500/700)"
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Check if the "Total withdrawal limit" is $700
b. CPF Mobile app
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Download CPF Mobile app
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Log in using your Singpass
√¢¬Ä¬¢ Select "My Healthcare" from the menu bar and check if the limit is $700 under "Outpatient Treatment"']

question: Are there measures in place to help patients suffering from chronic diseases if the new MediSave withdrawal limits are still insufficient?
answer:
['The Government has been significantly increasing support for patients with chronic conditions. Taken together, the limits will be adequate for the large majority of patients.
* From November 2019, the new CHAS Green extended CHAS subsidies in GPs to all Singaporeans for chronic conditions, regardless of income. Complex chronic subsidies for CHAS Orange and Blue were also raised.
* The Merdeka Generation Package provides additional CHAS subsidies for chronic care in GPs, and additional subsidies in SOCs and Polyclinics.
* Flexi-MediSave eligible age was lowered to 60.
Needy patients who face difficulties with their subsidised medical bills with the new limits in place, may approach their medical institutions for more advice. For example, they may be able to apply for more financial support through MediFund.']

question: I was diagnosed with a complex chronic condition in the middle of the year. How does this affect my MediSave500/700 withdrawal limit?
answer: ['If you are diagnosed with a complex chronic condition in the middle of the year, your MediSave 500/700 withdrawal limit will automatically be increased from $500 to $700, and the new limit will apply for the entire year.']

question: I am a patient with a complex chronic condition. Will I enjoy the higher withdrawal limit of $700 under MediSave500/700 even after my condition improves?
answer: ['The MediSave500/700 withdrawal limit is a yearly limit. This means that you will continue to be able to withdraw up to $700 in the new year if you have had visits for two or more conditions listed under the Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP), or one CDMP condition with complications in that year.']

question: Are the MediSave withdrawal limits for simple and complex chronic conditions aligned with the CHAS subsidy level for simple and complex chronic conditions?
answer: ['The eligibility criteria for the higher MediSave700 limit is similar to the eligibility criteria for the higher CHAS subsidy for complex chronic conditions.']

question: If I have used $500 from my MediSave account for my treatment under MediSave500, can I still withdraw from my family members' MediSave accounts to pay for my treatment?
answer: ['From 1 January 2021, each patient is eligible to withdraw up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for non-complex chronic patients) for their own treatment, regardless of how many MediSave accounts are being withdrawn from.']

question: If I have used $500 from my MediSave account for my chronic condition treatment, can I still use my MediSave for my approved dependant's treatment under MediSave500/700?
answer: ['From 1 January 2021, MediSave account holders can use their MediSave to pay for their approved dependant's treatment under MediSave500/700, up to the individual limit ($500 or $700) of the approved dependant. As the withdrawal limits is based on a per-patient basis, withdrawals can be made for your approved dependants' even if you have withdrawn for your own treatments.']

question: Can I use MediSave to pay for my mammogram screening?
answer:
['If you are aged 50 years old or above, you can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave or your approved dependants' MediSave for your mammogram screening.
Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. To use your grandchildren's or siblings' MediSave, you must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident.']

question: I am concerned of the state of my health, and would like to go for some health screenings. Can I use my MediSave for them?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave to pay for your own or your approved dependants' outpatient scans or health screenings at the [participating medical institutions](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/list-of-medical-institutions-medisave-medishield-life.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB). Approved dependants refer to your spouse, children, parents, grandchildren and siblings. Please note that your grandchildren and siblings must be Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents.
![Use of MediSave for outpatient scans and screenings](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/FAQ_HealthScreening.png)The use of MediSave for mammograms are for female patients aged 50 years or above. This is in line with recommendations from the Screening Test Review Committee from The Academy of Medicine Singapore.
You may also use MediSave for colonoscopy if you are 50 years old or above, according to the withdrawal limits in the image above.']

question: I intend to send my newborn child for health screenings. Which of the health screenings for newborns can be covered by my MediSave?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave for the following health screenings for your newborn:
1. Hearing test
2. G6P deficiency screening
3. Metabolic screening
4. Thyroid function test
You can use up to $700 (for patients with complex chronic conditions) or $500 (for patients with non-complex chronic conditions) yearly per patient from your MediSave for your newborn's health screenings.']

question: What is the MediSave Maternity Package?
answer: ['The MediSave Maternity Package is a package that allows MediSave to be used to pay expenses incurred during delivery and pre-delivery medical expenses such as consultations, ultrasounds, tests, medications etc.']

question: Can I use my MediSave for my maternity expenses?
answer:
['MediSave can be used to pay for the delivery and pre-delivery medical expenses.
Pre-delivery expenses have to be claimed under the MediSave Maternity Package. However, post-natal consultation fees cannot be claimed under MediSave.']

question: How much MediSave can I use for my maternity expenses?
answer:
['Under the MediSave Maternity Package, you can use your MediSave for pre-delivery medical expenses, delivery expenses and daily hospital charges.
Each MediSave Maternity Package has a different MediSave withdrawal limit, depending on the delivery procedure (e.g. caesarean or vaginal delivery). If you do not wish to claim for pre-delivery expenses, you can still√Ç¬†use your√Ç¬†MediSave savings for the delivery procedure and daily hospital charges. Each delivery procedure has a different withdrawal limit.
![3 ways you can use MediSave for maternity expenses](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/FAQ_MediSaveMaternityExpenses.png)
You may refer to the details on the [withdrawal limits for maternity expenses](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/MediSaveMaternityExpenses.pdf)(PDF, 0.1MB).']

question: Am I able to use my MediSave for pre-delivery medical expenses before my delivery?
answer:
['You can only use MediSave for pre-delivery expenses after you have delivered.
You will have to present the bills incurred for pre-delivery medical care to the hospital where you delivered. The hospital will submit these bills, together with the bill for the delivery expenses, for MediSave withdrawal under the MediSave Maternity Package on your behalf.']

question: Can I use MediSave savings for Assisted Conception Procedure (ACP) treatments?
answer: ['![Use of MediSave for Assisted Conception Procedure treatments](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/FAQ_ACP.png)']

question: Can I use my MediSave for the cost of terminating my pregnancy?
answer:
['You can use your MediSave for the cost of termination of pregnancy (TOP). Depending on the complexity of the procedure, you can withdraw between $1,500 to $1,650 for your TOP as part of the MediSave Maternity Package..
This includes a $900 withdrawal limit for your pre-delivery expenses. In addition, if the procedure was conducted in a day surgery setting, you may also claim an additional $300 per day for Daily Hospital Charges.']

question: What are the MediSave withdrawal limits for pre-delivery expenses, and how do I make a MediSave Maternity Package claim?
answer:
['The MediSave Maternity Package is a package that allows MediSave savings to be used to pay expenses incurred during delivery and pre-delivery medical expenses such as consultations, ultrasounds, tests, medications etc.
![Use of MediSave for pre-delivery medical expenses](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/images/FAQ_MediSaveWithdrawalLimitsMMP.png)√Ç¬†You will have to present the bills incurred for the pre-delivery medical care to the hospital where your newborn is delivered. The hospital will submit these bills, together with the bill for the delivery expenses, for a MediSave claim under the MediSave Maternity Package.']

question: I have used my MediSave to pay for my medical expenses. Can my employer or insurer reimburse me in cash?
answer: ['Your employer or insurer cannot pay you in cash for the part of your medical bill that has been paid using your MediSave or MediShield Life. Your employer or insurer must reimburse the respective utilised amount back to your MediSave Account or MediShield Life.']

question: I have received reimbursement from my employer/insurer for my medical bills paid using my MediSave. How do I return the monies to my MediSave Account?
answer: ['If you have received reimbursement from your employer or insurer, you may send us the amount via a cheque, with a copy of your medical bill and a letter to inform us of the request. The cheque is to be paid to "CPF Board". You can send the documents to: Central Provident Fund Board Healthcare Payments and Claims Department 238B Thomson Road #08-00 Tower B Novena Square Singapore 307685']

question: Who is required to reimburse my MediSave Account for my hospitalisation expenses?
answer: ['Third parties who have a contractual obligation (e.g. your insurer/employer) are required to reimburse your MediSave Account for your hospitalisation expenses.']

question: How do I check my reimbursement status if I had previously made a claim to my insurer after using my MediSave and MediShield Life for my medical expenses?
answer:
['You can view the reimbursement details at [cpf.gov.sg/healthcare](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare).
Simply login to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare)√Ç¬†under *my cpf* digital services with your Singpass and proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims' to view the recent transactions, or click on 'View past 15 months' for more transactions.
For claims with reimbursement, you will see the message "You have been reimbursed for this claim. View details". Click 'View details' to view the reimbursement details.']

question: Can an overseas insurance company disburse the approved claim to my MediSave Account by telegraphic transfer or only by cheque?
answer: ['Your insurer may submit reimbursements to MediSave and MediShield Life electronically via [cpf.gov.sg](https://www.cpf.gov.sg). To access the MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement service, please log on to [cpf.gov.sg](https://www.cpf.gov.sg)√Ç¬†and go to Employers => E-Services => MediSave/MediShield Reimbursement.']

question: How can I retrieve my healthcare payments and claims statement online?
answer:
['You can view your healthcare payments and claims details (containing information such as the name of patient, hospital registration number (HRN), hospitalisation period, etc), with transaction dates within the last 15 months at√Ç¬†[cpf.gov.sg/healthcare](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare).
Please follow these steps:
1. Login to your [Healthcare dashboard](http://cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) under my cpf digital services with your Singpass
2. Proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims' and select 'View past 15 months'
3. Select the period you require and click 'Search'.
4. Select the PDF icon at the top-right-hand corner of the page to save/print the statement.
Here is a [step-by-step guide](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/Guide%20to%20print%20healthcare%20payments%20and%20claims_Jun2023.pdf) on how you can retrieve the healthcare payments and claims statement.
Please note that you need not provide hardcopy healthcare payments and claims statement to make a reimbursement claim. If your insurer or employer requires such a statement, they should accept a digital copy.']

question: How can I apply for reimbursements for my MediSave and MediShield Life?
answer:
['If you have utilised your MediSave and/or MediShield Life for medical expenses, and your employer or insurer has contractual obligations to reimburse you for your medical expenses, please approach them to find out how they can reimburse to your MediSave and MediShield Life.
Most employers and/or insurers will require one or more of the following supporting documents before they reimburse to your MediSave and MediShield Life:
i. Your finalised medical bill, which should show the breakdown of the bill and the source of payment i.e. payment made by cash, MediSave, Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life.
ii. MediSave/MediShield Life claims statement, which can be accessed online, for members with Singpass:
1. Login to your√Ç¬†[Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/healthcare)√Ç¬†under√Ç¬†*my cpf*digital services with your Singpass
2. Proceed to 'Latest healthcare payments and claims' to view the recent transactions or click on 'View past 15 months' for more transactions.
For claims with reimbursement, you will see the message "You have been reimbursed for this claim. View details". Click 'View details' to view the reimbursement details.
iii. Hardcopy MediSave transaction statement, which is sent weekly to members who have used their MediSave to pay for medical expenses, for members without Singpass.
The √¢¬Ä¬úHospital Registration Number√¢¬Ä¬ù (HRN) found in the "Healthcare payments and claims" statement and the MediSave transaction statement will help your employer/insurer to identify the claim to be reimbursed. The HRN is a 13-character alphanumeric registration number that looks like this: 522016A02QL6E.']

question: If I had used cash, MediSave and MediShield Life for my medical bill, is there an order in which my employer or insurer should perform the reimbursement?
answer: ['Subject to the contractual obligations, your employer or insurer should perform the reimbursement in the following order: i. To reimburse you in cash, for the amount that you paid in cash ii. To reimburse the amount of MediSave utilised from your payer√¢¬Ä¬ôs or your MediSave Account, back to your payer√¢¬Ä¬ôs or your MediSave Account iii. To reimburse the amount utilised from your MediSave-approved Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life, back to the Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life This minimises your cash outlay and restores your MediSave Account savings.']

question: I do not have a Singpass account. How will I be notified of my MediSave deduction?
answer:
['You will be notified of your MediSave deduction digitally via your contact details maintained with CPF Board.
We strongly encourage you to update your contact details with us using Singpass to obtain timely notification of your MediSave deduction.
Having a Singpass account provides added convenience and security when accessing Singapore government services.√Ç¬†You can register a Singpass account by following the instructions on the√Ç¬†[Singpass website](https://www.singpass.gov.sg/home/ui/register/instructions).']

question: I have directed a medical institution to submit a claim on my behalf. However, I would like to make an amendment to that claim. What should I do?
answer: ['Please approach the medical institution that submitted the claim on your behalf for assistance.']

question: How do I revoke the authorisation for the use of MediSave savings for my own and/or family member(s) medical expenses?
answer:
['If you had signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (Single Institution), please approach the Medical Institution where you signed the form to revoke your authorisation.
If you had signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (Multiple Institutions), you can approach any Public Healthcare Institution to obtain a copy of the revocation form. Alternatively, you may also download this [form](https://www.moh.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider5/forms/revocation-form-for-mcaf(m).pdf?sfvrsn=845f19ec_0), and mail the completed form to the address indicated below.
Attn: MCAF Administrator Harbourfront Centre P.O. Box 074 Singapore 910932']

question: Can I appeal to use the new $300 limit for my outstanding medical bills or for any treatments incurred before 1 June 2021?
answer:
['You will not be able to use the new $300 limit for any treatments received before 1 June 2021.
The new limit will only be applicable for treatments received on or after 1 June 2021.']

question: Can I use my MediSave for hearing aids?
answer:
['MediSave cannot be used for the purchase of hearing aids. This is because MediSave is primarily designed to help Singaporeans offset costly hospitalisations, day surgeries and selected outpatient treatments.
However, you may apply for the Seniors√¢¬Ä¬ô Mobility and Enabling Fund (SMF) which provides subsidies to eligible seniors for a range of assistive devices, including hearing aids.√Ç¬†You can call the Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) at 1800 650 6060 or visit [AIC website](http://www.aic.sg/financial-assistance/seniors-mobility-enabling-fund) for more details.']

question: Can I withdraw√Ç¬†my MediSave in cash?
answer:
['MediSave is primarily designed to help Singaporeans save up during their working years for their healthcare needs in old age. Generally, MediSave cannot be withdrawn in cash and are instead paid directly to MediSave-accredited medical institutions for approved medical treatments.
However, under MediSave Care, severely disabled Singaporeans aged 30 and above may withdraw up to $200 per month in cash from their own and/or their spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account(s). This is because long-term care needs vary significantly across such individuals, and cash withdrawals will provide patients and their caregivers the flexibility to decide on their desired care arrangements and long-term care services. You may refer to [AIC√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](http://www.aic.sg/financial-assistance/medisave-care) and our [FAQs](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medisave-care/what-is-medisave-care) for more details on MediSave Care.
The Ministry of Health (MOH) will continue to review their financing policies to ensure that care remains affordable for our citizens, while MediSave balances are not depleted prematurely.']
