['We advise you to pay your outstanding MediShield Life premiums before the due date to avoid enforcement actions.
Please click on the link below for the payment options.
[How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-can-i-view-and-pay-my-dependant-msl-premiums)']

question: Why have I received a notice from the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) informing me that I owe MediShield Life premiums?
answer:
['IRAS is authorised under the MediShield Life Scheme Act to carry out enforcement actions to recover MediShield Life premiums.
Fully pay your outstanding premiums by the deadline indicated by IRAS to avoid further enforcement actions or apply for assistance to help you pay the premiums. To do so, please click on the link below for the payment options.
[How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-can-i-view-and-pay-my-dependant-msl-premiums)']

question: Will I still be imposed with interest and penalty if I make partial payment for my outstanding premiums?
answer:
['Compounded annual interest of 4% and penalties of up to 17% may continue to be imposed so long as the MediShield Life premiums remain outstanding.
Fully pay your outstanding premiums to avoid enforcement actions. To do so, please click on the link below for the payment options.
[How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)s' CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-can-i-view-and-pay-my-dependant-msl-premiums)']

question: What does the outstanding MediShield Life premium amount stated in the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore√¢¬Ä¬ôs (IRAS) notice refer to?
answer:
['The amount stated in IRAS' notice includes any outstanding MediShield Life premiums, interest and penalties as at the print date.
Any new interest and penalties that may be imposed on your outstanding premiums can be found in√Ç¬†IRAS' notice.']

question: I do not wish to pay the MediShield Life premium for my child as I am divorced. Why do I have to pay for his outstanding MediShield Life premium?
answer:
['Parents are liable to pay for their child√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediShield Life premiums until their child is 21 years old.
If you do not have custody and are not liable to maintain your child, please send a copy of the court documents to√Ç¬†[cpf.gov.sg/writetous](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous)√Ç¬†for assessment.']

question: I received a Final Reminder notification regarding my outstanding MediShield Life premiums, will the amount payable still be increased?
answer:
['The Final Reminder notification shows the amount of your outstanding MediShield Life premiums as at the date sent.
Please pay your full outstanding premiums by the deadline indicated in the notification. Otherwise, the amount payable will increase as the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will impose compounded interest of 4% and penalties of up to 17% on your outstanding premiums.√Ç¬†To do so, please click on the link below for the payment options.
[How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)s' CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-can-i-view-and-pay-my-dependant-msl-premiums)']

question: Why does my Healthcare dashboard state that my MediShield Life premiums may be recovered from my bankruptcy estate?
answer: ['Outstanding MediShield Life premiums incurred prior to your bankruptcy date may be recovered from your bankruptcy estate. These premiums will therefore not be reflected as outstanding premiums payable in your Healthcare dashboard. To pay your outstanding premiums incurred prior to the date of your Bankruptcy Order, please obtain approval from the Private Trustee or Official Assignee. You can contact them at 1800 225 5529 (during office hours) or visit [www.mlaw.gov.sg](https://www.mlaw.gov.sg/).']

question: I have renounced my citizenship/Permanent Residency (PR) and noticed that my CPF savings has been used to pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums. Can I request for a refund?
answer: ['There is no refund of the CPF savings used to pay your outstanding MediShield Life premiums because insurance coverage had been provided to you before you renounced your citizenship/PR.']

question: How do Government pensioners benefit from MediShield Life?
answer:
['Government pensioners can use MediShield Life as a complement to their post-retirement medical benefits, to pay for overall out-of-pocket expenses for large hospitalisation bills that are incurred from:* Co-payments for large hospitalisation bills that exceed their post-retirement medical benefits
* Ward upgrades beyond their eligibility in Restructured Hospitals e.g. when a pensioner eligible for Class B1 ward chooses to stay in Class A ward
* Private hospital expenses, which are not covered by Civil Service medical benefits today.
The Public Service Division has sent letters to pensioners to inform them of their MediShield Life benefits in 2015.']

question: I disagree with MediShield Life coverage. Please do not cover me under MediShield Life. How can I appeal against MediShield Life coverage?
answer: ['MediShield Life provides universal coverage to all Singapore Citizens (SCs) and Permanent Residents (PRs) so that they have assurance against large healthcare bills. MediShield Life is mandatory for all SCs and PRs, as by sharing in the national risk pool, Singapore residents collectively play our part in supporting our healthcare costs.']

question: I'm residing overseas and do not require MediShield Life, how do I withdraw from MediShield Life?
answer:
['MediShield Life provides universal coverage to Singapore Citizens (SCs) and Permanent Residents (PRs) so that they have assurance against large healthcare bills. MediShield Life is mandatory for all SCs and PRs, as by sharing in the national risk pool, Singapore residents collectively play our part in supporting our healthcare costs.
The MediShield Life Council (MLC) recognises that there is a small and distinct group of Overseas Singaporeans (OS) who live outside Singapore permanently, have no intention to reside in Singapore, and feel that they will not benefit from MediShield Life.
If you belong to the OS group, you can apply for a suspension of premium collection even though you will remain covered under MediShield Life. You can refer to the [Suspension of MediShield Life Premium Collection](https://form.gov.sg/#!/5e9535952b18f50011eee456) for more information on the eligibility criteria and application process.']

question: Can overseas Singapore Residents return to Singapore if they do not pay their MediShield Life premiums?
answer: ['Overseas Singapore residents will still be able to return to Singapore even if their premiums are not paid. However, the Government may impose travel restrictions on defaulters leaving Singapore if sustained outreach to the insured has been ignored.']

question: How can I apply for the suspension of MediShield Life premium collection?
answer:
['The MediShield Life Council (MLC) recognises that there is a small and distinct group of Overseas Singaporeans (OS) who live outside Singapore permanently, have no intention to reside in Singapore, and feel that they will not benefit from MediShield Life.
If you belong to the OS group, you can apply for a suspension of premium collection even though you will remain covered under MediShield Life. You can refer to the [Suspension of MediShield Life Premium Collection](https://form.gov.sg/#!/5e9535952b18f50011eee456) for more information on the eligibility criteria and application process.']

question: What should I do if my application for suspension of MediShield Life premium collection is approved and I later decide to relocate back to Singapore?
answer: ['Please inform the MediShield Life Team once you have relocated back to Singapore. Your suspension of MediShield Life premium collection will cease, and the accumulated sum of premiums suspended from collection, with compound interest, will be payable. You may refer to the [Terms & Conditions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tnc/declaration-for-medishield-life-suspension) for more information.']

question: Will my new CPF working contribution partially pay off my outstanding MediShield Life premiums if I am on a GIRO payment plan?
answer:
['Yes, your new CPF working contributions will be used to pay your outstanding MediShield Life premiums. This helps to reduce the outstanding amount and avoid enforcement actions.
The monthly instalment amount of your current GIRO payment plan remains unchanged. The payment plan will automatically end earlier when your outstanding premiums are fully paid.']

question: What is the duration of a standard GIRO payment plan to pay outstanding MediShield Life premiums?
answer:
['The duration of a GIRO payment plan for the outstanding MediShield Life premiums can be up to 12 months.
A payment plan will be issued after the GIRO application is approved by your bank. Please ensure sufficient balance in your bank account. Otherwise, GIRO deductions will be suspended after two consecutive unsuccessful deductions and re-activation will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.']

question: Will checks be conducted for new Singapore Residents who are covered under MediShield Life?
answer:
['For new Singapore Residents who are covered under MediShield Life, we will have a range of checks, including reviewing medical records after they are covered. They are required to declare their health status upon receipt of the In-Principle Approval (IPA) letter from the Immigration & Checkpoint Authority of Singapore (ICA).
If they are identified to have serious pre-existing medical conditions, they will be subjected to 30% Additional Premiums for 10 years. Those who make false health declarations will be guilty of an offence under the MediShield Life Scheme Act and will be liable to pay penalties.']

question: How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?
answer:
['You can log in to your√Ç¬†[Healthcare dashboard](http://cpf.gov.sg/healthcare)√Ç¬†to view your/your dependant(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life coverage information under the √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù and √¢¬Ä¬úHealth insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù section respectively.
You can pay the premiums by:
1) Asking a family member to perform a Change of Payer to take over the premium payment using his/her MediSave.
MediShield Life:√Ç¬†[Change of Payer for MediShield Life Cover](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ChangePayerOfMediShieldCoverToMyself/Information)
CareShield Life/ElderShield:√Ç¬†[Change of Payer for CareShield Life/ ElderShield](https://careshieldlife.gov.sg/change-payer)
2) Performing a voluntary top-up to your/your dependant(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account via√Ç¬†[e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage)√Ç¬†by selecting √¢¬Ä¬úContribute to My MediSave√¢¬Ä¬ù.
MediSave top-ups are generally credited within 3 working days. You can view the MediSave top-up(s) and or premium deduction(s) in your/your dependent(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs√Ç¬†[Transaction history](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history)√Ç¬†at√Ç¬†[cpf.gov.sg](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/).
Please note that MediSave top-ups could be deducted for healthcare premiums and medical expenses based on when deductions were due. Please ensure that you have sufficient MediSave for all payments.
More payment options are available in the link below:
[I have renounced my citizenship/am residing overseas with no local bank account. How do I pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-does-renounced-or-overseas-member-pay-outstanding-premiums)']

question: I am receiving hardcopy letters. How do I start receiving digital notifications?
answer:
['You can login to [your account](https://cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings)√Ç¬†with your Singpass and update your contact details to start receiving digital notifications.
If you do not have a Singpass account, you may [register for a Singpass account](https://www.singpass.gov.sg/home/ui/login).√Ç¬†Having a Singpass account would allow you to access a wide range of government services in a secure manner. Hence, we strongly encourage you to register for a Singpass account if you have not done so.']

question: Can I choose to receive hardcopy letters instead?
answer: ['The digital notifications will be accessible anytime and anywhere. We encourage members to partner us in our efforts to go digital and go green, and experience for themselves the convenience of digital notifications. If you do not have an email address or a mobile number registered with CPF Board, you will continue to receive hardcopy letters. No further action is required.']

question: Why am I receiving digital notifications instead of hardcopy letters regarding MediShield Life related matters?
How do I submit the "MediShield Life and CareShield Life Health Declaration for Permanent Resident Applicant" form?
answer:
['Please submit the [MediShield Life and CareShield Life Health Declaration for Permanent Resident Applicant form online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/health-declaration-pr-applicants)√Ç¬†and log in using your Singpass.
Declaring for Self
If you are the Person To Be Insured and you are aged 21 years or older, please select the option to declare for √¢¬Ä¬úMyself√¢¬Ä¬ù under the section - Selection of Self or Family Member Declaration.
Declaring for Family Member
If you are aged below 21 years, please get your parent/legal guardian to log in using his/her Singpass to the e-Service and select option to declare for √¢¬Ä¬úFamily Member√¢¬Ä¬ô to declare the health status on your behalf.
If you are aged 21 years or older but do not have a Singpass, please get your family member to log in using his/her Singpass and select the option to declare for √¢¬Ä¬òFamily Member√¢¬Ä¬ô to submit the HD form on your behalf.
No Singpass
Alternatively, if you are not able to apply for Singpass or do not have a family member with Singpass that can help you submit the HD form online, you can [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index?section=M_MediSave).
Form Processing Time
After you have submitted your [health declaration](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/health-declaration-pr-applicants), please note the following:
* Your health declaration will generally be processed within seven working days. You can check the status of your health declaration via √¢¬Ä¬ú[My activities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivity)√¢¬Ä¬ù.
* If the status is still showing √¢¬Ä¬òPending review√¢¬Ä¬ô after seven working days, the Agency of Integrated Care (AIC) has evaluated your declaration and requires you to undergo a disability assessment. AIC will notify you of the details, or you can contact AIC at [apply@aic.sg](mailto:apply@aic.sg).
* If you are required to attend a disability assessment, please do so as soon as possible within the timeframe specified in AIC√¢¬Ä¬ôs letter. After the assessment, your assessors will submit their report to AIC. Only after AIC has evaluated the report will the status of your health declaration be updated to √¢¬Ä¬úCompleted√¢¬Ä¬ù, and you can then schedule an appointment with ICA.
Completion of Formalities with the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA)
Individual applicants should only schedule an appointment with ICA after their health declaration status shows √¢¬Ä¬úCompleted√¢¬Ä¬ù.
For family unit applications under the same ICA reference number, please ensure that all members have a √¢¬Ä¬úCompleted√¢¬Ä¬ù health declaration status before scheduling an appointment with ICA.']

question: Can I cancel or terminate my MediShield Life cover?
answer: ['MediShield Life provides universal healthcare coverage to Singapore Citizens (SCs) and Permanent Residents (PRs) regardless of their pre-existing medical conditions, for life. Coverage is mandatory for SCs/PRs and cannot be cancelled or terminated. With every Singapore resident collectively supporting our healthcare costs by paying premiums and pooling our healthcare risks under MediShield Life, we can keep annual premiums affordable to support payouts for those of us who incur unexpectedly large hospital bills.']

question: How will I be notified of the MediShield Life premium deduction?
answer:
['You can access your [Transaction history](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history)√Ç¬†to check the MediShield Life transactions from your MediSave Account.
You can also log in to [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/healthcare) 'Coverage and premium details' for details of your and/or your dependants' MediShield Life premiums and subsidies.']

question: How do I terminate my dependant√¢¬Ä¬ôs GIRO arrangement for MediShield Life premiums?
answer: ['You can approach your bank to terminate your dependant√¢¬Ä¬ôs GIRO arrangement for MediShield Life premiums.']

question: How do I pay my MediShield Life premiums using e-Cashier?
answer:
['If you have an online banking account with UOB/ DBS/ POSB/ OCBC/Standard Chartered Bank, please refer to the below steps to use√Ç¬†[e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage)√Ç¬†to pay your MediShield Life premiums:
1. Visit [e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage).
2. Key in your√Ç¬†NRIC number.
3. Select paying as a √¢¬Ä¬òMember√¢¬Ä¬ô and making payment for √¢¬Ä¬òContribute to my own/recipient's MediSave Account (Tax deductible)√¢¬Ä¬ô and follow the instructions provided.
4. After keying in the recipient√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF Account Number, his/her relationship to you and your e-mail address, enter the payment amount and click √¢¬Ä¬òNext√¢¬Ä¬ô.
5. You will be prompted to pay using your internet banking facilities.√Ç¬†*Payment via eNETS has been discontinued from 23 April 2023. [Find out more](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/general-information---useful-tips/electronic-services/why-is-payment-via-enets-discontinued).*
If you require further assistance, you can call us at 1800-222-3399 (or +65-6222-3399 from overseas), Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.30pm Singapore time or write to us at√Ç¬†[cpf.gov.sg/writetous](http://cpf.gov.sg/writetous).']

question: I have received a call claiming to be from MediShield Life. What should I do if this is a scam and my contact details are shared with external agencies?
answer:
['The MediShield Life Team does not contact members to request sensitive personal information or engage any external agencies to call members on MediShield Life matters. The MediShield Life Team will not disclose members√¢¬Ä¬ô contact details to external agencies without members√¢¬Ä¬ô consent.
If you receive an unexpected phone call from someone who claims to be from the MediShield Life Team, please be vigilant and do not provide your sensitive personal information (E.g. Singpass ID/password, bank account or credit card details). When in doubt, you may end the conversation with the individual and check with the organisation which the caller claims to represent directly. To verify the authenticity of such calls, you can call us directly at 1800 222 3399 or [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index?utm_source=shortURL).']

question: Why are there changes to cancer treatment financing?
answer:
['Before 1 September 2022, MediShield Life paid up to $3,000/month for all cancer drugs, and Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) often covered costs above that on an as-charged basis (i.e. no claim limit), with a small co-payment.
Such a design meant that drug companies had no incentive to charge lower prices for drug treatments that cost less. As a result, we paid higher prices for many cancer drugs as compared to other countries such as Australia, South Korea and the United Kingdom.
The changes to cancer treatment financing allow us to negotiate lower prices for cancer drugs and ensure that cancer treatment costs and insurance premiums remain affordable for Singapore residents in the long term.']

question: How will the new Cancer Drug Treatment benefit under MediShield Life and MediSave impact my claims from 1 September 2022?
answer:
['MediShield Life and MediSave will only cover treatments on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) from 1 September 2022. Each cancer drug treatment on the CDL will have its own MediShield Life claim limits and MediSave withdrawal limits.
You may refer to the [CDL](https://www.moh.gov.sg/home/our-healthcare-system/medishield-life/what-is-medishield-life/what-medishield-life-benefits/cancer-drug-list)√Ç¬†for the list of cancer drug treatments that are claimable under MediShield Life and MediSave, and their respective claim and withdrawal limits. Please consult your doctor if you wish to find out whether the treatment that you are currently undergoing is on the CDL.
The CDL will only come into effect for Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) on 1 April 2023, upon renewal or application. If you have an IP, you will continue to be covered under your current policy terms until it is renewed on or after 1 April 2023.']

question: What are the criteria for inclusion in the Cancer Drug List?
answer:
['Generally, the Cancer Drug List comprises of drugs that are clinically proven and more cost-effective in treating a particular cancer.
A drug is clinically proven if it is registered with the Health Sciences Authority (HSA) for the particular clinical indication and has met the required standards of safety, quality and efficacy. A drug is cost effective if it provides good value in treating the particular cancer as compared to the existing standard of care, in terms of health benefits to the patient and cost.']

question: Can a patient claim for cancer drug services from the Cancer Drug Services limit if he is receiving a treatment that is not on the Cancer Drug List?
answer: ['Yes, patients may claim for cancer drug services from the annual Cancer Drug Services limit even if the service was rendered for a cancer treatment not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) (i.e. the claim limit is not specific to treatments on the CDL).']

question: Is there support for patients undergoing cancer drug treatment that is not on the Cancer Drug List when the changes kicked in?
answer:
['We encourage you to discuss with your doctor if there are suitable alternatives on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) that are subsidised and covered by insurance. However, if switching treatments is not feasible, there is support to help existing patients see through their current course of treatment:
* MOH will provide additional financial support for all public healthcare institution (PHI) patients without an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), and who had started treatments that are unsubsidised or not on the CDL before 1 Sep 2022. If you are a subsidised patient and still face difficulties affording your bills, you can approach a Medical Social Worker (MSW) in your PHI for financial assistance such as MediFund.
* If you have an IP that is being renewed between 1 Apr 2023 and 30 Sep 2023, and have received cancer drug treatment between 1 Jan 2023 and 31 Mar 2023, insurers have committed to preserve your current IP coverage until 30 Sep 2023.
* If you are a private patient, you can also approach your doctor to refer you to subsidised care in a PHI, where you can apply for financial assistance. The PHI√¢¬Ä¬ôs medical team will review your treatment plan and provide financial counselling (e.g., eligibility for subsidies) before you decide whether to transfer to a PHI.
IP riders may also cover selected treatments beyond the CDL, though the extent of coverage may vary. A summary of each insurer√¢¬Ä¬ôs IP and rider coverage for cancer drug treatments / services can be√Ç¬†found in this [link](https://www.lia.org.sg/media/3717/insurers-urls_ips-and-ip-riders.pdf).√Ç¬†You may wish to check with your insurer, should you have further queries on your IP and rider coverage.']

question: Will MediShield Life premiums increase due to the increase in GST?
answer:
['MediShield Life premiums are inclusive of the prevailing GST rate.
In Budget 2022, the Minister for Finance announced that the GST rate will be increased from 7% to 8% with effect from 1 January 2023 and from 8% to 9% with effect from 1 January 2024. As GST is levied on MediShield Life premiums at the prevailing GST rate, the premiums will increase accordingly.
The new MediShield Life premium rate table (for policy periods on or after 1 Jan 2023) can be found on the CPF website, under [View premiums](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/MediShield%20Life%20Premiums%20by%20Age%20Group.pdf).']

question: With the GST increase, what is being done to help Singaporeans cushion the impact of premium increase?
answer:
['The Government has announced the enhanced Assurance Package for GST to cushion the impact of the planned GST increase for at least 5 years for most Singaporean households. This includes MediSave top-up of $150 each year from 2023 to 2025, for Singaporeans aged 20 years and below, or 55 years old and above, which may be used to offset the premium increase.
The Assurance Package for GST also includes cash payouts of $700 to $1,600 over five years, for all Singaporeans aged 21 years and above.
Older Singaporeans aged 65 and above, whose residential address is a property that does not exceed an Annual Value of $21,000 and who own only one property will also continue to receive an annual MediSave top-up of up to $450. This is beyond the transitional support covered by the Assurance Package.']

question: I am prescribed a drug that is not on the Cancer Drug List. Can I claim under the Cancer Drug Services Limit?
answer:
['The cancer drug services limit is meant to cover ancillary services that patients may require as part of their cancer drug treatment.
If the drug you are prescribed is a supportive medication to manage the symptoms and side effects of your cancer drug treatment (e.g. antibiotics to reduce risk of infection, pain medication or anti-nausea medication), it is claimable under the Cancer Drug Services limit.
However, if the drug is used for the treatment of the cancer / tumour itself (e.g. chemotherapy, immunotherapy or targeted therapy), it should be claimed under the Cancer Drug Treatment limit instead. Cancer Drug Treatments that are not listed on the Cancer Drug List are not eligible for MediShield Life, MediSave and Integrated Shield Plan claims and should not be claimed under Cancer Drug Services limit.']

question: I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status, what will happen to my MediShield Life cover?
answer:
['When MediShield was replaced by MediShield Life, the Government had given concession to a small number of foreigners with MediShield cover to continue their coverage under MediShield Life.
With the closure of CPF accounts for all foreigners on 1 April 2024, you will continue to be covered under MediShield Life as long as you continue to pay your premiums.
If you are using your own MediSave Account to pay the premiums and no alternative payment arrangements are made, your MediShield Life cover will lapse.
[I am (i) residing overseas or (ii) have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status. How do I pay my CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-does-renounced-or-overseas-member-pay-outstanding-premiums)']

question: How are MediShield Life claim limits sized when more than one cancer drug is used in the treatment?
answer:
['In general, the MediShield Life (MSHL) claim limits for cost-effective treatments are set based on the post-subsidy bills for subsidised patients in Public Healthcare Institutions (PHIs).
The Cancer Drug List (CDL) includes treatments that involve a single drug or multiple drugs (i.e. combination treatments). For combination treatments, the applicable MSHL claim limit depends on whether the combination treatment has been assessed to be cost-effective:
* **If the combination treatment is cost-effective**, the MSHL claim limit is sized to be sufficient to cover the post-subsidy cost of the entire combination in PHIs.
* **If the combination treatment is not cost-effective**, it may be listed on the CDL subject to negotiations with the drug companies. However, the claim limit would be pegged to the highest individual claim limit of the drugs in the combination. Doctors and patients are encouraged to use treatments that have been assessed to be cost-effective.']

question: Why is the MediShield Life claim limit for a particular combination treatment not the sum of all the claim limits for individual drugs in that combination?
answer:
['If a particular combination treatment is cost-effective, the MediShield Life (MSHL) claim limit is sized to be sufficient to cover the post-subsidy cost of the entire combination in Public Healthcare Institutions (PHIs). In some cases, the claim limit for the entire combination is the same as the highest-cost drug in that combination because the cost of the other drugs in the PHIs are low and can therefore be adequately covered by the same claim limit.
If a particular combination treatment is not cost-effective, the MSHL claim limit is pegged to the highest individual claim limit of the drugs in the combination. Doctors and patients are encouraged to use treatments that have been assessed to be cost-effective, for which MSHL claim limits have been sized for.']

question: What happens if I have to change treatment in the middle of the month? Does it mean that the new treatment is not claimable?
answer: ['For patients who have to switch treatment in the middle of the month, both treatments would be claimable up to the higher of the MediShield Life, MediSave and Integrated Shield Plan claim limits applicable for each individual treatment.']

question: My cancer drug treatment is on a 3-weekly cycle. Is the cancer drug limit sufficient for months when I need to undergo 2 rounds of treatment?
answer:
['For cost-effective cancer drug treatments on 3-weekly cycles, the MediShield Life (MSHL) claim limits have typically been sized to cover the post-subsidy costs of two treatment courses in a month.
For other cancer drug treatments, the MSHL claim limit has been sized to cover up to the monthly cost of the cost-effective alternative.']

question: How do I know if I/my dependants are covered under MediShield Life (MSL) or Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
answer: ['You can log in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/healthcare) to view your/your dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô MediShield Life or Integrated Shield Plan coverage information. The information is available under √¢¬Ä¬úHealth insurance √¢¬Ä¬ì Coverage and premiums details√¢¬Ä¬ù.']

question: As I am covered under an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), why are there two transactions made in my Yearly CPF Statement of Account?
answer:
['An√Ç¬†Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is made up of two components, namely:
1. The MediShield Life component √¢¬Ä¬ì reflected as MSL, and
2. The additional private medical insurance component √¢¬Ä¬ì reflected as PMI.
Hence, there would be two transactions reflected for any deduction/refund of IP.']

question: My family members are covered with free Integrated Shield Plan (IPs) provided by a private insurer. Do I still need to pay MediShield Life premiums for them?
answer: ['If your family members are covered with free Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), please check directly with your [insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/ListOfInsurersContactInfo.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) who is administering the IPs if you still need to pay MediShield Life premiums for them.']

question: What would happen to my Integrated Shield Plan if I renounce my Singapore Citizenship/ Permanent Residency?
answer: ['The MediShield Life (MSL) component of your Integrated Shield Plan would terminate at the end of the current policy year. To continue with your policy, you need to check with your [insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/ListOfInsurersContactInfo.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) whether they will insure you fully (without the MSL component).']

question: What happens to my existing Integrated Shield Plan (IP) when I apply for a new IP?
answer:
['Your existing Integrated Shield Plan (IP) will automatically be terminated when your new IP commences. This ensures you will only pay premiums for one IP, as medical claims can only be paid from one IP at any one time. Your insurer will refund any unused premium for the remaining cover period of the terminated IP.
Before you buy a new IP, you should check if your new insurer will cover all your pre-existing medical conditions. While the MediShield Life component of your new IP will continue to cover you for life, including any pre-existing medical conditions, private insurers generally will impose exclusions i.e. they generally do not pay claims for pre-existing medical conditions that you already suffer from before the start of your IP.']

question: Would I have duplicate coverage if I buy an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) as I am covered under MediShield Life now?
answer: ['There is no duplication in coverage. Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents are automatically covered under MediShield Life, for no matter how long you live. You will continue to be able to tap on MediShield Life benefits when you buy an IP because Integrated Shield Plan (IP) comprises both your MediShield Life component and the additional private insurance component.']

question: Can I insure my dependent under Integrated Shield Plan (IP), but insure myself under MediShield Life and vice-versa?
answer: ['Yes, you can choose to cover yourself under MediShield Life and get Integrated Shield Plan (IP) from different private insurers for your dependents, or vice versa.']

question: How do I update my personal particulars (including change of address) for my Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
answer: ['As your√Ç¬†Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is administered by the private insurer you have chosen to cover you, please approach your [insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/ListOfInsurersContactInfo.pdf) (PDF,0 .4MB) directly on all matters relating to your IP.']

question: How will I know the amount of premiums that I need to pay for my/ my dependents' Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
answer: ['Your insurer administering the Integrated Shield Plan (IP) will notify you of your premium details before your policy is renewed. You can approach your [insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/ListOfInsurersContactInfo.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) directly for further clarifications.']

question: Why is there Additional Withdrawal Limit (AWL) for Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
answer:
['MediSave is sized to help Singaporeans with lifelong healthcare expenses. These include hospitalisation bills and healthcare insurance premiums.
The premium you pay for your√Ç¬†Integrated Shield Plan (IP) consists of both the MediShield Life (MSL) and additional private insurance components. MSL premiums can be paid fully using MediSave. However, premiums for the additional private insurance component are significantly higher than MSL. As such, the Additional Withdrawal Limit (AWL) strikes a balance between the use of MediSave for higher private insurance coverage and preserving MediSave for future healthcare expenses during retirement. You should consider whether co-paying the higher IP premiums using cash is affordable over the long term.']

question: I am an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) policyholder. Am I eligible for MediShield Life Premium Subsidies or Additional Premium Support (APS)?
answer: ['Integrated Shield Plan (IP) policyholders will be able to receive MediShield Life premium subsidies if they meet the eligibility criteria. However, they are not eligible for√Ç¬†Additional Premium Support (APS), as APS is targeted at those with financial difficulties. Should you have difficulty paying your premiums, you may wish to consider terminating your IP and applying for APS.']

question: Is there a limit to the number of family members that I can help pay Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums using my MediSave?
answer: ['There is no limit to the number of family members you can use your MediSave to pay for√Ç¬†Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums. However, you should consider the long-term affordability of IP premiums for your family members and whether you will have enough MediSave savings for your own medical needs especially during your retirement years.']

question: What happens if I do not pay my Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
answer: ['If you do not pay your Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums within your insurer√¢¬Ä¬ôs stipulated Grace Period, your insurer will terminate your IP coverage and you would lose the additional private insurance coverage. However, you would continue to be covered under MediShield Life and pay the lower MediShield Life premiums. You may wish to refer to your IP policy contract for details on the Grace Period.']

question: What will happen if I have insufficient MediSave to pay for my Integrated Shield Plan?
answer: ['Your insurer will notify you of the outstanding amount payable√Ç¬†for your Integrated Shield Plan and advise you how to make payment to the insurer. Please contact your insurer if you require further assistance.']

question: Do I have to pay Additional Premium (AP) for pre-existing conditions if I have an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), and would these conditions be covered after AP is paid?
answer:
['An Integrated Shield Plan (IP) comprises two parts, namely the MediShield Life (MSL) and the additional private insurance component. MSL is sized for B2/C wards at Government hospitals, while the additional private insurance is sized for A/B1 wards at Government hospitals and private hospitals.
The 30%√Ç¬†Additional Premium (AP) for serious pre-existing medical conditions is only applicable to the MSL component of your IP premiums.
For the additional private insurance coverage component, it will be separately assessed by your IP insurer. Generally, private insurers exclude pre-existing medical conditions from their coverage. You should contact your [IP insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/ListOfInsurersContactInfo.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) to find out more.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to purchase an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) for my family member who is a foreigner?
answer: ['Integrated Shield Plan (IP)√Ç¬†coverage for Singaporeans and Permanent Residents include the MediShield Life (MSL) component. You can use your MediSave to purchase a similar non-integrated healthcare plan for your foreign dependent. However, such plans for foreigners will not have the MSL component. Please approach your insurer to advise on the plans offered.']

question: Can I use my MediSave to pay for my family members' Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
answer: ['You can use your MediSave to pay Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums for your family members. They include your spouse, parents, children, grandparents and siblings.']

question: What are CareShield Life/ElderShield supplements?
answer:
['Members insured under CareShield Life and ElderShield can consider purchasing Supplements from private insurers to have additional benefits such as higher payouts or coverage for less severe disability.
There are no restrictions on the number of supplement policies one can be covered.√Ç¬†Supplement premiums can be paid using MediSave, up to a limit of $600 per calendar year per person insured.√Ç¬†Premiums for Supplements range widely and commensurate with the type of benefits they offer. You may refer to the [FAQ for Supplements](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/supplements.html) for more information.
For more information on your CareShield Life/ElderShield Supplements, please contact your insurer:
**Singapore Life Limited****Address:** 4 Shenton Way, #01-01, SGX Centre 2, Singapore 068807 **Website:**[singlife.com](https://singlife.com/en) **Email:** cs\_life@singlife.com **Hotline:** 6827 9933 **Income Insurance Limited Address:** 75 Bras Basah Road, Income Centre, Singapore 189557 **Website:**[income.com.sg](https://www.income.com.sg/)**Hotline:** 6332 1133 **The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited** **Address:** 1 Pickering Street #13-01, Great Eastern Centre, Singapore 048659 **Website:**[greateasternlife.com](https://www.greateasternlife.com/)**Email:** wecare-sg@greateasternlife.com **Hotline:** 1800-248-2888
You can check your CareShield Life/ElderShield supplement plan by following these steps:
a. Visit the [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/). b. Log in using your Singpass. c. Hover over "my cpf" and click on "Healthcare" under "My dashboards". d. Click on √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù on the anchor links or scroll down to the √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù section.
If you are covered under a Supplement plan, this section will show the insurer of your Supplement plan (i.e. Singlife, Great Eastern, or Income Insurance). Do contact your insurer to find out which Supplement plan you are covered under.
If you do not have any Supplement plan, this section will not reflect any information.']

question: What is a private Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
answer: ['A private Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is an optional medical insurance plan provided by private insurance companies which offers additional benefits on top of MediShield Life. You will need to pay higher premiums using MediSave and cash when you are older.']

question: Do I get additional payouts from buying Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
answer: ['In the majority of hospitalisation bills, you are unlikely to get additional payout from your Integrated Shield Plan (IP) if you stay in B2/C wards in public hospitals.']

question: Do I need a private Integrated Shield Plan (IP)?
answer:
['All Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents are covered under MediShield Life no matter how long you live, regardless of age or health condition. MediShield Life helps to pay for large hospital bills and selected costly outpatient treatments such as dialysis and chemotherapy for cancer. It is sized for subsidised treatment in B2/C wards of the public hospitals.
You do not need an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) if you plan to stay in B2/C wards in public hospitals which are heavily subsidised. In fact, majority of Singaporeans, even those who had bought IP, chose to stay in B2/C wards. In particular, eight in 10 seniors choose B2/C wards when they are hospitalised.
If you buy an IP but choose to stay in B2/C wards in public hospitals, you might want to reconsider whether you should pay for additional private insurance.
However, if you are firm in choosing B1/A wards in public hospitals or seeking treatment at private hospitals, you can consider getting an IP that matches your ward preference. If so, you should be prepared to pay additional premiums for the additional coverage.']

question: Will I receive hospitalisation subsidies if I choose A ward type in public hospital or choose to go to a private hospital?
answer: ['You will not receive any hospitalisation subsidy in an A ward type in a public hospital or at a private hospital. Hence, if you are inclined to stay in an A ward in a public hospital or go to a private hospital for treatment, you should consider an Integrated Shield Plan (IP) that covers the cost for the particular ward/hospital type.']

question: What should I consider when I purchase or review my Integrated Shield Plan (IP) coverage with my insurer?
answer:
['Buying and maintaining an√Ç¬†Integrated Shield Plan (IP) is a significant lifetime financial commitment. The degree of protection you need evolves and changes with your circumstances and age. As you reach your retirement years, your earning power is likely to reduce while your premiums will rise sharply and your priorities may shift. Depending on your hospital/ ward preferences, you may not want to pay additional premiums for an IP. You should consider the following carefully:
1. Are you likely to choose to seek treatment or be hospitalised at a public or private hospital?
2. If you intend to go to a public hospital, will you choose a B2/C ward (six to eight beds) or Standard B1 ward (four beds) or A ward (single bed), taking into account affordability?
3. If you intend to stay in B2/C wards, you need not buy an IP. This is because MediShield Life is generally sufficient as payouts are pegged to B2/C wards after government subsidies. The deductible and co-insurance can be paid via MediSave, as well as any remaining co-payment subject to the MediSave withdrawal limits.
4. If you prefer to go to a private hospital, assess your means and ability to pay the additional premiums throughout your lifetime. Your annual premiums will increase sharply with age, which means that your premiums will be much higher in your retirement years. Based on the median premiums for each IP plan type, you can potentially save a significant sum.
You may also refer to the [checklist](/content/dam/web/member/faq/healthcare-financing/documents/Checklist_for_FAQ_24052022.pdf)√Ç¬†when reviewing your IP coverage.
*Did You Know? Your additional private insurance premiums could be ~4 times of your MediShield Life premiums for someone in their 70/80s. Click [this link](/member/healthcare-financing/getting-supplementary-coverage)√Ç¬†to find out more.*']

question: How do I switch to a lower Integrated Shield Plan (IP) / terminate my existing IP?
answer: ['You can instruct your [private insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/ListOfInsurersContactInfo.pdf) (PDF, 0.4MB) to assist you in switching or terminating your Integrated Shield Plan (IP). You will continue to be covered under MediShield Life.']

question: Why was the payment for my Integrated Shield Plan (IP) / MediShield Life (MSL) unsuccessful even though there are sufficient funds in my MediSave Account (MA)?
answer: ['The funds in your MediSave Account (MA) may be reserved for other healthcare payments, such as ElderShield/CareShield Life premiums, hospitalisation bills, or premium payments for your dependents√¢¬Ä¬ô healthcare policies. These may have resulted in insufficient funds in your MA to pay for your Integrated Shield Plan / MediShield Life.']

question: I have recently bought an Integrated Shield Plan (IP). Why was there more than one deduction made from my MediSave Account (MA) this year?
answer:
['The first deduction from your MediSave Account (MA) was for the renewal of your MediShield Life (MSL) coverage, which is mandatory for all Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents. When you buy an Integrated Shield Plan (IP), there would be another premium deduction for the additional private coverage component. There will be a pro-rated refund of the MSL premiums for the remaining unused MSL policy year.
For example, your MSL coverage period was 01 January 2020 to 31 December 2020 and the annual MSL premium of $435 was deducted in January. You subsequently purchased an IP in February 2020 with an annual premium of $600. After you purchase the IP, the unused premium from your MSL coverage of $398.75, would be refunded back to your MA.
![Additional deduction from MediSave for IP](/content/dam/web/member/faq/healthcare-financing/images/transactionssample.png)
\*PMI = Private Medical Insurance/Additional private insurance coverage portion of an Integrated Shield Plan']

question: I am paying the Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums for my dependants. Why is this information not reflected on my Yearly CPF Statement of Account?
answer: ['Your dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô details would not be reflected if you are not using your MediSave to pay for their Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums. However, you can log in to your [Healthcare dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/healthcare) to view your dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô coverage information. The information is available under √¢¬Ä¬úHealth insurance - Coverage and premiums details√¢¬Ä¬ù.']

question: How do I change the payer for my/my dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Integrated Shield Plan (IP) premiums?
answer: ['As your Integrated Shield Plan is administered by the private insurer you have chosen to cover you, please approach your [insurer](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/List_of_Private_Insurers.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.4MB) directly to make the change.']

question: What is ElderShield?
answer:
['ElderShield was first launched by the Ministry of Health in September 2002 as a severe disability insurance scheme which provides basic financial protection to those who need long-term care especially in their old age. It provides a monthly cash payout for up to 72 months to help pay out-of-pocket expenses√Ç¬†in the event of severe disability.
ElderShield was offered to eligible Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents (PRs) who had a MediSave Account when they turned 40 years oldin 2019 or earlier.
For more FAQs on ElderShield, please visit the√Ç¬†[CareShield Life website](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/faqs/eldershield.html)']

question: How can I check if I am covered by ElderShield?
answer:
['You can check for your ElderShield or Supplement coverage through the CPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs website. The steps are as follows:
a. Visit the [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/).
b. Log in using your Singpass.
c. Hover over *√¢¬Ä¬úmy cpf√¢¬Ä¬ù*and click on √¢¬Ä¬úHealthcare√¢¬Ä¬ù under "My dashboards".
d.√Ç¬†Click on √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù on the anchor links or scroll down to the √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù section.
If you are covered under ElderShield, this section will inform you of the ElderShield Plan that you are covered under, i.e. ElderShield 300 or ElderShield 400.
If you are not covered under CareShield Life/ElderShield, this section will inform you that you are not covered under CareShield Life/ElderShield.']

question: How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?
answer:
['You can log in to your√Ç¬†[Healthcare dashboard](http://cpf.gov.sg/healthcare)√Ç¬†to view your/your dependant(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs CareShield Life/ ElderShield and MediShield Life coverage information under the √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù and √¢¬Ä¬úHealth insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù section respectively.
You can pay the premiums by:
1) Asking a family member to perform a Change of Payer to take over the premium payment using his/her MediSave.
MediShield Life:√Ç¬†[Change of Payer for MediShield Life Cover](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ChangePayerOfMediShieldCoverToMyself/Information)
CareShield Life/ElderShield:√Ç¬†[Change of Payer for CareShield Life/ ElderShield](https://careshieldlife.gov.sg/change-payer)
2) Performing a voluntary top-up to your/your dependant(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account via√Ç¬†[e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage)√Ç¬†by selecting √¢¬Ä¬úContribute to My MediSave√¢¬Ä¬ù.
MediSave top-ups are generally credited within 3 working days. You can view the MediSave top-up(s) and or premium deduction(s) in your/your dependent(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs√Ç¬†[Transaction history](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history)√Ç¬†at√Ç¬†[cpf.gov.sg](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/).
Please note that MediSave top-ups could be deducted for healthcare premiums and medical expenses based on when deductions were due. Please ensure that you have sufficient MediSave for all payments.
More payment options are available in the link below:
[I have renounced my citizenship/am residing overseas with no local bank account. How do I pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-does-renounced-or-overseas-member-pay-outstanding-premiums)']

question: I have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status, what will happen to my ElderShield cover?
answer:
['**ElderShield policyholders who have renounced their Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status before 1 March 2024** You can retain your ElderShield policy as long as your policy was paid up before 1 March 2024 or you continue to make payment for your premiums.
As foreigners would no longer have CPF accounts from 1 April 2024 onwards, you will have to make alternative premium payment arrangement to continue payment, if you wish to retain your cover. If you are using your own MediSave Account to pay for the premiums and no alternative payment arrangements are made to continue, your ElderShield policy will lapse, with no refund of past premiums paid. However, in scenarios where there were a minimum number of premiums paid, your ElderShield cover will be converted to a policy with reduced payouts.
**ElderShield policyholders who renounce their Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status after 1 March 2024** In line with the closure of CPF accounts, your ElderShield policy will be automatically terminated and there will be no refund of premiums paid. This is as per how MediShield Life and CareShield Life policies are terminated upon renunciation of Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Resident status.
[I am (i) residing overseas or (ii) have renounced my Singapore Citizenship/Permanent Resident status. How do I pay my CareShield Life/ElderShield/MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-does-renounced-or-overseas-member-pay-outstanding-premiums)']

question: What is CareShield Life?
I made a top-up to my MediSave for payment of CareShield Life premium. Has the top-up been credited?
answer: ['You may view the top-up you made to your MediSave via Transaction History at cpf.gov.sg (Singpass login is required).']

question: Do I have to join CareShield Life?
answer:
['If you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident born in 1980 or later, you will automatically join CareShield Life on 1 October 2020 or when you turn 30, even if you have any pre-existing conditions or disabilities.
If you are a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident born between 1970 and 1979, you will be automatically enrolled in CareShield Life from 1 December 2021, if you are currently covered under the ElderShield 400 (ESH400) scheme and√Ç¬†have not developed severe disability at the point of auto-enrolment. You can opt out of CareShield Life by 31 December 2023 if you do not wish to join the scheme and you will automatically be placed back onto your ESH400 scheme. Those who are not auto-enrolled can choose to join CareShield Life. If you are an ElderShield insured in this group, you will have a 60-day free-look period from the commencement of your CareShield Life coverage, for you to consider your decision. If you choose to opt out, you will be given a full premium refund and automatically be placed back onto your original ElderShield 300/400 scheme. You will not be able to opt out from the scheme after the applicable opt-out/free-look periods.
For more FAQs on CareShield Life, please visit the√Ç¬†[CareShield Life website](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/faqs/careshield-life.html).']

question: How can I view and pay my/my dependant(s)'s CareShield Life/ElderShield and MediShield Life premiums?
answer:
['You can log in to your [Healthcare dashboard](http://cpf.gov.sg/healthcare) to view your/your dependant(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs CareShield Life/ ElderShield and MediShield Life coverage information under the √¢¬Ä¬úLong-term care insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù and √¢¬Ä¬úHealth insurance√¢¬Ä¬ù section respectively.
You can pay the premiums by:
1) Asking a family member to perform a Change of Payer to take over the premium payment using his/her MediSave.
MediShield Life: [Change of Payer for MediShield Life Cover](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/ChangePayerOfMediShieldCoverToMyself/Information)
CareShield Life/ElderShield: [Change of Payer for CareShield Life/ ElderShield](https://careshieldlife.gov.sg/change-payer)
2) Performing a voluntary top-up to your/your dependant(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account via [e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage) by selecting √¢¬Ä¬úContribute to My MediSave√¢¬Ä¬ù.
MediSave top-ups are generally credited within 3 working days. You can view the MediSave top-up(s) and or premium deduction(s) in your/your dependent(s)√¢¬Ä¬ôs√Ç¬†[Transaction history](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/statements/transaction-history) at [cpf.gov.sg](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/).
Please note that MediSave top-ups could be deducted for healthcare premiums and medical expenses based on when deductions were due. Please ensure that you have sufficient MediSave for all payments.
More payment options are available in the link below:
[I have renounced my citizenship/am residing overseas with no local bank account. How do I pay my outstanding MediShield Life premiums?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/how-does-renounced-or-overseas-member-pay-outstanding-premiums)']

question: Is there a hotline for the CareShield Life, ElderShield or MediSave Care schemes?
answer: ['You can call the Healthcare Hotline at 1800-222-3399. The operating hours are from Monday to Friday (excluding public holidays), 8.30am to 5.30pm. Alternatively, you can also [write to us](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/enquiry-feedback.html). For more FAQs on CareShield Life, please visit the [CareShield Life website](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/FAQs).']

question: What is MediSave Care (also known as MediSave Withdrawals for Long-Term Care)?
answer:
['MediSave Care is a long-term care scheme which was launched on 1 October 2020. Under MediSave Care, Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents aged 30 and above who are severely disabled will be able to make monthly cash withdrawals from their own and/or their spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave for their long-term care needs.
After setting aside a minimum amount to ensure adequacy for other medical expenses, severely disabled Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will be able to withdraw up to a total of $200/month from their own and/or their spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave. The table below shows the MediSave balances and corresponding monthly withdrawal quanta.
Table: MediSave Balances and corresponding Monthly MediSave Withdrawal Quantum for Severely Disabled Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents aged 30 and above.1
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **MediSave Balance** | Monthly Withdrawal Quantum | |
| $20,000 and above | $200 | |
| $15,000 and above | $150 | |
| $10,000 and above | $100 | |
| $5,000 and above | $50 | |
| Below $5,000 | Nil | |
1Serverely Disabled Singapore Citizens and√Ç¬†Permanent Residents can withdraw from their spouse's MediSave Account, if they have insufficient MediSave balances, and their spouse has MediSave balances of $5,000 or more. Withdrawals from their spouse's MediSave will also be subject to the same MediSave balance thresholds. The total withdrawal from their own and/or spouse's MediSave is capped at $200/month.
For more FAQs on MediSave Care, please visit the√Ç¬†[CareShield Life website](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/faqs/medisave-care.html).']

question: How can I apply for MediSave Care?
answer:
['To apply for MediSave Care, you may submit an application to the Agency for Integrated Care, and arrange for a disability assessment by a MOH-accredited severe disability assessor.
For more FAQs on MediSave Care, please visit the√Ç¬†[CareShield Life website](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/faqs/medisave-care.html).']

question: Will my MediSave Care withdrawal limit automatically change as and when my MediSave balance changes?
answer:
['The eligible withdrawal quantum for MediSave Care is based on the MediSave balance at the point of withdrawal, if the individual has authorised to withdraw the maximum quantum. The table below shows the MediSave balances and corresponding monthly withdrawal quanta.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **MediSave Balance** | **Monthly Withdrawal Quantum** |
| $20,000 and above | $200 |
| $15,000 and above | $150 |
| $10,000 and above | $100 |
| $5,000 and above | $50 |
| Below $5,000 | Nil |
For more FAQs on MediSave Care, please visit the [CareShield Life website](https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg/FAQs).']

question: What is ElderFund?
answer:
['ElderFund is a discretionary assistance scheme, officially launched in end Jan 2020. It is targeted at assisting severely disabled lower-income Singapore Citizens aged 30 and above, who are not able to benefit from CareShield Life, ElderShield and Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly (IDAPE), and have low MediSave balances and inadequate personal savings to meet their long-term care needs.
Eligible Singapore Citizens can receive up to $250 in monthly cash payouts for as long as they remain severely disabled.
For more FAQs on ElderFund, please visit the [AIC website](https://www.aic.sg/ElderFund "AIC website").']

question: Are my MediSave Account savings covered under CPF Nomination?
answer: ['CPF Nomination covers all savings in your MediSave Account, including those in your Ordinary, Special and Retirement Accounts.']

question: Can I make a CPF nomination if I am holding more than one CPF account?
answer:
['If you are a Singaporean/Permanent Resident (PR) and you are holding more than one CPF account, you will need to merge your CPF accounts before making the CPF nomination.
Maintaining only one CPF account will simplify your transactions with the Board. You can make a CPF nomination once your CPF accounts are merged.
You can find out what are the documents needed to merge your accounts and how to submit them to us [here](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/your-cpf-account-and-personal-particulars/new-singapore-citizenship-or-permanent-residency).']

question: I submitted a CPF nomination form under my old account. Do I need to make a new CPF nomination if I have merged my CPF accounts?
answer: ['You do not need to submit a new CPF nomination form. If you have a valid CPF nomination form under your old CPF account, the CPF nomination status will automatically be updated in your new account. Hence, you do not need to make a new CPF nomination under the new CPF account unless you wish to change your nominee(s).']

question: I made a CPF nomination some time ago without appointing any authorised person(s). Do I need to make a new nomination if I wish to appoint an authorised person in my nomination?
answer:
['While your CPF nomination that you had made will remain in-force, should you wish to appoint an authorised person(s), you will need to make a new CPF nomination.
The Board also encourages you to review your nomination regularly so that it continues to fit your intentions. You can make your nomination online at *my cpf* Online Services.']

question: What happens if I do not inform the CPF Board of my marriage in the required manner?
answer: ['If we are not informed of the marriage in the [required manner](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/do-i-need-to-notify-cpf-board-if-i-get-married-after-making-my), the distribution of your CPF savings will follow your existing nomination, which may not be your latest bequeath intention to distribute your CPF savings.']

question: Can both parents nominate the same child with disabilities?
answer: ['Both parents of an eligible child with disabilities can participate in the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS). The child with disabilities will then receive separate streams of payout from each parent√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings upon the parent√¢¬Ä¬ôs demise.']

question: Can parents cancel their Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination after making one?
answer:
['Parents can cancel their Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination by making a new CPF nomination.
The new nomination will supersede the SNSS nomination which they have made earlier.
To make a nomination, you can do so [online](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) using your Singpass.']

question: Will there be a charge levied on members for Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS)?
answer: ['There will be no charge levied on members for making a CPF nomination under Special Needs Savings Scheme.']

question: Apart from Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), how else can parents set aside money for their child under the CPF system?
answer:
['Parents can also set aside money for their child by topping up to the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS)√Ç¬†nominee's CPF accounts based on current√Ç¬†CPF rules. These top-up monies will enjoy CPF interest rates√Ç¬†and will be set aside specifically for the child's retirement√Ç¬†needs instead of being disbursed under the SNSS.
For parents who are under the CPF LIFE scheme, and have made a Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination, they can opt not to receive their monthly CPF LIFE payouts, and retain the monies in their Retirement Account (RA).
To do so, members can inform the Board√Ç¬†of their intention in writing at least 2 months before their Payout Eligibility Age (PEA) or anytime after they have reached their PEA. In the request, members should indicate their name, NRIC number, signature and their intention to retain their CPF LIFE payouts in their CPF Retirement Accounts (RA) for the benefit of their SNSS nominee(s).']

question: Can parents determine the amount of monthly payouts for their nominated child with disabilities?
answer: ['Parents can determine the amount of monthly payout for their nominated child with disabilities at the point of application, subject to√Ç¬†a minimum payout of $250√Ç¬†per month with a minimum duration of√Ç¬†at least one year.']

question: Will the payouts be made directly to persons with disabilities?
answer:
['a) If the person with disabilities is 18 years old or above, and is of sound mind at point of disbursement, the disbursement will be made to the person with disabilities via his/her bank account.
b) If the person with disabilities is below 18 years old, the disbursement will be made to the legal guardian or the court-appointed deputy (if he has one), when the deputy or legal guardian applies to the Board on behalf of the person with disabilities.
c) If the person with disabilities is 18 years old or above and lacks mental capacity:
1. If he made a valid Lasting Power of Attorney to appoint a donee, CPF Board would make payment to the donee when he steps forward to apply on behalf of the person with disabilities.
2. If he had not made a valid Lasting Power of Attorney, a third party may apply to the court to be appointed as the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nominee's deputy, and the Board will make payment to the court-appointed deputy when he applies to the Board on behalf of the person with disabilities.']

question: I would like to change how much my child can receive monthly under the Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), how can I make the change?
answer: ['Under the√Ç¬†Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS), parents can revise the monthly payout by submitting a new nomination indicating the new amount.']

question: What is a legal entity?
answer:
['A legal entity is a legal body capable of receiving monies, including CPF savings in its own right.
For an entity to be capable of receiving monies, it has to be recognised under the law as being capable of doing certain things in its own name and not in the name of its members, such as owning and holding property, suing others and being sued. Such entities would include societies registered under the Societies Act (Cap. 311), companies (including public companies limited by guarantee) registered under the Companies Act (Cap.50), and limited liability partnerships (LLP) registered under the Limited Liability Partnerships Act (/cap. 163A).']

question: How do I change my CPF nomination?
answer:
['You can [make a new nomination online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/makeCPFNom) at *my cpf* Online Services.
If you cannot find witnesses to witness your online nomination, you can visit the ServiceSG Centres. Officers at the ServiceSG Centres can act as witnesses for your online nomination. Click [here](https://www.psd.gov.sg/transformation/servicesg) for the list of ServiceSG Centres locations and its operating hours.
Alternatively, you can visit any of our CPF Service Centres and complete the CPF Nomination Form in the presence of our Customer Service Executives (CSEs) who can act as your witnesses and clarify any questions you may have. You can book an appointment with us through our [CPF Appointment Service](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/appt) at the CPF website. The appointment can be made on your preferred date and time, subject to the availability of appointment slots.
Your new nomination will supersede your earlier nomination.']

question: How do I cancel a CPF nomination I made earlier?
answer:
['You can cancel your CPF nomination by making a new CPF nomination. The new nomination will supersede the nomination which you have made earlier.
To make a nomination, you can do so√Ç¬†[online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/makeCPFNom)√Ç¬†using your Singpass.']

question: What happens to my existing CPF nomination when I make a new one?
answer: ['Your new CPF nomination will supersede any earlier CPF nomination which you have made. This includes any instructions made through the earlier CPF nomination for the Board to disclose your CPF account information and nomination details to an authorised person(s) upon your demise. The Board will follow your latest instruction to disclose in accordance with your new nomination.']

question: Where do I submit the completed CPF nomination form?
answer:
['We encourage you to [make your CPF nomination online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/makeCPFNom) at my cpf Online Services.
Alternatively, you can visit any of our CPF Service Centres and complete the CPF Nomination Form in the presence of our Customer Service Executives (CSEs) who can act as your witnesses and clarify any questions you may have. You can book an appointment with us through our [CPF Appointment Service](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/appt) at the CPF website. The appointment can be made on your preferred date and time, subject to the availability of appointment slots.']

question: Can a blind person make a CPF nomination?
answer:
['A blind person can make a CPF nomination if he wants his CPF savings to be distributed according to his wishes.
If he chooses not to make a CPF nomination, his CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office (PTO) for distribution to his family members under the Intestate Succession Act or the Inheritance Certificate (for Muslims). This ensures that the welfare of his dependants is provided for.']

question: Why do I need to provide the NRIC or a unique identification number of my nominees in my CPF nomination form?
answer: ['The NRIC or a unique identification number of your nominees will facilitate the Board's identification of your nominees which allow them to claim your CPF savings swiftly and easily.']

question: How can I check my CPF nomination details?
answer:
['You can view your CPF nomination details (including your authorised persons) at [cpf.gov.sg/ViewNOMDetails](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/viewNOMDetails) with your Singpass.
If your nomination details are not available online, you can [submit an online request](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/ViewNomDetails) with your Singpass and you will be able to view your nomination details generally within four working days. An email will be sent to you to inform you that your nomination details can be viewed online.
If your nomination was made quite a while ago, we strongly encourage you to make a new nomination as your circumstances might have changed. You can easily [make a nomination online](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom).']

question: What happens to my CPF savings if I had made a CPF nomination?
answer:
['If you had made a valid CPF Nomination, the following will be distributed to your nominees in the proportion as stated in your CPF nomination upon your death:
(a) CPF savings in your Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts; (b) Unused CPF LIFE premiums; and (c) Discounted Singtel shares1.
The following are not covered by CPF Nomination:
(a) Properties bought with your CPF savings2; (b) Payout from Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS)3; and (c) Investments made under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)4.
1 Discounted Singtel shares will form part of your estate if you do not make a CPF nomination.
2 The treatment of the deceased√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of the property is dependent on the manner of holding. If the property is held under Joint Tenancy, ownership of property will be transferred to the surviving owner(s). If the property is held under Tenancy-in-Common, the deceased's share of property will form part of his estate.
3 You can make a DPS nomination with your DPS insurer or make a will to determine the beneficiaries of the DPS claim benefits. Without a DPS nomination or will, the benefits will be paid to the proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased√¢¬Ä¬ôs estate or a family member.
4 These will form part of your estate, except for insurance policies where if you have made a nomination with your insurance company, the death benefits from the policies will be paid to your nominated beneficiaries.
Watch this [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y3XI20jYA3g) to find out why you need to make a CPF nomination.']

question: I have bought an annuity in place of the retirement sum when I turned 55. Will my nominees receive the remaining guaranteed sum from my annuity when I pass away?
answer: ['If you had bought an annuity in place of the retirement sum when you turned 55, your nominees will receive the remaining guaranteed sum from your annuity when you pass away.']

question: What happens to my CPF savings if I did not make a CPF nomination?
answer:
['When you are no longer around, we will pay your CPF savings to the [Public Trustee's Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution in cash to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore. This ensures that the welfare of your dependants is provided for.
The following assets are due to the beneficiaries of the deceased's estate:
a. Discounted Singtel shares;
b. Properties bought with your CPF savings1;
c. Payout from Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS)2; and
d. Investments made under CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS)3.
1 The treatment of the deceased√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of the property is dependent on the manner of holding. If the property is held under Joint Tenancy, ownership of property will be transferred to the surviving owner(s). If the property is held under Tenancy-in-Common, the deceased's share of property will form part of his estate.
2 You can make a DPS nomination with your DPS insurer or make a will to determine the beneficiaries of the DPS claim benefits. Without a DPS nomination or will, the benefits will be paid to the proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased√¢¬Ä¬ôs estate or a family member.
3 These will form part of your estate, except for insurance policies where if you have made a nomination with your insurance company, the death benefits from the policies will be paid to your nominated beneficiaries.
Watch this [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y3XI20jYA3g) to find out why you need to make a CPF nomination.']

question: How will CPF savings be distributed under the intestacy laws?
answer:
['Member's CPF savings will be transferred to the [Public Trustee's Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (Cap 146) if he did not make a CPF nomination.
For a Muslim member, his CPF savings will be distributed in accordance with the [Inheritance Certificate](http://www.muis.gov.sg/). His family can obtain the certificate from the Syariah Court, Family Link @ Lengkok Bahru, 8 Lengkok Bahru, #03-01, Singapore 159052.']

question: Who is the Public Trustee?
answer:
['The Public Trustee is a government body that acts as a trustee of the deceased's estate. It ensures that the assets of the deceased are distributed to the rightful beneficiaries.
If you require further information or clarification, please contact:
The Public Trustee's Office 45 Maxwell Road #07-11, The URA Centre (East Wing) Singapore 069118 Tel: 1800 2255 529 Website: [pto.mlaw.gov.sg](http://pto.mlaw.gov.sg)']

question: If I have made a CPF nomination, how will my CPF savings be paid to my nominees?
answer:
['By default, your nominee(s) will receive the CPF savings due to them **in cash**√Ç¬†or GIRO.
If you have made a CPF nomination, you can check your [details](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/esvc/web/schemes/nominationdetails/home) to find out how your CPF savings will be distributed to your nominee(s).
**Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS)**
If you have made a nomination under the Special Needs Savings Scheme, your children will receive your CPF savings on a monthly basis upon your demise. Find out more about [SNSS Nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/what-is-the-special-needs-savings-scheme).
Please contact the Board if you have any enquiries on the above.']

question: How would my child's CPF savings be distributed if he were to pass away?
answer:
['The minimum age to make a CPF nomination is 16 years old.
If a member passes away before attaining 16 years of age, he would not have a valid CPF nomination, and his CPF savings would be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act or the Administration of Muslim Law (for Muslims). If a member passes away at 16 years of age or above and has made a valid CPF nomination, his CPF savings will be distributed according to his wishes, otherwise his CPF savings would be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office for distribution in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act or the Administration of Muslim Law (for Muslims).']

question: Can I make or revoke a CPF nomination on someone's behalf?
answer:
['A CPF nomination must be made or revoked by the CPF member personally.
However, if a CPF member lacks capacity under Section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act ("MCA"), only the Courts are allowed to make or revoke a CPF nomination on behalf of the member.
An interested party can apply to the Court to do so, and the court would decide in the interest of the member who is lacking capacity, whether to accept the application to make or revoke a CPF nomination on his behalf.']

question: How can a donee/deputy make or revoke a CPF nomination for members who lack mental capacity?
answer: ['For CPF members who lack capacity under Section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act ("MCA"), only the Courts can make or revoke a CPF nomination on their behalf.']

question: What are the documents that CPF Board requires if the Court has accepted an application to make or revoke a nomination and how should these documents be submitted?
answer:
['**Make a CPF nomination for members who lack mental capacity**
If the Court accepts the application to make a CPF nomination on behalf of a member, the court may appoint a person to carry out the making of the nomination.
