If you are the person appointed by the Court to carry out the making of the nomination, please complete the relevant CPF nomination form and indicate that you are the authorised person ordered by the Court to make the CPF nomination on behalf of the member who lacks capacity. The CPF nomination form must be affixed with the Court's Seal.
The witnesses to the nomination may be our Customer Service Executives (CSEs) at any of our [Service Centres](/member/contact-us/visit-us). If 2 other witnesses are chosen, please note that the witnesses to the CPF nomination must be at least 21 years old and not lack capacity. Please note that the witnesses cannot be the nominees or the authorised person signing on behalf of the member.
We encourage you to hand-deliver the completed CPF nomination form (affixed with the Court's Seal), with a certified true copy of the Order of Court and your NRIC to any CPF Service Centre. Alternatively, you may wish to send the documents to the Board by post. You can mail the documents to:
Attention: Nominations Department
Central Provident Fund Board Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060 Singapore 905060
**Revoke a CPF nomination for members who lack mental capacity**If the Court accepts your application to revoke the CPF nomination, and makes the order revoking the CPF nomination, please furnish the Board with a copy of the Order of Court and your NRIC (both documents to be certified as true copies by your lawyers).
We encourage you to hand-deliver the completed CPF revocation form (affixed with the Court's Seal), with a certified true copy of the Order of Court and your NRIC to any CPF Service Centre. Alternatively, you may wish to send the documents to the Board by post. You can mail the documents to:
Attention: Nominations Department
Central Provident Fund Board Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060 Singapore 905060
You should seek your lawyer's advice as an application to court is required.']

question: How does CPF Board ensure that changes to CPF nomination of members who lack mental capacity, are done in their best interest?
answer: ['The treatment of CPF nominations has been aligned with that of wills under the Mental Capacity Act 2008 (MCA). Safeguards are in place under the MCA as the Court in making decisions on behalf of a member who lacks capacity, has to take into account what is in the member's "best interests". This includes taking into consideration the member's past and present wishes and feelings, his beliefs and values that would likely influence his decision if he had the mental capacity. The Court will also have to take into account the views from persons who were close to the member.']

question: What happens if my nominee and I (e.g. husband and wife) nominate each other and both of us pass away simultaneously?
answer:
['In the event of simultaneous death, the older person is deemed to have died first.
Please see below for examples to illustrate the above.
Example 1: Where you and your nominee have nominated each other only
If you are the older nominee, your CPF savings will be paid to your nominee's estate.
If you are the younger nominee, it is deemed that your nominee has died first and there is therefore no nominee. Your CPF savings will be forwarded to the√Ç¬†[Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/)√Ç¬†for distribution to your family members in accordance with the Intestate Succession Act (Cap 146) for Non-Muslims, and the Administration of Muslim Law Act for Muslims.
Example 2: Where you and your nominee (e.g. spouse) have nominated each other, and other people
Assuming you appointed the nominees as follows:
1. Spouse - 60%
2. Mother - 30%
3. Son - 10%
If you are the older spouse, 60% of your CPF savings will be paid to your spouse's estate. Your mother and son will receive 30% and 10% of your CPF savings respectively. If you are the younger spouse, it is deemed that your spouse has died first. His/her share of your CPF savings will be passed on to the surviving nominees in the same proportion as their specified shares. Your mother and son will receive your CPF savings as follows :
1. Mother - 75% [original 30% + 3/4 of your spouse's share (equivalent to 45%)
2. Son - 25% [original 10% + 1/4 of your spouse's share (equivalent to 15%)']

question: How do I make a Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nomination?
answer:
['| |
| --- |
| The Special Needs Saving Scheme (SNSS) caters to Persons with Special Needs (PSN) who are nominated by their parents to draw a fixed monthly payout from the parents' CPF savings upon the parents' demise. For more details on SNSS, please visit SNTC's√Ç¬†[website](https://www.sntc.org.sg/home). |
What is required before making an SNSS nomination?
Before you apply for SNSS nomination, you are required to obtain an eligibility letter from Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC). SNTC will issue the letter to you after confirming your nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs eligibility for the SNSS. You may then proceed to any of our√Ç¬†[Service Centres](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/visit-us)√Ç¬†to make the SNSS nomination. For more details on SNSS, please visit SNTC's√Ç¬†[website](https://www.sntc.org.sg/home).']

question: Can I nominate a trust company to receive my CPF savings for the benefit of my nominee?
answer:
['A trust company is a legal entity\* which is capable of receiving monies (including CPF savings) in its own right. As such, you can nominate a trust company to receive your CPF savings. One example of such a trust company is the Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC), which can receive CPF savings as a nominee, who will then transfer these CPF savings to the trust funds set up by their clients.
Members should note that when appointing a trust company as a nominee, the trust company will receive the CPF monies in its own right.
Members would need to have a separate arrangement (such as a letter of intent) with the trust company on how to channel their CPF savings to their trust fund and use it to benefit the intended beneficiary.
CPF Board is not in the position to enforce or ensure that the trust company will use the CPF savings for the benefit of the intended beneficiary. This is strictly a private arrangement between you and the trust company.
\* What is a legal entity?
A legal entity is a legal body capable of receiving monies, including CPF savings in its own right.
For an entity to be capable of receiving monies, it has to be recognised under the law as being capable of doing certain things in its own name and not in the name of its members, such as owning and holding property, suing others and being sued. Such entities would include societies registered under the Societies Act (Cap. 311), companies (including public companies limited by guarantee) registered under the Companies Act (Cap.50), and limited liability partnerships (LLP) registered under the Limited Liability Partnerships Act (/cap. 163A).']

question: Can I nominate a trust fund to receive my CPF savings for the benefit of my nominee?
answer:
['CPF members are not allowed to nominate a trust fund as it is not a legal entity\* which is capable of receiving monies.
\* What is a legal entity?
A legal entity is a legal body capable of receiving monies, including CPF savings in its own right.
For an entity to be capable of receiving monies, it has to be recognised under the law as being capable of doing certain things in its own name and not in the name of its members, such as owning and holding property, suing others and being sued. Such entities would include societies registered under the Societies Act (Cap. 311), companies (including public companies limited by guarantee) registered under the Companies Act (Cap.50), and limited liability partnerships (LLP) registered under the Limited Liability Partnerships Act (/cap. 163A).']

question: What happens if the CPF Board finds out that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity?
answer:
['| |
| --- |
| If the Board is informed of any facts or circumstances which may affect the validity of the CPF nomination and has evidence and supporting documents to ascertain the fact that the member lacked capacity at the time of making the CPF nomination, the Board will invalidate the CPF nomination made by such a member.Anyone, who is of the view that the CPF nomination is invalid on the grounds that the member lacked capacity at the time the said CPF nomination was made, could also apply to Court to set aside the nomination. |
What happens if the CPF Board deems that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity?
If the CPF Board deems that the CPF nomination was made whilst the member lacked capacity within the meaning of section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act 2008, the Board will invalidate the nomination. The previous CPF nomination (if any) made by the member would remain valid (assuming the member did not lack capacity when he made the previous CPF nomination). The member's CPF savings would be distributed in accordance with the intention of the member in his previous valid CPF nomination. If there is no previous valid CPF nomination, the CPF savings would be paid to the Public Trustee for distribution in accordance with intestacy laws.']

question: My elderly parent would like to check his/her existing CPF nomination. How can I help him/her do so?
answer:
['Your parent can [view his/her CPF nomination details online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/viewNOMDetails) with his/her Singpass. Find out [more information on how he/she can check his/her nomination details](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/how-can-i-check-my-cpf-nomination-details).
However, we would strongly encourage making a new nomination instead, especially if the previous nomination was made some time ago. Making a new nomination would ensure that your parent√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF monies are distributed according to his/her latest wishes upon his/her demise. The new nomination would supersede any earlier nominations made, and the same nominee(s) can be re-nominated, if desired. This would also provide the Board with the latest particulars of the nominee(s), and allow us to reach out to them more quickly to claim the monies.
Making a new nomination is easy and convenient. Find out [how a member can make a CPF nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/how-can-i-make-a-cpf-nomination).']

question: Why should I make a CPF nomination?
answer:
['By making a CPF nomination, you have the flexibility to decide who should receive your CPF savings upon your demise. Your nominee(s) will also receive your CPF savings more quickly (within five weeks), with no fees charged.
If you do not make a CPF nomination, the Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office (PTO) will distribute your CPF savings according to [intestacy](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/files/intestacybrochure.pdf) or Muslim Inheritance laws. Under this process, beneficiaries will need to provide documentation to prove their relationship with you. As time and effort is required to identify and verify your eligible beneficiaries, the entire process may take up to six months and it will incur an administrative fee which will be deducted from your CPF savings. This means your beneficiaries will receive less of your CPF savings.
With a CPF nomination, CPF Board will generally take less than five weeks to distribute your CPF savings to your nominee(s). [Make a CPF nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom)√Ç¬†so that your CPF savings are swiftly distributed to your loved ones when you are no longer around.']

question: Who can make a CPF nomination?
answer: ['You can make a CPF nomination as long as you are a CPF member, above 16 years old and must not lack mental capacity. Members who are bankrupt or have disabilities (e.g. visual impairment) can also make a CPF nomination.']

question: Why is there a minimum age for making a CPF nomination?
answer: ['CPF members should be of sufficient maturity when they make a decision to nominate and bequeath their CPF savings. Therefore, a minimum age of 16 is set for making a nomination, in line with the minimum age to work and earn wages under the Employment Act.']

question: When should I make a CPF nomination?
answer: ['We encourage you to make a CPF nomination as soon as you begin to accumulate savings in your CPF account. As you progress in life, you should also review your nomination regularly, especially after major life events (marriage, childbirth, divorce etc.) so that your nomination continues to fit your intention.']

question: What is covered by CPF nomination?
answer:
['You can refer to the infographic below to find out what a CPF nomination covers.
![A table showing what CPF assets is covered and not covered under CPF nomination](/content/dam/web/member/faq/account-services/images/whatdoestheCPFnominationcover.png)']

question: I have already made a will. Do I still need to make a CPF nomination for my CPF savings?
answer:
['Yes, you will still need to make a CPF nomination as CPF savings are excluded from your estate and therefore cannot be covered by a will.
Excluding CPF savings from your estate protects your savings from any creditor claims on outstanding loans that you may have after your demise. This ensures that your CPF savings are fully preserved for your loved ones.
You are encouraged to make a CPF nomination to distribute your CPF savings according to your wishes.']

question: Who can I include as my nominee?
answer:
['You can nominate any person (regardless of age or nationality) or [organisation](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/i-would-like-to-nominate-an-organisation-to-receive-my-cpf).
If you are nominating someone who is not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, please provide the nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs full name, foreign identification number and mailing address in your nomination form so that the Board can contact him swiftly when distributing your CPF savings. Find out [more](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/what-are-the-things-i-need-to-prepare-to-make-an-online).']

question: What happens to my CPF savings if my nominee is below 18 years old?
answer:
['If your nominee is below the age of 18 at the time of claim, his share will be transferred to the [Public Trustee's Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) and held-in-trust until he reaches 18 years of age.
Alternatively, you can nominate a trustee/trust company to receive your CPF savings on behalf of your beneficiary who is a minor.
You are advised to make arrangements with the trustee/trust company on how to channel your CPF savings to your intended beneficiaries. Please note that we are not in a position to enforce or ensure that the trustee/trust company will apply the CPF savings received for the benefit of your intended beneficiaries. This is strictly a private arrangement between you and the appointed trustee/trust company.']

question: I would like to nominate an organisation to receive my CPF savings when I pass away. Are there any requirements for the type of organisation I can nominate?
answer:
['You can nominate an organisation if it is a legal entity capable of receiving monies, including CPF monies, in its own right.
For an entity to be capable of receiving monies, it must be recognised under the law as being capable of doing certain things in its own name and not in the name of its members, such as owning and holding property, suing others, and being sued. Such entities would include companies (including public companies limited by guarantee) registered under the Companies Act 1967 and limited liability partnerships (LLP) registered under the Limited Liability Partnerships Act 2005.
You may also nominate societies registered under the Societies Act 1966.
You can check if the organisation has been registered as a society, company, or LLP via the following websites:
1. [Registry of Societies (for registered societies)](https://www.ros.mha.gov.sg/)
2. [ACRA's BizFile page (for companies, LLPs)](https://www.acra.gov.sg/home/)
**Alternatives if the organisation is not a legal entity**
If you would like to nominate an organisation that is not a legal entity or registered with the Registry of Societies (ROS), you can consider the following alternatives:
1. Discuss with the organisation on nominating a person holding an official position (e.g. General Manager or Chief Executive) within the organisation, or
2. Nominate a trustee/trust company to receive your CPF savings on behalf of the organisation.
Please note that the person holding an official position in the organisation or the trustee/trust company will receive the CPF savings in his/its own right. Members are encouraged to make arrangements with the said person or the trustee/trust company on how to thereafter channel their CPF savings to the organisation.
Please also note that CPF Board is not in a position to enforce or ensure that the said person or the trustee/trust company will apply the CPF savings received for the benefit of the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs intended beneficiaries. This is strictly a private arrangement between the member and the person or trustee/trust company.
If you require further clarification, you can [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index) for assistance.']

question: If my nominee is a bankrupt, can he still claim my CPF savings?
answer: ['If your nominee was or is an undischarged bankrupt, we are legally obliged to inform the Official Assignee (OA) and transfer the nominated monies to the OA upon his instructions. This is by virtue of the laws in Singapore relating to bankruptcy which vest the property of a bankrupt in the OA upon the making of a bankruptcy order.']

question: Will my nominee(s) be notified when I make a nomination?
answer: ['Your nomination is confidential. We will not disclose your nomination details to anyone, including your nominee(s). We will only contact your nominee(s) regarding the distribution of your CPF savings when you pass away.']

question: Why do I need witnesses when I make a CPF nomination?
answer:
['Disputes on who should receive your CPF savings may sometimes arise after you have passed on. That is why you have to appoint two witnesses who can attest that you have made your nomination willingly and calmly. Your witnesses cannot be your nominee or an organisation.
Witnesses do not need to know your nominee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô details to perform their roles as witnesses. Where necessary, your witnesses can help us understand how the nomination was made so that we can distribute your CPF savings according to your wishes.']

question: Who can be my witnesses for my CPF nomination?
answer:
['Your witnesses must be two different individuals who:
1. are at least 21 years of age;
2. must not lack mental capacity; and
3. are not any of your nominee(s).
If you are making an online nomination, your witnesses must have a valid Singpass.']

question: Can my nominee be my witness?
answer: ['Your nominee cannot be one of your witnesses, to prevent a conflict of interest.']

question: My witnesses are residing in a different country from me. Can I appoint them as witnesses for my CPF nomination?
answer:
['Yes, you can make an online nomination and appoint them as your witnesses as long as they meet the [criteria to be a witness](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/who-can-be-my-witnesses-for-my-cpf-nomination) and have a valid Singpass.
Once√Ç¬†you have decided on your witnesses, you should contact them and inform them of your intention to make a nomination. You should request that they confirm this when asked to do so by CPF Board.']

question: Will my witnesses know the details of my CPF nomination?
answer:
['Your CPF nomination details will not be made known to your witnesses. Your witnesses will only need to declare that they are aware of your intention to make a nomination and specify how the witnessing request was communicated to them.
Making your nomination online provides added privacy and confidentiality, as your witnesses will not be able to see your nomination details.']

question: Do I need to review and update my CPF nomination after making one?
answer: ['Yes. Making a CPF nomination is not a one-time affair as your circumstances may change (e.g. marriage, childbirth, divorce etc). You are encouraged to [review your CPF nomination](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/do-i-have-to-update-or-change-my-cpf-nomination-record-when) so that it remains relevant to your latest circumstances.']

question: Do I have to update or change my CPF nomination record when there are changes to my circumstances (e.g. marriage, child birth, divorce, death of my nominee)?
answer:
['You are encouraged to [make a new CPF nomination](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/how-can-i-make-a-cpf-nomination) to√Ç¬†keep your nomination relevant to your latest circumstances.
See the infographic below for some examples of life milestones when you should consider reviewing your nomination.
![Major life events that members should consider making or reviewing their existing nomination](/content/dam/web/member/faq/account-services/images/doihavetoupdateorchangemycpfnominationrecordwhentherearechangestomycircumstances.png)']

question: What happens to my CPF nomination upon marriage?
answer:
['Your CPF nomination will be revoked upon marriage. When you get married, you will form a new family nucleus. Your nomination is revoked upon marriage so that you can reconsider your bequeath intentions based on your new family nucleus. This practice is similar to wills, which are also revoked upon marriage under the Wills Act.
You are strongly encouraged to [make a new CPF nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) after your marriage if you want your CPF savings to be distributed according to your wishes.
[Do I need to notify CPF Board of my marriage](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/do-i-need-to-notify-cpf-board-if-i-get-married-after-making-my)?']

question: Do I need to notify CPF Board if I get married after making my CPF nomination?
answer:
['If your marriage is registered with the Singapore Registry of Marriages (ROM) or Registry of Muslim Marriages (ROMM)
You do not need to notify us of your marriage. However, any CPF nomination you had made previously will be revoked upon your marriage. You are strongly encouraged to [make a new CPF nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) so that your CPF savings will be distributed according to your wishes.
If your marriage is not registered with ROM or ROMM
You will be required to complete the [Notification of Marriage in relation to CPF Nomination form](https://www.form.gov.sg/5f0eb467c26b3700116d8080) so that we are informed of your marriage. If you have a CPF nomination made before this marriage, your nomination will be revoked.
Alternatively, you can [make a new nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) after getting married if you do not wish to notify us of your marriage. This new nomination will supersede any previous nomination you had made before your marriage.']

question: What happens to my CPF nomination upon divorce?
answer:
['Divorce does not revoke a CPF nomination. This treatment is similar to that of wills (which are not revoked upon divorce).
Some members may still wish to bequeath their CPF savings to their ex-spouse and/or children via their existing nominations, and therefore, it is best for members to review their latest personal circumstances and update their nomination accordingly.
You can [make a new nomination online](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom).']

question: What happens if I have children after making my CPF nomination?
answer: ['Childbirth does not change your existing CPF nomination. However, you should [make a new nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) if you wish to include your child as one of the beneficiaries of your CPF savings.']

question: What happens if one or all of my nominees pass away?
answer:
['If your nominee passes on before you, his/her share will be given to the surviving nominee(s) in the same proportion you have specified.
If there are no surviving nominee(s), your nomination is considered revoked and your savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office for distribution under the [intestacy](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/files/intestacybrochure.pdf) or Muslim Inheritance laws.']

question: How can I make a CPF nomination?
answer:
['Online
You can [make a CPF nomination online](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) by logging in to *my cpf* digital services with your Singpass. Making your nomination online is convenient as it can be done anytime, anywhere. You will need to [prepare your Singpass, as well as the particulars of your nominee(s) and witnesses](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/what-are-the-things-i-need-to-prepare-to-make-an-online).
If you cannot find witnesses to witness your online nomination, you can visit the ServiceSG Centres. Officers at the ServiceSG Centres can act as witnesses for your online nomination. Click [here](https://www.psd.gov.sg/transformation/servicesg) for the list of ServiceSG Centres locations and its operating hours.
At CPF Service Centres
Alternatively, you may visit any of our CPF Service Centres to make√Ç¬†your CPF nomination. Please [make an appointment](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/appt) at least one working day in advance, as counter services at CPF Service Centre are available by appointment only. Our Customer Service Executives will act as your witnesses for your nomination. Find out [what are the supporting documents you need to bring along with you](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/what-supporting-documents-do-i-need-if-i-am-making-a-nomination).']

question: Can I indicate my nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of my CPF savings as a fixed amount instead of a percentage?
answer:
['No. In the event that your CPF savings are insufficient to meet this fixed amount you had specified in your nomination, we will not be able to distribute your CPF savings according to your wishes.
Indicating nominee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô entitlement as a percentage of your CPF savings will allow us to distribute your CPF savings to your nominee(s) according to your wishes, regardless of changes to your CPF balances. The total entitlement for all nominees must sum up to 100%.']

question: How can I make a CPF nomination if I am overseas?
answer:
['You can [make an online nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) using your Singpass.
Your witnesses need not be physically present with you to verify your intention to nominate. However, your witnesses must have a valid Singpass to complete the witnessing for your nomination.']

question: How long does it take to process applications relating to CPF nomination?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our normal processing time for applications relating to CPF nomination.
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Nomination** | **Manual Transaction** | **E-Transaction** |
| Making a nomination | Four working days upon receipt of application |
| Request to view my nomination details online Note: For hardcopy based nominations only. For online nominations, the details will be available immediately after it is processed. | Not applicable | Four working days |
| Request to revoke my existing nomination(s) | Four working days upon receipt of application | Not applicable |']

question: How can I check the status of my nomination?
answer:
['You can check the status of your online nomination at [cpf.gov.sg/MyActivities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/myactivities "http://www.cpf.gov.sg/myactivities") using your Singpass.
We will send you an email/SMS once your nomination is routed to your witnesses. Upon the completion of witnessing by your witnesses, we will generally process your nomination within 4 working days. You will also receive an email/SMS of the status.
Once your online nomination has been processed, you will receive one more email/SMS notification on the final status of your nomination.
If you wish to view the details of your nomination, you can then access the information at [cpf.gov.sg/viewnomdetails](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/viewnomdetails).']

question: Can I change my CPF nomination? Is there a limit to the number of times I can change my nomination?
answer:
['Yes, you can change your CPF nomination by [making a new nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom). Your new nomination will supersede your existing nomination, including any instructions to disclose your CPF account and nomination details to an authorised person(s) when you pass away.
There is no limit to the number of times you can change your nomination.']

question: Is my CPF nomination still valid if one or both of my witnesses pass away?
answer: ['Yes, your nomination will remain valid.']

question: Can I still make a CPF nomination if I am seriously ill?
answer:
['Yes, you can do so provided you are conscious and must not lack mental capacity when making the nomination.
You can consider appointing a doctor to be one of your witnesses in your nomination. You can request your doctor to write a memo stating that you have the mental capacity to make a CPF nomination and submit it to us.']

question: My nominees have changed their personal particulars (e.g. names, addresses or passport numbers). Do I need to update the changes in my CPF nomination?
answer:
['**If your nominee is a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident**
You do not need to update the changes in your CPF nomination.
For name changes, the Board will request your nominee to present document(s) e.g. Deed Poll, as proof of their name change when they apply to withdraw the CPF monies after your demise.
**If your nominee is a foreigner**
You should [make a new CPF nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) with their latest particulars. This will help us identify and contact your nominee easily to distribute your CPF savings.']

question: What is online nomination? How is it different from submitting a hardcopy nomination?
answer:
['Online nomination allows you to submit your CPF nomination online, anytime, anywhere, without the need for your witnesses to be physically present to sign the hardcopy form. The process is simple and takes place entirely online:
1. You log in with your Singpass and submit the [online nomination form](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom) with the required details.
2. Inform your witnesses so that they are aware of your intention to make this nomination.
3. Your appointed witnesses are notified by email and/or SMS to perform witnessing.
4. The appointed witnesses log in with their Singpass and affirm your intention to make the nomination.']

question: Why should I make my CPF nomination online?
answer: ['Online nomination is convenient √¢¬Ä¬ì you can make your nomination anytime, anywhere. Your personal information is protected as your witnesses will not be able to see your nomination details.']

question: What are the things I need to prepare to make an online nomination?
answer:
['You will need:
* **A valid Singpass**
* **Witnesses√¢¬Ä¬ô particulars:**
1. Full name\* as per NRIC
2. NRIC
3. Email and/or Singapore registered mobile number (for receiving of SMS notification to perform witnessing)
* **Nominee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô particulars:**
1. NRIC/FIN (e.g. passport or foreign identification card number)
2. Full name\* as per NRIC/foreign identification document
3. Mailing address\*\* (for foreigners only)
4. Email address (optional)
\* It is important to provide full names of your nominees and witnesses as indicated on their NRICs, including comma, hyphen and space accordingly. However, you should exclude the Hanyu Pinyin, Alias and married name. See [examples of NRIC names](/content/dam/web/member/faq/account-services/images/examples-of-nric-names.png).
\*\* Mailing address is required for foreigners to facilitate us in contacting them when distributing your CPF savings. Mailing address for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will be based on the address registered with Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA).']

question: Is it safe to make my CPF nomination online?
answer:
['There are multiple layers of checks in place so that CPF members can make their nomination online in a safe and secure manner.
A Singpass is required to log in securely to *my cpf* digital services to make your online nomination. Singpass has multiple layers of security measures in place, including Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) login. We will also send SMS and email notification alerts to your registered mobile number/email address when you make your nomination online.
The combination of these measures will provide a safe and secure environment for you to make your nomination online.
You are also encouraged to adopt good security practices such as not sharing your Singpass credentials with others and changing your passwords regularly.']

question: How many nominees can I specify in my online nomination?
answer: ['You can specify up to 15 nominees. If you wish to nominate more than 15 nominees, you can make a nomination at our CPF Service Centres.']

question: What should I do if I wish to amend an online nomination I have submitted?
answer:
['You can amend your nomination if either or both your witnesses have not witnessed your nomination. You can do so by [withdrawing your nomination](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/how-can-i-withdraw-my-online-nomination) and submitting a new one.
If both your witnesses have already witnessed your nomination, you will not be able to withdraw and amend the nomination. However, you can submit a new nomination after your earlier nomination is processed. Your new nomination will supersede your earlier nomination.
You can only submit one nomination within the same day. This includes the nomination that has had its witnessing process completed that day.']

question: How can I withdraw my online nomination?
answer:
['You can withdraw your application so long as at least one of your witnesses has yet to complete the witnessing:
1. Log in to√Ç¬†*my cpf*√Ç¬†digital services using your Singpass at[cpf.gov.sg/MyActivities](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/myactivities).
2. In transaction details, click on √¢¬Ä¬úwithdraw this application√¢¬Ä¬ù and confirm your intent to withdraw the application.
Please note that after you withdraw your online nomination, your existing nomination status remains unchanged. If both your witnesses have completed their witnessing and you wish to make a new nomination, you can submit one [here](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom).']

question: I encountered an error informing me that the name I keyed for my nominee was different from his NRIC/CPF Account No. How can I resolve this?
answer:
['If your nominee is a Singaporean or Singapore Permanent Resident, you should key in the full name as per his NRIC including any commas, hyphens and spaces.
However, you should exclude the Hanyu Pinyin, Alias and Married name. See [examples](/content/dam/web/member/faq/account-services/images/examples-of-nric-names.png) of NRIC names.
If you are still encountering problems in submitting your nomination, we recommend that you check the following:
1. Avoid copy-pasting the details from another program or app as there might be hidden characters that might get copied. Key in the nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs particulars directly instead.
2. If you are using an iOS device (such as iPhone or iPad), disable the √¢¬Ä¬úSmart Punctuation√¢¬Ä¬ù feature in iOS (iOS device Settings > General > Keyboard > Turn off Smart Punctuation). This feature might create unrecognisable characters in the application form.
3. Avoid opening multiple browser tabs. Use only one browser tab and clear your browser cache.
4. Consider using a different device to submit your nomination if submission via your original device is still unsuccessful.
Please [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if you encounter further issues. Alternatively, you may visit any of our [CPF Service Centres](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/visit-us) to make a nomination.']

question: I am using an iOS device (iPhone or iPad) to submit my online nomination, and I was not able to submit my nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs particulars. How can I resolve this?
answer: ['If you are using an iOS device (such as iPhone or iPad) to submit your nomination, the √¢¬Ä¬úSmart Punctuation√¢¬Ä¬ù feature in iOS may prevent you from submitting your nomination. You can disable the feature by performing the following steps on your device: Settings > General > Keyboard > Turn off Smart Punctuation.']

question: How do I submit an organisation as my nominee in my online nomination?
answer: ['If you would like to nominate an organisation, select 'Registration No.' under the √¢¬Ä¬òSelect identification type√¢¬Ä¬ô field and indicate the organisation√¢¬Ä¬ôs unique corporate registration number (such as Unique Entity Number (UEN)) in the √¢¬Ä¬òRegistration number of organisation√¢¬Ä¬ô field.']

question: What should I do if I encounter problems with the online nomination service?
answer:
['If you are encountering problems, you can troubleshoot most errors by performing the following steps:
1. Avoid copy-pasting the details from another program or app as there might be hidden characters that might get copied. Key in the nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs particulars directly instead.
2. If you are using an iOS device (such as iPhone or iPad), disable the √¢¬Ä¬úSmart Punctuation√¢¬Ä¬ù feature in iOS (iOS device Settings > General > Keyboard > Turn off Smart Punctuation). This feature might create unrecognisable characters in the application form.
3. Avoid opening multiple browser tabs. Use only one browser tab and clear your browser cache.
4. Consider using a different device to submit your nomination if submission via your original device is still unsuccessful.
If you are still facing problems after performing the above troubleshooting steps, you can write to us so that we can look into it.
Alternatively, you may visit any of our CPF Service Centres to make a nomination in-person.']

question: I have been requested to witness an online nomination. What do I need to do?
answer:
['As a witness, you will need to declare that you are aware of the CPF member√¢¬Ä¬ôs intention to make a nomination and specify how the request was communicated to you.
If you are ready with this information, please [login](https://cpf.gov.sg/WitnessNom) with your Singpass to complete your witnessing.']

question: Why can√¢¬Ä¬ôt witnesses view the CPF member√¢¬Ä¬ôs nomination details?
answer: ['The role of a witness is to affirm the CPF member√¢¬Ä¬ôs intention to make a CPF nomination. There is no need for witnesses to know the nomination details to perform their role as witnesses.']

question: Is there a deadline for me to witness an online nomination?
answer:
['Yes, you have seven calendar days from the time you receive the SMS/email notification request to complete the witnessing.
If you cannot complete the witnessing in time, please inform the CPF member, as the nomination application will expire and the CPF member will need to submit a new application.']

question: Why can√¢¬Ä¬ôt I access the online nomination witnessing request that was sent to me?
answer:
['You will not be able to access the online nomination witnessing request if:
* the nomination application had expired (after seven calendar days from application date);
* the member making the CPF nomination has withdrawn the nomination; or
* you have already completed witnessing the nomination.']

question: How can I be sure that I√¢¬Ä¬ôm witnessing a legitimate nomination?
answer: ['It is your responsibility as a witness to ensure that the CPF member making the nomination has specifically requested for you to witness his nomination. You should check with the member to affirm his intention to make a CPF nomination before proceeding to witness his nomination.']

question: I received a request to witness an online nomination from someone I do not know. What should I do?
answer: ['Do not complete the witnessing process. Please [contact us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) immediately so that we can follow up with the CPF member.']

question: What supporting documents do I need if I am making a nomination at the CPF Service Centre?
answer: ['You are strongly encouraged to bring along photocopies of your nominee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô identification documents (such as NRIC or foreign identification document) indicating their particulars.']

question: Do I need my own witnesses to be present if I am making my nomination at any CPF Service Centre?
answer: ['Our Customer Service Executives can act as your witnesses.']

question: Why should I authorise specific person(s) to access my CPF account information when I pass away?
answer:
['Upon your demise, your next-of-kin may want to know how much CPF savings you have accumulated, who you have nominated to receive them and how much.
To protect your privacy, only your nominee(s) will be told the amount they will receive but they will not know how much CPF savings you have in total, nor who else you have nominated to receive your CPF.
This protects your privacy but can sometimes result in unhappiness. To avoid this, you may choose to authorise specific persons to access your CPF account information upon your demise. Without this explicit authorisation, your account information and nomination decisions will not be revealed.']

question: How can I authorise specific person(s) to access my CPF account information when I pass away?
answer:
['You can designate authorised person(s) by completing the section √¢¬Ä¬úDisclosure of CPF information√¢¬Ä¬ù in the [nomination form](https://cpf.gov.sg/makecpfnom), when you are making a nomination.
If you already have an existing nomination, you will need to make a new nomination to add in the authorised person(s) whom you would like to give access to your CPF account information after you pass away.']

question: Is there a limit to the number of authorised person(s) I can appoint?
answer:
['For online nominations, you can specify
* any or all of your nominees, and
* up to five persons who are not your nominee(s)
as your authorised person(s).']

question: What information will be disclosed to the authorised person(s) when I pass away?
Will the Board disclose my CPF account information and nomination details to the authorised person(s) while I√¢¬Ä¬ôm still alive?
answer: ['No, the information will only be disclosed after you pass away, and only when requested by any of your authorised person(s).']

question: I am an authorised person. How can I request to view a deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF account and nomination details?
answer: ['You can [contact us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) to submit your request to obtain a deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF account and nomination details.']

question: What happens to my CPF nomination if I lose mental capacity after making my nomination?
answer: ['Your CPF nomination will not be affected and remains valid even after you lose mental capacity.']

question: Can I appoint someone to make or revoke my CPF nomination on my behalf before I lose mental capacity?
answer: ['No. Only the Court is allowed to make or revoke a CPF nomination on behalf of the member, under Section 4 of the Mental Capacity Act 2008.']

question: What is the Special Needs Savings Scheme?
answer:
['The Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) allows parents of children with special needs to nominate their child to receive a regular stream of fixed payouts from their CPF savings in the event of the parent√¢¬Ä¬ôs demise.
CPF members interested to nominate their children under SNSS can approach the [Special Needs Trust Company](https://www.sntc.org.sg/services/special-needs-savings-scheme-(snss)) for more information.']

question: How is Special Needs Savings Scheme different from CPF nomination?
answer:
['Unlike a CPF nomination, where the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings are distributed in one lump sum, CPF savings under Special Needs Savings Scheme will be distributed to the nominee on a monthly basis, based on the amount specified by the CPF member, until the bequeathed savings run out.
This enables parents to set aside CPF savings for the long term care of children with special needs.']

question: Can I nominate part of my CPF balances under the Special Needs Savings Scheme, while nominating the rest under the CPF cash nomination?
answer: ['Yes. You can decide the percentage of your CPF balances to be nominated under the Special Needs Savings Scheme, and the remaining CPF savings to be nominated under the cash nomination rules for other beneficiaries.']

question: What interest rates will be paid on the monies for Special Needs Savings Scheme nominees?
answer:
['The nominated monies will continue to earn the same CPF interest, including extra interest, in the SNSS nominee√¢¬Ä¬ôs account, as the rate earned by CPF members.
Extra interest is paid on the first $60,000 of the combined balance of the parent(s) who nominated the child under SNSS and the child√¢¬Ä¬ôs own CPF savings, with up to $20,000 from the child√¢¬Ä¬ôs Ordinary Account.
Please refer to CPF interest rates for more information on the CPF interest rates.']

question: Who should I contact if I want to know more information on the Special Savings Needs Scheme?
answer:
['You may contact the Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC) who is the appointed scheme administrator.
Parents can visit SNTC√¢¬Ä¬ôs [SNSS website](https://www.sntc.org.sg/services/special-needs-savings-scheme-(snss)). Alternatively, SNTC can be contacted via phone at 6278 9598 or via email at [enquiries@sntc.org.sg](mailto:enquiries@sntc.org.sg) for more information.']

question: I received an SMS message from CPF Board that I checked my nomination details when I did not do so.
answer:
['If you received this SMS when you did not check your nomination details, it could be possible that
1. the previous owner of your mobile number had forgotten to update his/her latest mobile number with the Board;
2. you had given consent to your loved ones to register the same mobile number with the Board.
For (1), you can [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if you wish to remove the contact details of the other party from your rightful contact details.
For (2), you can directly ask the other member to update his/ her contact detail via my cpf digital services - [Account settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings) with their Singpass.']

question: How can I check the authorised person(s) appointed in my CPF nomination?
answer: ['You can view the authorised person(s) you previously appointed in your CPF nomination at [cpf.gov.sg/viewNOMDetails](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/viewNOMDetails) with your Singpass. If you require more help in checking your CPF nomination, find out more [here](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/how-can-i-check-my-cpf-nomination-details).']

question: How should I notify the CPF Board of my overseas marriage in relation to my CPF nomination?
answer:
['You can notify us by completing the form[Notification of Marriage in relation to CPF Nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/NOMmarriage). We may require generally up to five working days from the submission of the completed form (including all supporting documents) to act on the marriage notification. If you have a CPF nomination made before this marriage, your nomination will be revoked.
You are strongly encouraged to make a new√¢¬Ä¬Ø[CPF nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/makeCPFnom)√¢¬Ä¬Øafter your marriage if you want your CPF savings to be distributed according to your wishes.']

question: How long will CPF Board take to process my online nomination?
answer: ['If you submit your nomination online, the Board will process it generally within four working days from the date that both your witnesses complete the witnessing of your nomination. You can [check the status of your online nomination](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/esvc/web/services/myactivity/myactivity) under √¢¬Ä¬úMy Activities√¢¬Ä¬ù by logging in to *my cpf* Online Services using your Singpass.']

question: Do I need to indicate the address of my nominees, if they do not live in Singapore?
answer: ['Mailing address is required for foreigners to facilitate us in contacting them when distributing your CPF savings. Mailing address for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will be based on the address registered with Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA).']

question: What information relating to my witnesses do I need to provide when I make a nomination online?
answer:
['You will need to provide the following information of your witnesses when making an online nomination:
1. NRIC
2. Full Name\* as per NRIC
3. Email and/or Singapore registered mobile number (for receiving of SMS notification to perform witnessing)
\*It is important to provide your witnesses' full name as indicated on his NRIC, including comma, hyphen and space accordingly. However, you should exclude the Hanyu Pinyin, Alias and married name. See√Ç¬†[examples of NRIC names](/content/dam/web/member/faq/account-services/images/examples-of-nric-names.png).']

question: Can I make a new nomination instead of notifying CPF Board of my marriage?
answer: ['You can make a√Ç¬†[new nomination](https://cpf.gov.sg/makeCPFnom)√Ç¬†if you do not wish to notify us of your marriage. The new nomination will supersede your previous nomination (if any).']

question: What is the sequence of disbursement for Special Needs Saving Scheme√¢¬Ä¬ôs monthly payout from CPF account? (i.e. which of the deceased√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF account will be disbursed first?)
answer: ['The CPF savings nominated under Special Needs Savings Scheme will be paid via monthly payouts, starting from the lowest interest earning account, i.e. the Nominee Ordinary Account (NOA) first before moving to Nominee Special Account (NSA) and then Nominee Retirement Account (NRA).']

question: How fast can a Special Needs Savings Scheme (SNSS) nominee receive the fund into their bank account after the death of member?
answer: ['For Special Needs Savings Scheme cases, the payment will commence in the following month upon receipt of the completed application form and supporting documents. The payment is generally processed on the 12th of every month until the monies due to the nominee are exhausted.']

question: If I have not made a CPF nomination at the point of my passing, what will be distributed to my family under intestacy laws?
answer: ['If you have not made a CPF nomination at the point of your passing, we will pay the savings in your Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts to the [Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution to your family member(s) in accordance with the intestacy laws or inheritance certificate (for Muslims) in Singapore.']

question: Can my nominee be below 18 years old?
answer:
['Yes, your nominee can be of any age.
If your nominee is below 18 years old at the time of claim, his share will be transferred to the Public Trustee's Office and held-in-trust until he reaches 18 years of age.']

question: If my nominee passed away, what do I need to do next?
answer:
['If your nominee(s) passes on before you, his/her share will be given to surviving nominee(s) in the same proportion you have specified.
If there are no surviving nominee(s), your nomination is considered revoked, and your savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office for distribution under the intestacy or Muslim Inheritance laws.
We encourage CPF members to review their nominations whenever there are changes to their circumstances, such as death of nominee, and make a new CPF nomination if necessary. This will allow them to reallocate the shares to surviving nominee(s) based on their wishes, or even include new nominees.']

question: What happens to a member's CPF savings when he passes away?
answer:
['How a deceased member's CPF savings will be distributed depends on whether he had made a valid [CPF nomination](/member/account-services/providing-for-your-loved-ones/making-a-cpf-nomination) before his passing. See [what is covered under CPF nomination](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/what-are-the-cpf-monies-and-assets-of-a-deceased-member-covered).
Deceased member had made a valid CPF nomination
The deceased member's remaining CPF savings will be distributed in cash to his nominee(s) according to his CPF nomination. CPF Board will generally take less than five weeks to pay a deceased member's CPF savings to his nominee(s).
Members can also grant authorised person(s) access to their CPF account information upon their death when making their CPF nomination. [Find out more](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/why-should-i-authorise-specific-persons-to-access-my-cpf-account).
Deceased member had not made a valid CPF nomination
The deceased member's remaining CPF savings will be forwarded to the [Public Trustee's Office (PTO)](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution according to [intestacy](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/files/intestacybrochure.pdf) or [Muslim Inheritance laws](https://www.muis.gov.sg/officeofthemufti/Resources/).
Under this process, beneficiaries will need to provide documentation to prove their relationship with the deceased member. As time and effort is required to identify and verify the eligible beneficiaries, the entire process may take up to six months, and will incur an administrative fee. PTO will deduct this fee from the deceased member's CPF savings, which means beneficiaries will receive a lesser amount of CPF savings.
[Make a CPF nomination](/member/faq/account-services/cpf-nomination-scheme/how-can-i-make-a-cpf-nomination) so that your CPF savings are swiftly distributed to your loved ones when you are no longer around.']

question: What are the CPF monies and assets of a deceased member covered under a CPF nomination?
answer:
['The table below shows which of a deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF monies and assets are covered/not covered under a CPF nomination:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Covered under CPF nomination** | **Not covered under CPF nomination** |
| i. CPF savings in Ordinary, Special, MediSave and Retirement Accountsii. CPF LIFE premium balance, if anyiii. Discounted Singtel shares | i. Properties bought using CPF savingsii. Payouts from Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Schemeiii. Investments under CPF Investment Scheme |
For more information, you can refer to the [Losing a Loved One (PDF, 1.4MB) brochure](/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/PamphletLosingaLovedOne1.pdf).']

question: Will the nominee(s) be notified to claim the deceased member's CPF savings?
answer:
['We will contact the nominee(s) generally within 10 working days from the day we are notified of the member's passing, to provide them with details on the withdrawal process.
In some rare cases, there may be ongoing investigations related to a member√¢¬Ä¬ôs nomination and the Board would require additional time. Interested parties can contact the Board at [cpf.gov.sg/writetous](http://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) to find out the status of the case.']

question: How will the deceased member's CPF monies and assets be distributed if he was a bankrupt?
answer:
['The treatment of a deceased bankrupt member's CPF monies and assets depends on whether there is a valid nomination:
Deceased member had made a valid nomination
The deceased member's remaining CPF savings will be distributed in cash to his nominee(s).
Deceased member had not made a valid nomination
The deceased member's remaining CPF savings will be forwarded to the [Public Trustee's Office (PTO)](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution according to [intestacy](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/files/intestacybrochure.pdf) or [Muslim Inheritance laws](https://www.muis.gov.sg/officeofthemufti/Resources/).
The deceased member's discounted Singtel shares are due to his estate and the Official Assignee may lay claims on the shares.']

question: Will the deceased member's CPF savings continue to earn interest after his death?
answer: ['Unclaimed CPF savings will continue to earn [base interest](/member/growing-your-savings/earning-higher-returns/earning-attractive-interest) in the respective accounts for up to 6 months. The CPF savings will not earn [extra interest](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/cpf-interest-rates/how-much-extra-interest-can-i-earn-on-my-cpf-savings) once we are notified of the member's death. Nominee(s) continue to have the right to claim the nominated savings at any time.']

question: What happens to a deceased member's discounted Singtel shares?
answer:
['The treatment of the deceased member's discounted Singtel shares depends on whether he had made a valid nomination before his passing.
Deceased member had made a valid nomination
If the deceased member had made a valid nomination, his discounted Singtel shares will be distributed to his nominee(s) in the proportion he had indicated in his CPF nomination form. The nominee can either [instruct the Board to sell the shares or transfer the shares to his Central Depository (Pte) Ltd securities account](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/can-the-nominee-instruct-the-board-when-to-sell-the-discounted-s).
The dividends and proceeds stop earning CPF interest upon the member's passing, as they are not CPF monies but assets held on behalf of the beneficiaries.
Deceased member had not made a valid nomination, or passed away before 1 January 1996
If the deceased member had not made a valid nomination, or had passed away before 1 January 1996, his discounted Singtel shares will form part of his estate. The dividends and proceeds stop earning CPF interest upon the member's passing, as they are not CPF monies but assets held on behalf of beneficiaries as part of the deceased member's estate. Find out [how you can claim the deceased member's discounted Singtel shares](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/how-can-i-claim-the-deceased-members-discounted-singtel-shares).']

question: Can the nominee instruct the Board when to sell the discounted Singtel shares and at a certain price?
answer:
['The nominee should ask for the discounted Singtel shares to be transferred to his Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (CDP) account if he wishes to sell the shares at a certain price.
From April 2022, if the nominee wishes for the shares to be transferred to his CDP account, he will need to instruct us within six weeks from the notification of the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs death. If we do not receive any instructions from the nominee within six weeks, we will sell the shares. The sale proceeds will be disbursed to the nominee, together with other nominated CPF monies, in cash. Find out what are the [conditions under which we would sell the deceased member's discounted Singtel shares](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/will-the-board-sell-the-discounted-singtel-shares-due-to-the).']

question: Will the Board sell the discounted Singtel shares due to the nominee?
What happens to the deceased member's CPF LIFE premium?
answer: ['The deceased member's [CPF LIFE premium balance](/member/faq/retirement-income/monthly-payouts/how-much-cpf-life-premium-balance-will-my-beneficiaries-receive-) (if applicable) will be paid to his nominee(s) together with his CPF savings.']

question: Can the deceased member's MediSave be used to pay his final hospitalisation bill?
answer:
['Yes, the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs entire MediSave can be used to pay the last hospital bill if he had signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF), which authorises the use of the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave to pay the hospitalisation bill, before his passing.
Any remaining MediSave after the payment of the last medical bill will be distributed to the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs nominee(s) if he had a valid nomination. This is provided that the MediSave deduction is completed before the distribution of the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF balances.
What if the deceased member had not signed the Medical Claims Authorisation Form (MCAF)?
The deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs spouse, parents, child (if age 21 or older), or donee/deputy can sign the form at the hospital. You are encouraged to do this as soon as possible as hospitals have to submit the MediSave claim **before** the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave is distributed (typically within two weeks of the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs passing). If the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave has been distributed, you will not be able to use his MediSave for the last hospital bill.
If there is no immediate family or donee/deputy, a caregiver who has been taking care of the deceased member during his lifetime may write to the Ministry of Health through the hospital to seek approval for the use of the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave for the last hospital bill.']

question: Will the deceased member's CPF savings be used to pay his income tax liabilities?
answer: ['No, the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings will not be used to pay his income tax liabilities. This is because CPF savings do not form part of the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs estate.']

question: What happens to the deceased member's investments bought using his CPF savings?
answer:
['CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) investments are not covered under CPF nomination. When a member passes away, his CPFIS investments\* and any cash balance in his Investment Account will form part of his estate.√Ç¬†Doing so allows beneficiaries of the estate to decide how best to manage these assets, including the preferred timing for the sale of assets such as unit trusts and stocks. These decisions should be made by the beneficiaries as the decisions could affect the value of the CPFIS investments. CPF monies covered under CPF nomination can then be disbursed quickly without having to await the beneficiaries√¢¬Ä¬ô decision on the CPFIS investments.
The estate administrator/executor can contact the respective product providers or agent bank to claim the investments and cash balance. These investments, cash balance and death benefits may be used to settle the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs debts in accordance with the Probate and Administration Act.
\* Except for insurance policies where the member had√Ç¬†made an insurance nomination with the respective insurance company. The nominated beneficiaries can contact the insurance company to claim the death benefits.']

question: What happens to the deceased member's property bought using his CPF savings?
answer: ['The CPF savings used to buy the property need not be refunded to the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF account. The property will form part of his estate if it is held in tenancy-in-common or passed on to the remaining surviving owner(s) if it is held in joint tenancy.']

question: What happens to the deceased member's CPF savings used for CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['If the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings had been used under the CPF Education Loan Scheme for himself or someone else, the withdrawn monies, including accrued interest, do not have to be refunded to his account.']

question: Do I need to inform CPF Board when my family member passes away?
answer:
['If the deceased person was a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, there is no need to inform CPF Board of the death.
If the deceased person was a foreigner with a CPF account, you will have to [inform CPF Board of his death](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/how-do-i-report-the-death-of-a-foreigner-who-was-a-cpf-member).']

question: How do I report the death of a foreigner who was a CPF member?
answer:
['You can report the death of a foreigner who was a CPF member by post or by [making an appointment to visit our CPF Service Centre](https://cpf.gov.sg/appt), with the following documents:
i. The deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs original death certificate and current passport duly cancelled due to his passing, or a copy certified by an official from a [Singapore Overseas Mission](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/what-is-a-singapore-overseas-mission-) with their official seal/stamp
ii. A letter from the relevant authority confirming the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs identity number, if the death certificate does not show it
iii. Evidence of your relationship with the deceased member
iv. Your identity card or passport, and contact details']

question: How do I apply to withdraw the deceased member's CPF savings?
answer:
['You will be notified if you are one of the nominees to receive the deceased member's CPF savings generally within 10 working days after the Board is informed of the member's death.√Ç¬†To apply for withdrawal of the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings, please choose the option that is applicable to you:
I have not received any payment for the deceased member's CPF savings.
As an appointed nominee, you can apply to receive the deceased member's CPF savings by submitting the online form [√¢¬Ä¬úApplication to Withdraw Deceased Member's CPF√¢¬Ä¬ù](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/withdrawal-savings-member-who-passed-away).
I have received payment before, but I was notified of new balances in the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings since the last payment to me.
You can apply to receive the balance by submitting the online form [√¢¬Ä¬úChange payment details (for withdrawal of deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings)√¢¬Ä¬ù](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/DeathPayment).']

question: How can I claim the deceased member's discounted Singtel shares if he had not made a nomination or if he passed away before 1 January 1996?
answer:
['If the deceased member had not made a nomination or if he passed away before 1 January 1996, we will transfer the discounted Singtel shares to his securities account or the estate securities account opened by his appointed executor(s) or administrator(s). If there is no securities account or estate securities account, the appointed executor(s) or administrator(s) may instruct the Board to sell the Singtel shares.
If no executor/administrator\* is appointed for the estate of the deceased member, a representative of the deceased member's family or a [proper claimant](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/who-is-a-proper-claimant-and-when-can-they-claim-monies) may instruct CPF Board to sell the shares and claim the sales proceeds or any dividends in cash. The following documents have to be submitted:
1. Indemnity Agreement with declaration that the deceased member has no will, and no Grant of Probate or Letter of Administration has been issued for his estate
2. Letter of Consent from all immediate family members\*\* of the deceased member
3. Proof of relationship to the deceased member, e.g. marriage certificate, birth certificate
[Read more on the documents required](/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/NNwithSDS.pdf).
\*For small estates (below $50,000), the deceased member's family has the option of approaching the Public Trustee to administer the shares together with the estate of the deceased member.
\*\*For Muslim members, all beneficiaries under the Islamic inheritance laws would have to complete the Letter of Consent.']

question: How will the deceased member's CPF savings be paid to me?
answer: ['Your share of the deceased member's CPF savings will be paid to you via Inter-bank GIRO.']

question: When will the deceased member's CPF savings be paid to me?
answer:
['The service standards for processing of a deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings are shown in the table below:
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs nomination status** | **Service** | **Normal processing time** |
| With nomination | Distribution of deceased member's CPF savings to nominee(s) | 15 working days\* |
| Without nomination | Transfer of CPF savings by the Board to the Public Trustee | 15 working days\*\* |
\* Generally, an additional seven working days is required if the deceased member had held discounted Singtel shares. Processing time also excludes two working days required for transmission of funds.
\*\* From the date the Board is notified of member√¢¬Ä¬ôs death.']

question: I have applied to withdraw the deceased member's CPF savings. Can I change my payment details?
answer:
['You can change your payment details for your application to withdraw the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings by submitting the form applicable to you:
I am a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident
Please complete the√Ç¬†online form [√¢¬Ä¬úChange payment details (for withdrawal of deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings)√¢¬Ä¬ù (Form NAC/SUPP/L)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/DeathPayment).
I am not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident
Please complete the form [√¢¬Ä¬úChange payment details (for withdrawal of deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings or account closure)√¢¬Ä¬ù (Form NAC/SUPP/F) (PDF,0.3MB)](/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/FORM%20NAC_SUPP_F.pdf) and mail it back to us.']

question: Is there a deadline for me to claim the deceased member's CPF savings?
answer: ['You are encouraged to claim the deceased member's CPF savings as early as possible. You can do so anytime by submitting an√Ç¬†[online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/withdrawal-savings-member-who-passed-away).']

question: I am an appointed nominee. How will the deceased member's CPF savings be paid to me if I am bankrupt?
answer:
['If you are an undischarged bankrupt at the time you become entitled to receive the nominated monies, we are legally obliged to inform the Official Assignee ("OA") and transfer the nominated monies to the OA upon their instruction. This is by virtue of the laws in Singapore relating to bankruptcy, which vest the property of a bankrupt in the OA upon the making of a bankruptcy order.
If the deceased member held any discounted Singtel shares, they would be sold upon the OA√¢¬Ä¬ôs instruction.']

question: What happens to the CPF savings if the nominee passed away before he could receive the CPF savings of the deceased member?
answer:
['The CPF savings would form part of the deceased nominee's estate and would be paid to the Executor/Administrator appointed under the Grant of Probate (GP)/Letters of Administration (LA).
If there is no Executor/Administrator appointed, the CPF savings may be paid to a [proper claimant](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/who-is-a-proper-claimant-and-when-can-they-claim-monies) if the sum does not exceed $50,000.']

question: Who is a proper claimant and when can they claim monies due to the deceased member/nominee's estate?
answer:
['A proper claimant is a beneficiary, usually a family member, of the deceased member/nominee. The proper claimant can claim monies due to the deceased member/nominee's estate via an application process in the scenarios as stated below, where individual items do not exceed $50,000:
1. Dividends, sale proceeds and other monies in respect of discounted Singtel shares belonging to a [deceased member who passed away before 1 January 1996 or did not make a nomination](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/what-happens-to-a-deceased-members-discounted-singtel-shares), and who does not have any personal representatives; or
2. Nominated CPF savings that would have been paid to the deceased nominee who had passed away before he could receive it.
For more details, please [write to us](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous).']

question: How will the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings be distributed to a nominee who is certified to lack mental capacity permanently?
answer: ['The deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings would be paid to a Donee or Deputy appointed to act on the nominee's behalf under the Mental Capacity Act.']

question: How do I claim the CPF savings of a family member who has been missing for many years?
answer:
['You will first need to obtain a presumption of death certificate, which declares the person as presumed to be dead, from the Court. This is in line with industry practice where a person is treated as alive until the person has been officially reported as deceased. For any financial assistance in obtaining the presumption of death certification from the Court, you can contact the [Legal Aid Bureau](https://lab.mlaw.gov.sg/).
If the missing person is a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident
After having obtained the presumption of death certificate, the missing person should be reported as deceased with the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA).
Once this is done, his CPF savings will be distributed to his appointed nominee(s) if he has a valid nomination. Otherwise, his CPF savings will be forwarded to the [Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution according to [intestacy](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/files/intestacybrochure.pdf) or [Muslim Inheritance laws](https://www.muis.gov.sg/officeofthemufti/Resources/).
If the missing person is a foreigner who holds a CPF account
If the missing person is a foreigner who holds a CPF account, the following documents have to be submitted at any of our CPF Service Centres:
i. the original presumption of death certificate;
ii. the missing person√¢¬Ä¬ôs original passport (if any);
iii. an original letter from the relevant authority confirming the missing person√¢¬Ä¬ôs identity number (if the presumption of death certificate does not bear the missing person√¢¬Ä¬ôs identification details);
iv. documentary evidence of your relationship with the missing person; and
v. your original identity card/passport and contact details.
If the death reporting is submitted via post from outside of Singapore, all the documents mentioned above have to be certified true by an official from a [Singapore Overseas Mission](/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/what-is-a-singapore-overseas-mission-)√Ç¬†with their official seal/stamp duly affixed.
Once the missing person is officially reported as deceased, his CPF savings will be distributed to his appointed nominee(s) if he has a valid nomination. Otherwise, his CPF savings will be forwarded to the [Public Trustee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Office](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/) for distribution according to [intestacy](https://pto.mlaw.gov.sg/files/intestacybrochure.pdf) or [Muslim Inheritance laws](https://www.muis.gov.sg/officeofthemufti/Resources/).']

question: What is a Singapore Overseas Mission?
answer:
['Singapore Overseas Missions located in certain countries can help CPF members residing overseas in witnessing and certification of applications and documents.
You will need to visit the Singapore Overseas Mission in person. Find out where is the [overseas mission nearest to you](https://www.mfa.gov.sg/Overseas-Missions/Find-A-Singapore-Overseas-Mission).']

question: Why am I not allowed to use my bank account with a non-local bank to receive the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings?
answer: ['To better protect you from scams, we will only accept bank accounts where the bank is able to provide automated bank account verification to CPFB. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to you. Currently, only POSB, DBS, OCBC and UOB are able to provide this service. We welcome any other bank to set up similar arrangements with us.']

question: What is the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is a term-life insurance scheme which provides insured members and/or their families with some money to get through the first few years should the insured members meet an untimely death, suffer from terminal Illness or total permanent disability.
DPS covers insured members up to 65 years old. Members up to 60 years old will be covered for a maximum sum assured of $70,000. For members above age 60 and up to age 65, DPS covers them up to a maximum sum assured of $55,000.
DPS is currently solely administered by Great Eastern Life.']

question: Am I covered under the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer: ['You can check the status of your Dependants' Protection Scheme coverage via: - your yearly CPF Statement of Account - the "[Providing for your loved ones](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/providing-for-your-loved-ones)" dashboard by logging in with your Singpass If you do not have a Singpass, you can apply for one at the [Singpass website](http://www.singpass.gov.sg/).']

question: What is the purpose of the Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer: ['CPF members who are working and earning an income may have dependants who are reliant on their income. If such CPF members suddenly meet with an accident or contract a terminal illness that results in the loss of their income, the dependants who are reliant on them may be left in the lurch. The impact is greater when the member has not yet accumulated enough CPF or other savings which could be bequeathed to their dependants to tide them over the first few years of their untimely demise. Therefore, Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is useful to such working CPF members. This is also the reason why DPS coverage is automatically extended to members upon their first CPF contribution between age 21 and 65']

question: Who will be covered under Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer:
['All Singaporeans and Permanent Residents between age 16 and 65 can be covered under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS).
DPS coverage is automatically extended to Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents upon a valid CPF working contribution between 21 and 65 years old.
Members aged 16 and above who were not extended a DPS cover automatically but wish to be insured can apply to join DPS with Great Eastern Life directly.']

question: Is Dependants' Protection Scheme compulsory?
answer:
['Coverage under the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is not compulsory. Insured members can contact their existing insurer, Great Eastern Life or NTUC Income, to terminate their DPS cover any time by completing the opt out form.
Member should consider the benefits of DPS carefully before he/she terminates his/her DPS cover. Continuing with the DPS cover will provide some financial protection for the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs family. If member decides to rejoin DPS in the future, he/she will need to submit a health declaration again and the cover will be provided subject to him/her being in good health then.']

question: Who do I contact for enquiries on Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer:
['For enquiries relating to Dependants' Protection Scheme, you may contact Great Eastern Life:
Address : The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited 1 Pickering Street, #01-01 Great Eastern Centre Singapore 048659 Website : [Great Eastern Life](http://www.greateasternlife.com/DPS) E-mail : [dps-sg@greateasternlife.com](mailto:dps-sg@greateasternlife.com) Hotline : 68394565']

question: Do all CPF members need Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Not all CPF members need Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS). Members should consider whether there are persons who are reliant on their current income. Some examples of members who may not need DPS include:
* Those whose dependants have already grown up and become financially independent, e.g. children who reach adulthood and started working.
* Those who have already built up enough CPF or private savings, as such savings could be bequeathed to their dependants directly, to tide them over the first few years of expenses in the event of an untimely death.
* Those who already have their own private term or life insurance, which provides enough insurance protection and payout to tide dependants over the first few years of expenses in the event of an untimely death.
