Insurance premiums, including for DPS, become more expensive with age. Should members decide that they wish to opt out of DPS, they may do so by informing Great Eastern Life to terminate their DPS cover any time by completing the opt out form. Opting out of DPS will allow such members who may not need DPS to retain more of their CPF savings for their retirement income.']

question: I am a Singaporean or a Permanent Resident but I am not living in Singapore. What will happen to my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover?
answer: ['You will remain insured under the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) as long as premiums are paid. DPS coverage is worldwide and a claim can be made when a member meets the claim criteria.']

question: I am no longer a Singaporean or a Permanent Resident. What will happen to my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['The Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) is only extended to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.
If you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or a Permanent Resident, your DPS cover will be terminated and any unused premium will be refunded to you.']

question: Can I terminate my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover?
answer:
['Coverage under the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is not compulsory. You can terminate your DPS cover any time by completing the opt out form. Please approach your DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life for the form.
Please consider the benefits of DPS carefully before you terminate your DPS cover. Continuing with your DPS cover will provide some financial protection for your family. If you decide to join DPS again in the future, you will need to submit a health declaration again and the cover will be provided subject to you being in good health then.']

question: I do not have a Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) cover. Why do I need to declare my health to be covered under DPS?
answer:
['As with any life insurance, the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover may be declined or deferred if a member has serious pre-existing illnesses before policy commencement. This underwriting practice is necessary to ensure that the scheme remains viable and the premiums are kept affordable for all insured members.
The DPS insurer will not consider claims from a member who has serious pre-existing illnesses, or has given false or misleading statements or withheld relevant information in the health declaration.
Please refer to [Great Eastern Life](http://www.greateasternlife.com/DPS) for more information on the examples of serious pre-existing illnesses that will affect your eligibility to be covered.']

question: How do I apply to be insured under Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer: ['You may do so by submitting your Dependants' Protection Scheme application to [Great Eastern Life](http://www.greateasternlife.com/DPS)√Ç¬†directly.']

question: My Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) cover was issued by NTUC Income. Will Great Eastern Life take over all obligations when my cover is transferred? What if I have developed medical conditions on or after the commencement of my cover under NTUC Income?
answer: ['Great Eastern Life is required to take over all obligations of Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) covers issued under NTUC Income. This means that Great Eastern Life will continue to cover any medical conditions that had developed on or after the commencement of members√¢¬Ä¬ô DPS covers under NTUC Income.']

question: How much premium do I need to pay to be covered under Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS)?
answer:
['The premium payable yearly will be based on the age you have reached, at the point of payment.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Age (as of payment date)** | **Yearly Premium for $70,000 sum assured** |
| 34 years and below | $18 |
| 35 √¢¬Ä¬ì 39 years | $30 |
| 40 √¢¬Ä¬ì 44 years | $50 |
| 45 √¢¬Ä¬ì 49 years | $93 |
| 50 √¢¬Ä¬ì 54 years | $188 |
| 55 √¢¬Ä¬ì 59 years | $298 |
| 60 - 64 years | $298 (for sum assured of $55,000) |
^Premiums are payable on member√¢¬Ä¬ôs DPS policy commencement date and on subsequent yearly policy renewal dates.']

question: How do I pay my Dependants' Protection Scheme premiums?
answer:
['Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) premium will be automatically deducted from your CPF savings on your annual policy renewal date.
If you do not have sufficient funds in your CPF savings to pay the annual premium, you can either make a cash top-up directly to the appointed DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life (GEL), or be insured for a lower amount (the minimum coverage is $5,000).
Alternatively, you can pay your DPS premiums directly in cash (via GIRO) to the DPS insurer GEL. Visit [GEL√¢¬Ä¬ôs website](http://www.greateasternlife.com/DPS) for more information.']

question: Can I get any money back after my Dependants' Protection Scheme cover ends when I reach the age limit?
answer:
['Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is a term-life insurance scheme which does not include any saving or investment component. Hence, there is no cash back when the member's DPS cover expires at age 65.
This is because DPS is designed to provide members with the maximum financial protection at the lowest possible premium.']

question: What is the Dependants' Protection Scheme claim criteria?
answer:
['A Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) claim can be made when a member passes away or is certified to be suffering from terminal illness or total permanent disability.
For more information on DPS claim criteria, please refer to√Ç¬†[Great Eastern Life](http://www.greateasternlife.com/DPS).']

question: What are the claim exclusions for Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer:
['Claim benefits under Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) will not be payable if any of the following events occur within the first policy year of the cover:
* member committed self-inflicted injury or suicide,
* member committed a criminal offence punishable by death, or
* the claim arose out of member's own intentional criminal act.
DPS benefits are also not payable if:
* member was not in good health before the commencement of DPS cover,
* member provided false or misleading information, or
* the claim arose from wars or any warlike operations or participation in any riot']

question: I have not made a nomination before. How do I make a nomination for my Dependants' Protection Scheme?
answer:
['If you are at least 18 years old and wish to have the death claim benefits paid to specific person/organization i.e. beneficiary(s), you are advised to make a nomination by submitting the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) nomination form (available on Great Eastern Life√¢¬Ä¬ôs website) to the insurer.√Ç¬†Should you wish to amend your nomination thereafter, you can do so by submitting a new nomination.
**Reminder:**
DPS claim benefits do not form part of CPF proceeds and will not be distributed based on your CPF Nomination.']

question: How do I check if I have made a Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) nomination?
answer:
['To check your Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) nomination, please contact your DPS insurer directly.
**Reminder:** DPS claim benefits do not form part of CPF proceeds and will not be distributed based on your CPF Nomination. From 1 April 2021, DPS will be solely administered by Great Eastern Life. If you had previously made a nomination under NTUC Income, you are to make a new DPS nomination.']

question: My Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is covered by NTUC Income prior to 1 April 2021. When my DPS cover is transferred over to Great Eastern Life from 1 April 2021, do I need to declare my health?
answer: ['No, members who are already insured under Dependants' Protection Scheme√Ç¬†(DPS) prior to 1 April 2021 do not need to submit a new health declaration form for illnesses that developed on or after the commencement of their DPS covers under NTUC Income. Great Eastern Life is required to take over all obligations of DPS covers issued under NTUC Income. This means that Great Eastern Life will continue to cover any medical conditions that had developed on or after the commencement of members√¢¬Ä¬ô DPS covers under NTUC Income.']

question: How do I claim the Dependants' Protection Scheme benefits?
answer:
['A member can make a claim by directly submitting an application to Great Eastern Life .
**Note:** For members previously insured under NTUC Income, if the claim event date is before 1 April 2021, they can submit their claim application to NTUC Income directly.']

question: I have already made a nomination for Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme prior to 1 April 2021. Do I need to make a new nomination after 1 April 2021?
answer:
['From 1 April 2021, Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) is solely administered by Great Eastern Life.
If your DPS policy was under NTUC Income, it has been automatically transferred to Great Eastern Life. As the DPS policies with NTUC Income has ceased after 31 March 2021, nominations of DPS policies previously made under NTUC Income is no longer valid. As such, if you had previously made a nomination under NTUC Income, under the Insurance Act, you will be required to make a new nomination. Your new insurer, Great Eastern Life, would have sent out the nomination forms to you.
If your DPS policy is under Great Eastern Life and you had made a nomination previously, there is no need for you to submit a new nomination, unless you wish to nominate new beneficiaries.
Please note that DPS claim benefits do not form part of CPF savings and will not be distributed based on your CPF Nomination.']

question: I was issued a bonus sum assured in 2003 and/or 2005. Will it be carried over to my Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme policy under the newly enhanced scheme?
answer:
['CPF Board distributed surpluses in the form of bonus sum assured to the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) members insured before DPS was privatised in 2005. Members can contact their DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life to check if they qualified for the bonus sum assured previously.
To standardise the sum assured for all insured members to the new amount of $70,000 from 1 April 2021 under the newly enhanced DPS, existing members who were eligible for the bonus sum assured will receive a one-time premium rebate in lieu of the bonus sum assured. The one-time rebate has been credited into members√¢¬Ä¬ô CPF Ordinary Accounts in May 2021.']

question: How will the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme claim benefits be distributed?
answer:
['For claims under medical grounds, the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) benefits will be paid out to the insured member directly.
For death claims, if the insured member has made a DPS nomination, or has a will which is made known to the DPS insurer, the beneficiary(s) according to the nomination or will (whichever takes effect at the later date) will receive the benefits.
If no nomination or will is made, the benefits will be paid to proper claimant(s). A proper claimant can be the executor of the deceased's estate or family member, e.g. spouse, parent, child, or sibling.
For more details, please approach the appointed DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life.']

question: My family member has passed on and was covered under the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme. As the next-of-kin, how do I claim the DPS benefits?
answer:
['Once the Board is notified of the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs death by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority, we will inform the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme insurer, Great Eastern Life, who will then send claim application details to the assigned nominee(s). However, if no nomination was made, the claim application details would be sent to the deceased member√¢¬Ä¬ôs correspondence address instead.
You can also make a claim by directly submitting an application to Great Eastern Life.
**Note**: For members previously insured under NTUC Income, if the claim event date is before 1 April 2021, they can submit their claim application to NTUC Income directly.
NTUC Income can be contacted at: Email: healthcare@income.com.sg Phone: 6332 1133 Website for claim submission: <https://www.income.com.sg/claims/life-insurance>']

question: How do I inform CPF Board of a change in my address?
answer:
['By default, CPF letters are sent to your residential address on your Singapore Identity Card. If you are residing at a new address and have been receiving your CPF letters at your old residential address, please apply for the change of your residential address (local or overseas) via Immigration & Checkpoints Authority√¢¬Ä¬ôs (ICA) e-Services using your Singpass.
Participating government agencies and statutory boards (including CPF Board) will be informed of the change in address through the One-Stop Change of Address Reporting Service (OSCARS) within one day. You will not be receiving an additional acknowledgement from CPF Board for updates via OSCARS.
Please visit√Ç¬†[ICA website](https://www.ica.gov.sg/)√Ç¬†for more information.']

question: How can I inform CPF Board if I changed my name?
answer:
['We use the principal name registered in your NRIC to transact with you. Principal name usually excludes variants such as hanyu pinyin, married name and other aliases.
If you have updated your principal name registered in your NRIC recently, you do not need to inform us separately. Your name will automatically be updated in our records.
If you have not updated the name registered in your NRIC or would like to transact with us using your hanyu pinyin, married or other aliases, you will need to update your principal name in your NRIC first.']

question: When and how should I inform CPF Board about changes to my particulars?
answer: ['For Singapore Citizens/Permanent Residents, you do not need to inform us separately as your latest particulars will automatically be updated in our records.']

question: How long does it take to update my particulars?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for the service standards in updating your particulars.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | Normal Processing Time |
| **Update of Personal Particulars for Singapore Citizens/Permanent Residents** | 3 working days |
| **Merging of CPF accounts** | 7 working days |']

question: Do I need to inform CPF Board of my new Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency?
answer:
['You do not need to inform us of your latest particulars when you become a new Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. Your Singapore identity card number will be used as your CPF account number to transact with us.
If you are already holding an existing CPF account (example: SA123456D or TC987654B), you would need to inform us so that we can combine your CPF accounts.
To facilitate your transaction with us, we will combine your CPF accounts within seven working days after we have successfully verified your identity.
I have:
Recently obtained Singapore Citizenship
Please submit the following documents/information to us where applicable.
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **If you are:** | **Documents / Information required** | **Additional document(s)** |
| **Ex-Malaysian** | 1. Both sides of your Singapore Identity Card
2. Both sides of your Singapore Citizenship Certificate
3. Change of name document (example : deed poll), if you have changed your name
4. Your email address and contact number (we will contact you if we require more information)
| NA |
| **Foreigner****(excluding ex-Malaysian)** | Your old passport page(s) showing your personal particulars and passport number registered with us earlier |
If you are submitting via the following modes:
Our mailing details are as follows:
Central Provident Fund Board
Accounts Information & Services Department
Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060
Singapore 905060
Please note that your documents must be certified true by an official from a Singapore Overseas Mission with his/her official seal/stamp duly affixed. You may wish to visit the [Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs website](https://www.mfa.gov.sg/) to locate the Singapore Overseas Mission nearest to you.
Please bring along your original documents and book an appointment to visit us at our [CPF Service Centres](/member/contact-us/visit-us).
Recently obtained Permanent Residency
Please submit the following documents/information to us where applicable.
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **If you are:** | **Documents / Information required** | **Additional document(s)** |
| **Malaysian** | 1. Both sides of your Singapore Identity Card
2. Your√Ç¬†current passport page(s) showing your passport number, personal particulars and re-entry permit or Form 7 issued by Immigration and Checkpoint Authority
3. Change of name document (example : deed poll), if you have changed your name
4. Your email address and contact number (we will contact you if we require more information)
| Both sides of your Malaysia Identity Card |
| **Foreigner (excluding Malaysian)** | Your old passport page(s) showing your personal particulars and passport number registered with us earlier |
If you are submitting via the following modes:
Our mailing details are as follows:
Central Provident Fund Board
Accounts Information & Services Department
Robinson Road P.O. Box 3060
Singapore 905060
Please note that your documents must be certified true by an official from a Singapore Overseas Mission with his/her official seal/stamp duly affixed. You may wish to visit the [Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs website](https://www.mfa.gov.sg/) to locate the Singapore Overseas Mission nearest to you.
Please bring along your original documents and book an appointment to visit us at our [CPF Service Centres](/member/contact-us/visit-us).']

question: What is my CPF account number?
answer:
['If you are a:
Singapore Citizen / Permanent Resident
Your CPF account number is your NRIC number (e.g. S1234567F).
For Singapore Citizens, your CPF account number is your Singapore Birth Certificate number or Citizenship Certificate number (if you received Singapore Citizenship after birth) (e.g. T1234567F).
For Permanent Residents, your CPF account number is the Unique Identification Number (UIN) stated on your entry permit (e.g. T1234567F).
Foreigner
If you were previously a Singapore Citizen/Permanent Resident, your CPF account number would be your earlier NRIC number (e.g. S1234567F).
Otherwise, your CPF account number could begin with the letter 'S' or 'T', followed by the letter 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' or 'F' (e.g. SA123456D or TC987654B).']

question: When do I have a CPF account?
answer: ['Your CPF account is automatically created when a first top-up or CPF contribution is received.']

question: What should I do if I receive mails from CPF Board that do not belong to me and my family member(s) at our address?
answer: ['Please state the reason for return, e.g. 'no such person' or 'change of owner', and drop the mail into SingPost's "Return Mail Here" mailbox. The undelivered mail will be returned to us.']

question: How do I get a document that shows I do not have a CPF account?
answer:
['You can login to [*my cpf* digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/) via your Singpass. You will see a message "No information can be displayed here as you do not have a CPF account."
You can click on√Ç¬†![the PDF icon](/content/dam/web/member/faq/images/pdficon_pbs.png)√Ç¬†located above the graphic, to save or print a copy.']

question: How do I check my CPF account balances, contribution, transaction records, including records beyond 15 months?
answer:
['There are a few ways to check your details:
1. You can login to [*my cpf*√Ç¬†digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/) or [CPF Mobile](/member/tools-and-services/cpf-mobile-app) app via your Singpass to view your statement which shows your account balances, 15-months Contribution History and 15-months Transaction History. Please refer to this [guide](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/faq/general-information---useful-tips/documents/Guide_to_view_and_save_CPF_statements.pdf) (PDF, 0.28MB) on how to view and save your statement on your mobile device. You can also watch the [instructional video](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/infohub/educational-resources/how-to-access-your-cpf-statements-online) in your preferred language on how to access your CPF statements online. If you do not have a Singpass and/or 2FA, please visit the [Singpass website](https://www.singpass.gov.sg/) to obtain one.
2. You can call us at 1800-227-1188 (code 2) between 8.30am and 10pm to request the hardcopy statements to be sent to your address in our records. You will receive the statements within four working days.
For records beyond the last 15 months, you can refer to your last 10 years of Yearly Statement of Account online.']

question: How do I inform CPF Board if I have changed my contact details?
answer:
['You can instantly update your mobile number and/or email address via the [Account Settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings) page with your Singpass.
An SMS or email One-Time PIN (OTP) will be sent to your new mobile or email address for verification before the changes can take effect.']

question: Would other members receive my CPF notifications if they have registered the same contact detail(s) as me?
answer:
['Members will receive CPF notifications at their email address and/or mobile number registered with us.
Other members can receive your CPF notifications only if they share the same email address or mobile number as you.']

question: What should I do if I receive a notification that is not meant for me?
answer:
['This could happen because:
* You are sharing contact detail(s) with your next-of-kin for handling of CPF matters; or
* Your contact detail is a recycled mobile number/email address registered by another member with us previously; or
* You are using a common business mobile number/email address shared within a company.
If you did not intentionally share your contact details with another member or wish to stop this arrangement, please [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index) with a screenshot of the notification you have received.']

question: I have reviewed my contact detail(s) and am aware that it is also registered under another family member. Can we continue to share contact detail(s)?
answer:
['We understand that some CPF members require help from family members on their CPF matters, and could have registered the same contact information with us.
No further action is needed if your contact details are still valid.
Otherwise, you can update your new contact details via the [Account settings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/account-settings) page with your Singpass.']

question: What happens to my CPF account if I am no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident?
answer:
['Your CPF account will be closed and your CPF savings will be transferred to your bank account if you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, as the CPF system is intended to help Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents retire with peace of mind in Singapore. To transfer your CPF savings, please submit√Ç¬†the [account closure form](/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/how-do-i-apply-to-close-my-cpf-account-on-grounds-of-leaving).
If you are currently holding onto a pass or permit that enables employment or long term stay in Singapore, your CPF account can only be closed after the legislative changes are made by end of 2023. You may submit your account closure form from January 2024.']

question: Can I choose to transfer my CPF savings partially when my CPF account is closed?
answer: ['No, your CPF savings will be paid to you in full.']

question: What happens to my CPF LIFE plan when my CPF account is closed?
answer: ['Your CPF LIFE plan will be terminated and you will receive your CPF LIFE premium balance (if any) together with your CPF savings when your account is closed.']

question: What happens to my investments when my CPF account is closed?
answer:
['The treatment of your investments when your CPF account is closed will depend on the investment scheme you have participated in.
CPF Investment Scheme - Ordinary Account (CPFIS-OA)
We will inform the agent bank to close your CPF Investment Account. The agent bank will then contact you for the√Ç¬†withdrawal# of your investments and cash balance (if any). Your investments will be transferred to your own name and you may thereafter continue servicing your investments using cash or liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.
# Central Depository (Pte) Ltd (√¢¬Ä¬úCDP√¢¬Ä¬ù) imposes a transfer fee of√Ç¬†$10.00 (excluding GST) for every share counter transferred from your CPF Investment Account to your CDP Account.
CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account (CPFIS-SA)
We will inform your product provider(s) to transfer your investment to your own name. Thereafter, you may liquidate them as you wish and have the sale proceeds paid to you directly.
Once transferred, your CPFIS investments and cash balance in your CPF Investment Account will no longer be protected from any claims by your creditors and/or the Official Assignee.
Special Discounted Shares (SDS) scheme
Your discounted Singtel shares will be liquidated. The sale proceeds will be transferred to your bank account along with your CPF savings, after your CPF account is closed.']

question: What happens to the top-ups I had received in my Special or Retirement Account when I close my CPF account?
answer: ['Any remaining monies which you have received through CPF transfers and cash top-ups will be transferred to your bank account after your CPF account is closed. This is subject to√Ç¬†[safeguards to prevent premature withdrawals](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-does-cpf-board-guard-against-premeditated-early-cpf-withdrawals).']

question: Do I have to refund the sale proceeds when I sell my property after my CPF account is closed?
answer: ['No, you do not have to refund your property sale proceeds after your CPF account is closed.']

question: What happens to my CPF savings if I have unpaid taxes, MediShield Life premiums or CareShield Life premiums when my account is closed?
answer:
['If you have unpaid tax/MediShield Life premiums/CareShield Life premiums/Outstanding education loan owed to a CPF member,√Ç¬†we may recover the unpaid amount from your CPF savings before transferring the balance to your bank account.
You are encouraged to settle any outstanding liabilities (e.g. insurance, tax and housing liabilities) before your CPF account is closed.']

question: Do I need to refund the transferred CPF savings if I decide to obtain Singapore Citizenship or permanent residency again after I have closed my account?
answer: ['You will need to refund the amount transferred, including the interest you would have earned, if you are an ex-Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident returning to obtain Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.']

question: Will I be able to return to Singapore for work if I have closed my CPF account?
answer:
['For enquiries on work permit or employment pass application, please contact Ministry of Manpower at 6438 5122 or send your enquiries to them using the [online feedback service](https://service2.mom.gov.sg/efeedback/Forms/efeedback.aspx).
For enquiries on applying for permanent residency in Singapore, please contact the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority at 6391 6100 or [email them](mailto:ica_feedback@ica.gov.sg).']

question: I am not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. How do I close my CPF account and transfer my CPF savings to my bank account?
answer:
['**For Malaysian Citizens only**
You may complete the [online form](https://form.gov.sg/63573e845cfdb20012171772) for the Board to issue you a cheque for your CPF savings. The Board may request additional supporting documents to assess your eligibility to receive the CPF savings.
You will need your CPF Account Number if you are submitting the online form. If you do not have your CPF Account Number, please refer to the alternative modes under [√¢¬Ä¬úFor all other non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents√¢¬Ä¬ù](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/account-services/account-closure/closing-your-account-when-you-leave-singapore), as we are unable to disclose your CPF Account Number over the phone.
**If you have a Singpass or Singapore bank account**
Alternatively, you may close your CPF account via [My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/mymailbox) or [Write to Us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) if:
* You have a valid Singpass; or
* You do not have a valid Singpass but have a personal√Ç¬†POSB/DBS/OCBC/UOB bank account maintained under your Singapore NRIC number
Please click [here](/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/Alternative%20channels.pdf)√Ç¬†for more details.
**For all other non-SC/PR**
**If you are not in Singapore**
You may submit the [account closure form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/FORM%20CPF-CA.pdf) and the required [supporting documents](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/LMdocuments.pdf) by post. You are strongly encouraged to mail in your documents via registered mail.
Both the account closure form and all original supporting documents must be witnessed/certified true by an official of a [Singapore Overseas Mission](https://www.mfa.gov.sg/Overseas-Missions/Find-A-Singapore-Overseas-Mission)√Ç¬†with his official seal/stamp duly affixed.
Alternatively, if you are residing in a country which is part of the [Apostille Convention](https://www.hcch.net/en/instruments/conventions/status-table/?cid=41)**:**
* Your documents must first be witnessed and certified true by a Notary Public;
* Thereafter, the notarised documents must be certified by the designated [Competent Authority](https://www.hcch.net/en/instruments/conventions/authorities1/?cid=41) of your country via the issuance of an apostille certificate.
**If you are in Singapore**
To facilitate faster processing, you are strongly encouraged to close your CPF account and transfer your CPF savings to your bank account before leaving Singapore. Once you have left the country, additional verification will be required for forms completed overseas as certification at a Singapore Overseas Mission is required. These may incur additional administrative charges.
Make an [appointment](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/appt/oas/close-acct) to visit the CPF Service Centre to close your CPF account and transfer your CPF savings to your bank account. Please note that no walk-ins are allowed without an appointment.
When visiting the CPF Service Centre, please bring along:
1. Your original copies of the [supporting documents](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/LMdocuments.pdf) stated on the CPF account closure form.
**If you are below age 21**
Your parent or legal guardian can close your CPF account using this [form](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/account-services/documents/FORM%20CPF-CAC.pdf).']

question: What is a Singapore Overseas Mission?
answer:
['Singapore Overseas Missions located in certain countries can help CPF members residing overseas in witnessing and certification of application forms and documents.
You will need to visit the Singapore Overseas Mission in person. Find out where is the [overseas mission nearest to you](https://www.mfa.gov.sg/Overseas-Missions/Find-A-Singapore-Overseas-Mission).']

question: How can I get the letter from Immigration & Checkpoints Authority confirming the cancellation of my Singapore permanent residency?
answer: ['To obtain the letter from Immigrations & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) confirming the cancellation of your Singapore permanent residency, you can contact ICA at 6391 6100 or [email](mailto:ica_feedback@ica.gov.sg) them.']

question: Do I have to go to Singapore to cancel my Permanent Resident status if I am closing my CPF account upon leaving Singapore?
answer: ['To check the procedure of cancelling your Permanent Resident status for the purpose of closing your CPF account upon leaving Singapore, you can contact Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) at 6391 6100 or [email](mailto:ica_feedback@ica.gov.sg) them.']

question: How will my CPF savings be transferred to my bank account when my CPF account is closed?
answer:
['You can choose to receive your CPF savings in three ways when your CPF account is closed:
**1. Bank transfers via Interbank GIRO (IBG) to your Singapore bank account**
**2. Telegraphic transfer to your bank account overseas**
You will need to bear all bank charges:
i. for telegraphic transfer to an overseas bank account
ii. if you provide insufficient bank account details resulting in an unsuccessful telegraphic transfer
**3. Cheque**
i. Please ensure your bank can clear cheques issued in Singapore Dollars
ii. Upon receiving the cheque, please ensure that you bank it in **within six months from the date of issuance**√Ç¬†to avoid paying additional charges for re-issuance of cheques
iii. You will need to bear all bank charges for overseas bank clearance of cheque.']

question: When can I expect to receive my CPF savings upon account closure?
answer:
['In view of the recent surge in applications to close CPF accounts, the processing duration has been extended up to 14 weeks. We seek your understanding on this matter.√Ç¬†**a. Online applications**This is the fastest mode, with average processing time of about 10 weeks from the point of form submission. The processing duration may be longer if additional supporting documents are required.√Ç¬†**b. Applications by post or in-person**The average processing time is about 14 weeks from the time we have received all required documents. Please note this excludes the time taken to transfer your CPF savings to your bank account, as it depends on the payment mode. If the volume of applications is high, the processing duration may be longer.√Ç¬†After your account is closed, the general time taken to receive your CPF savings will depend on the payment mode:1. **Bank transfer via Interbank GIRO to a bank account in Singapore:** Two working days;
2. **Telegraphic transfer:** Five to twelve working days; or
3. **Cheque:** The time taken for the cheque to reach you will depend on your country√¢¬Ä¬ôs courier service.
Please only contact us to check on your account closure status if you have yet to receive a response from us **after four months from the time you requested the Board to close your account**.√Ç¬†We seek your understanding that we will not be responding to any enquiries prior to that.']

question: When will my CPF account be closed if I am not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident?
answer:
['If you are not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident before 1 March 2024
You may close your CPF account and transfer your CPF savings to your bank account at any time. If you do not do so by 31 March 2024, your CPF account will be **[automatically closed](/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/what-happens-when-my-cpf-account-is-closed-and-i-have-yet-to)** on 1 April 2024.
If you renounced Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency from 1 March 2024
You may close your CPF account and transfer your CPF savings to your bank account when your renunciation is completed, i.e. when you are not a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident. If you do not do so, your CPF account will be automatically closed in the month following your renunciation; i.e. if you are no longer a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident in March 2024, your account will be closed in April 2024.']

question: What happens when my CPF account is closed and I have yet to transfer my CPF savings to my bank account?
answer:
['Any remaining savings will stop earning the prevailing CPF interest. As a concession, these savings will earn the commercial Singapore bank interest rate until 31 March 2027. Thereafter, no interest will be paid. You may still transfer the remaining savings to your bank account, at any time.
Your participation in all the schemes administered by the CPF Board will also cease. Please refer to the section ["Schemes' participation upon account closure"](/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents "Schemes participation upon account closure") for more information regarding schemes√¢¬Ä¬ô participation when your CPF account is closed.']

question: How can I request information regarding my CPF balances, CPF interest earned or, my CPF transaction statement?
answer:
['Due to difficulties in authenticating a caller√¢¬Ä¬ôs identity over the phone and email, we seek your understanding that the Board is unable to disclose any information relating to a specific CPF account via phone and email. This is for your own protection.
Your full CPF balances will be transferred to your bank account once you have [closed your CPF account](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/account-closure-for-non-singapore-citizens-and-non-permanent-residents/how-do-i-apply-to-close-my-cpf-account-on-grounds-of-leaving).']

question: Are all non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents eligible for account closure?
answer:
['Yes, all non-Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents (including Malaysian citizens residing in West Malaysia) not holding onto a pass or permit that enables employment or long term stay in Singapore, may close their accounts with immediate effect.
From January 2024, legislation changes will be made to allow all other non-Singapore Citizens and non-Permanent Residents to close their account, without further restrictions.']

question: What happens to my CPF savings if I have an outstanding CPF education loan when my account is closed?
answer:
['I have used another CPF member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings for my education
If you have an outstanding CPF education loan owing to another CPF member, your CPF savings may be used to pay the education loan before transferring the remaining CPF savings to your bank account. In the event that your CPF savings are not sufficient to cover your full education loan, your repayment liability remains even after your CPF account is closed.
I have used my CPF savings for my own education or my child/spouse/sibling/relative√¢¬Ä¬ôs education
The repayment of all such outstanding CPF Education Loans to you will be waived.']

question: What happens if I used my Retirement Account (RA) savings to purchase annuity(ies) under the Retirement Sum Scheme (RSS) or used my annuity(ies) to apply for exemption from setting aside a retirement sum?
answer: ['Once your CPF account is closed, the surrender value of your annuity, if any, will be payable to you directly in the event of termination of the annuity(ies) or to your beneficiary upon your demise.']

question: What happens to my MediShield Life/ElderShield plans when my account is closed?
answer:
['If you are a non-SC/non-PR covered under MediShield Life/ ElderShieldbefore 1 March 2024,
(i) your cover(s) will cease unless you inform us of your wish to continue your cover(s) via [Write to Us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) and make alternative payment arrangement for the premiums to be paid.
(ii) ElderShield policyholders with paid-up policies will remain covered and no further action is required from this group.
[For more details on MediShield Life](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/medishield-life/what-will-happen-to-my-msl-cover-renounced-sc-pr)
[For more details on ElderShield](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/healthcare-financing/eldershield/what-will-happen-to-my-esh-cover-renounced-sc-pr)']

question: What happens to my CPF contributions if I have outstanding MediSave payable as a self-employed person when my CPF account is closed?
answer: ['With effect from 1 March 2024, the outstanding MediSave payable will be waived automatically when you renounce your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency.']

question: What happens to my Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover when my account is closed?
answer: ['When you have renounced your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency, your HPS cover will cease upon the sale of your HDB flat or at the end of the current HPS policy year, whichever is earlier. There will be no further renewal of your HPS cover, even if you are in the process of selling your HDB flat, as the scheme is only applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.']

question: What happens to my Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) cover when my account is closed?
answer:
['Your Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) cover will be terminated as the scheme is only applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.
Your DPS insurer will refund the unused DPS premiums for the current policy year to your CPF account. The unused DPS premiums will be paid to you along with your CPF savings, after we have processed your account closure.
If you wish to find out more, please contact your DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life at [dps-sg@greateasternlife.com](mailto:dps-sg@greateasternlife.com).']

question: What do I need to do to restore my lapsed Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover after I obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?
answer:
['You may [Write to Us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous "Write to us") to request to reinstate your previous Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover, if your HPS cover has lapsed and you are still the owner of the same HDB flat with an outstanding housing loan under the same mortgagee..
If your HPS cover has ceased for more than six months, the reinstatement of your HPS cover is subject to you being in good health and you would need to provide your health declaration to us. Please visit√Ç¬†[cpf.gov.sg/HPSHealthDeclaration](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/HPSHealthDeclaration) and log in with your Singpass to submit the form.']

question: What do I need to do to restore my Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) cover after I have obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?
answer: ['Please contact Great Eastern Life at [dps-sg@greateasternlife.com](mailto:dps-sg@greateasternlife.com) for more information on your eligibility to re-join the scheme.']

question: What can I do if I have not received my cheque or my cheque has expired?
answer:
['Please notify the Board via [My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/mymailbox) or [Write to Us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/contact-us/write-to-us) if you have not received your cheque within three months from the point of form submission.
Should there be any exceptions, please note that you will need to bear all administrative charges following the re-issuance of the cheque.']

question: What if a non-Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident with a CPF account has passed away before he had closed his account and transferred all his CPF savings?
answer: ['The next of kin will have to [inform CPF Board of his death](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing)√Ç¬†with the original death certificate. Thereafter, the deceased√¢¬Ä¬ôs remaining savings will be [distributed to his beneficiaries](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/account-services/distribution-of-cpf-savings-upon-member-s-passing/what-happens-to-a-members-cpf-savings-when-he-passes-away), depending on whether he had made a valid CPF nomination before his passing.']

question: How can I find out more information on Account Closure for non-Singaporeans and non-Permanent Residents?
answer: ['For more information, please call us at 6776 6776.']

question: What is the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['The CPF Education Loan Scheme is a loan scheme which allows you to use your Ordinary Account (OA) savings to pay for your own, children√¢¬Ä¬ôs, spouse√¢¬Ä¬ôs, siblings' or relatives' subsidised tuition fees.
Only [full-time subsidised diploma√¢¬Ä¬ã√¢¬Ä¬ã/degree courses at Approved Educational Institutions (AEIs)](/member/faq/other-schemes/cpf-education-loan-scheme/what-courses-are-covered-by-the-cpf-education-loan-scheme) are covered under this loan scheme. The student would need to start repaying the principal amount withdrawn plus the accrued interest in cash, to your CPF account, one year after graduation or termination of studies, whichever is earlier.
If the institution or course does not fall under this scheme, you and the student can consider taking up a loan with the commercial banks or approaching the institution for other financial assistance options.']

question: What is the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL)?
answer:
['Students in polytechnics and autonomous universities can apply for the Tuition Fee Loan to cover a portion of their tuition fee. The table below shows a quick guide on MOE Tuition Fee Loan.![MOE Tuition Fee Loan](/content/dam/web/member/faq/other-schemes/images/MOETuitionFeeLoan.png)
Additionally, being a loan from MOE, the TFL repayment and interest can be suspended in periods of economic downturn. For instance, MOE has suspended the TFL repayment and interest from 1 June 2020 to 30 September 2021 to support households affected by Covid-19, and had done so in the past as well. On the other hand, repayment of the CPF education loan and interest cannot be suspended as it is to restore the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings for his retirement needs, and retirement security remains important, if not more so, during economic downturns.']

question: What is the MOE Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA)?
answer:
['The Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) is part of the Post-Secondary Education Scheme to help parents save for their children√¢¬Ä¬ôs post-secondary education. The PSEA is administered by MOE and is opened automatically for all eligible Singaporeans.
Funds in your Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) can be used to pay for your own or your siblings√¢¬Ä¬ô approved programmes in MOE's [list of approved institutions](https://www.moe.gov.sg/financial-matters/psea/how-to-use).
It can also be used to repay approved financing schemes such as loans under the CPF Education Loan Scheme and MOE Tuition Fee Loan taken for studies in autonomous universities, polytechnics, ITE (Diploma), and art institutions.
To check your PSEA fund balance, you can call the√Ç¬†MOE√¢¬Ä¬ôs 24-hour automated PSEA hotline at 62600777 to check your balance. Latest PSEA balance information will be updated every Wednesday.√Ç¬†**Closure of√Ç¬†PSEA**The PSEA will be closed around the middle of the year in which you turn 31. Any unused funds in the PSEA will be transferred to your CPF-OA. Once transferred to CPF-OA, it cannot be reversed to PSEA and will be subjected to CPF-OA usage rules.√Ç¬†For student who took up CPF Education Loan or MOE Tuition Fee Loan to finance their education, you may consider using PSEA funds to repay your outstanding education loan before it√¢¬Ä¬ôs transferred to your CPF-OA.
Alternatively, you can opt to transfer the balance to your sibling√¢¬Ä¬ôs existing PSEA (if applicable) when you receive the transfer option letter from MOE in the year you turn 31 years old.
For more information on PSEA, please visit [MOE PSEA website](https://www.moe.gov.sg/financial-matters/psea)']

question: What do I need to consider before deciding which education loan to take?
answer:
['You may need to consider the following before deciding on a loan type for your education:
* What other loan options are you and the student eligible for besides the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
* How much CPF savings can you use under the CPF Education Loan Scheme? Is it sufficient to fully finance the course?
* If using CPF, how would it affect your housing needs (if any) and retirement planning?
* How does the estimated loan repayment period affect the total interest to be paid?']

question: What are the Financial Assistance offered at Approved Educational Institutions?
answer:
['**Useful websites on financial assistance offered at Approved Educational Institutions:**

question: How do I apply for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL)?
answer:
['To apply for MOE Tuition Fee Loan (TFL), please follow one of the following steps below:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| SMU Students | To approach SMU |
| NTU and NUS Students | To approach OCBC or DBS |
| All other students | To approach DBS |
For more information on MOE TFL, please visit [MOE TFL website](https://www.moe.gov.sg/financial-matters/government-loan-schemes/tuition-fee-loan) or approach your institution.']

question: How do I apply for the use of my Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) funds?
answer:
['For payment of approved fees and charges, you can withdraw the Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) funds by establishing a Standing Order with MOE or by submitting ad hoc withdrawal applications as and when withdrawals are to be made. The form to use will depend on the approved institution you are in. You should consult the approved institution you are studying in on which form to use.
For more information on PSEA, please visit [MOE PSEA website](https://www.moe.gov.sg/financial-matters/psea).']

question: How much Ordinary Account (OA) savings can I use under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['You can use your Ordinary Account (OA)√Ç¬†savings up to the Available Withdrawal Limit under the CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme. The Available Withdrawal Limit is either 40% of your accumulated OA savings1, or your remaining OA balance2, whichever is lower. The amount that can be used is also subject to the tuition fees payable.
If you are 55 years old√Ç¬†or older, you need to set aside the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) in the Retirement Account before you can use the remaining savings in the OA up to the Available Withdrawal Limit. The FRS can be set aside fully with cash, or with cash (i.e. at least the Basic Retirement Sum) and property.
The Available Withdrawal Limit will change if there is a new withdrawal, repayment or refund in your OA.√Ç¬†You may check the amount of CPF savings that can be used for education by logging in to your [Education dashboard](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/educationdashboard) with√Ç¬†your Singpass. 1Made up of your current OA balance plus any OA savings that were previously withdrawn for education and investment, excluding the amount used for housing
2After setting aside any amounts reserved for housing or other schemes (if any).']

question: How much of tuition fees can be paid using Ordinary Account (OA) savings?
When is the application period for the approved educational institutions?
answer: ['You may refer to the [Application Schedule to Use CPF Savings under the CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/ApplicationScheduleToUseCpfSavings/ViewApplicationSchedule) for the application period of the approved educational institutions.']

question: Do I have to submit supporting documents to prove the relationship if I am applying to use my parent's, spouse's, siblings' or relatives' CPF under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['Supporting documents to verify the relationship between you and the member is not required at the time of application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. However, we may request for such documents to verify the relationship for audit purposes.']

question: When must the CPF member endorse the online application submitted under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['The CPF member must login to the Uniform Resource Locator (URL) provided in the email within 14 days from the date of the application, and click 'Confirm' if he/she wishes to withdraw his/her CPF savings to pay for the student's tuition fees. The online application will be automatically rejected if no action is taken by the member after 14 days.']

question: Why does the CPF member need to login to endorse my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['The CPF member must endorse your CPF Education Loan Scheme application using his/her Singpass, to apply to withdraw his/her CPF savings for your tertiary education.']

question: How do I check the status of my application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['You can check the status of your CPF Education Loan Scheme√Ç¬†application under "My Activities" by logging in to [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/) using your Singpass.']

question: How do I check for the reasons if my application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme is rejected?
answer: ['You can check the reason for rejection of your CPF Education Loan Scheme application under "My Activities" by logging in to [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/) with your Singpass.']

question: Can I still apply for CPF Education Loan Scheme after the application period had closed?
answer: ['All applications under the CPF Education Loan Scheme should be submitted within the application period. You may refer to the [Application Schedule to Use CPF Savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/ApplicationScheduleToUseCpfSavings/ViewApplicationSchedule) for the application period of the approved educational institutions.']

question: Why is there a cap on the amount of Ordinary Account savings that I can use for education purposes?
answer: ['The primary objective of CPF savings is to help members save for their retirement needs. Hence, to avoid depleting members' CPF savings, there is a limit on the amount of savings that can be used for education. The student would also have to repay in cash, the amount withdrawn plus accrued interest after he graduates or leaves the institution to fully restore the member's CPF savings.']

question: What happens if there are not enough savings in my Ordinary Account for payment of tuition fees?
answer:
['You will be informed in writing if there are not enough savings in your Ordinary Account for the payment of the tuition fees. You will need to make alternative arrangement to pay the tuition fees in cash, or consider other financing options such as the Tuition Fee Loan or use of the student's Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) savings.
The TFL is available to all full-time students of the polytechnics and universities and covers up to 75% and 90% of the tuition fees payable respectively. It is also interest-free during the course of study, unlike the CPF loan where interest starts to accrue from the time of withdrawal.
Additionally, being a loan from MOE, the TFL repayment and interest can be suspended in periods of economic downturn. For instance, MOE has suspended the TFL repayment and interest from 1 June 2020 to 30 September 2021 to support households affected by Covid-19, and had done so in the past as well. On the other hand, repayment of the CPF education loan and interest cannot be suspended as it is to restore the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings for his retirement needs, and retirement security remains important, if not more so, during economic downturns.']

question: Apart from the Ordinary Account savings, can I use my savings from other CPF Accounts under CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['Only Ordinary Account savings can be used under the CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme.']

question: Can I reserve my Ordinary Account (OA) savings for my child's tertiary education, so that the savings are not transferred to the Retirement Account (RA) when I turn 55?
answer:
['As your Ordinary Account (OA)√Ç¬†savings are meant to boost your retirement savings when you turn 55, you will not be able to√Ç¬†reserve your√Ç¬†OA savings for your child√¢¬Ä¬ôs tertiary education. At age 55, your Special Account (SA) and OA savings will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA)√Ç¬†to meet the Full Retirement Sum (FRS) applicable to you. Your RA savings will earn an attractive interest rate of up to 6% per year and provide you with lifelong monthly payouts in retirement. You are eligible to withdraw in cash the remaining OA and SA savings after setting aside the FRS, or up to $5,000 if you are unable to set aside the FRS. You can then use the cash as you wish, including towards your child√¢¬Ä¬ôs education.
You may wish to consider the MOE√¢¬Ä¬ôs Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) to finance your child√¢¬Ä¬ôs education. The TFL is available to all full-time students of the polytechnics and universities and covers up to 75% and 90% of the tuition fees payable respectively. It is also interest-free during the course of study, unlike the CPF loan where interest starts to accrue from the time of withdrawal.√Ç¬†Additionally, being a loan from MOE, the TFL repayment and interest can be suspended in periods of economic downturn. For instance, MOE has suspended the TFL repayment and interest from 1 June 2020 to√Ç¬†30 September 2021 to support households affected by Covid-19, and had done so in the past as well. On the other hand, repayment of the CPF education loan and interest cannot be suspended as it is to restore the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings for his retirement needs, and retirement security remains important, if not more so, during economic downturns.√Ç¬†Your child can also approach his [educational institution](/member/faq/other-schemes/cpf-education-loan-scheme/what-are-the-financial-assistance-offered-at-approved-educationa) to find out about the other financial assistance schemes available.']

question: Why can't I use more Ordinary Account (OA) savings for my child's tertiary education?
answer:
['CPF is primarily for members√¢¬Ä¬ô retirement needs. Hence, while members can take a loan from their CPF Ordinary Account (OA) for their own or immediate family√¢¬Ä¬ôs education, there is a limit on the total amount that can be used.
You may wish to consider MOE√¢¬Ä¬ôs Tuition Fee Loan (TFL) to finance your child√¢¬Ä¬ôs education. The TFL is available to all full-time students of the polytechnics and universities and covers up to 75% and 90% of the tuition fees payable respectively. It is also interest-free during the course of study, unlike the CPF loan where interest starts to accrue from the time of withdrawal.
Additionally, being a loan from MOE, the TFL repayment and interest can be suspended in periods of economic downturn. For instance, MOE has suspended the TFL repayment and interest from 1 June 2020 to√Ç¬†30 September 2021 to support households affected by Covid-19, and had done so in the past as well. On the other hand, repayment of the CPF education loan and interest cannot be suspended as it is to restore the member√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF savings for his retirement needs, and retirement security remains important, if not more so, during economic downturns. Your child can also approach his [educational institution](/member/faq/other-schemes/cpf-education-loan-scheme/what-are-the-financial-assistance-offered-at-approved-educationa)√Ç¬†to find out about the other financial assistance schemes available.']

question: Why is my email address required for the online application under CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['An email will be sent to the CPF member, one day after you submit an online CPF Education Loan Scheme application. The member must log in to the Uniform Resource Locator (URL) provided, using his/her own Singpass, in order to apply to withdraw his CPF savings for your tertiary education. Hence, providing a valid and correct email address is very important.
In the event that a wrong email address is provided by the student in the online application form, the student have to cancel the online application immediately and submit a new application with the correct details once the cancellation request is processed.']

question: What if I lose the endorsement email or did not receive the endorsement email for the use of my CPF savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['Both the student and the member will receive a copy of the email that is sent for member's endorsement on the use of his/her CPF savings for the student's education. The member can use either email to endorse the application using his/her own Singpass. A reminder email would be sent generally within the next three days if the member had not endorsed the application\*. The member can respond directly to the reminder email to endorse the application.
Should you have any queries on the application process, you may reach us at [cpf.gov.sg/writetous](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous).
Note: The member is also advised to ensure that his/her email settings are in place and the email address used by the student in the application is accurate.']

question: If I have already paid the tuition fees, can I be reimbursed under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['CPF savings can only be used for tuition fees that are due and payable directly to the approved educational institutions.']

question: When will payment be made to the institution under the CPF Education Loan scheme?
answer: ['Payment to the institution under the CPF Education Loan Scheme is based on an agreed schedule between CPFB and the institutions. Generally, payments will be made about one to two months after the application closing date. Please note that the schedule may be changed and is indicative only. The payment made to the institution is subject to availability of funds in the CPF member's Ordinary Account, at the point of deduction for payment to the institution.']

question: Will I receive any notification after payment has been made to the institution under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['If you (i.e. the CPF account holder) have used your CPF savings to pay for the tuition fees, you should receive a notification generally by the following month after the payment has been made to the institution.']

question: How will the CPF savings be deducted when more than one person's savings are used for education?
answer: ['When more than one person's CPF savings are used, the deductions will take place in the order the application forms are received and processed. For example, the first parent to apply to use his savings will pay first. The second parent will pay only when the first parent's savings are not enough to pay for the full tuition fees. If there are not enough savings in the payers' CPF accounts, the student will have to pay for any shortfalls in cash, to the approved educational institution.']

question: How will the CPF savings be deducted if I am paying for more than one student's tuition fees under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['If you are using your CPF savings to pay for the fees of more than one student under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, the deduction will take place based on the payment date to the institution. For example, if the payment date for Institution A is 1 Feb and for Institution B is 3 Feb, the savings will be used to pay Institution A first before paying Institution B. If there are not enough savings in the CPF account, the student will have to pay for any shortfalls in cash, to the approved educational institution.']

question: What are the alternative options available to finance my tuition fee besides the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['Besides the CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme, there are [other ways to finance a tertiary education](/content/dam/web/member/faq/other-schemes/documents/Other_ways_to_finance_education.pdf) (PDF, 0.5MB) in Singapore. You may want to consider the following factors when deciding on the best option to finance your studies:
* Eligibility
> There are different eligibility criteria for each financing option. For example, in order to be eligible for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan, an applicant needs to be a recipient of the MOE Tuition Grant. For more information on your eligibility, you may refer to the relevant websites (for example, MOE and banks) that provide details of the various financing options.
>
>
* Amount of coverage for tuition fee
> The various financing options may not cover up to 100% of your tuition fee. You may want to refer to the respective website of the various financing options to find out how much coverage is provided for your tuition fee.
* Rate of interest
> The rate of interest varies across different loans, so you may want to compare the rate of interest to find out which loan is most suitable for you. It is also important to know when interest will start accruing for your loan. For example, for the MOE Tuition Fee Loan, there is no interest accrued during the course of your study; whereas for the CPF Education Loan scheme, interest starts to accrue as soon as the CPF savings is deducted from a member√¢¬Ä¬ôs account.
* Repayment
> It is important to know when you are expected to start the repayment of your tuition fee loan and how you will finance the repayment of your tuition fee loan (i.e. minimum monthly repayment amount). You may also want to compare the maximum repayment period for each loan.
You can view a [quick comparison](/content/dam/web/member/faq/other-schemes/documents/Quick_Comparison.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB) between the CPF Education Loan and MOE Tuition Fee Loan.√Ç¬†You can also refer to [an example](/content/dam/web/member/faq/other-schemes/documents/Comparison_EDNSchemeandMOETuitionFeeLoanScheme.pdf) (PDF, 74KB) on how the loan repayment period affects the total amount repaid under the CPF Education Loan and MOE Tuition Fee Loan. [Find out whether MOE Tuition Fee Loan or CPF Education Loan is better for you](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/other-schemes/cpf-education-loan-scheme/i-intend-to-take-a-loan-to-finance-my-education-which-is-better).']

question: What other financing options do I have if I am not allowed to use CPF savings for unsubsidised courses under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['If you are not allowed to use CPF savings for unsubsidised courses under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, you may wish to apply for a study loan with commercial banks, or approach your institution for financial assistance schemes that they can offer to you.']

question: What is the interest rate for loans taken under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['Interest on the outstanding CPF education loan is computed based on the prevailing Ordinary Account (OA) interest rate.
You can refer√Ç¬†to the [CPF Interest Rates](/member/faq/growing-your-savings/cpf-interest-rates/what-are-the-cpf-interest-rates) for more information.']

question: How is the interest rate computed for the amount withdrawn under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['Under the CPF Education Loan Scheme, the interest will start to accrue from the time CPF savings are withdrawn from member's Ordinary Account (OA). Interest is calculated on a monthly basis and is compounded on a yearly basis, pegged at the prevailing interest rate for OA.']

question: How long does it take to process my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['Applications under the CPF Education Loan Scheme that have been endorsed by the CPF member will generally be processed by the next day after the institution has transmitted its student enrolment data to us. If the enrolment data is not yet submitted to us by the institution, your application status will be shown as "Approved in principle".']

question: What are the service standards for processing applications relating to CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing applications relating to√Ç¬†CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| Apply to use CPF for my education | **Online**: 1 working day\* \*upon receipt of application and enrolment confirmation from√Ç¬†institution |
| Cancel use of CPF for education | **Online**: within 1 working day |
| Change my monthly instalment rate |
| Repay my education loan | **Online**: within 2 working days **Manual**: within 14 working days |
| Revoke use of CPF for education | **Online**:√Ç¬†within 7√Ç¬†working days |
| Waive the repayment by my child(ren) | **Online**: within√Ç¬†8 working days |
| Apply for deferment | **Online**: within 1 working day |
You are encouraged to submit your applications online using your Singpass√Ç¬†for a shorter processing time.']

question: What does the status shown under "My Activities" mean for online applications made under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['You may refer to the following table for the status and what it mean for online applications made under the CPF Education Loan Scheme.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Status displayed under √¢¬Ä¬úMy Activities√¢¬Ä¬ù** | **What it means** |
| a) Pending | CPF member has yet to endorse application.Please remind the CPF member to endorse it. Applications not endorsed within 14 days from submission date will be automatically rejected. |
| b) Approved in principle | The CPF member has endorsed the application.Application is under processing, pending confirmation of your enrolment data from the institution. |
| c) Successfully Processed | Approved subject to available funds at deduction.Deductions from the CPF member√¢¬Ä¬ôs Ordinary Account will be made to the institution upon claim by the institution. A notification will be sent to the CPF member√Ç¬†generally by the following month after the deductions are made. |
| d) Rejected | Your application has been rejected.Please log in to the [CPF website](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/) with your Singpass, for more information on the rejection under √¢¬Ä¬úMy Activities√¢¬Ä¬ù. |
| e) Member rejected the application | Rejected by CPF member.Application process has been terminated. |
| f) Cancelled | Cancelled as requested. |']

question: Why do we need to use a Singpass for the online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['Singpass, which stands for "Singapore Personal Access", is the common password to transact with the Government online. Singpass is the online equivalent of the identity card, and is required for e-services where users must identify themselves online. Please refer to the [Singpass website](http://www.singpass.gov.sg/) for more information.']

question: What if we do not have a Singpass to submit our online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['You may apply for a [Singpass](https://www.singpass.gov.sg/) online. After obtaining your Singpass, you may complete and submit an online application to √¢¬Ä¬úUse CPF Savings for Education Loan Scheme√¢¬Ä¬ù via *[my cpf Online Services √¢¬Ä¬ì My Requests](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/UseForEducation/UseForEducationLanding).*']

question: How do I amend my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme after submission?
answer: ['The application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme cannot be amended once it has been submitted. However, you may cancel the application and submit a new one.']

question: How do I cancel my online application under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['You may submit your application online to cancel your "Application to use CPF savings for Education" through [*my cpf* Online Services - My Request](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/CancelTheUseOfFundForEducation/LandingPage) using your Singpass.']

question: How do I revoke the use of CPF savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['You must be the CPF member (whose CPF savings is withdrawn) in order to apply to revoke the use of CPF savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme. You may submit your application online to revoke the use of CPF savings for education through [*my cpf* Online Services - My Requests](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/RevokeUseOfCpfSavingsForEducation/CoverPage) using your Singpass. You will be informed through email notification on the status of the application if you have registered your email with the Board through [*my cpf* Online Services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/MemberPortalServices). For online applications, the status of the applications can also be found under [*my cpf* Online Services - My Activities.](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/MyActivity/MyActivity)']

question: What should I do if I have submitted an application to use CPF savings for education under Institution A, but have now enrolled with Institution B instead?
answer: ['You can only use CPF savings to finance one course of study at any point in time. You need to cancel your existing application before you submit a new one.']

question: What should I do if there is a change in payer for my tuition fees under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['If there is a permanent change in payer (CPF member whose CPF savings is withdrawn), please perform the following steps:
1. You have to apply to use the new payer√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF Ordinary Account (OA) savings for your education through [*my cpf* Online Services - My Requests](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/UseForEducation/UseForEducationLanding) using your Singpass. You may check the opening schedule of this application via [Application Schedule to Use CPF Savings under the CPF Education Loan Scheme](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/ApplicationScheduleToUseCpfSavings/ViewApplicationSchedule).
2. The current payer has to apply to revoke the use of his/her CPF savings for your education through [*my cpf* Online Services - My Requests](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/RevokeUseOfCpfSavingsForEducation/CoverPage) using his/her Singpass.
Once we have successfully processed the application to use new payer√¢¬Ä¬ôs OA and revoked the current payer√¢¬Ä¬ôs OA usage, the next deduction of fees will come from the new payer's OA. Otherwise, we will continue to deduct the tuition fees from the current payer's OA.√Ç¬†Please note that an administrative fee of $10.70 (inclusive of GST) will be charged for each deduction from the CPF member's OA.']

question: Why does the CPF Education Loan Scheme cover only approved full-time subsidised courses?
answer: ['The CPF Education Loan Scheme is meant for students studying for full-time courses because these courses are heavily subsidised by the government. Also, these students have no income and are likely to have difficulties paying their tuition fees with their own cash savings. Most of them are young adults going straight from school or national service to the universities, polytechnics or arts colleges. Part-time courses are generally tailored for working adults who are in a better position to pay their tuition fees as they have their own income. If they do not have enough savings for a part-time course, they can defer and build up enough personal savings to pay for their course fees later. Part-time students can therefore plan ahead with greater flexibility to ensure that they can meet the tuition fees.']

question: Why are only subsidised courses by the approved educational institutions included under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer: ['The CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme is a loan scheme that allows CPF members to use their CPF savings to provide their children with a basic tertiary education. Only courses that are heavily subsidised by the Ministry of Education (MOE) are included under this loan scheme because the fees for such courses are significantly lower than unsubsidised courses. Hence, member's CPF savings for retirement is less likely to be affected should the student be unable to repay the loan.']

question: Why doesn't the CPF Education Loan Scheme cover overseas studies?
answer: ['Local education at approved educational institutions is heavily subsidised by the government so students should be able to repay the CPF savings withdrawn in cash. On the other hand, overseas education is very costly and would affect the payer's retirement savings if the student is unable to repay the CPF savings withdrawn.']

question: Why doesn't the CPF Education Loan Scheme cover postgraduate courses?
answer: ['The CPF Education Loan√Ç¬†Scheme was introduced in 1989 to help low income families support themselves or their children through a basic local tertiary education. Students who have graduated with basic tertiary qualifications have earning capabilities which enable them to build-up their savings for further studies. Universities also have various schemes, such as the Tuition Fee Loan Scheme and Study Loan Scheme, to help students pay their tuition fees.']

question: How does the education loan repayment work?
answer:
['The student has to start repaying the education loan one year after graduation or termination of studies, whichever is earlier. The student will receive a notification on the loan repayment details generally about three months before it commences. If the student intends to start the repayment earlier, the student can contact us through [My Mailbox](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/mymailbox) using his/her Singpass.
Repayment must be made√Ç¬†either in one lump sum or via monthly instalments over a maximum of 12 years. The monthly instalment rate will be computed for the student based on the loan amount and repayment period.√Ç¬†The student **cannot use his own CPF savings** for the repayments to the CPF member's CPF Account.
Students are encouraged to repay the full loan as early as possible to save on the interest payable and to allow the account holder to use these monies for his/her housing and retirement needs. This can be done by making lump sum repayments or repaying a higher monthly instalment amount. Students can use the [CPF Education Loan Repayment Period Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/EducationLoanRepaymentPeriodCalculator/EducationLoanRepaymentPeriodCalculate) to compute how long it will take for them to repay the loan or the [Monthly Instalment Rate Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/EducationMonthlyInstalmentRateCalculator/EducationMonthlyInstalmentRateCalculate) to work out a suitable loan repayment plan.']

question: How do I make a repayment under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
['You can make repayment via GIRO or other [modes of repayment](/member/faq/other-schemes/cpf-education-loan-scheme/what-are-the-modes-of-repayment-under-the-cpf-education-loan) approved by CPF Board. This can be made in either a lump sum or monthly instalments.
For monthly instalments, GIRO repayment is the most convenient and preferred mode of repayment as it√Ç¬†automatically deducts the required amount each month. You may apply for GIRO online or by mail.
**Online using *my cpf* (recommended)**
1. Log in with your [Singpass](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/MemberPortalServices).
2. Submit a GIRO application via My Requests.
**Mail**
1. Download and complete the [FORM EDN/GIRO: Repay Education Loan Using GIRO](/content/dam/web/member/faq/other-schemes/documents/FORM_EDN_GIRO.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.4MB).
2. Mail it to the address printed overleaf of the GIRO application form.
Online applications are recommended as it will generally be processed immediately. Log in with [Singpass](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/PortalServices/MemberPortalServices)√Ç¬†on the CPF website to check the GIRO application status under My Activities.
For lump sum repayment, you are encouraged to repay online at cpf.gov.sg via '[e-Cashier](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Miscellaneous/Cashier/ECashierHomepage)'.
Please note that even if you make a partial lump sum repayment, you are still required to continue with your regular monthly repayments. This ensures that you are not late for your monthly repayment and fulfil the payment obligations. Do make your repayment for the required month at least three working days before the end of the month to ensure sufficient processing time.']

question: How much do I have to repay under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?
answer:
