answer: ['CPF contributions are not payable on the honorarium given to a professional person who is not employed by you, e.g. Board Chairman, Non-Executive Director, Honorary Secretary and Auditor of a sports club.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on leave pay?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on the total wages given to your employee in each calendar month, including leave pay.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursement of relocation expenses incurred by my employee?
answer:
['**Where your employee is required to relocate from Singapore to overseas**
CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursement of relocation expenses (e.g. air tickets, baggage charges, shipping cost, taxi fare from airport and packing charges) as they are given in respect of overseas employment.
**Where your employee is required by you to relocate back to Singapore**
CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursement of relocation expenses incurred by your employee to relocate from overseas to work in Singapore if the following conditions are fulfilled:
a) your employee had been working for you in Singapore;
b) your employee was required by you to relocate overseas for official purposes; and
c) your employee is now required by you (i.e. same employer) to return to Singapore to continue with employment in Singapore.
Otherwise, you will still need to pay CPF contributions on any reimbursement of relocation expenses.
**Where your employee relocates to Singapore to start a new employment with you**
CPF contributions are payable on the reimbursement of relocation expenses if your employee is originally based overseas (e.g. previously he was staying overseas, or working for another employer overseas) but relocates to Singapore to begin his new Singapore employment with you. The reimbursement of relocation expenses in such a case is considered as employment benefit which increases your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash awards?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable on any cash awards given to your employee that are given in respect of employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment.
Some examples are:
* Best Employee Award
* Commendation Award
* Good Customer Service Award
* Good Quality Service Award
* Innovation Award
* Outstanding Performance Award
* Productivity Award
If the award given is not related to the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment, CPF contributions are not payable. For example, a patent award is given to the winner of a design competition and the competition is not related to employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on overtime pay?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on overtime pay given to your employee..']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on compensations given under the Work Injury Compensation Act (WICA)?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not payable on compensations given to your employee due to√Ç¬†work-related injuries or diseases under the [Work Injury Compensation Act](https://www.mom.gov.sg/workplace-safety-and-health/work-injury-compensation) (WICA).
Medical leave wages (MLW) are payable for the days your employee is issued with medical leave or light duty.
If your employee is on medical leave, CPF contributions are not payable on the MLW given to him.
If your employee is given light duty, he will continue to earn wages. You will have to top-up his wages to the full Average Monthly Earnings (AME). MLW is the difference between AME and the actual wages earned. CPF contributions are payable on wages given for work done but not payable on MLW.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on payments given to my employee for his involvements in ad-hoc projects?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable for all payments given to your employee in respect of his employment, i.e. for his services or work done.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payments given to my employee for his suggestions?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable on cash payments given to your employee for his suggestions that are work-related.
CPF contributions are not payable on cash payments given for suggestions that are not work-related. For example, a cash prize is given to the winner of a naming competition and the competition is not related to employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on advance salary given to my employee?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable on the salary due to your employee in each calendar month.
For advance salary that is not due to your employee but was given earlier, you are not required to pay CPF contributions on it yet. You will have to pay CPF contributions for the amount in the month it is payable to your employee.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on service charge given to my employee?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on service charge collected by you from customers and given as incentive to your employee.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) allowance if I deposit directly into my employee's SRS account?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable on Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) allowance as it can be accessed by your employee any time (with a 5% penalty for early withdrawal).
The CPF treatment is the same regardless of whether it is deposited directly into your employee's SRS account or you pay to him in cash.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payment given to my employee for personal insurance?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on cash payments given to your employee to purchase his personal insurance.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on the client referral fee given to your employee for recommending business clients to you?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on client referral fees given to your employee for recommending business clients to you.']

question: Are CPF contribution payable on the employee's share of CPF contribution (which is part of his gross wages) if I choose not to recover it from my employee's wages?
answer:
['As an employer, you are required to pay the total CPF contributions, inclusive of employer and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share, to CPF Board for your employee.
You are entitled to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions when paying your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages for the month.√Ç¬†If you decide not to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share, you will not be able to do so after the wages are paid to your employee.
**Example**
Your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs monthly wage is $1,000 and the total CPF contribution is $370. This consists of employee's share ($200) and employer's share ($170) of CPF contributions.
If you decide not to recover the employee's share of $200, you will still need to pay $370 to his CPF account based on his monthly wages of $1,000.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on the Employment Assistance Payment (EAP)?
answer: ['CPF contributions are not payable on Employment Assistance Payment (EAP) given to your employee if you are unable to offer re-employment when your employee reaches the minimum retirement age of 62, up to the age of 67.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on Long Service Award (LSA)?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable on cash award given to your employee in recognition of his long service.
However, to promote loyalty, CPF contributions are not payable on Long Service Award (LSA) that is given to your employee with at least 5 years of service and subsequent LSA for each 5-year period of service with you, up to the amount of your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Ordinary Wages (OW) for the month in which the LSA is paid. In the event that there are multiple types of LSA given to the same employee, only the first LSA granted to the employee in each 5-year period can qualify for this exemption.
If the LSA exceeds the OW for the month, CPF contributions are payable on the amount in excess of OW. If your employee has no OW payable in that month, CPF contributions are payable on the entire LSA.
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Scenarios** | **Are CPF contributions payable?** |
| **LSA√Ç¬†amount is OW and below** | No |
| **LSA amount is more than OW** | Yes, on the amount of LSA exceeding OW |
| **OW is $0** | Yes, on the entire LSA |
The CPF treatment is the same even if the LSA is payable after your employee has left employment.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on monthly pension given to my retired employee?
answer: ['CPF contributions are not payable on monthly pension given to your employee who has retired as he is no longer in your employment.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursement given to my prospective employee for his payment in lieu of notice to his former employer for leaving the company before the end of notice period?
answer:
['From October 2022, CPF contributions are **not** payable on the reimbursement given to your prospective employee for the payment in lieu of notice he made to his former employer in order to commence his employment with you earlier. This is in consideration of the fact that payment in lieu of notice is liquidated damages for the breach of contract.
For clarity, CPF contributions are also **not** payable if you make the payment in lieu of notice on behalf of your prospective employee directly to his employer. There is no change in the Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs position on this.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on financial assistance given to my employee?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on cash payments given to assist your employees who are facing financial difficulties.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on referral fee given to my employee?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not payable on referral fee given to your employee for recommending new staff to your company if it is not part of his official duties.
CPF contributions are payable on referral fee if introducing new staff to join your company is part of your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs official duties.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on retention cash incentive given to my employee to encourage him to continue his employment with me?
answer: ['CPF contributions are payable on cash incentive given to your employee for retention of your employee's employment.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on COVID-19 allowance given to my employees to defray their transport, meal, lodging and utility expenses as they are required to work at a different location?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable on COVID-19 allowance given to your employees.
CPF contributions are not payable on cash payment given to defray your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô transport, meal, lodging or utility expenses if they are required to work at a different location (not their normal place of work) provided that the following conditions are fulfilled:
a. The payment is provided in the form of reimbursement based on actual expenditure of which proof must be shown;
b. The reimbursement does not increase the employees√¢¬Ä¬ô wages; and
c. Your employees are only entitled to such reimbursements based on their continued attendance at employment and work in Singapore of which transport, meal, lodging and utility expenses would be incurred due to the COVID-19 situations, e.g. lockdown, Work From Home, Leave Of Absence or relocation to other site.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable if I disburse funding support given by the Government (e.g. Employment Grant) to my employees?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not payable on cash payments given by the Government to you.
However, CPF contributions are payable if you disburse any cash payments to your employees.']

question: What happens if I am unable to pay CPF contributions on time due to COVID-19?
answer:
['The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date.
Timely payment of CPF contributions is important for employees to meet their housing, retirement and healthcare needs.
Nevertheless, we appreciate that the COVID-19 situation is extremely challenging and difficult for businesses in some sectors. Apart from the [support measures](https://www.gov.sg/article/cushioning-the-impact-of-covid-19)√Ç¬†announced by the Government at Singapore Budget 2020, companies facing cash flow issues can explore the following options to keep their businesses viable:
* Tapping on training support schemes to send their employees for training and upskilling and receive [absentee payroll funding](https://www.ssg.gov.sg/ETSP_EnhancedAP.html);
* Making adjustments to work arrangements with or without wage cuts;
* Making direct adjustments to wages; or
* Putting employees on no-pay leave.
Employers can refer to the [Tripartite Advisory on Managing Excess Manpower and Responsible Retrenchment](https://www.mom.gov.sg/TAMEM) for guidance on the appropriate measures to cope with cash flow issues and manage excess manpower.
You may also wish to look out for the additional support measures√Ç¬†for workers and businesses√Ç¬†in response to the COVID-19 pandemic that the Government announced at Singapore Budget 2021:
* [COVID-19 Resilience Package](https://www.gov.sg/article/budget-2021-covid-19-resilience-package).']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on training allowance given to your trainee under the SGUnited Traineeship Programme if you are the host company?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not payable on training allowance for your trainee under the SGUnited Traineeship Programme so long as he is not employed under a [contract of service](https://www.mom.gov.sg/employment-practices/contract-of-service).
You and your trainee may enter into an employer-employee relationship at any time, including upon completion of the programme, in which case, CPF contributions would be payable on wages given to your employee.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursement of transport expenses between assigned place of work and the actual work location if my employee has to work at the latter?
answer: ['CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursement of transport expenses between assigned place of work (e.g. home during the COVID-19 period in compliance with the government√¢¬Ä¬ôs requirements or advisories) and actual work location (e.g. office, hospital) if it is incurred for official purposes. The reimbursement amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursement of COVID-19 test?
answer:
['If your employee is required by authorities and/or medical practitioners to take a COVID-19 test, CPF contributions are not payable on the reimbursement of the fees incurred. The amount reimbursed must not exceed the actual expenditure.
CPF contributions are also not payable if your employee has to take the COVID-19 test due to work requirements, e.g. pre-departure test before your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs overseas business trip. This is because the cash payment is incurred on behalf of you for official purpose. Likewise, for this reimbursement, the amount reimbursed must not exceed the actual expenditure.
However, if the COVID-19 test is done due to personal reasons (e.g. personal overseas trip), CPF contributions are payable for such reimbursement as it is your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs personal expenses.']

question: What is the Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling?
answer:
['The [Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/what-payments-attract-cpf-contributions#section-header-1659668379) limits the amount of OW that attract CPF contributions in a calendar month for all employees. It will be gradually raised to $8,000 by 2026. The increase takes place in four steps, as shown in the table below, to allow employers and employees to adjust to the changes.
Table: Changes in CPF salary ceilings
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| | **CPF Ordinary Wage ceiling** | **CPF annual salary ceiling** |
| **From 1 Jan 2016 to 31 Aug 2023** | $6,000 | $102,000 (no change) |
| **From 1 Sep to 31 Dec 2023** | $6,300 (+$300) |
| **From 1 Jan to 31 Dec 2024** | $6,800 (+$500) |
| **From 1 Jan to 31 Dec 2025** | $7,400 (+$600) |
| **From 1 Jan 2026** | $8,000 (+$600) |']

question: How do I calculate the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling and the amount that attracts CPF contributions?
answer:
['The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling sets the maximum amount of AW on which CPF contributions are payable per year. An employee's AW ceiling is computed on a per employer per year basis.
You can access the following resources to help you with the computation:
a. [AW ceiling Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/additional-wage-ceiling-calculator)
b. [Examples on the Computation of the AW ceiling](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Examples_on_Additional_Wage_Ceiling_Computation_Sep2023.pdf) (PDF, 0.6MB)']

question: As an employer, how do I apply to the Board for a single Additional Wage (AW) ceiling if my employees were transferred to another related company during the year?
answer:
['The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling is computed on a per employer per calendar year basis. However, you may apply for a single AW ceiling for transferred employees within two related companies, if:
1. Both employers are related;
2. Your employee has been informed on the application; and
3. The Terms & Conditions of the employment contract remain unchanged.
Please note that this application is only for transferred employees whose mandatory CPF contributions have exceeded/will exceed the AW ceiling.
To apply for a single AW ceiling, you may submit an [online request](https://cpf.gov.sg/singleawc)']

question: How do I calculate CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) paid before the end of the year/last month of employment?
answer:
['As an employer, you should use current year's Ordinary Wages (OW) to estimate the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling whenever AW are payable. Alternatively, you can also estimate the AW ceiling using previous year√¢¬Ä¬ôs OW.
Once the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs total OW for the year are known, usually at the end of the year or in the last month of employment, you should re-calculate the AW ceiling based on the total OW subject to CPF contributions. You can refer to these√Ç¬†[Examples](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Examples_on_Additional_Wage_Ceiling_Computation_Sep2023.pdf)√Ç¬†on the computation of the AW ceiling.
Any shortfall in the CPF contributions after the re-computation should be paid together with December's contributions or contributions for your employee's last month of employment, whichever is applicable. If you have overpaid the CPF contributions, you can apply for a [refund](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfExcessContribution/Home).']

question: My employee has resigned, and I have to top up the CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) after re-computing the AW ceiling. However, I am unable to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions from his wages. What should I do?
answer:
['You may apply to waive the employee's share of contributions if you meet the following conditions:
1. Deducted but unable to recover the employee's share of contributions in full or in part from the wages of employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs last month of employment; and
2. Made attempts but failed to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share from the employee; and
3. Have applied estimated AW ceiling in the earlier months;
You may [write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous) to submit your application with the following information:√Ç¬†1. Employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs last month of employment.
2. Details of employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Ordinary Wage (OW), Additional Wage (AW) and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of contributions deducted for the year in this [format](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Template.xlsx).
3. Correspondence with the employee as proof that you have made attempts but failed to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of contributions from the employee.
You are still required to pay the employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of contributions and the waiver request is subject to the Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs approval.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on the amount that I√¢¬Ä¬ôve deducted from my employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages due to lateness?
answer:
['You may deduct your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages for being absent from work. However, the amount of deduction cannot exceed the period of absence. The [authorised salary deductions](https://www.mom.gov.sg/employment-practices/salary/salary-deductions) are listed in the Employment Act.
CPF contribution are payable on the nett wages after deduction, i.e. CPF contributions are not payable on the amount deducted where your employee did not earn any wages as he was late for work.
The deduction should reduce the wages for the month in which your employee was late for work, and not the month where the deduction was made.
**Example**
Your employee was late for work on the last day of January, and the deduction of $30 was made only in February√¢¬Ä¬ôs payroll. You should:
* Pay CPF contributions on the full wages of $2,000 for February
* Re-calculate the wages for January, i.e. pay CPF contributions on wages of $1,970 ($2,000-$30). If you have already paid CPF contributions on the full wages of $2,000 for January, you can apply for a refund using the Refund of CPF Contributions Paid (RFM/Form 40) via our [Online Application service](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfCpfContributionsPaid/LandingPage).']

question: How do I calculate CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) when there is a change in Age Group during the year?
answer:
['The change in CPF contribution rate should be applied from the first day of the following month after your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs birthday month. For example, if your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs 55th birthday falls on 15 January 2021, the change in CPF contribution rate for age above 55 to 60 years old will be applied from the month of February 2021 and the subsequent months.
Any shortfall in CPF contributions on Additional Wages (AW) should follow the applicable rate for the month in which the AW were paid. The shortfall should be paid together with December√¢¬Ä¬ôs contributions or contributions for your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs last month of employment, whichever is applicable.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on cash payments given to my employee who is required to be relocated overseas for work?
answer:
['Reimbursement of relocation expenses
CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursement of relocation expenses incurred by your employee who is required to be stationed/posted to work overseas. In addition, CPF contributions are not payable on wages and any other reimbursement payable to him for his overseas employment.
Relocation allowance
CPF contributions are payable if the relocation allowance is given to your employee for his employment in Singapore, e.g. the allowance is given to relocate from overseas to Singapore to work.
However, CPF contributions are not payable on relocation allowance given to him for overseas employment, e.g. the allowance is given to relocate from Singapore to overseas to work.']

question: Is overtime (OT) pay classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) or Additional Wages (AW)?
answer:
['For wages to be classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) for the month, it must satisfy both conditions below:
* The√Ç¬†wages are due or granted wholly or exclusively in respect of an employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment during that month; and
* The√Ç¬†wages for that month are payable by 14th of the following month.
Wages which are not classified as OW will be Additional Wages (AW) for the month. The overtime (OT) pay has to be apportioned to OT performed in each calendar month before classification. Please see examples below. **Example 1**:√Ç¬†OT performed in a calendar month
| | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **S/N** | **OT performed** | **Payable date for OT pay** | **Classification** | **CPF payable by** |
| a | 1 to 30 Apr | 10 May | OW for Apr | 14 May |
| b | 1 to 30 Apr | 30 May | AW for May | 14 Jun |
**Example 2:** OT performed across two calendar months, e.g. 25 Mar to 24 Apr
| | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **S/N** | **OT performed** | **Payable date for OT pay** | **Classification** | **CPF payable by** |
| a | 25 Mar to 24 Apr | 30 Apr | OT pay from 25 Mar to 30 Mar= AW for Apr\*OT pay from 1 Apr to 24 Apr= OW for Apr | 14 May |
\*As CPF contribution is computed based on calendar month, the OT component from 25 Mar to 30 Mar can only be classified as OW if it is payable by 14th of the month following Mar i.e. 14 Apr. Since the OT pay is only payable on 30 Apr, it does not fulfil the second condition for it to be classified as OW.']

question: What are Ordinary Wages (OW) and Additional Wages (AW)?
answer:
['For wages to be classified as Ordinary Wages (OW) for the month, it must satisfy both conditions below:
* The wages are due or granted wholly or exclusively in respect of an employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment during that month; and
* The wages for that month are payable\* by 14th of the following month.
Wages which are not classified as OW will be Additional Wages (AW) for the month.
Example of OW: monthly salary Example of AW: annual performance bonus
\*Please note that the payable date refers to the date where company is contractually obligated to pay employee the wages. Do note that the Employment Act (EA) also imposes certain requirements on the timing for salary payment if employee is covered under EA. If there are circumstances that resulted in administrative delays in payment e.g. new employee joins after payroll cut-off date, you should use the payable date to determine the classification of wages.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on reimbursements of employee/flexible benefits?
answer:
['In general, CPF contributions are required on all employee benefits as the cash payments payable to your employees increase their wages. Some examples are reimbursements of childcare expenses, eldercare expenses, gym subscription fee, holiday expenses, personal insurance premium and personal mobile phone subscription fee.
However, CPF contributions are not payable on the following as they do not fall under the definition of √¢¬Ä¬úwages√¢¬Ä¬ù in the CPF Act:
a) Reimbursements of medical and dental benefits
CPF contributions are not payable on reimbursements of medical and dental treatment expenses incurred by employee, their spouse and children if it is considered necessary by registered doctors, TCM practitioners, and/or dentist for the treatment or diagnosis of any illness (excludes solely aesthetic defect). This approach supports employment practices to provide medical and dental benefits for employees and their dependants beyond an employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs statutory obligations, while ensuring that members have adequate CPF contributions for retirement. Some examples are reimbursements of medical consultation fee and medication prescribed by medical practitioner for treating illness, and scaling and polishing by dentist.
If the treatments, procedures or items are ordered by medical practitioners as part of medical or dental treatment, CPF contributions are also not payable even if they are performed by non-registered medical practitioners. Some examples are physiotherapy, chiropractic therapy, health screening, vaccination, health supplement and medical device. Otherwise, CPF contributions are payable if your employees go on their own accord.
If you are in doubt whether a certain treatment, procedure or item is medically required for your employee, you should check with a registered medical practitioner and apply the CPF treatment accordingly.
b) Reimbursements incurred for official purposes
CPF contributions are not payable on [reimbursements incurred for official purposes](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/employer-obligations/what-payments-attract-cpf-contributions/are-cpf-payable-on-reimbursements). The reimbursed amount must not exceed the expenditure incurred. Similarly, any of the claims made under the employee/flexible benefit schemes that are for official purposes will also not attract CPF contributions. Some examples are reimbursements of course and exam fee, mobile phone subscription fee and professional membership fee that are required for work.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on excess leave taken by my employee due to re-computation of leave entitlement when he leaves employment?
answer:
['Any excess leave will reduce the wages in the month where the excess leave was taken. CPF contributions must be computed on the wages after deduction of the excess leave taken in that month.
If CPF contributions have already been paid, you should apply for an [adjustment](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/compliance-and-rectifications/applying-for-adjustment-of-cpf-contributions) or [refund](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/compliance-and-rectifications/applying-for-refund-of-cpf-contributions) of the excess CPF contributions instead of offsetting it from the CPF contributions in the current month.
**Example**
John earns $1,000 per month and is entitled to 12 days of annual leave a year (equivalent to one day per month). He left employment on 30 June, and his pro-rated leave entitlement is six days.
He has taken nine days of annual leave in May.
| | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Month** | **Wages** | **Leave taken in that month** | **Excess Leave** | **Deduction for excess leave** | **Wages after deduction for excess leave** |
| May | $1,000 | 9 | 3 | $150 | $850 |
| June | $1,000 | 0 | 0 | $0 | $1,000 |
To find out more on the definition and calculation of daily wages, please refer to the [Ministry of Manpower website](https://www.mom.gov.sg/employment-practices/salary/monthly-and-daily-salary).
As shown above, the employer should re-compute CPF contributions for May based on wages of $850. Since his employer would have already paid CPF contributions for May, his employer should apply for a refund/adjustment of CPF contributions for May. His employer should not offset the excess CPF contributions paid from the month of June.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on "per diem" payments?
answer:
['√¢¬Ä¬úPer diem√¢¬Ä¬ù payments refer to money paid to your employees for daily living expenses, and include the additional expenses incurred for living away from home. They may also be given for trips made by your employees to attend overseas training and conferences where the payments are meant to cover certain living expenses incurred overseas such as the cost of meals, transport expenses and other incidental expenses like laundry.
**√¢¬Ä¬úPer diem√¢¬Ä¬ù payments that are given as a lump sum allowance**
CPF contributions are payable on √¢¬Ä¬úper diem√¢¬Ä¬ù payments that are given as a lump sum allowance as they increase your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages.
**√¢¬Ä¬úPer diem√¢¬Ä¬ù payments that are given as reimbursements for official purposes**
CPF contributions are not payable on √¢¬Ä¬úper diem√¢¬Ä¬ù payments that are given as reimbursements for expenses incurred for official purposes (e.g. accommodation, meal expenses).
As the employer, you must be able to prove that the reimbursements are for expenses incurred for official purposes. The amount reimbursed must not exceed the actual expenditure.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on compensation in lieu of notice?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not payable on compensation in lieu of notice payable by you to your employee. However, CPF contributions are still payable on the wages given to your employee until his last date of employment.
If your employee must pay you compensation in lieu of notice and you decide to offset the compensation against the wages payable to your employee, CPF contributions are still payable on the wages before the offset.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable for work-related team-based awards given to my employees?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not payable on the team-based awards as such awards would not be remuneration due or granted in respect of an individual√¢¬Ä¬ôs employment.
However, CPF contributions are payable on the awards if they are payable to a single employee or where you have the discretion on the amount payable to each team member, e.g. you stipulate that the cash award is payable to a particular employee or have discretion on how the award is divided amongst the team members (e.g. the one with higher contributions obtains higher quantum).']

question: Are CPF contributions payable on salary deductions?
answer:
['You can deduct your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs salary for specific reasons only. The√Ç¬†[authorised salary deductions](https://www.mom.gov.sg/employment-practices/salary/salary-deductions)√Ç¬†are listed in the Employment Act.
Where employee worked a complete month and is entitled to full salary
CPF contributions are computed on the full salary payable to your employee before the deduction of moneys he owed you, e.g. due to damage or loss of money or goods, recovery of loans.
Example:
Your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs monthly salary is $2,000 but he has to repay you $50 due to a lost good. CPF contributions are payable on $2,000 before deducting $50 from his nett wages.
Where employee did not work a complete month and is entitled to a lower salary
You can find out more in the FAQs listed below:
Deduction due to lateness: [Are CPF contributions payable on the amount that I√¢¬Ä¬ôve deducted from my employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages due to lateness?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/employer-obligations/what-payments-attract-cpf-contributions/are-cpf-payable-on-the-amount-deducted-for-lateness)
Deduction due to excess leave taken: [Are CPF contributions payable on excess leave taken by my employee due to re-computation of leave entitlement when he leaves employment?](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/employer-obligations/what-payments-attract-cpf-contributions/are-cpf-payable-on-excess-leave-taken-by-my-employee)']

question: What are the changes to the CPF salary ceilings from 1 September 2023?
answer:
['The CPF monthly and annual salary ceilings have been updated periodically in the past to keep pace with rising salaries. We are updating the monthly salary ceiling now, so that the CPF system continues to remain relevant in meeting the retirement needs of the broad majority of resident employees.
The CPF monthly salary (i.e. Ordinary Wage) ceiling will be gradually raised from $6,000 to $8,000 by 2026 for all employees. The increase will take place in four steps, as shown in the Table below, to allow employers and employees to adjust to the changes.
Table: Changes in CPF salary ceilings
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| | **CPF Ordinary Wage ceiling** | **CPF annual salary ceiling** |
| **Current** | $6,000 | $102,000 (no change) |
| **From 1 September 2023** | $6,300 (+$300) |
| **From 1 January 2024** | $6,800 (+$500) |
| **From 1 January 2025** | $7,400 (+$600) |
| **From 1 January 2026** | $8,000 (+$600) |
Employees who are earning above $6,000 will benefit from this change.
The annual salary ceiling, which limits the total amount of Ordinary Wages and Additional Wages that attract CPF contributions, will remain at $102,000 at this juncture. It will be reviewed periodically to ensure it continues to cover the broad majority of CPF members. The CPF Annual limit will also remain at $37,740.']

question: With the increase in Ordinary Wage ceiling from September 2023, how should I compute the Additional Wage ceiling?
answer:
['If your employee is earning monthly Ordinary Wages (OW) that are above $6,000, the estimated Additional Wage (AW) ceiling for the year 2023 should be $102,000 √¢¬Ä¬ì ($6,000 x 8) √¢¬Ä¬ì ($W x 4) where W is capped at the Ordinary Wage (OW) ceiling of $6,300 from September 2023.
For example, if your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs monthly OW is $7,000, the estimated AW ceiling for 2023 will be $28,800 instead of $30,000. You should pay CPF contributions on the AW up to $28,800.
If your employee is earning monthly OW that are $6,000 or below, the estimated AW ceiling will not be affected by the increase in OW ceiling.']

question: What should I do if I have paid based on the Additional Wage ceiling of $30,000, before the Ordinary Wage ceiling increase was announced?
answer: ['Please re-compute your [Additional Wage (AW) ceiling](/employer/faq/employer-obligations/what-payments-attract-cpf-contributions/how-should-i-compute-additional-wage-ceiling-2023) based on the increased Ordinary Wage ceiling of $6,300 from September 2023. If you have overpaid the CPF contributions, please [apply](/employer/faq/compliance-and-rectifications/applying-for-refund-of-cpf-contributions/how-to-apply-for-refund-of-excess-cpf-paid-above-aw-ceiling)√Ç¬†for a refund via RFM/Form CAPVC for each affected employee(s).']

question: What is the Skills Development Levy (SDL)?
answer:
['The Skills Development Levy (SDL) is a compulsory levy imposed under the [SDL Act](https://sso.agc.gov.sg/Act/SDLA1979) *for all your employees, including foreign employees, working in Singapore.* The SDL is in addition to CPF contributions.
Currently, CPF Board collects SDL on behalf of the SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG). The SDL collected is channelled to the Skills Development Fund (SDF), which is used to support workforce upgrading programmes and to provide training grants to you when you send your employees for training under the National Continuing Education Training system.
The SDL and SDF are administered by SSG.
For more information, please visit [**SSG√¢¬Ä¬ôs website**](https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/) or call their call centre at 6785 5785.']

question: Who do I have to pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) for?
answer:
['You have to pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) for all your employees working in Singapore, including:
√¢¬Ä¬¢ employees employed on permanent, part-time, casual and temporary basis
√¢¬Ä¬¢ foreign employees on work permits and employment pass holders
SDL is payable to the SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG) for foreign employees.']

question: How do I pay Skills Development Levy (SDL)?
answer:
['You can pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) together with your employees' monthly CPF contributions to CPF Board. If you hire only foreign employees, please make your SDL payment directly to the SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG).
You can visit [**SSG√¢¬Ä¬ôs website**](https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/)for more information on the payment procedures and the computation of SDL.']

question: How do I calculate Skills Development Levy (SDL)?
answer:
['You have to contribute Skills Development Levy (SDL) for all your employees\*. The levy payable for each employee is at 0.25% of their monthly total wages. The minimum payable is $2 for an employee earning less than $800 a month and the maximum is $11.25 for an employee earning more than $4,500 a month.
After you have computed the SDL for each employee, add up the SDL calculated and round the total amount down to the nearest dollar.
Here√¢¬Ä¬ôs an example of an SDL computation:
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Employee** | **Total wages for the calendar month** | **SDL Payable** |
| A | $609.50 | $2.00(Minimum of $2.00 is payable because the√Ç¬†total wages√Ç¬†is less than $800) |
| B | $2,000.00 | $5.00 |
| C | $4,500.00 | $11.25 |
| D | $4,502.03 | $11.25(Maximum of $11.25 is payable because the total wages is more than $4,500) |
| E | $10,000.00 | $11.25(Maximum of $11.25 is payable because the total wages is more than $4,500) |
| Total SDL | $40.75 |
| Total SDL Payable | **$40.00****(rounded down to the nearest dollar)** |
You can visit√Ç¬†[**SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG)√¢¬Ä¬ôs**](https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/)website for more information on the payment procedure and computation of SDL.
\* Employees include full-time, casual, part-time, temporary and foreign employees working in Singapore..']

question: How do I back pay the Skills Development Levy (SDL) which was omitted?
answer:
['You will need to make a lump sum back payment of the whole amount for the period which you did not contribute or have been underpaying Skills Development Levy (SDL) immediately. You can do so by adding the amount of back payment to the SDL payable for your next CPF submission, or pay to SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG) directly.
Please note that as an employer who is liable to pay SDL, you should keep a proper payment record as SSG may conduct audits.']

question: Is Skills Development Levy (SDL) payable for students on vacation job?
answer: ['For information on whether Skills Development Levy (SDL)√Ç¬†is payable for students on vacation job, please refer to [Annex A](https://sdl.ssg.gov.sg/DOCs/Annex_A_SDL_FAQ.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) and search for √¢¬Ä¬òStudent Pay√¢¬Ä¬ô under the type of payment as published in [SkillsFuture Singapore Agency's website](https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/).']

question: Which categories of employees or workers are exempted from Skills Development Levy (SDL)?
answer: ['For information on which categories of employees are exempted from Skills Development Levy (SDL), please refer to the [Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) on SDL](https://sdl.ssg.gov.sg/Docs/SDL-Frequently-Asked-Questions.pdf) at SkillsFuture Singapore Agency (SSG)√¢¬Ä¬ôs website.']

question: What happens if I do not pay Skills Development Levy (SDL) on time?
answer: ['There will be a penalty of 10% per annum for late contribution on the outstanding amount under the Skills Development Levy (SDL) regulations.']

question: What should I do if I have omitted or under-paid to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs)?
answer:
['If you have omitted or underpaid to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs), please select the following SHGs to find out how to back pay the contributions.
**For Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) Fund, Eurasian Community Fund (ECF) and Singapore Indian Development Association (SINDA) Fund**
Please back pay starting from January of the current year, even if there were omissions for past years. Please include the omitted amounts in your next contribution submission to CPF Board.
**For Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF)**
Please back pay starting from the day it was omitted (including past years√¢¬Ä¬ô omissions). Please include the omitted amounts in your next contribution submission to CPF Board.']

question: What should I do if I have made a payment to a wrong Self-Help Group (SHG) for my employees?
answer: ['For contributions paid to a wrong Self-Help Group, please [submit a request](/employer/compliance-and-rectifications/applying-for-adjustment-of-cpf-contributions) to CPF Board for adjustment.']

question: How do I pay my employees' Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions?
answer: ['You are expected to deduct the Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions from your employees' wages. You can pay the SHG contributions to CPF Board when making your CPF contributions.']

question: How would I know if my employee has changed religion and hence I would need to change my employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions accordingly?
answer:
['Only contributions to the Mosque Building & Mendaki Fund (MBMF) is based on your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs religion. Contributions to other Self-Help Groups (SHGs) are based on your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs race indicated on the NRIC.
Your employees are responsible to update you on any changes. Any deduction should also be reflected in your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs payslip so that the employees can highlight to you if the contributions are not deducted correctly for the right SHG.']

question: Must my employees contribute to the Self-Help Group (SHG) funds?
answer:
['As an employer, you are expected to deduct your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô contributions to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs) from their wages. Employees who do not wish to contribute or wish to contribute a different amount can contact the respective SHGs for more information.
To find out which SHGs your employees should make their contributions to, you may refer to [this page](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups#section-header-1003964251) for more information.']

question: Is Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions deductible if my employee did not work for the full month?
answer: ['Contributions to the Self-Help Group (SHG) funds are payable as long as your employee is paid wages in the month. It does not depend on the number of days worked.']

question: Are Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions payable for an intern on an internship programme?
answer:
['For Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) Fund, Eurasian Community Fund (ECF) and Singapore Indian Development Association (SINDA) Fund:
Contributions to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs) funds are payable for interns on internship programme if CPF contributions are payable. You may refer to [this FAQ](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/employer-obligations/who-should-receive-cpf-contributions/are-cpf-payable-for-students) for more information on whether CPF contributions are payable for student employees.
For Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF):√Ç¬†Please refer to the section on "Student Pay" at the [MUIS website](https://www.muis.gov.sg/mosque/Mosque-Infrastructure/About-MBMF/Employer-Information) to find out whether MBMF is payable for an intern.']

question: How do I determine which Self-Help Group my employee should contribute to?
answer:
['You are expected to request for your employee's race/religion to determine the correct Self-Help Group (SHG) to contribute to. For employees with double-barrelled race, you can refer to the first component of the double-barrelled race on your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs NRIC to ascertain which SHGs fund your employee should contribute to.
Employees who do not wish to contribute or wish to contribute a different amount can contact the respective SHGs for more information.
You can refer to the following examples on how to determine the correct Self-Help Group (SHG) for your employees:
**Employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs race indicated on NRIC is Indian-Chinese**
As the first component of the double-barrelled race indicated in your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs NRIC is Indian, your employee will need to contribute to the Singapore Indian Development Association (SINDA) Fund.
However, your employee can choose to contribute to both funds, SINDA and Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC), by informing you of their preference.
**Employee is a Muslim and race indicated on NRIC is Indian**
Your employee will need to contribute to both SINDA and Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF).
**Employee is a Muslim and race indicated on NRIC is Indian-Chinese**
As the first component of the double-barrelled race indicated in the NRIC is Indian and your employee is a Muslim, your employee will need to contribute to both SINDA and MBMF.']

question: Why should contributions be made to the Self-Help Groups (SHGs)?
answer: ['Self-Help Groups (SHGs) were set up to uplift low-income households and the less privileged, in the Chinese, Eurasian, Muslim, and Indian communities in Singapore. Your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô contributions to SHGs can help their respective communities.']

question: My employee has left the organisation. Are Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions still payable?
answer: ['Contributions to the Self-Help Groups are payable as long as there are outstanding wages payment to be made.']

question: If my employee is under multiple employment, is he/she required to contribute to the Self-Help Group (SHG) fund via all his/her employers?
answer: ['You are expected to deduct your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs contributions to the Self-Help Group (SHG) from his/her wages. However, your employee can choose to contribute through one employer only by informing his/her SHG.']

question: Are Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions payable for 13th month wage?
answer: ['Contribution to the Self-Help Group (SHG) funds are based on the total gross monthly wages, which include the 13th month wage.']

question: My employees do not wish to contribute to their respective Self-Help Groups (SHGs). What can my employees do?
answer: ['Your employees who do not wish to contribute to their respective Self-Help Groups (SHGs) can [contact the respective SHGs](/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups#text-d28653cd7a) for more information.']

question: How do I apply for a refund of Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions?
answer: ['If you have overpaid any Self-Help Group (SHG) contributions, please [contact the respective SHGs](/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups#text-d28653cd7a) directly for a refund.']

question: What does the Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF) comprise?
answer:
['The Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF) comprises three components:
√Ç¬∑ The Mosque Building component is used to build new mosques, upgrade and redevelop current mosques.
√Ç¬∑ The Mendaki component is used to develop educational and social programmes to strengthen and uplift Malay/Muslim families.
√Ç¬∑ The Religious Education component is used to support current and future religious education needs of the Muslim community.']

question: What are the contribution rates for the respective Self-Help Groups?
answer: ['You may refer to [this page](/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups#section-header-1649538385) to find out the contribution rates for the respective Self-Help Groups (SHGs).']

question: What are the CPF contribution rates for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents?
answer: ['For more details on the CPF contribution rates, see [rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay#section-header-92607856) for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents.']

question: Where can I find the past CPF contribution and allocation rates?
answer: ['Please refer to the [past CPF contribution and allocation rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay/past-cpf-contribution-and-allocation-rates).']

question: Do the same CPF contribution rates apply to part-time/casual/temporary employees?
answer:
['Like full-time employees, the CPF contribution rates for part-time, casual or temporary workers depend on your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô citizenship status, age group and wage band.
The nature of the employment does not affect the contribution rates applicable.']

question: How is the CPF contribution rate applied when my employee moves to the next age group?
answer:
['The contribution rates of your employee aged above 55, 60, 65 or 70 years shall be applied from the first day of the month after the month of his√Ç¬†55th, 60th, 65th√Ç¬†or 70th birthday.
Example:
Your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs√Ç¬†55th birthday falls on 13 January 2022.
| CPF contribution rate |
| --- |
| For wages earned in January 2022 (55 years and below) | For wages earned in February 2022 (Above 55 to 60 years) |
| 37% of total wages (>$750) (Employer's share = 17%; Employee's share = 20%) | 28% of total wages (>$750) (Employer's share = 14%; Employee's share = 14%) |
Note:
* The employee is deemed to have attained 55 years of age on his√Ç¬†55th birthday and would be classified in the "55 years and below" age group; and
* deemed to be above 55 years old on the day after his√Ç¬†55th birthday. As the contribution rates are applicable on a monthly basis, he will be classified in the "Above 55 to 60 years" age group in the month after his√Ç¬†55th birthday i.e. month of February 2022.']

question: Why are the employee's contribution rates lower/different for those earning total monthly wages of more than $500 but less than $750?
answer: ['For employees earning total monthly wage of more than $500 but less than $750, the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions are computed based on phased-in rates to avoid a sudden drop in the employees√¢¬Ä¬ô take home pay when there is an increase in wage. You can use our [CPF Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-contribution-calculator)√Ç¬†to calculate the CPF contributions applicable to your employees.']

question: Are CPF contributions rounded to the nearest dollar?
answer:
['The total contributions for the calendar month should be rounded off to the nearest dollar. Cents should be dropped for amounts less than 50 cents. Amounts of 50 cents and above should be treated as an additional dollar.
You are entitled to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions when paying your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages for the month. The cents should always be dropped for the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions.
You can use our [CPF Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-contribution-calculator) to calculate√Ç¬†the CPF contributions applicable to your employees.
You can also use [CPF EZPay](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/making-cpf-contributions/submitting-cpf-contributions-via-cpf-ezpay) to auto-compute your CPF contributions for greater convenience!']

question: My employee has recently obtained his Singapore Permanent Resident status. Do I need to pay CPF contributions for him?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable once your foreign employee obtains his Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status. Please ensure that your employee informs you when he becomes a SPR.
For the first two years of obtaining the SPR status, both you and your SPR employee will contribute CPF at [graduated rates](/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay#section-header-1452036554)√Ç¬†(refer to Tables 2 and 3). It is to help your employee adjust to the lower take-home pay.
From the third year onwards, you and your SPR employee will contribute CPF at the [full rates](/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay#section-header-1452036554)√Ç¬†(refer to Table 1).
The first year rate will apply from the day your employee becomes a SPR. You should use the date indicated on his entry permit (Form 5/5A) issued by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority of Singapore (ICA). The second and third year rates will apply from the month following the anniversary of his SPR conversion.
**Example**
If your employee has obtained the SPR status on 15 January 2020, the start and end dates for first, second and third year of obtaining SPR status are shown in the table below:
![An example to illustrate the year of SPR status](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/images/YearOfSPRStatus.png)
You can use our [calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-contribution-calculator) to compute the CPF contributions for your SPR employee.']

question: My employee's Singapore Permanent Resident status was reinstated. Which issue date should I use to determine his CPF contribution rates?
answer:
['CPF contributions will be payable from the day your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status was reinstated. Please ensure your employee informs you when he becomes an SPR.
To determine the year of SPR status, you should refer to the date indicated on your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs valid entry permit (Form 5/5A) issued by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority of Singapore (ICA).
Find out more about [making CPF contributions for SPRs](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay/do-i-need-to-contribute-cpf-for-my-new-spr-employee).']

question: What are the CPF contribution rates for Singapore Permanent Residents (SPRs)?
answer: ['For more details on the rates, see [rates for Singapore Permanent Residents (SPRs)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay#section-header-1452036554).']

question: Are there different CPF contribution rates for Singapore Permanent Resident employees of different nationalities?
answer: ['The [CPF contribution rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay) are applied consistently to all Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) employees regardless of their nationalities.']

question: How can I contribute more CPF for my employee who just obtained his Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status?
answer:
['You and your employee can contribute CPF at higher rates in the first two years after your employee has obtained Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status.
There are two options available:
1. You and your employee both contribute at full rates; or
2. You contribute at full rates while your employee continues to contribute at graduated rates.
You can submit a joint application with your SPR employee based on your entity type:
[For UEN-registered entities](https://form.gov.sg/5f7f089bf5ce78001141869f)
[For individuals trading under own name](https://form.gov.sg/5f7f2aa926630200115ff090)']

question: My employee has renounced his Singapore Citizenship/Singapore Permanent Resident status in a month. Do I need to pay his CPF for the entire month?
answer:
['If your employee has renounced his Singapore Citizen/Singapore Permanent Resident (SC/SPR) status, you would need to pay CPF contributions for him for the period when he is still a SC/SPR. CPF contributions are not required from the day your employee becomes a foreigner.
For Ordinary Wages (OW), you will need to pay CPF contributions on the pro-rated OW. For Additional Wages (AW), CPF contributions are required depending on when the AW is payable to your employee.
Please ensure your employee informs you when he renounces his SC/SPR status.
**Example**
Assuming your employee renounces his SC/SPR status and becomes a foreigner on 10 January 2022 and he receives OW and AW for January 2022.
For OW
* CPF contribution is only required on the pro-rated wages for the period 1 to 9 January 2022.
For AW
* CPF contribution is required on the AW if it is payable to the employee between 1 to 9 January 2022.
* CPF contribution is not required on the AW if it is payable on or after 10 January 2022.']

question: My Singapore Permanent Resident employee contributed CPF at a higher rate than stipulated ones in his previous employment. Am I required to pay CPF at the higher rate?
answer:
['The higher contribution rate ceases upon a change of employment within the first two years of obtaining Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status i.e. the rates will go back to the [graduated rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay#section-header-1452036554). Therefore, there is no need to contribute CPF at higher rates.
If you and your SPR employee wish to contribute at higher rates, you can submit a joint application with your SPR employee based on your entity type:
[For UEN-registered entities](https://form.gov.sg/5f7f089bf5ce78001141869f)
[For individuals trading under own name](https://form.gov.sg/5f7f2aa926630200115ff090)']

question: My Singapore Permanent Resident employee obtained his Singapore Citizenship in the middle of the month. When will the contribution rates for a Singapore Citizen apply?
answer:
['The CPF contribution rates for Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) will apply on your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages until your employee obtains a Singapore Citizenship. Once your employee has obtained a Singapore Citizenship, the Singapore Citizen rates will apply.
For Ordinary Wages (OW), you will need to pro-rate your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs OW and apply the appropriate rates to determine the CPF contributions. You can [**write to us**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/FeedbackSubscription/Index?utm_source=shortURL)√Ç¬†for assistance on the computation if the Ordinary Wages for the month exceeds the Ordinary Wage√Ç¬†ceiling or if the pro-rated wages are below $750.
For Additional Wages (AW), you will need to apply the applicable contribution rate depending on when the AW is payable to your employee.
**Example**
Assuming your employee is in the second year of Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status and becomes a Singapore Citizen on 15 June 2020.
For OW
* The second year SPR rate should be applied on the pro-rated wages for the period 1 June to 14 June 2020.
* The Singapore Citizen rate should be applied on the pro-rated wages for the period of 15 June to 30 June 2020.
For AW
* The second year SPR rate should be applied on the AW if it is payable between 1 June and 14 June 2020.
* The Singapore Citizen rate should be applied on the AW if it is payable between 15 June and 30 June 2020.']

question: When will my employee and I know the status of our application to jointly contribute CPF at higher rates for a Singapore Permanent Resident?
answer:
['The application to jointly contribute CPF at higher rates for a Singapore Permanent Resident will generally be processed within seven working days once all required documents are submitted.
Once processed, a notification letter will be sent to your Principal Place of Business (PPB). The letter will also state the month from which the new CPF contribution rate will be applied.
To ensure that you receive the notification letter, please [inform](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/AuthenticationProviderSelection/SelectSPCPProvider?returnAction=/eSvc/Web/Services/ChangeOfAddress/CoverPage&theme=Employer) us if there are any changes to your PPB.']

question: Must I contribute CPF at a higher rate for my Singapore Permanent Resident employee?
answer:
['You are not required to contribute CPF at a higher rate for your Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) employee who is in the first two years of his SPR status. However, you are required to contribute CPF at the graduated rates.
If you and your SPR employee wish to contribute at higher rates, you can submit a joint application with your SPR employee based on your entity type:
[For UEN-registered entities](https://form.gov.sg/5f7f089bf5ce78001141869f)
[For individuals trading under own name](https://form.gov.sg/5f7f2aa926630200115ff090)']

question: When can I apply to pay CPF contribution at a higher rate for my Singapore Permanent Resident employee?
answer: ['You can start applying from the day your employee became a Singapore Permanent Resident.']

question: Will employers similarly receive support for the increase in CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2023?
answer:
['Similar to the support provided in 2022, the CPF Transition Offset (CTO) will provide transitory wage offsets to alleviate the rise in business costs due to the increase in CPF contribution rates for senior workers.
Find out more about√Ç¬†[CPF Transition Offset](http://go.gov.sg/sec-cto-eec).']

question: When is the due date for CPF contributions?
answer: ['The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the√Ç¬†14th of the following month (or the next working day if the√Ç¬†14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date.']

question: How do I recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions?
answer:
['As an employer, you need to pay both the employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions to CPF Board. You are entitled to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions when paying your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages for the month. For example, the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions for January can only be deducted from the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages in January.
It is a serious offence to recover or attempt to recover any amount more than what is allowed from your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages.
If you failed to recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions due to your error (e.g. system glitch, omission of CPF contributions due to employer's oversight, wrong computation of employee's share) before paying your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs wages for the month, you cannot recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions from subsequent months√¢¬Ä¬ô wages.
However, if the failure to do so was not due to your error, you must do the following before you can recover the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions from wages payable by you to your employee:
* you have paid the CPF contributions to the Board, and
* you have either forwarded your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs written consent to CPF Board, or obtained CPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs written permission on the matter.
This must be done within six months from the time the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions should have been recovered.']

question: Are CPF contributions payable if I have been contributing to my Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) employee's pension scheme in his home country?
answer: ['CPF contributions are mandatory for your Singapore Permanent Resident employee working in Singapore regardless of any contributions to another pension scheme in his home country.']

question: Where can I download the CPF contribution rate booklets?
answer:
['The CPF contribution rate booklets are no longer available.
You can use our [CPF Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-contribution-calculator) to calculate the CPF contributions applicable to your employees. For more details on the CPF contribution rates, see [rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay#section-header-92607856) for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents.
You can also use [CPF EZPay](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/making-cpf-contributions/submitting-cpf-contributions-via-cpf-ezpay) to auto-compute your CPF contributions for greater convenience!']

question: What were the changes to the CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2023?
answer:
['The CPF contribution rates for employees aged above 55 to 70 have been increased to strengthen their retirement adequacy. The changes in CPF contribution rates for Singapore Citizens and Singapore Permanent Residents (from third year and onwards) took effect from 1 January 2023.
There is no change to the CPF contribution rates for other age groups.
Find out more about the [revised CPF contribution rates](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/how-much-cpf-contributions-to-pay).']

question: How do I calculate CPF contributions for wages paid to my employees?
answer: ['Please use our [CPF Contribution Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/cpf-contribution-calculator) to compute the CPF contributions payable to your employees.']

question: How do I compute CPF contributions for employees whose wages are not paid monthly?
answer:
['When wages are not paid according to the calendar month, e.g. weekly or fortnightly, you have to apportion the wages according to the calendar month for which CPF contributions are paid. The apportionment is necessary to determine the Ordinary Wages for the calendar month on which CPF contributions are payable.
**Example:**
Company XYZ pays its employees wages every week. In the table below, the computation of CPF contributions for the month of February is based on the wages from 1 to 28 February i.e. wages from 26 to 31 January on the first week and 1 March on the last week are excluded. ![Highlighted dates to be excluded for CPF contribution for February](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/images/calendar.jpg "Highlighted dates to be excluded for CPF contributions computation")']

question: I am paying a bonus to an ex-employee. Would CPF contribution for the bonus be contributed for his last month of employment or the month when it is due or payable?
answer:
['If the bonus is due and payable in a particular month after your employee leaves employment, CPF contribution for the bonus should be contributed for that month..
However, if the bonus payment was a result of an oversight in paying the bonus due to your employee in his last month of employment or earlier, you should indicate that particular month as the contribution month. Please note that interest will be levied on any late payments.']

question: What are the common mistakes made by employers when contributing CPF?
answer: ['For more details regarding common mistakes made by employers when contributing CPF, please refer to this [document](/content/dam/web/employer/employer-obligations/documents/MistakesbyEmployerswhenDeterminingCPFContributions.pdf).']

question: How do I contact the CPF Board on employer matters?
answer:
['Our website provides comprehensive information on CPF matters. You may find the answers you need from our√Ç¬†**[Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)](/employer/faq)**. This is the quickest way to get your answer.
If your queries are not found in the FAQs, you can√Ç¬†**[contact us](/employer/contact-us)**.']

question: Besides CPF contributions, is CPF Board the collecting agent for other payments?
answer:
['The CPF Board is also the collecting agent for the following payments:
1. [Skills Development Levy (SDL)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/skills-development-levy)
2. [Mosque Building and Mendaki Fund (MBMF)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups)
3. [Singapore Indian Development Association (SINDA) Fund](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups)
4. [Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) Fund](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups)
5. [Eurasian Community Fund (ECF)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/contributions-to-self-help-groups)
6. [SHARE Programme Donations](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/employer-obligations/share-donations)']

question: Are CPF contributions required on Additional Wages (AW) that are payable after my employee has died?
answer:
['CPF contributions are not required on Additional Wages (AW) that are payable to your employee after his death if he was neither a Singapore Citizen nor Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) as at the date of his death.
On the other hand, CPF contributions are required on the AW that are payable to your employee after his death if he was a Singapore Citizen or SPR as at the date of his death.']

question: My foreign employee has obtained his Singapore Permanent Resident status. How do I compute CPF contributions on his Ordinary and Additional Wages for the month?
answer:
['CPF contributions are payable once your foreign employee obtains his Singapore Permanent Resident (SPR) status. Please ensure that your employee informs you when he becomes a SPR.
For Ordinary Wages (OW), you will need to pay CPF contributions on the pro-rated OW. For Additional Wages (AW), CPF contributions are required depending on when the AW is payable to your employee.
**Example**
Assuming your employee obtains his SPR status on 15 March 2022 and he receives OW and AW for March 2022.
For OW
* CPF contribution is required on the pro-rated wages from 15 to 31 March 2022.
For AW
* CPF contribution is not required on the AW if it is payable while the employee was a foreigner i.e. before 15 March 2022.
* CPF contribution is required on the AW if it is payable on or after 15 March 2022.']

question: What are the changes to the CPF contribution rates for senior workers that will take effect from 1 January 2024?
answer:
['To strengthen senior workers√¢¬Ä¬ô retirement adequacy, the Tripartite Workgroup on Older Workers had recommended in 2019 that CPF contribution rates for senior workers aged above 55 to 70 years be raised gradually to help senior workers save more for retirement.
The first two steps of increases took effect on 1 January 2022 and 1 January 2023. The Government will continue to raise the senior worker contribution rates in 2024 with a long-term target to have the full increase rolled out by 2030.
The changes to the CPF contribution rates from 1 January 2024 are shown below:
*For employees earning monthly wages exceeding $750*
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Employee's age√Ç¬†(years)** | | **CPF Contribution Rates from 1 January 2024** |
| **Current√Ç¬†Total****(% of wage)** | **Total****(% of wage)** | **By employer****(% of wage)** | **By employee****(% of wage)** |
| 55 and below | 37 | 37 | 17 | 20 |
| Above 55 to 60 | 29.5 | 31(+1.5) | 15(+0.5) | 16(+1) |
| Above 60 to 65 | 20.5 | 22(+1.5) | 11.5(+0.5) | 10.5(+1) |
| Above 65 to 70 | 15.5 | 16.5(+1) | 9(+0.5) | 7.5(+0.5) |
| Above 70 | 12.5 | 12.5 | 7.5 | 5 |
(a) The increase in the CPF contribution rates will be fully allocated to the Special Account to help senior workers save more for retirement.
(b) For those earning monthly wages of more than $500 to $750, the employee contribution rates will continue to be phased in.
(c) There were no changes to the graduated contribution rates for first and second year Singapore Permanent Residents.']

question: My employees do not wish to contribute to the SHARE programme. What can they do?
answer: ['Your employees can contact the HR department to cease the payroll deduction.']

question: What is the Social Help and Assistance Raised by Employees (SHARE) Programme?
answer:
['The SHARE programme is a voluntary monthly giving programme run by Community Chest, the philanthropy and engagement arm of the National Council of Social Service.
CPF Board collects your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô SHARE donations on behalf of Community Chest, from your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô wages made through the company payroll.']

question: How do I pay my employees' SHARE donations?
answer: ['You are expected to deduct the SHARE donations from your employees√¢¬Ä¬ô wages. You can pay SHARE donations to CPF Board when making your CPF contributions.']

question: What is Additional Wage ceiling and how do I calculate it?
answer:
['The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling limits the amount of AW that attract CPF contributions. The AW ceiling is applied on a per employer per calendar year basis. The Additional Wage ceiling is computed as follows:
| |
| --- |
| $102,000\* - Total Ordinary Wage subject to CPF contributions for the year*\*Equivalent to 17 months x Ordinary Wage ceiling of $6,000* |
The AW ceiling formula above does not take into account the revision of Ordinary Wage ceiling of $6,300 from Sep 2023. Please refer to this [FAQ](https://cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/employer-obligations/what-payments-attract-cpf-contributions/how-should-i-compute-additional-wage-ceiling-2023) on how to compute the AW ceiling for the year 2023.
You can access the following resources to help you with the computation:
a.√Ç¬†[AW√Ç¬†ceiling Calculator](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/additional-wage-ceiling-calculator)
b.√Ç¬†[Examples on the Computation of the AW ceiling](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Examples_on_Additional_Wage_Ceiling_Computation_Sep2023.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.6MB)']

question: How do I apply the Additional Wage ceiling for the following scenarios: a) Employee A is working for two companies concurrently? b) Employee B is transferred from another entity?
answer:
['The Additional Wage (AW) ceiling is applied on a per employer per calendar year basis.
As such, if your employee is working for two companies concurrently or if your employee is transferred from another entity, you must apply the AW ceiling separately.']

question: What should be the amount indicated on the refund application form for Wages and Contribution Paid?
answer: ['You are required to declare the actual wages and contributions paid to allow accurate computation of excess CPF contributions.']

question: When should I submit the application for excess contribution on Additional Wages?
answer: ['You should submit it when the employee's Total Wages for the year are known, usually after the contribution payment for December or in the last month of employment.']

question: Do I have to submit the employee(s) bank statement(s) if I have already indicated the bank account details on the application form for refund of CPF contributions paid in excess?
answer:
['To better protect employees from scams, we will only accept bank accounts where CPF Board is able to perform automated bank account verification with the bank directly. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to the employee.
If your employee(s) use DBS Bank Ltd (DBS), Post Office Savings Bank (POSB), United Overseas Bank Ltd (UOB) or Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Ltd (OCBC), you do not need to submit any supporting documents for the CPF refund application.
However, if your employee(s) are using any other banks√¢¬Ä¬ô accounts, the refund will be made via cheque.']

question: My employee and I do not wish to apply for refund. Can the excess CPF contributions be retained in the employee's CPF account?
answer:
['For CPF contributions paid in error or on conditional wages, the refund application must be submitted to the Board within one year from√Ç¬†the date of payment of CPF contributions or date wages are repayable to the employer respectively. Hence, if you do not wish to apply for the refund, you would not be able to do so subsequently.
However, if the excess contributions are paid above the CPF Annual Limit, they should not be retained and must be refunded to the employer/employee.']

question: How do I check the status of my refund application for CPF contributions?
answer: ['To check the status of your refund of CPF contributions, you may√Ç¬†[write to us](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/writetous)with yourCPF Submission Number (CSN) and/ or Transaction Reference Number. Do note that refund of CPF contributions will generally be processed within 1 month upon receipt of the required information.']

question: How long does CPF Board take to process my refund application?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standards for processing refund of CPF contributions:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing Time** |
| CPF Contributions Paid in Error | Within one month upon receipt of the necessary information\* |
| CPF Contributions Paid on Conditional Wages Repayable |
| CPF Contributions Paid in Excess of the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling |
\*This excludes the two working days that banks require to credit the monies to√Ç¬†your bank account.
As we are currently experiencing high volume of applications, a longer processing time may be expected for your application(s). Once your application(s) have been successfully processed, we will notify you on the details of the refund.']

question: I would like to apply for a refund of excess CPF contributions paid to my employee(s). Which refund application form should I use?
answer:
['Please refer to the table below to find out more information on the refund type that is applicable to you:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Refund Type** | **Examples** |
| 1. CPF Contributions Paid in Excess of the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling [(RFM/Form CAPVC)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfExcessContribution/Home "CPF Contributions Paid in Excess of the Additional Wage (AW) Ceiling")Note: The employer must provide the 12 months√¢¬Ä¬ô wage records and contribution details of the employee for the purpose of computation of the AW ceiling. | * There were changes to the employees√¢¬Ä¬ô Ordinary Wages which resulted in changes in the AW ceiling
* You did not estimate the annual AW ceiling and paid CPF contributions based on your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs actual AW during the year..
To estimate the AW ceiling during the year and reduce the amount that needs to be refunded at the end of the year, you can access the following resources:a. [AW ceiling Calculator](https://cpf.gov.sg/employer/tools-and-services/calculators/additional-wage-ceiling-calculator)b.
