[Examples on the Computation of the AW ceiling](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Examples_on_Additional_Wage_Ceiling_Computation_Sep2023.pdf) (PDF, 0.6MB) |
| 2. CPF Contributions Paid on Conditional Wages Repayable [(RFM/Form 40)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfCpfContributionsPaid/LandingPage "CPF Contributions Paid on Conditional Wages Repayable")Note: The refund application must be submitted to the Board immediately and no later than one year from **the date wages are repayable to the employer**. | * You paid CPF contributions on a conditional wage which your employee has to repay as he did not fulfil certain conditions tied to the payment.
* You paid CPF contributions on paid annual leave which were later converted to no pay leave due to your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs resignation/termination or extended no pay leave period.
|
| 3. CPF Contributions Paid in Error [(RFM/Form 40)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfCpfContributionsPaid/LandingPage "CPF Contributions Paid in Error ")Note: The refund application must be submitted to the Board immediately and no later than one year from **the date of payment of CPF contributions**. | * You overlooked your employee's age group or citizenship status and used wrong contribution rates.
* You paid CPF contributions for an employee who has left the company.
Find out the [list of common situations](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Refund_reasons_2023.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) where CPF contributions are paid wrongly. |']

question: How can I apply for refund of excess CPF contribution paid above Additional Wages (AW) ceiling?
answer: ['You can submit the refund application for excess CPF contribution paid above Additional Wages (AW) ceiling√Ç¬†[online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfExcessContribution/Home).']

question: I overpaid the late payment interest. Must I apply for a refund of the excess amount?
answer: ['CPF Board will automatically refund the excess late payment interest to you either by Direct Debit (if the bank account that you had previously registered with us is still valid), or by cheque. You will receive a letter informing you of the refund.']

question: One of my staff had left service last month but I have wrongly used the previous template for submission, should I re-submit another template without that resigned staff's details again?
answer: ['You should apply for a refund of CPF contributions that were paid in error for the employee who resigned.']

question: Five out of my 20 staff have salary revision this month and I have already submitted the CPF contributions using the previous template. Should I re-submit the correct details for all the staff?
answer: ['You should pay the shortfall of the CPF contribution for the five affected staff only.']

question: I have submitted CPF contribution twice for the same month, can I request for a full refund for the wrong submission?
answer:
['For refund of the whole payment submitted in a single file or on a single receipt date, you will need to apply online for a full refund of the wrong submission immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment. Please use the form based on your entity type:
[For UEN-registered entities](https://cpf.gov.sg/fullrefund)
[For Individuals trading under own name](https://cpf.gov.sg/fullrefundindividuals)']

question: How do we determine the date of conditional wages repayable?
answer:
['The date of conditional wages repayable√Ç¬†is the date on which the employee's obligation to repay the conditional wages arises due to non-fulfilment of the condition(s) tied to the payment, under the terms of employment or mutually agreed between the employer and employee.
Below are the guidelines that can be used in determining the date of wages repayable:
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Conditional Wages** | **Condition** | **Guidelines - Date of Wages Repayable** |
| Sign-on/Retention bonus | Fulfilment of minimum service period | Last date of service |
| Conditional performance bonus |
| Paid annual leave | (a) Last date of service (for resignation/termination) or(b) Commencement date of no pay leave (for staff still in-service) |
| Commission | Meeting of performance/ sales target(s) | (a) Repayable date as provided in employment contract or any other relevant agreement(b) Computation date\* if (a) is not applicable\*The date which employer is able to establish the amount of conditional wages repayable by the employee to the employer |
| Conditional salary increments |
| Advance salary paid on sales of goods/services | Return of goods/services |
| Paid study leave | Completion of course | (a) Course discontinuation date or(b) Repayable date as provided in employment contract or any other relevant agreement |']

question: Who is the Authorised Officer for submitting the Refund of CPF Contributions Paid?
answer: ['The authorised officer for submitting the √¢¬Ä¬òRefund of CPF Contributions Paid√¢¬Ä¬ù service is the person in charge of the company's CPF contributions or someone who has an authoritative portfolio in the company.']

question: I have over-contributed CPF to my staff, can I apply for a refund?
answer:
['If you have over-contributed CPF to your staff, you can apply for a refund.
For refund of the whole payment submitted in a single file or on a single receipt date, you can refer to the [process](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/compliance-and-rectifications/applying-for-refund-of-cpf-contributions/can-i-request-for-a-full-refund-if-i-submitted-cpf-twice) to apply for a full refund of the whole payment.√Ç¬†For refund of CPF paid to specific employee(s), you can apply for a refund using the Refund of CPF Contributions Paid (RFM/Form 40) [online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfCpfContributionsPaid/LandingPage).√Ç¬†Please note that:* You have to notify the employee on the refund.
* Both employer and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions will be refunded to you. You are responsible to refund the employee's share of CPF contributions (where applicable) to your employee.
* The refund is subject to the availability of funds in the employee's CPF accounts.
* In the event where wages are declared incorrectly, resulting in excess refund of CPF contributions, you will have to make good the shortfall in contributions and the corresponding late payment interest.']

question: What should be the amount to be indicated on the application form under the columns "Correct Ordinary Wages" and "Correct Additional Wages"?
answer:
['You should indicate the correct amount for the Ordinary and Additional Wages, after excluding any overpaid wages or conditional wages repayable. This will be the amount of wages subject to CPF contributions and will be used by the Board to compute the correct amount of CPF Payable by you.
The Board will compute the refund amount (i.e. CPF Paid √¢¬Ä¬ì CPF Payable) based on the correct wage details declared on the application form.
In the event where wages are declared incorrectly, resulting in excess refund of CPF contributions, you will have to make good the shortfall in contributions and the corresponding late payment interest.']

question: What are conditional wages?
answer:
['Conditional wages are wages paid to employee with condition(s) attached. Depending on the terms of employment or mutual agreement, such wages are repayable to employer when the employee fails to fulfil the condition(s).
Below are some examples of conditional wages:
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Conditional Wages** | **Condition** | **Reason(s) for Failure to Fulfil the Condition** |
| Sign-on/Retention bonus | Fulfilment of minimum service period | (a) Resignation(b) Termination |
| Conditional performance bonus |
| Paid annual leave | Resignation/termination resulting in a reduction of annual leave entitlement which has to be converted to no pay leave |
| Commission | Meeting of performance/sales target(s) | Did not meet the agreed target(s) |
| Conditional salary increments |
| Advance salary paid on sales of goods/services | Return of goods/services | Goods or services were returned, e.g. due to client√¢¬Ä¬ôs cancellation of insurance policy during free-look period etc. |
| Paid study leave | Completion of course | Failure to complete course |
| Conditional salary increments |']

question: Do I need to refund the employee's share of CPF contributions to employee before applying for a refund of the contributions paid in error/on conditional wages repayable?
answer: ['It is the employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs responsibility to ensure that the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions is deducted correctly. Therefore, the employer must refund the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions (where applicable) to employee before applying for the refund. If the refund application is successful, both employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of contributions will be refunded to the employer.']

question: Which refund reason should I select for my refund of contributions paid?
answer: ['You should select the reason which best describes your reason for overpayment of CPF contributions. You may refer to this [list of reasons](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/employer-obligations/documents/Refund_reasons_2023.pdf) (PDF, 0.3MB) which illustrates some examples for each refund reason.']

question: Why must refund or adjustment of CPF contributions paid in error be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment of the CPF contributions?
answer: ['Any errors in CPF contributions should be rectified early while the documentary evidence is fresh. To encourage employers and employees to check their CPF contributions and come forward to rectify errors as soon as possible, any request for refund and adjustment of CPF contributions paid in error must be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment of the CPF contributions.']

question: What should I do if excess contributions have been made on Additional Wages (AW)?
answer:
['You should only make CPF contributions on the Additional Wage (AW) up to the annual AW ceiling.
If excess contributions have been made, employers and employees can [apply for a refund](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Services/RefundOfExcessContribution/Home).
All refund applications should only be submitted√Ç¬†when the employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs Total Ordinary Wages for the year are known and the Additional Wage (AW) ceiling is finalised, usually after the end of year or in the last month of employment.']

question: Why can√¢¬Ä¬ôt the refund be paid to a non-local bank account since I have provided the bank statement for verification?
answer:
['To better protect employers from scams, we will only refund to the employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs Direct Debit account, or OCBC and UOB bank accounts where CPF Board is able to perform automated bank account verification with the banks. This ensures that payment will only be made to a bank account belonging to the employer.
If you have a bank account with any of the eGIRO [participating banks](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/making-cpf-contributions/payment-modes/who-are-the-egiro-banks-for-dda-online-appn), you should [apply for DDA online](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/making-cpf-contributions/payment-modes/how-do-i-apply-for-direct-debit-to-pay-cpf) as the refunds made via cheques may take a maximum of 14 working days to reach you.']

question: How do I make payment for composition amount and late payment interest?
answer:
['Payment for composition amount and late payment interest can be made via the following methods:
**Composition Amount**2. [Employer's Online Services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Employer/MyRequestEmployer)
**Late Payment Interest**2. CPF EZPay
3. CPF EZPay Mobile
Please refer to the [Payment Methods Guide](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/compliance-and-rectifications/documents/PaymentMethodsGuide.pdf "Payment Methods Guide") (PDF, 0.1MB) for more information.
To check the status of your transaction for the payment of the composition amount, please follow these steps:
1. Go to [cpf.gov.sg/employer](/employer)
2. Click on **Login**
3. Select **Other employer services**
4. Login with your Singpass
5. Key in the CPF Submission Number and click on **Proceed** to continue
6. On the top menu bar, click on **Employer services** and select **Enquiry on application submission status** under category "Past transactions"
7. Select √¢¬Ä¬úComposition Offer for Late Payment Offence√¢¬Ä¬ù and the date of transaction
8. Click √¢¬Ä¬úNext√¢¬Ä¬ù to proceed']

question: How does CPF Board calculate interest on late payment?
answer:
['The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Enforcement action would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date. The minimum interest payable is $5.
**Example**
XYZ Company made a CPF contribution of $3,000 for the month of October on 20 November . This payment is late by 19 days. Therefore, the amount of late payment interest will be:
= $3,000 x 1.5% x 19/30 (stop at the fourth decimal)\*
= $28.50
\*Number of days the payment is late/number of days in the month.
The final figure is to be rounded down to the nearest dollar, i.e. the cents should be dropped for the interest. Hence, the late payment interest payable will be $28.']

question: How much composition amount should I pay?
answer: ['The composition amount is indicated in the letter of offer/notice to attend court. Please refer to the√Ç¬†[**penalties that may be faced by employers who do not comply with the CPF Act**](/employer/compliance-and-rectifications/enforcement-and-penalties-for-non-compliance).']

question: I am unable to pay my outstanding CPF contributions/interest on late contributions for my employees now. Can I pay the composition amount first?
answer: ['You are required to pay all outstanding CPF contributions and interest on late contributions before the Board can accept payment of composition amount. For any clarification, please contact or email the case officer indicated in the Board's letter or Notice to Attend Court.']

question: My employee owes me money. Can I use the amount owed to me to offset the employer's share of CPF contributions that is payable on his wages?
answer: ['You are required to pay both the employer and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of CPF contributions based on the monthly wages payable to your employee at the prevailing CPF contribution rates.']

question: Can I agree to my employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs request not to be paid CPF contributions so that he can get higher take-home pay?
answer: ['You should not agree to your employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs request not to be paid CPF contributions so that he can get higher take-home pay. Failure to pay CPF contributions to an employee (i.e. Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident who is employed in Singapore under a contract of service) is an offence under the CPF Act.']

question: What is the purpose of the late payment interest?
answer: ['The late payment interest, subjected to a minimum amount of $5, serves to deter employers from paying CPF contributions late for their employees.']

question: What will happen if I pay late or do not pay CPF contributions for my employees?
answer: ['If we detect CPF non-compliance, which includes late payment and non-payment of CPF contributions, we will take enforcement actions to recover any CPF contributions owed to employees. We may charge late payment interest and impose composition amount on non-compliant employers. Please refer to the [Recovery Process](/content/dam/web/employer/compliance-and-rectifications/documents/Recovery_Process.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB).']

question: Why should I be jailed for non-payment of CPF contributions?
answer:
['CPF Board takes a serious view on employers who do not fulfil their CPF obligations to their employees. The jail term reflects the severity of CPF offences and serves as a strong deterrence to errant employers. It is also a reminder of the importance of employers√¢¬Ä¬ô legal obligation to pay CPF contributions correctly and promptly for their employees.
If we detect CPF non-compliance, which includes late payment and non-payment of CPF contributions, we will take enforcement actions to recover any CPF contributions owed to employees. We may charge late payment interest and impose composition amount on non-compliant employers.
If you fail to pay the CPF arrears, you will be taken to court. The court will order you to pay the contributions, interest as well as a court fine and/or be sentenced to imprisonment.
The penalties stipulated under the CPF Act for employers convicted of late payment offence are:
* Up to $5,000 court fine and no less than $1,000 per offence and/or up to 6 months√¢¬Ä¬ô imprisonment for first conviction
* Up to $10,000 court fine and no less than $2,000 per offence and/or up to 12 months√¢¬Ä¬ô imprisonment for subsequent convictions']

question: What should I do if I am unable to pay my employees their CPF contributions on time?
answer:
['It is the employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs obligation to ensure that CPF contributions are paid on time and to communicate the CPF contributions payment dates to your employees. Your employees have the right to check with you on the non-payment of their CPF contributions, including asking for an explanation and when you will be making payment. CPF contributions are important to employees for their housing, healthcare and retirement needs. Information on the payment date and amount of CPF contributions will help them to manage their financial needs and commitments.
If you are unable to pay your employees their CPF contributions on time, you have to ensure that the CPF arrears are paid as soon as possible and that the CPF contributions are accorded priority amongst the company√¢¬Ä¬ôs outstanding payments. You should also inform your employees beforehand the reasons for being late and when they can expect the payment.
CPF Board takes a serious view of employers who default on CPF contributions. The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. [Enforcement action](/employer/compliance-and-rectifications/enforcement-and-penalties-for-non-compliance) would be taken against employers who fail to pay by the 14th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday). This includes imposing late payment interest charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date.
Find out more√Ç¬†on your√Ç¬†obligations as an employer under the CPF Act and the Employment Act at the [Workright website](https://www.mom.gov.sg/employment-practices/employment-act/workright).']

question: I incurred late payment interest for my employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs late CPF contribution as he did not inform me of his Singapore Permanent Resident status. Can I recover the interest from him?
answer: ['The late payment interest is payable by the employer. It is an offence for employers to recover any sum in excess of the employee's share of CPF contributions from his wages.']

question: Why is composition amount imposed on employer?
answer:
['It is an offence under the CPF Act for late and/or non-payment of CPF contributions and late payment interest. The composition amount is offered to allow defaulting employers to settle their CPF offences out of court, after settling the CPF arrears.
Prosecution actions will be taken against employers who do not settle the CPF arrears and compound the offence out of court, before the deadline given.']

question: I have overpaid CPF contributions for my employees. Can I offset or adjust the excess amount paid to a future month?
answer:
['You may apply to the Board to adjust the excess CPF contributions paid to a later month if you have overpaid CPF contributions for your employees.
However, you cannot apply to adjust excess contributions paid to a future month when CPF contributions are not due nor payable yet. For illustration, please refer to the following table:
![Is month end adjustment allowable](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/compliance-and-rectifications/images/Month%20end%20Adj.jpeg)
You can submit an√Ç¬†[online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/AdjustmentOfCpfPayment/Home) for "Adjustment of CPF Payment" if you have a CPF Account number and CPF Submission Number (CSN).
Note: 1. Application for√Ç¬†the adjustment has to be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment. Otherwise, it will be deemed as properly paid and cannot be adjusted.
2. You have√Ç¬†to inform all employees affected by the adjustment.
3. Application√Ç¬†is subject to the availability of funds in the member's CPF account.
4. You will be notified by the Board after the adjustment has been processed.
5. The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Late payment interest will be charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date if employers fail to pay by the 14th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).']

question: How long does it take to adjust employer's CPF payment?
answer:
['Please refer to the table for our service standard for processing adjustment of employer√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF payment:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Service** | **Normal Processing√Ç¬†Time** |
| Adjustment of employer's CPF payment | 6 working days\* |
\* As we are currently experiencing high volume of applications, a longer processing time may be expected for your application(s). Once your application(s) have been successfully processed, we will notify you on the details of the adjustment.']

question: I have indicated the wrong relevant month/CPF Submission Number (CSN)/payment type in my CPF contribution. How can I request to make an adjustment?
answer:
['If there are errors in your CPF contributions, you can submit an√Ç¬†[**online application**](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/eSvc/Web/Schemes/AdjustmentOfCpfPayment/Home)√Ç¬†for "Adjustment of CPF Payment". You will need to have a√Ç¬†CPF Account number and CPF Submission Number (CSN).
Note:
1. Application for the adjustment has to be made immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment. Otherwise, it will be deemed as properly paid and cannot be adjusted.
2. You have to inform your employees who are affected by the adjustment.
3. Application is subject to the availability of funds in the member's CPF account.
4. You will be notified by the Board after the adjustment has been processed.
5. The due date for CPF contributions is on the last day of the calendar month. Late payment interest will be charged at 1.5% per month commencing from the first day after the due date if employers fail to make the payment by the 14th of the following month (or the next working day if the 14th falls on a Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday).']

question: If I have accidentally submitted the CPF contribution twice, what should I do?
answer: ['If you have accidentally submitted your CPF contribution twice, you can [apply for a full refund](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/faq/compliance-and-rectifications/applying-for-refund-of-cpf-contributions/can-i-request-for-a-full-refund-if-i-submitted-cpf-twice) of the wrong submission immediately and no later than one year from the date of payment.']

question: What is Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['Under the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme, a MediSave contribution is required as and when a self-employed person (SEP) earns a service payment. Every time a service fee is paid to the SEP, the corporate service buyers (CSBs) or intermediaries making the payment will first deduct and credit a portion of the service fee to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account, before paying the remainder of the service fee to the SEP.
CAYE does not change the amount of MediSave contributions SEP have to make based on their net trade income.
SEPs who provide services to government agencies are automatically enrolled into CAYE.']

question: Why did the Government introduce Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) enables self-employed persons (SEPs) to make small regular contributions as and when they earn income. This reduces the MediSave contributions they have to pay in the following year (after SEPs declare their net trade income and have their MediSave computed).
CAYE can also help SEPs grow their money as they can start to earn an interest of up to 5% on their MediSave savings earlier.']

question: Why is Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) only piloted on Government procurement entities?
answer: ['The Government, as a service buyer, has taken the lead to implement and pilot Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE). There are currently no plans to extend CAYE to the private sector.']

question: When are Government procurement entities required to implement Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Government procurement entities are required to implement Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) for payment of service fee to self-employed vendors. Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors covered under CAYE when they log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of their participation in CAYE via prompts.']

question: Under the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme, will corporate service buyers only be making MediSave contributions for self-employed vendors?
answer: ['Under the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) scheme, corporate service buyers do not need to make MediSave contributions for self-employed persons (SEPs) as SEPs are required to contribute to their MediSave Account.']

question: Are corporate service buyers required to make MediSave contributions under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) for vendors who are both an employee and self-employed person?
answer:
['Corporate service buyers are required to make MediSave contributions via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) for vendors who provide their services as self-employed persons, regardless of whether they are concurrently an employee.
If payment is made to the vendor√¢¬Ä¬ôs company (which hires the vendor as an employee), CAYE is not required. The vendor will continue to receive employee CPF contributions from his/her employer.']

question: Are all corporate service buyers required to participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['It is mandatory for all Government Procurement Entities (GPEs), including all Ministries, Departments, Organs of State and Statutory Boards as corporate service buyers, to participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE).']

question: What are corporate service buyers required to do under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Under Contribute-As-You-Earn, corporate service buyers are required to deduct and transmit a portion of the service fee to the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account, before paying the SEP the remainder of the service fee. This is done through either the bank or online submission modes.']

question: What are the payment modes available under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['Corporate service buyers (CSBs) can make Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions via two payment modes:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| Bank mode | * CSBs will pay the full service fee payment to CPF Board√¢¬Ä¬ôs appointed bank, OCBC, via GIRO Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA).
* OCBC will compute and pay the net service fee to the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account, and credit the required CAYE√Ç¬†contribution to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account.
|
| Online submission mode√Ç¬†via Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA) | * CSBs will log into the CAYE digital services using their Corppass and key in the service fee to be paid to the SEP.
* The CAYE digital services will indicate the CAYE contribution√Ç¬†required for each SEP.
* CSBs will only pay the CAYE contribution to SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account√Ç¬†via DDA.
* CSBs will pay the net service fee to SEP separately.
|']

question: What is the deadline to make Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer: ['Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions must be paid to the self-employed person (SEP) no later than the day that the service fee was paid to the SEP. For example, if you pay your SEP vendor his net service fee on 8 March 2023, you will need to pay his CAYE contributions by 8 March 2023.']

question: Is there a need to amend the conditions of contract for contracts signed before the inception of Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['As Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) is mandatory under the law, there is no need to amend the conditions of contract for contracts signed before the inception of CAYE. For new contracts signed moving forward, the Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board will work with the Ministry of Finance to inform new vendors of the CAYE requirements.']

question: What happens if corporate service buyers fail to pay the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer: ['Corporate service buyers (CSBs) are required to self-rectify if any non-compliance is detected. Please refer to the [Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) implementation guide](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/corporate-service-buyers/documents/CAYE%20Implementation%20Guide%20for%20CSB.pdf) issued by the CPF Board. CPF Board has conducted briefings to CSBs and will work closely with CSBs to ensure full adoption and compliance of CAYE.']

question: Which self-employed persons must participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Freelancers and sole-proprietors who are Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents and who have completed jobs/ projects with Government procurement entities as their service buyers, will automatically be enrolled onto Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE). Self-employed persons (SEPs) who logged on to Vendors@Gov will see pop-up prompts informing them of their CAYE requirements.']

question: Are companies who bid for jobs with corporate service buyers required to participate in Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), even if it is operated by a single person?
answer: ['Contribute-As-You-Earn is not applicable to companies registered under the Companies Act, based on Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority√¢¬Ä¬ôs (ACRA) definition.']

question: Will payments to sub-contractors be under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Contribute-As-You-Earn is not applicable to sub-contractors because they do not have a direct contractual relationship with corporate service buyer.']

question: Which payments are under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['All tax-liable payments to freelancers and sole proprietors are under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), except√Ç¬†[this list of payments](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/corporate-service-buyers/documents/Payments%20Excluded%20from%20CAYE.pdf).
These requirements will be communicated to corporate service buyers (CSBs) through legislation and implementation guides.
To facilitate the implementation of CAYE, Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors who are under CAYE when they log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of their obligation via prompts.
For invoices outside of Vendors@Gov, CSBs will need to identify self-employed persons covered under CAYE through:
1. the NRIC used by the vendor to transact, or
2. the Unique Entity Number (UEN) issued by ACRA. CSBs can use the Enterprise Data Hub (EDH) to check whether the vendor√¢¬Ä¬ôs business entity type is a sole-proprietorship or partnership.']

question: Are directors who receive director fees covered under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['No. Under the Income Tax Act, directors of companies are considered as √¢¬Ä¬úemployee√¢¬Ä¬ù for income tax purposes. Directors√¢¬Ä¬ô fees are therefore taxable as employment income and would not be covered under Contribute-As-You-Earn.']

question: Are small value payments exempted from Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['No, the payments from small value purchases are not exempted from Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE).
However, buy-and-claim purchases are exempted from CAYE. This is because such purchases are usually for goods or services that are very small in value which the staff is prepared to pay in advance and seek reimbursement thereafter.']

question: How will corporate service buyers know how much Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution to deduct from the service fee?
answer:
['The amount of Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution to be deducted from the service fee depends on the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs CAYE contribution rate. The SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs CAYE contribution rate is automatically computed by the CAYE system based on the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave contribution rate, estimated revenue and estimated expenses.
Under the bank mode, you only need to pay the entire service fee to the appointed bank, OCBC. OCBC will check with CPFB√¢¬Ä¬ôs CAYE system for the amount to be deducted and credited to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account (MA).
Under the online submission mode, you can key in the total service fee in the CAYE digital services, and the amount to be deducted and credited to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MA would then be provided. You can then proceed to pay the MediSave contributions through the CAYE digital services and the service fee amount directly to the SEP.
If an SEP queries about his/her CAYE contribution amount or rate, please direct the SEP to the CAYE digital services for SEPs where the SEP can log in to view his transaction details.']

question: What will be the applicable Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate used?
answer:
['Both the bank and online submission modes will use the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution rate applicable as at the date of submission for consistency. If the self-employed person logs in to the CAYE digital services to update his CAYE contribution rate, the rate will only be effective the next day.
Corporate service buyers using the online submission mode are to log in to the CAYE digital services to determine the CAYE contributions only when they are ready to transmit the service fee.']

question: How can corporate service buyers using the bank mode check the breakdown of the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee to the self-employed person?
answer:
['Corporate service buyers can view the status of the payment made and the amount split between the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee made to the self-employed person by:
1. Referring to the return file provided by the appointed bank, OCBC; or
2. Logging onto the CAYE online digital services with your Corppass ID and select View Transaction History > Transaction Type > Make CAYE Contributions.']

question: Under  Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), what happens if the self-employed person has contributed up to the maximum mandatory contributions for the year?
answer: ['There will be no further Contribute-As-You-Earn deduction and the full service fee will be paid to the self-employed person.']

question: Would Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) be applicable on invoices for goods provided by self-employed vendors?
answer: ['Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) will apply to all taxable revenue, including profits made on goods provided. To avoid over-collection of CAYE contributions, self-employed persons (SEPs) can log in to the CAYE digital services to adjust their estimated expenses to include the costs of goods. The SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs CAYE contribution rate will then be adjusted accordingly.']

question: For GST-registered sole proprietors, are the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions computed based on the full service fee, inclusive of GST?
answer: ['Yes, Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) will apply to the full amount of the service fee inclusive of GST. To avoid over-collection, self-employed persons can include the GST as part of their estimated expenses on the CAYE digital services.']

question: Are there any changes required to the corporate service buyer√¢¬Ä¬ôs payment system/process to reconcile the payments made via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['You may consider changing your payment system/ process to reconcile payments made via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), if necessary.
Generally, if you√¢¬Ä¬ôre using the bank mode, you will receive a return file from OCBC within three working days from the Funds Deduction Date stated in your bank file. The return file can be used to reconcile payment made to the self-employed persons (SEPs).
If you√¢¬Ä¬ôre using the online submission mode (DDA mode), you may download the CAYE payment file via the CAYE digital services to reconcile the payment made to the SEPs.']

question: For corporate service buyers who currently do not have an account with OCBC, are they required to open an account with the appointed bank, OCBC, if they wish to opt for bank mode payments?
answer: ['You do not need to have a bank account with OCBC for Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE). However, you'IIneed to obtain and complete a Host-to-Host (H2H) application form from OCBC to establish a H2H file transfer link-up with the bank.']

question: For corporate service buyers using OCBC accounts, is there still a need to set up a Direct Debit Authorisation arrangement with OCBC to facilitate the deduction of service fee for bank mode payments?
answer: ['You√¢¬Ä¬ôll need to sign up for GIRO with OCBC to authorise OCBC to deduct the full service fees from your agency√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank accounts for the purpose of Contribute-As-You-Earn.']

question: For bank mode payments, will there be any form of authorisation catered in the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) system to ensure that all payment instructions are verified?
answer: ['There will not be any form of authorisation catered in the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) system as the Host-to-Host (H2H) file transfer between corporate service buyers and the appointed bank, OCBC, is a fully automated process. The payment file will need to be authorised and encrypted before transmission to OCBC. To fulfil your agency√¢¬Ä¬ôs internal audit or compliance requirement, the authorisation needs to be completed before the file is transmitted to OCBC.']

question: For bank mode payments, when do corporate service buyers need to submit a payment file to OCBC to make Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions by the stipulated deadline?
answer:
['Corporate service buyers using the Contribute-As-You-Earn bank mode need to submit the payment file to OCBC at least four working days before the service fee payment due date (as agreed with the self-employed vendor) to ensure timely payment to the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Account.
*(Note: It will generally take an additional two working days if the net service fee payment to the SEP exceeds $200,000.)*']

question: How do corporate service buyers know if the payment to self-employed persons is successful?
answer:
['Generally, for payment via bank mode, you will receive a return file from OCBC within three working days of the Fund Deduction Date indicated in your payment file to the appointed bank, OCBC.√Ç¬†This return file will indicate the amount of Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions and net service fee, the payment status, and rejection reason (for any unsuccessful payment).
For payment via the online submission mode, you can log into the CAYE digital services to view the payment status and CAYE contributions made to the self-employed person.']

question: Under what scenarios will monies transmitted via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) bank mode be returned to the corporate service buyer?
answer:
['The full service fees transmitted via the Contribute-As-You-Earn bank mode will be returned to the corporate service buyer if:
1. the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account is closed or invalid;
2. the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs NRIC is invalid; or
3. the CPF submission number in the bank file is invalid.']

question: Would payments made via the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) online submission mode be debited from the corporate service buyers√¢¬Ä¬ô bank account?
answer: ['Yes, payments made via the Contribute-As-You-Earn online submission mode would be debited from the corporate service buyers√¢¬Ä¬ô bank account via direct debit.']

question: How do corporate service buyers identify if the vendor is under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer:
['For self-employed persons (SEPs) who submit e-invoices, Vendors@Gov will automatically identify vendors covered under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) who log in through Corppass or Singpass. These vendors will be notified of CAYE via prompts. The e-invoice file format will be modified to store two additional columns, CAYE indicator and SEPs√¢¬Ä¬ô NRIC, which will subsequently be loaded into NFS@Gov and interfaced to agencies.
For invoices outside of Vendors@Gov, corporate service buyers (CSBs) need to identify and tag SEPs manually via:
1. the NRIC used by the SEP to transact; or
2. the Unique Entity Number (UEN) issued by ACRA. CSBs can use the Enterprise Data Hub (EDH) to check whether the vendor√¢¬Ä¬ôs business entity type is a sole proprietorship or partnership. If it is a sole proprietorship, CAYE will apply.']

question: Do corporate service buyers with existing CPF Submission Number (CSN) for making CPF contributions to employees need to register for a Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) CSN?
answer: ['Corporate service buyers (CSBs) with existing CPF Submission Number (CSN) are required to register for a Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) CSN for CAYE transactions. This is because the existing CSN that CSBs have is only for the purpose of making CPF contributions to employees. A CAYE CSN will enable self-employed persons (SEPs) to identify CSBs who made CAYE contributions on their behalf. The CSN for employee transactions cannot be used for CAYE transactions, and vice versa. CSBs who need to apply for a CAYE CSN may do so via√Ç¬†[CAYE digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/caye/company/).']

question: With the additional step to split the service fee under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), would this result in a delayed payment of service fee that may exceed the credit terms?
answer:
['If you√¢¬Ä¬ôre paying via the bank mode for Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), please submit the payment file to OCBC at least four working days before the service fee is due, to ensure timely payment. This is because the earliest date of deduction that you can select will be one working day from the date of file transmission to OCBC.√Ç¬†Thereafter, it will generally take two working days for the CAYE contribution to be deposited into the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account. This timeframe includes one working day for crediting the net service fee to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account and another one working day to credit the CAYE contribution to the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account.
*(Note: An additional two working days will be required if the net service fee payment to the SEP exceeds $200,000.)*
Please refer to this [document](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/corporate-service-buyers/documents/CAYE%20Bank%20mode%20illustration.pdf) for the illustration of the bank mode process.
If you are using the online submission mode (DDA mode) to make payments, please log into the CAYE digital services at least four working days before the service fee is due to ensure timely payment. This is because the earliest deduction date that you can select will be two working days later (if the submission was made before 5pm). Payment to SEP will generally take up to two working days from the date of deduction.
Please refer to this [document](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/corporate-service-buyers/documents/Illustration%20process%20for%20CAYE%20digital%20submission%20Mode.pdf) for the illustration of the digital submission mode process.']

question: Do corporate service buyers need to factor in an approving authority to ensure accuracy of records submitted under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE)?
answer: ['Under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), corporate service buyers are advised to factor in an approving authority within their internal processes before making payment to ensure accuracy of records submitted (i.e. no fraudulent transactions, no error in payment amount or self-employed person to be paid). Once submitted, CAYE payments are considered correctly paid.']

question: Does CPF Board accept credit notes to offset future payments if there have been erroneous payment of Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer: ['CPF Board does not accept credit notes for the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions. If the corporate service buyer (CSB) has made an erroneous payment, the CSB can request a refund of the CAYE contribution from CPF Board within one year from the time the contribution was credited into the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account. The CSB will have to seek a refund of the remaining service fee made from the SEP directly and re-transmit the CAYE contributions.']

question: What if the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution was paid in error (i.e. paid wrong amount, or paid to the wrong self-employed person)?
answer: ['Corporate service buyers (CSBs) can request a refund of the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution from CPF Board within one year from the time the contribution was credited into the self-employed person√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account. After receiving a refund of the CAYE contribution paid in error, the CSB will be required to re-submit the correct CAYE contribution via the CAYE digital services.']

question: Can corporate service buyers recover the overpaid Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions due to overpayment of full service fee?
answer:
['If there is over-payment, corporate service buyers (CSBs) can request a full refund of the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions from CPF Board within one year from the time the contribution was credited into the self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave account (MA). The CSB will have to seek a refund of the remaining service fee made from the SEP directly. After receiving a refund of the CAYE contribution paid wrongly, the CSB will be required to re-submit the correct CAYE contribution via the CAYE digital services.
Example:
CSB A paid Mr Tan, their SEP vendor, a service fee of $120 through the bank mode. The bank deducted and paid $12 to Mr Tan√¢¬Ä¬ôs MA and the net service fee of $108 to Mr Tan√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account. However, CSB A subsequently realised that the correct service fee amount agreed upon by both parties was $100. CSB A should:
1. Put in a request on the CAYE digital services for a refund of the CAYE contribution ($12) by selecting the transaction that was made in error (e.g. based on Mr Tan√¢¬Ä¬ôs NRIC and the payment reference number) and providing the relevant supporting documents.
2. Seek the remaining $108 from Mr Tan directly.
3. Submit another CAYE contribution transaction for Mr Tan based on the correct gross service fee of $100.']

question: What happens if payment to the self-employed person via the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) bank mode is unsuccessful?
answer: ['For unsuccessful payments made via the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) bank mode (e.g. due to invalid bank account number or invalid NRIC provided), the full service fee will be returned to the corporate service buyer√¢¬Ä¬ôs bank account via FAST.√Ç¬†It will generally take an additional two working days if the full service fee exceeds S$200,000.']

question: What happens if the corporate service buyer provided an invalid NRIC for crediting of the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contributions?
answer:
['Under Contribute-As-You-Earn, if the NRIC provided is invalid, you will be prompted to amend the NRIC if you are using the online submission mode. If you are using the bank mode, you√¢¬Ä¬ôll automatically receive a refund for that record.
If the NRIC provided is valid, but not tied to any individual, CPF Board will contact you to submit a refund request.']

question: Under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), what happens if the self-employed person is not registered on Vendors@Gov?
answer: ['Corporate service buyers should ask the self-employed person to register at Vendors@Gov so that they are able to submit an e-invoice for the purpose of Contribute-As-You-Earn.']

question: Under Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE), what should corporate service buyers do to set-off monies from an upcoming payment?
answer: ['To set-off monies (e.g. due to over-payment, or excess non-revenue payment made earlier) from an upcoming payment, corporate service buyers (CSBs) need to make the transaction via the Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) online submission mode. This means that CSBs need to key in the full service fee payable to derive the MediSave payable via CAYE, and thereafter set-off any monies from the net service fee payable to the self-employed person.']

question: What happens if the amount of MediSave contributions the self-employed person has made via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) is lower than his MediSave payable for the year?
answer:
['The self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave payable for income earned in the year will be computed after the SEP has declared his actual income in the following year.
If the SEP√¢¬Ä¬ôs total Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) contribution is lower than his MediSave payable for the latest year, he will be required to top up the shortfall.
| | | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Example:Sam has made a total contribution of $2,100 via CAYE in 2023. The following year, Sam is informed that his MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $3,000. Sam will have to top-up the shortfall of $900.This example is illustrated within the table below:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Estimated 2023 NTI** | $21,000 |
| **CAYE contributions in 2023** | $2,100 |
| *(After 2023 NTI declaration)* |
| **Declared 2023 NTI** | $30,000 |
| **MediSave payable for work done in 2023** | $3,000 |
| **Shortfall Sam has to top up** | $900(i.e. $3,000 - $2,100) |
|']

question: What happens if the amount of MediSave contributions the self-employed person has made via Contribute-As-You-Earn (CAYE) is higher than his MediSave payable for the year?
answer:
['The self-employed person (SEP)√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave payable for income earned in the year will be computed after the SEP has declared his actual income in the following year.
If the self-employed person (SEP) has outstanding MediSave payable from previous years, his excess CAYE contributions will be used to offset those payables1. Any excess thereafter will be refunded to him. He can also choose to retain the excess CAYE contributions in his MediSave Account (MA).
| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Example:Based on his estimated income of $22,000 for 2023, Sam contributed $2,200 via CAYE. In the following year, he declared that he earned a lower Net Trade Income of $19,000 for 2023. As such, Sam√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave payable for his work done in 2023 is $1,900. Hence, he has excess CAYE contributions of $300 for the year. Sam also has an outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022 which would be offset by the excess CAYE contributions, leaving a final excess amount of $200. This amount will be refunded to him2. He can also choose to keep this $200 in his MA.This example is illustrated within the table below:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Estimated 2023 NTI** | $22,000 |
| **CAYE contributions in 2023** | $2,200 |
| *(After 2023 NTI declaration)* | |
| **Declared 2023 NTI** | $19,000 |
| **MediSave payable for work done in 2023** | $1,900 |
| **Outstanding MediSave payable for 2022** | $100 |
| **Amount Sam will receive as a refund** | $200(i.e. $2,200 - $1,900 - $100) |
|
1This will take effect for CAYE contributions made from 2023. The SEP may [write to us](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous) if he does not wish to use his CAYE contributions to offset his outstanding MediSave payable from previous years.
2Sam may also choose not to use his CAYE contributions to offset his outstanding MediSave payable of $100 incurred in 2022. In this case, he will be refunded $300 instead.']

question: Do I have to inform my employees if I wish to make Voluntary Contributions (VC) for them?
answer: ['It is good practice to inform your employees if you wish to make Voluntary Contributions (VC) for them. This will help your employees take into account any VC made by you if they are also making VC on their own.']

question: What are the applicable limits if I wish to make Voluntary Contributions (VC) for my employees?
answer:
['You can make three types of Voluntary Contributions (VC) for your employees:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Type of VC** | **VC Limit** |
| i) Cash top-ups to your employee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô Special or Retirement Account | For members below 55: up till the current Full Retirement Sum (FRS)For members 55 and above: up till the current Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)[Learn more](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/faq/growing-your-savings/retirement-sum-topping-up-scheme/how-much-tax-relief-can-i-enjoy) about how you can earn tax deductions for cash top-ups made on your employee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô behalf. |
| ii) VC to your employee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô three CPF Accounts | Up to the CPF Annual Limit ($37,740 per employee per year) less the mandatory contributions received by the employee for the calendar year.Backdating of VC to an earlier date is not allowed. Do consider the mandatory CPF contributions you will be making for your employee, before making VC. If the total mandatory CPF contributions and VC received by the employee exceeds the CPF Annual Limit in the calendar year, VC in excess of the CPF Annual Limit will be refunded without interest. |
| iii) VC to your employee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô MediSave Account only under the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme (AMCS). | Up to $2,730 per employee per year. Any VC in excess of this limit will be refunded without interest to the employer in the following year.Backdating of VC to an earlier date is not allowed. AMCS contributions are not subject to the CPF Annual Limit and the employee(s)√¢¬Ä¬ô Basic Healthcare Sum (BHS). |
| | |']

question: What are the types of Voluntary Contributions (VC) I can make for my employees?
answer:
['You can make Voluntary Contributions (VC) to:
1. Your employee(s)' Special /Retirement Account only under the [Retirement Sum Topping Up Scheme (RSTU)](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-to-enjoy-higher-retirement-payouts/top-ups-for-loved-ones-employees-and-others) (tax relief available to both employer and employee).
2. Your employee(s)' three CPF accounts (no tax relief given for both employer and employee).*#*
3. Your employee(s)' MediSave Account via the Additional MediSave Contribution Scheme (AMCS) (tax free for employees and tax benefits available to employers).*#*
Please note that your employees must be Singapore Citizens or Singapore Permanent Residents only.
*#* The VC made will be treated as the current month's contribution. Backdating of VC to an earlier date is not allowed.
You can [find out more](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/making-voluntary-contributions) on the types of VC you can make for your employees.']

question: Do I need to take into account the employer and employee's CPF contribution rates when making Voluntary Contributions (VC) for my employees?
answer:
['You do not need to take into account the employer and employee√¢¬Ä¬ôs CPF contribution rates when making Voluntary Contributions (VC) for your employees.
However, you will need a different CPF Submission No. (CSN) to make voluntary contributions for your employees. You should not use your existing CSN for mandatory CPF contributions to make your VC.
Find out more on how you can [make voluntary contributions](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/employer/making-voluntary-contributions) for your employees.']

question: CPF Board encourages retirement savings but a limit was set for the contributions. Why is that so?
answer: ['There is a limit set as the CPF system is generally meant to cater to the needs of up to 80th percentile of workers in Singapore. Higher income earners would have other means to supplement their retirement income.']

question: Why are Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps reduced for CPF Investment Scheme funds?
answer: ['The purpose of CPF Investment Scheme is to provide alternative investment to help CPF members build up their retirement savings. As expenses of investment have a significant impact on returns, a regular review of the Total Expense Ratio (TER)√Ç¬†caps is important as high expense ratio would erode investment returns for CPF members. Where feasible, TER caps should be kept low to increase the fund√¢¬Ä¬ôs per-unit net asset value and enable CPF members to accumulate their retirement savings faster. This is in line with the efforts by regulatory authorities in other countries to reduce the cost of funds to investors.']

question: What actions should Fund Management Companies/insurers take if their existing CPF Investment Scheme List A funds are unable to comply with the Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
answer: ['Fund Management Companies (FMCs)/insurers have undertaken to comply with the Total Expense Ratio (TER)√Ç¬†caps for funds included under CPF Investment Scheme. If their List A funds are not able to comply with the new TER caps from 2016, **FMCs/insurers will be required to compensate the funds for the difference between the actual expense ratios and the new TER caps**. The funds would then be downgraded to List B with effect from the implementation date (see *[relevant reporting period](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RelevantReportingPeriod.pdf)*, (PDF, 0.1MB)). Under List B, funds are not allowed to take in new CPF monies.']

question: Do Fund Management Companies/insurers need to submit a new undertaking in view of the new Total Expense Ratio caps?
answer: ['There is no need to√Ç¬†submit a new undertaking. The previous undertaking continues to be valid for existing List A funds under CPF Investment Scheme.']

question: Can a fund downgraded to List B resume accepting CPF monies once the fund's Total Expense Ratio meets the cap subsequently?
answer: ['The fund would be upgraded to List A, and can take in CPF monies if its audited Total Expense Ratio meets the cap subsequently.']

question: How frequent will CPF Board assess whether a fund can or cannot take in CPF monies?
answer: ['CPF Board will assess whenever a fund√¢¬Ä¬ôs audited financial statements become available (i.e. yearly basis for most funds). A company that wishes to have its fund assessed more frequently may submit to CPF Board the fund√¢¬Ä¬ôs semi-annual audited financial statements according to its accounting period. The company must ensure that all subsequent published Total Expense Ratios (TERs)√Ç¬†of its funds are also in line with the TER cap.']

question: Will a fund be excluded from CPF Investment Scheme due to not meeting the Total Expense Ratio cap subsequent to the inclusion?
answer: ['The fund will remain under CPF Investment Scheme (as List B fund) but it will not be allowed to take in CPF new monies. However, the company will have to provide the fund√¢¬Ä¬ôs investors with options to hold, redeem or make free switches within 3 months from informing the CPF Board of not meeting Total Expense Ratio caps.']

question: Can my company apply for the new fund to be included under the CPF Investment Scheme if its last audited Total Expense Ratio (TER) does not meet the TER cap?
answer:
['Your company can apply to√Ç¬†include√Ç¬†the fund under List A if it undertakes to cap the TER of the fund with effect from the date it is launched for CPF subscription. The Letter of undertaking is attached below:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| √¢¬Ä¬ãFMCs | √¢¬Ä¬ãInsurers |
| [UT Inclusion of new fund under List A](/content/dam/web/member/faq/business-partners/documents/UT_Inclusion_of_new_fund_under_ListA.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB) | √¢¬Ä¬ã[ILP Inclusion of new fund under List A](/content/dam/web/member/faq/business-partners/documents/ILP_Inclusion_of_new_fund_under_ListA.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB) |']

question: What is the relevant reporting period (of audited expense ratio) that fund managers are required to submit?
answer:
['For existing CPF Investment Scheme√Ç¬†funds, the new Total Expense Ratio (TER)√Ç¬†caps will take effect from 1 Jan 2016. **As such, the compliance with the new TER caps for each fund will be based on the audited report for the financial year of the fund ended in a month in 2016**. The implementation date for the new TER cap for a fund will be one day after the deadline of submission of the audited report for the fund.
The Board encourages Fund Management Companies (FMCs)/Insurers to assess early whether their funds can meet the new TER caps. If their funds cannot meet the new TER caps, FMCs/ Insurers should inform the Board early.
However, FMCs/Insurers must factor in the period required for settling the purchase transactions and thus the last purchase date must be at least five working days before the implementation date. This means that after the last purchase date, if a CPF member buys a fund that does not meet the TER cap, FMCs/ Insurers should not channel the subscriptions into that fund. If the funds cannot meet the TER cap, FMCs/ Insurers should communicate the consequence clearly to their unitholders/ policyholders, **before** the last purchase date. Please refer to the [relevant reporting period](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RelevantReportingPeriod.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.1MB) for details.']

question: What are the new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps?
answer:
['The new Total Expense Ratio1 (TER) caps are as follows:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Risk Categories** | **New TER Caps (%)** |
| Higher Risk | 1.75 |
| Medium to High Risk | 1.55 |
| Low to Medium Risk | 0.95 |
| Lower Risk | 0.35 |
For CPF Investment Scheme List A funds, fund managers/insurers are not allowed to charge expenses more than the TER caps.
1 Guidelines on the computation of expense ratio can be found in the [Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS) website](http://www.imas.org.sg/uploads/media/2012/10/25/19_200505_-_IMAS_Revised_Guidelines_on_Expense_Ratio.pdf).']

question: How are the new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps determined?
answer: ['The new Total Expense Ratio (TER) caps are determined based on the FY2012 **median** TERs (for the relevant risk categories) of CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) List A funds, and taking into account industry feedback. Median TERs were also used in 2008 when CPF Board first implemented TER caps for funds under the CPFIS.']

question: What are the admission criteria that fund management companies (FMCs) and insurance companies need to meet, in order to be included under CPFIS?
answer: ['Please see the admission criteria for√Ç¬†[fund management companies (FMCs)](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/CRITERIAFORFUNDMANAGEMENTCOMPANIES.pdf) and [insurance companies](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/CRITERIAFORINSURERSTOBEINCLUDEDUNDERCPFIS.pdf).']

question: What does the Board's investment consultant look for when evaluating fund management companies (FMCs), insurance companies or their products?
answer: ['Please see the [evaluation criteria](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/EVALUATIONCRITERIAFORPROSPECTIVEFUNDMANAGEMENTCOMPANIESFORINCLUSIONUNDERTHECPFIS.pdf) provided by the Board's investment consultant.']

question: What are the CPFIS admission criteria for funds?
answer: ['You can refer to para 5 for the [admission criteria for funds](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/APPLICATIONANDADMISSIONCRITERIAFORFUNDSMANAGEDBYFMC.pdf).']

question: I submitted reimbursements via E-File today. I realised there was a mistake in my submission only after I submitted the excel file. What should I do?
answer:
['You can override your previous submission as long as it is done within the same day and before 5:30 pm. To do so, just resubmit the original file with the necessary amendments.
If you detected the error late, please email med\_refd@cpf.gov.sg for assistance.']

question: I was notified by the Medical Institution that my employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs medical bill was cancelled or amended. I would like to make amendments to the reimbursement I made previously. What should I do?
answer: ['Please email the details to med\_refd@cpf.gov.sg for assistance.']

question: If my employee/insured has used his/her MediSave and/or MediShield Life for medical expenses, do I need to reimburse my employee/insured?
answer: ['As an employer/ insurer, you are required to reimburse your employee/insured's MediSave and/or MediShield Life if you have the contractual obligation to provide for their medical expenses.']

question: What are the benefits of Internet Reimbursement?
answer:
['The Internet Reimbursement (IR) service allows you to submit MediSave/MediShield Life reimbursements for your employees/insured easily at your convenience. Benefits of our IR service include:
* **F**ast service turnaround time
* **A**ccurate reimbursements
* **S**treamlined processes
* **T**rack status of reimbursements online']

question: Apart from Internet Reimbursement service, are there other ways of submitting MediSave/MediShield Life reimbursements?
answer:
['As part of our efforts to go green and support the Smart Nation initiative, we only accept submissions via our Internet Reimbursement (IR) service.
If you are facing difficulties in submitting reimbursements via the IR service, please email med\_refd@cpf.gov.sg.']

question: Will I be notified on the status of my registration for MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement (IR)?
answer:
['Registration for MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement will only be processed after we have received both the registration form and Direct Debit Authorisation (DDA) form. We will notify you after the successful registration of your application.
You will be notified by the bank once they have approved your DDA form. This usually takes four to six weeks. Once your DDA is approved, you can submit reimbursements online.']

question: In what order should I reimburse my employee/insured if he/she has paid for his/her medical expenses using cash, MediSave and MediShield Life?
answer:
['Subjected to the contractual obligations, the order you are required to reimburse your employee/insured is as follows:
1. Amount√Ç¬†paid in cash
2. Amount√Ç¬†utilised from your employee's/insured's MediSave
3. Amount√Ç¬†utilised from your employee's/insured's MediSave-approved Integrated Shield Plan or MediShield Life
Reimbursing your employee/insured in this order minimises his/her cash outlay, and preserves his/her MediSave for future use.']

question: Can I reimburse my employee/insured in cash for a medical bill that was paid by his/her MediSave or MediShield Life?
answer: ['You cannot reimburse your employee/insured in cash if the medical bill was paid using his/her MediSave or MediShield Life. You must reimburse the respective utilised amount back to the employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave or MediShield Life.']

question: How many reimbursements can I submit via E-File at one time?
answer:
['You can submit up to 15,000 reimbursements at one time via E-File.
Please note that all 15,000 reimbursements should be submitted in one excel file.']

question: I realised that I had sent in multiple submissions of the same reimbursement via E-File. What should I do?
answer: ['If you have accidentally submitted duplicate reimbursements, please email med\_refd@cpf.gov.sg for assistance.']

question: Do I need to reimburse my employee/insured's MediSave/MediShield Life within a specific time period?
answer: ['We strongly encourage you to reimburse your employee/insured on a timely basis, which would be helpful to them, especially if they need their MediSave/MediShield Life for further treatments.']

question: Are there any charges for the MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement (IR) service?
answer: ['The MediSave/MediShield Life IR service is free.']

question: While filling the Internet Reimbursement (IR) registration form, I noticed that I will need to include a CPF Submission Number. What is a CPF Submission Number (CSN)?
answer:
['The CSN is a unique 15-digit alpha-numeric reference number provided by the Board to a registered company for the submission of employer contributions. It comprises your company's Unique Entity Number (UEN) and CPF Payment Code.
If you are unsure of your company's CSN, please approach your HR department for assistance.']

question: Why is there a need to fill in the policy number and claim number of my employee/insured in the E-File excel file for the MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement?
answer: ['The policy number and claim number fields were added in response to companies√¢¬Ä¬ô requests to track their MediSave/MediShield Life Internet Reimbursement submissions and correlate with their records. These twofields are not compulsory.']

question: My reimbursement submission via E-File is unsuccessful, and I was provided with a rejection reason. How should I correct my submission?
answer: ['You may refer to this [file](/content/dam/web/employer/faq/business-partners/documents/Rejection%20Reason.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.5MB)√Ç¬†for the list of rejection reasons and the corresponding actions before you resubmit.']

question: I noticed that I need to fill in the Hospital Registration Number (HRN) for the submission of reimbursement via E-File. How do I obtain the HRN?
answer:
['The HRN can be found in:
a. Your employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs final medical bill
b. Your employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs Healthcare payments and claims statement
c. Your employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave Transaction Statement
Please refer to this [guide](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/where-to-obtain-the-hospital-registration-number-hrn.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.5MB)√Ç¬†for more information on where you can find the HRN.']

question: How do I know if my reimbursement submission via E-File is successful?
answer:
['You can check the status of your submission via the below reports, by logging in to our Internet Reimbursement service using your Singpass:
| | |
| --- | --- |
| **Report Title** | **You will receive the reports by** |
| Successful | 5th working day after submission |
| Unsuccessful (After deduction) |
| Unsucessful (Before deduction) | Next working day after submission |
Please note:
* No reports will be generated if the submission file is not submitted successfully.
* Submissions√Ç¬†on weekends will be considered to have been submitted on the following Monday.
* The√Ç¬†daily cut-off time for reimbursement submissions is at 5.30pm on each working day. If you send in your submission after the cut-off time, it will be considered to have been submitted on the next working day.
Please refer to this [guide](/content/dam/web/member/healthcare/documents/How%20to%20retrieve%20online%20reports%20to%20check%20on%20the%20status%20of%20my%20E-File%20reimbursement%20submissions.pdf)√Ç¬†(PDF, 0.5MB)√Ç¬†for more information on how to retrieve and read the reports.']

question: I need to submit a reimbursement to my employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs MediSave and/or MediShield Life. How do I go about doing it?
answer:
['You can submit MediSave/MediShield Life reimbursements to your employees/insured quickly and easily via CPF√¢¬Ä¬ôs online reimbursement system, also known as Internet Reimbursement (IR) service.
Find out how you can [submit a reimbursement via IR](/employer/services-for-business-partners/medisave-medishield-life-reimbursements).']

question: Do I need to attach the employee/insured√¢¬Ä¬ôs hardcopy healthcare payments and claims statement for the submission of MediSave/MediShield Life reimbursement?
answer:
['CPF Board does not require any documents√Ç¬†from employers/insurers to process the MediSave/MediShield Life reimbursement.
You should not request for hardcopy healthcare payments and claims statement from your employee/insured. Employers/insurers should accept digital copy of the healthcare payments and claims statement from your employee/insured if it is required.']

question: Will taxi principal hirers who participate in the Drive and Save (DAS) scheme have their Taxi Vocational Licence (TDVL) be automatically renewed?
answer:
['Taxi Driver Vocational Licence (TDVL) will not be automatically renewed.
Taxi principal hirers must have fully paid their MediSave payable or are making monthly payments via GIRO to renew their TDVLs.
MediSave contributions and the co-contributions from taxi operators will go towards meeting their self-employed MediSave payable.']

question: Can taxi principal hirers who are not liable to make a MediSave contribution qualify for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution from their taxi operators?
answer:
['Taxi principal hirers who do not have outstanding MediSave payable can still receive Drive and Save co-contributions if they make:
* A voluntary contribution of at least $20 to their MediSave Account monthly, or
* A lump sum MediSave contribution of at least $240 in the past 12 months.']

question: How does each taxi operator know the Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution amount?
answer: ['Every month, the taxi operators will upload a list of hirers with their eligibility tags to CPF Board. CPF Board will then inform the participating taxi operators of the details of taxi principal hirers who have made sufficient MediSave contributions to qualify for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contributions. Exact contribution amounts will not be revealed.']

question: What sources of MediSave contributions are eligible for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution?
answer: ['MediSave contributions made by the taxi principal hirer as a self-employed person will qualify him for Drive and Save (DAS) co-contribution. CPF contributions received as an employee (from both employer and self) for taxi principal hirers who are concurrently employed, as well as government top-ups are excluded.']

question: Who is eligible for the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: ['Under the Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme, all taxi principal hirers who make regular contributions to their MediSave Account are eligible to receive co-contributions from participating taxi operators.']

question: What is Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme?
answer: ['The Drive and Save (DAS) Scheme is a tripartite co-contribution scheme initiated by the National Taxi Association (NTA) and the taxi industry, and supported by Ministry of Manpower and CPF Board. DAS aims to enhance the welfare of all taxi principal hirers.']

question: How can I withdraw my CPF savings?
answer: ['You can apply for withdrawal of your CPF savings from 55 by submitting an [online application](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/tools-and-services/forms-e-applications/withdraw-cpf-retirement-needs).']

question: What is PayNow QR?
answer:
['PayNow QR is a collection mode that offers an easier and faster avenue for customers to make payments to entities by scanning a QR code, via existing mobile banking applications.
It is available to customers of the following participating banks in Singapore: Citibank Singapore Limited, DBS Bank/POSB, HSBC, Maybank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, United Overseas Bank, Bank of China, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited
It adopts the same high security standards adopted by the Singapore banking industry for fund transfers including FAST and GIRO.']

question: Why am I not eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme if I have more than the current Basic Retirement Sum?
answer: ['The aim of the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is to help older Singaporeans who have lower retirement savings to save more and boost their retirement payouts.']

question: How much CPF savings can I invest?
answer:
['You can find out how much CPF savings you can invest by logging in to *[my cpf digital services](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/ds/dashboards/investment)*√Ç¬†with your Singpass > Select *my cpf* > My dashboards > Investment. You can also refer to the√Ç¬†[list of instruments available for investment under the CPF Investment Scheme](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_InstrumentsunderCPFIS.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB) to learn about the instruments that you can invest in.
The first $60,000 of your combined CPF accounts earns extra interest. To enable members to earn extra interest, only monies in excess of $20,000 in your Ordinary Account and $40,000 in your Special Account can be invested.
Details on the instruments included under the CPF Investment Scheme
You can refer to [Annex A](/content/dam/web/member/faq/documents/INV_AnnexA.pdf) (PDF, 48KB) for more details on the instruments included under the CPF Investment Scheme.
You may wish to refer to the risk classification tables for [unit trusts](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSUT.pdf) (PDF, 0.1MB), [investment-linked insurance products](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSILP1.pdf) (PDF, 0.2MB) and [exchange traded funds](/content/dam/web/member/business-partners/documents/RCSETF.pdf) (PDF, 40KB) which CPF monies can be invested in.']

question: What is net trade income?
answer: ['Net trade income is your gross trade income minus all allowable business expenses, capital allowances and trade losses as determined by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS).']

question: I heard from my healthcare provider that MediSave can no longer be used for package claims. If I had used my MediSave to pay for a package treatment before June 2018, can I still use my package at the clinic for subsequent treatments as my package is valid for 1 year?
answer: ['You may continue to use your package at the clinic, which is valid for up to 1 year from the initial visit date, if the package claim was made before June 2018.']

question: Does the Cancer Drug List also apply to inpatient cancer drug treatments under MediShield Life and MediSave?
answer: ['Currently, the Cancer Drug List does not apply to inpatient cancer drug treatments as these are covered separately under the inpatient claim limits for MediShield Life and MediSave, together with other costs incurred during the inpatient stay.']

question: What is CPF nomination?
answer: ['A CPF nomination allows you to specify who will receive your CPF savings and the proportion of your savings each nominee will receive when you pass away. Your nominee(s) will receive your CPF savings in cash.']

question: I do not have a Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS) cover. Do I need to declare my health to be insured under DPS?
answer:
['Yes, the eligibility for a DPS cover is subject to you being in good health when your policy commences.
As with any life insurance, DPS cover may be deferred or declined if a member has any serious pre-existing illnesses before policy commencement. This is to ensure that the scheme remains viable and the premiums are kept affordable for all insured members.']

question: My family member has passed on. How do I check if he was covered under the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme?
answer:
['To check if your family member was covered under the Dependants√¢¬Ä¬ô Protection Scheme (DPS), you may contact the appointed DPS insurer, Great Eastern Life.
Great Eastern Life can be contacted at:
| | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Address | : | The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited1 Pickering Street, #01-01Great Eastern CentreSingapore 048659 |
| Website | : | [www.greateasternlife.com/DPS](http://www.greateasternlife.com/DPS) |
