['[Top-ups to your retirement savings](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/member/growing-your-savings/saving-more-with-cpf/top-up-to-enjoy-higher-retirement-payouts)√Ç¬†and accrued interest are meant to build up your retirement savings and boost your retirement payouts. Hence, they cannot be withdrawn as cash in a lump sum or used for other purposes.
In addition to earning risk-free interest rates on your top-ups, you might have also benefited from tax relief. Allowing withdrawals of the top-ups and the accrued interest would defeat the purpose of the scheme and the incentives given.']

question: What happens to my CPF LIFE plan if my application to withdraw all my retirement savings using my pension/annuity is approved?
answer:
['If your application to withdraw all your retirement savings using your pension/annuity is approved, you can decide whether to:
i. terminate your CPF LIFE plan and receive a refund of the premium balance (if applicable); or
ii. keep your CPF LIFE plan and receive monthly payouts for as long as you live.']

question: What should I do if I can√¢¬Ä¬ôt connect to the CPFV app?
answer:
['You can try the following methods:
* Check that your internet connection is stable
* Relaunch the CPFV app and try to login again
* Make sure your device operating system and CPFV app are updated to the latest version
* Restart your mobile device
* Delete and reinstall the CPFV app']

question: Why am I not allowed to do a CPF transfer to my extended family members (e.g. uncles/aunts/cousins)?
answer: ['The CPF system is meant to provide for and safeguard your individual retirement adequacy. Hence we must be careful when considering allowing CPF transfers to extended family members, beyond immediate family members such as your parents, spouse and siblings. Meanwhile, you can consider using cash to top up to your extended family member's CPF account instead.']

question: Is there a limit to the number of nominees I can appoint?
answer:
['There is no limit to the number of nominees you can appoint.
If you are nominating up to 15 nominees, you can submit an online application. If you are nominating more than 15 nominees, please visit our CPF Service Centre to make a nomination.']

question: Who is eligible to make a nomination online?
answer: ['CPF members who are aged 16 and above, and have a valid Singpass, are eligible to make a nomination online.']

question: How will I be kept informed on my Home Protection Scheme cover details?
answer:
['We will send you a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) certificate generally within one to two weeks after your HPS cover has commenced and the premium paid.
The HPS certificate will include details such as the sum assured you are insured for, your share of cover, the policy commencement and expiry date, the address of the insured flat and your annual premium.']

question: Can I terminate my standing instruction to use my CPF Ordinary Account savings to pay for my co-owner√¢¬Ä¬ôs Home Protection Scheme premiums?
answer: ['If you wish to revoke your standing instruction to use your CPF Ordinary Account savings to pay your co-owner√¢¬Ä¬ôs Home Protection Scheme premium shortfall, please [write to us](https://cpf.gov.sg/writetous).']

question: How do I delete my account on the CPFV app?
answer:
['You can delete your account by following these steps:
1. Navigate to your account under your profile and tap on "Delete Account"
![](/content/dam/web/member/infohub/images-2/CPFV%20user%20account%20deletion%201.png)
2. Complete the exit feedback form
![](/content/dam/web/member/infohub/images-2/CPFV%20user%20account%20deletion%202.png)
3. Confirm that you would like to exit and delete your CPFV account. Note that account deletion is immediate and irreversible.
![](/content/dam/web/member/infohub/images-2/CPFV%20user%20account%20deletion%203.png)
4.√Ç¬†You will receive a confirmation that your CPFV account has been deleted successfully
![](/content/dam/web/member/infohub/images-2/CPFV%20user%20account%20deletion%204.png)']

question: I have applied to purchase Treasury Bills (T-bills) at primary auction under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS). When would my CPF savings be deducted for the purchase?
answer: ['Your CPF savings for T-bills purchase under CPFIS would be deducted only upon the successful allotment of the T-bills. In so doing, CPF members will continue earning CPF interest on their CPF savings, in case full or part of their T-bills application is unsuccessful. The deductions are done after the auction date (i.e. the date where the allotment of your T-bills purchase has been finalised) but before the issue date of the T-bills.']

question: I am currently under CPF LIFE and have deferred my monthly payouts. What should I do if I want to change my payout start age?
answer:
['It depends on whether you are starting your payouts at an earlier age or later age.
1. **For members who want to start payouts at an earlier age** If you wish to receive your payouts earlier (for example, currently deferred and will start at age 69, but wants to start at age 67 instead), please let us know only one month before your desired payout start date, and not anytime earlier, via the [Plan my monthly payouts](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/payout) service.
2. **For members who want to start payouts at a later age** We will send you a notification three months before your original payout start date. If you prefer to delay your payouts to a later age (for example, currently deferred and will start at age 68, but wants to start at age 69 instead), you can submit your request via the [Plan my monthly payouts](https://www.cpf.gov.sg/payout) service when you receive the notification.']

question: I am aged 55 and above. What will happen when my Special Account is closed and what is the rationale for doing so?
answer:
['Today, members aged 55 and above have two CPF accounts that hold savings intended for retirement payouts: the Special Account (SA) and the Retirement Account (RA). Both SA and RA savings earn the same long-term interest rate. However, some SA savings can be withdrawn on demand from age 55. As a principle, only savings that cannot be withdrawn on demand should earn the long-term interest rate, and savings that can be withdrawn on demand should earn the short-term interest rate. 

To rationalise the CPF system and better align CPF interest rates to the nature of CPF savings, we will close your SA if you are aged 55 and above from early 2025. SA savings will be transferred to your RA (up to your Full Retirement Sum) and will continue to earn the long-term interest rate. The remaining SA savings will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA), where they remain withdrawable and will earn the short-term interest rate. 

You can choose to transfer your OA savings to the RA at any time, up to the prevailing Enhanced Retirement Sum to earn long-term interest rates and receive higher retirement payouts. Once transferred, the RA savings can only be streamed out to you in retirement payouts.

You will be notified after the transfer of all SA savings to your RA and/or OA, and closure of your SA in early 2025. You will also be able to check the amounts transferred from your SA to your RA and/or OA from your CPF statement. No action is required from you now.

Watch the video on how the SA will be closed for you from early 2025. 

More details on the implementation date will be shared in the second half of 2024.  

For details on other specific areas of your CPF savings, refer to these FAQ pages:
ï	Retirement withdrawals 
ï	Retirement Sum Topping-Up Scheme 
ï	Monthly Payouts
ï	CPF Investment Scheme 
ï	Dependants' Protection Scheme']

question: I am below age 55. How does the closure of Special Account affect me?
answer: ['If you are below 55 in early 2025, you will not be immediately affected. Your Special Account (SA) will only be closed when you turn 55 when your Retirement Account is created. Read more on how your SA will be closed when you turn age 55 in the future.']

question: Once I meet my Full Retirement Sum, my Special Account savings will be transferred to the Ordinary Account which pays lower interest. What can I do to continue earning the interest rate that the Special Account pays?
answer:
['If you wish to earn higher interest and receive higher retirement payouts, you may transfer your Special Account (SA) savings that were channelled to the Ordinary Account (OA) due to the closure of SA, to the Retirement Account (RA), up to the prevailing Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS). The RA interest rate is the same as the SA. 

From 1 January 2025, the ERS will be raised to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum to allow members to save more in the RA and receive higher payouts, if they want. 

With the change, the ERS in 2025 would be $426,0001, up from $319,500 in 2024.  Hence, if you are aged 55 and above in 2025, you can save up to $426,000 in the RA.

Please note that CPF transfers are irreversible and the savings are set aside to boost your monthly payouts in retirement. Thus, the amount transferred cannot be withdrawn for any other purpose such as housing, investment, or immediate needs after age 55. Read more on how the top-ups will be used.

1 This is the limit for the savings set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, government grants received, plus retirement withdrawals).']

question: Will the closure of my Special Account affect how much I can withdraw from my CPF?
answer: ['When your Special Account (SA) is closed, the amount that you could have withdrawn from your SA will be transferred to your Ordinary Account and remains withdrawable. Find out more information on what you can withdraw from your CPF after the closure of your SA.']

question: Can I choose to transfer more savings from the Special Account to the Ordinary Account since I am still servicing my housing loan/education loan etc.?
answer:
['When your Special Account (SA) is closed, the savings in your SA will be transferred to the Retirement Account (RA), up to your Full Retirement Sum to increase your retirement payouts. Any remaining savings that are withdrawable on demand will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA). 

You may use the portion transferred to your OA for your housing loan/education loan (subject to applicable limits) or choose to withdraw them anytime for your immediate needs.  You cannot choose to allocate more SA savings or your future RA contributions to your OA to service your housing/education loan, etc.']

question: With the closure of the Special Account (SA) for CPF members aged 55 and above, how will the increase in CPF contribution rates for senior workers be allocated?
answer:
['With the closure of Special Account (SA), the increase in CPF contributions allocated to SA will be fully allocated to the memberís Retirement Account (RA) instead, up to the Full Retirement Sum (FRS), to boost retirement payouts. For members who have set aside the FRS in the RA, these contributions will be channelled to the Ordinary Account (OA). 

This will ensure that the additional contributions continue to earn the highest possible CPF interest rate to provide an even bigger boost to retirement payouts. RA balances currently earn a minimum interest rate of 4% a year, compared to a minimum of 2.5% in the OA. Plus, members aged 55 and above earn an extra interest of 2% per annum on the first $30,000 and 1% per annum on the next $30,000 of their combined CPF balances (capped at $20,000 for OA).']

question: Does the closure of my Special Account affect the retirement sum that I need to set aside?
answer: ['Your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) and Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) is determined when you turn 55 and will remain the same for the rest of your life. It is not affected by the closure of your Special Account.']

question: If I am aged 55 and above, when will my Special Account will be closed?
answer: ['Your Special Account will be closed by early 2025. More details on the implementation date will be shared in the second half of 2024.']

question: Will I be notified about the closure of my Special Account?
answer: ['You will be notified after your Special Account (SA) has been closed. You will also be able to check your CPF statement for the amounts that have been transferred from your SA to your Retirement Account and Ordinary Account.']

question: What can I withdraw from my CPF after the closure of my Special Account?
answer: ['After the closure of your Special Account (SA), you can continue to withdraw any amount from your Ordinary Account, after setting aside your Full Retirement Sum in your Retirement Account (RA). You can also continue to apply to withdraw your RA savings down to your Basic Retirement Sum if you own a property in Singapore with remaining lease that lasts you until you are 95 or older. Find out more information on the withdrawal of CPF savings for property owners.']

question: If I have not fully withdrawn the $5,000 that I could withdraw unconditionally when I reached age 55, what will happen when my Special Account is closed?
answer: ['At the point your Special Account (SA) is closed, any savings in your SA that form part of your $5,000 unconditional withdrawal amount will be transferred to your Ordinary Account, which you can continue to withdraw anytime.']

question: If I own a property, can I still withdraw the Special Account (SA) savings that have been transferred to my Retirement Account when my SA is closed?
answer: ['After your Special Account is closed, you can continue to withdraw your Retirement Account savings above the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) if you own an eligible property. Find out more information on the withdrawal of CPF savings for property owners.']

question: I donít want my Special Account savings to be transferred to either the Retirement Account or the Ordinary Account. Can I withdraw it?
answer: ['Savings from the Special Account (SA) that are transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) are not withdrawable as they are meant to provide you with payouts in retirement. Once you have set aside your Full Retirement Sum in RA, you may withdraw the remaining SA savings that are transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA).']

question: With the closure of the Special Account and the raising of the Enhanced Retirement Sum, how much is the maximum amount that I can have in my Retirement Account?
answer:
['From 1 January 2025, the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) will be raised to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum to allow members 55 and above to save more in the Retirement Account (RA) and receive higher payouts, if they wish to do so. 

With the change, the ERS in 2025 would be $426,0001, up from $319,500 in 2024.  Hence, if you are aged 55 and above in 2025, you can save up to $426,000 in the RA.

1 This is the limit for the savings set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received, plus retirement withdrawals).']

question: How does the closure of my Special Account affect the amount of tax relief that I can earn when I top up my Retirement Account in cash?
answer:
['For members 55 and above, with the closure of your Special Account (SA), your SA savings which are non-withdrawable will be transferred to your Retirement Account (RA), up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS) to increase your monthly payouts. 

Tax relief is only for cash top-ups up to the current FRS, and this has not changed. You can continue to enjoy tax relief on such top-ups within the current FRS.']

question: Can I have the option to top up more than the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS)?
answer: ['You are not able to top up more than the raised Enhanced Retirement Scheme (ERS). However, you may consider transferring the savings in excess of the raised ERS to your loved onesí CPF accounts, or withdraw the savings and invest privately for potentially higher returns.']

question: I am age 55 and above. How will the closure of Special Account (SA) affect my eligibility to voluntarily transfer my CPF savings to top up my own/loved onesí retirement savings?
answer:
['There are no changes to the eligibility rules on the transfer of CPF savings to top up your own/loved onesí retirement savings. 

When your Special Account is closed, your withdrawable SA savings (if any) will be transferred to your Ordinary Account (OA), and your available CPF savings for such top-ups will increase accordingly. You can check these amounts available for such top-ups via the Retirement Dashboard, after we complete the closure of your SA in early 2025.']

question: How does the closure of my Special Account affect my retirement payouts?
answer:
['If you are receiving monthly payouts, your payouts will increase if some or all of your Special Account (SA) savings are transferred to your Retirement Account (RA) when your SA is closed. You will be notified to check your monthly payouts after the transfer and closure of your SA in early 2025. 

You can also transfer your Ordinary Account savings to your RA, up to the prevailing Enhanced Retirement Sum, to increase your monthly payouts.']

question: I am aged 55 and above. What happens to my CPF Investment Scheme - Special Account after my Special Account is closed?
answer:
['If you are aged 55 and above, you can continue to hold your existing CPF Investment Scheme ñ Special Account (CPFIS-SA) investments until you decide to sell them or until they mature. Upon sale or maturity, your proceeds would be paid to your Retirement Account (RA) up to your Full Retirement Sum (FRS), with any remaining balance paid to your Ordinary Account (OA).

Before the closure of SA, CPF savings in SA can be used to invest after setting aside the FRS in your Retirement Account. With the closure of SA, your SA savings would be transferred to the OA once you have set aside the FRS in your RA and you can use them to invest under CPFIS-OA.']

question: I am currently holding investments under the CPFIS-SA. Do I need to do anything?
answer:
['You do not need to take any immediate action. You can continue to hold your existing CPFIS-SA investments until you decide to sell them or until they mature.

You can view your SA Portfolio by logging in to my cpf digital services with your Singpass > Select my cpf > My dashboards > Investment']

question: Where will proceeds from my CPFIS-SA investments go to after my Special Account has been closed?
answer: ['After your Special Account has been closed, the proceeds from your CPFIS-SA investments will be paid to your Retirement Account up to your Full Retirement Sum, with any remaining balance paid to your Ordinary Account.']

question: If I am currently using my Special Account (SA) for Dependantsí Protection Scheme premiums, how would I be impacted by the closure of SA?
answer:
['Transition measures will be put in place after your Special Account (SA) has been closed, to ensure that members aged 55 and above who are currently using SA for DPS have sufficient time to make the necessary alternative arrangements.

Impacted members will be notified and advised on the necessary steps to take.']

question: What are the enhancements to the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme from 2025?
answer:
['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) will continue beyond its pilot to help senior Singaporeans build up their retirement savings, through dollar-for-dollar matching grants from the Government to their Retirement Account. 

Enhancements	Current	From 1 January 2025
Increase in matching grant cap	$600 per year	$2,000 per year, with a $20,000 cap over an eligible memberís lifetime
Removal of age cap	Age 55 to 70	Age 55 and above

Tax relief for cash top-ups that attract the MRSS matching grant will be removed as the matching grant is already a significant benefit extended by the Government. Givers can continue to receive up to $16,000 in tax relief on cash top-ups that do not attract the matching grant.']

question: How do I check my eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme when it is enhanced from 2025?
answer:
['Your eligibility is automatically assessed annually at the beginning of the year. We will notify you via email or post in early 2025. You can also check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme in early 2025 via:
ï	Your Retirement Dashboard; or
ï	The MRSS eligibility checker (no login required).']

question: Do I need to apply to be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme when it is enhanced from 2025?
answer:
['You do not need to apply as your eligibility is automatically assessed annually at the beginning of the year. 

If you are eligible, we will notify you via email or post in early 2025. You can also check your eligibility through the MRSS eligibility checker in early 2025.']

question: Will the other eligibility criteria for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme be changed from 2025?
answer:
['No, there are no changes to the other eligibility criteria.

You will be eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme in 2025 if you are a Singapore Citizen and meet the following criteria.

Age	55 and above as of 31st December of the assessment year 2025
Retirement Account (RA) Savings*	Less than $106,500^.
Average Monthly Income	Not more than $4,000.

This covers a majority of senior workers.
Annual Value of Residence	Not more than $21,000.Property Ownership	Own not more than one property.

* RA savings refer to the cash set aside in the RA (excluding amounts such as interest earned, any government grants received), plus retirement withdrawals. If you are turning 55 in the assessment year and your RA has not been created at the time we assess your eligibility, your total Special Account and Ordinary Account savings will be assessed instead.

^ Basic Retirement Sum for 2025.

Find out how you can check your eligibility for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme.']

question: How will the increase in the annual matching grant from $600 to $2,000 per year from 2025 help seniors better meet their retirement needs?
answer:
['Eligible seniors can top up more to their CPF retirement savings and receive the higher matching grant amount. Correspondingly, they will also receive higher monthly CPF payouts. For instance, a senior aged 55 in 2025 who makes a cash top-up of $2,000/year over the next 10 years will see an increase in CPF retirement savings of at least $48,000 (inclusive of matching grant and CPF interest) in 2035, which translates to about a $260 increase in monthly CPF payouts*.
  
*Estimation for a male member that starts payout at age 65 on the CPF LIFE Standard Plan']

question: Why is there an annual cap of $2,000 of matching grant when the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is enhanced from 2025? Would the Government consider allowing eligible members to top up $20,000 at once and receive the lifetime matching grant of $20,000?
answer: ['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is targeted at lower-income and lower-means seniors to help them in saving more for retirement. As individualsí circumstances can change over time, the annual cap ensures that the scheme will help seniors who require the support over a longer period and not disproportionately benefit those who require short-term support.']

question: Why is the Government implementing a lifetime cap of $20,000 to the matching grant when the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is enhanced from 2025?
answer:
['The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme is targeted at lower-income and lower-means seniors to help them save more for retirement. The enhancements to provide $2,000 matching grant annually, capped at $20,000 over a lifetime, are a significant increase from the current scheme, and can increase eligible seniorsí CPF savings by at least $48,000 in 10 years, which translates to about a $260 increase in monthly CPF payouts*. 

While it may not help all eligible seniors meet the Basic Retirement Sum, it is part of a broader set of schemes providing retirement adequacy support. Other schemes, such as the Majulah Package and the Silver Support Scheme, will also help boost the retirement adequacy of seniors.

*Estimation for a male member that starts payout at age 65 on the CPF LIFE Standard Plan']

question: I received Matched Retirement Savings Scheme matching grants in the past, before the $20,000 lifetime cap takes effect in early 2025. Will the past matching grants count towards this $20,000 lifetime cap?
answer: ['The enhancements to the MRSS are effective from 2025 and thus, the lifetime cap will only be applied from 2025 onwards. Matching grants received in the past for cash top-ups made prior to 2025, will not count towards the $20,000 lifetime cap.']

question: Why is tax relief removed for cash top-ups that attract matching grant under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme from 2025?
answer:
['The matching grant is already a significant benefit extended by the Government.

Givers may continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for cash top-ups that do not attract the MRSS matching grant, if they meet the criteria under the Retirement Sum Topping Up Scheme (e.g., if the recipient has not met the current Full Retirement Sum).

Find out more on the conditions to qualify for tax relief.']

question: What incentives are there for me to top up to my loved ones under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme when the tax relief is removed from 2025?
answer:
['Topping up to your loved onesí CPF accounts helps them to build up more retirement savings and increases their monthly payouts in retirement. From 1 January 2025, recipients of cash top-ups who are eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS) can also receive a matching grant of up to $2,000 per year (an increase from $600 per year) from the Government, which will further boost their retirement savings.

You may continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for eligible cash top-ups that do not attract MRSS grants ($8,000/year for top-ups to yourself and another $8,000/year for top-ups to your loved ones).

Learn more on how this works']

question: How will the removal of tax relief for cash top-ups that attract matching grants under the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme affect givers from 2025?
answer:
['From 1 January 2025, if you are making a cash top-up to a recipient eligible for the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme (MRSS), your cash top-ups of $2,000 will first enable your recipient to enjoy the matching grant of up to $2,000 per year from the Government, and will thus not be eligible for tax relief. You can continue to enjoy tax relief of up to $16,000 a year for your cash top-ups that do not attract the MRSS grant ($8,000/year for top-ups to yourself and another $8,000/year for top-ups to your loved ones).

For example, if you make a top-up of $3,000 to your MRSS-eligible loved one, your loved one will first enjoy a matching grant of $2,000 from the Government, and you will be eligible for $1,000 of tax relief on your cash top-ups that did not attract the matching grant.

Find out more on the conditions to qualify for tax relief.']

question: I was ineligible for Matched Retirement Savings Scheme for the past few years after turning 71 years old. With the lifting of the age cap of 70 from 2025, will my eligibility be revised for the past few years?
answer: ['The enhancements to the MRSS are effective from 2025 and thus, the lifting of the age cap will be applied from 2025 onwards. The matching grant will be increased from $600 to $2,000 per year, with a $20,000 cap over an eligible memberís lifetime. With these enhancements, all eligible members from 2025 will enjoy the same total amount of matching grant over their lifetime.']

question: What is the increase in tax relief income threshold in 2024?
answer:
['You can enjoy tax relief of up to $8,000 on your cash top-ups made to your loved ones. As announced on 16 February 2024, the income threshold for you to enjoy tax relief for your cash top-ups to your spouse or sibling has increased:
Before 2024	From 1 January 2024
You will be eligible for the tax relief if your spouseís or siblingís income1 in the previous year does not exceed $4,000 or if the recipient is handicapped2	You will be eligible for the tax relief if your spouseís or siblingís income1 in the previous year does not exceed $8,000 (up from $4,000) or if the recipient is handicapped2
1.	Income would include income from bank interest, dividend and pension, investment income/rental income/directorship income.
2.	This refers to people who are incapacitated because of physical or mental infirmity. An example of a handicapped person is someone with visual-impairment, loss of hearing, loss of limb or dementia.

Other conditions to enjoy tax relief remain unchanged. 

Find out how to claim tax relief on your top-ups

If you wish to amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups made between 1 January to 16 February 2024, click here']

question: I made a cash top-up to my spouse/sibling between 1 January 2024 and 16 February 2024 and instructed that I did not wish to claim tax relief. With the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, how can I amend my instruction to claim tax relief?
answer:
['You can submit an application to amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups made in 2024, if your recipientís income in 2023 is between $4,000 and $8,000 (inclusive). 

If you indicated that you have a GIRO arrangement to make regular top-ups to your spouse or sibling in the application, your instructions for the GIRO arrangement will be amended to claim tax relief for future GIRO top-ups.

Please note that other conditions to qualify for tax relief apply.']

question: I have set up a GIRO arrangement to make top-ups to my spouse or sibling before 16 February 2024. With the increase in income threshold from $4,000 to $8,000, how can I amend my instructions for the GIRO arrangement to claim tax relief?
answer: ['The increase in income threshold for tax relief for cash top-ups to spouse or sibling will apply to cash top-ups made on 1 January 2024 or after. If you have a GIRO arrangement to make regular cash top-ups to your spouse or sibling and instructed to not claim tax relief previously, you can submit an application to amend your instructions to claim tax relief for top-ups from 2024 onwards.']

question: I cannot remember if I had instructed that I want/ donít want to claim tax relief for my cash top-ups to my spouse or sibling in my application. How can I check?
answer: ['You may check your past top-up applications by logging in to the CPF website and checking under ìmy cpfî > ìmy activitiesî.']

question: What is the change to the Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
answer:
['The Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) will be raised in 2025 from three times to four times of the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS). This will provide CPF members aged 55 and above the option to voluntarily top up more to their Retirement Account for even higher CPF monthly payouts in retirement. 

The ERS in 2025 will be $426,000. A member turning 55 years old in 2025 can receive about $3,330 per month of CPF LIFE payouts at age 65, if he chooses to top up to the raised ERS, up from about $2,530 today.

Learn how much payouts you can receive if you top up to the raised ERS.']

question: How much CPF monthly payout can I receive if I top up to the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
answer:
['The CPF monthly payout amount will depend on several factors, including when one sets aside the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) and when one starts payouts. As an example, a member who tops up to the ERS at age 55 in 2025 and starts payout in 2035 at age 65 will receive a payout of around $3,330 per month for life under the CPF LIFE Standard Plan. 

You can use the CPF LIFE Estimator to estimate your payouts if you top up to the raised ERS.']

question: How can I check the amount that I can top up to my Retirement Account to reach the raised Enhanced Retirement Sum in 2025?
answer:
['You may check your top-up limit on your Retirement Dashboard in early 2025 once the Enhanced Retirement Sum is raised.

Find out how the top-up limit is computed.']

question: With the raising of the Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS), does the Government plan to also raise the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) and Full Retirement Sum (FRS)?
answer: ['The Full Retirement Sum (FRS) will continue to be set at 2 times the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS). As the BRS is adjusted annually, the FRS will correspondingly be adjusted annually.']
